22.12: friend, how came you in hither, without a wedding garment? and he was speechless.
22.13: then said the king to the servants, bind him hand and foot, take him away, and turn him out in the dark: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
22.15: Upon this the Pharisees withdrew, and consulted how they might insnare him in his discourse.
22.16: they dispatch'd therefore some of their disciples, together with the Herodians, who thus address'd themselves to him; master, we know that you are sincere, and faithfully teach the divine law without fear or flattery: for you have no regard to the outward quality of men.
22.17: tell us therefore, what is your opinion? is it lawful to pay tribute to Cesar, or no?
22.18: but Jesus perceiving their malice, said, why, hypocrites, would you insnare me?
22.19: shew me the tribute money, and they brought him a penny.
22.20: and he said unto them, whose image and inscription is this?
22.22: on hearing this, they were filled with admiration, and so leaving him, they went their way.
22.23: About that time the Sadducees, who say there is no future life, came and propos'd this question,
22.24: master, said they, by the law of Moses, in case a man die without children, his brother is oblig'd to marry his wife, in order to perpetuate his brother's name.
22.25: now there happen'd among us seven brothers, the first married but died without issue, leaving his wife to his brother:
22.26: the same happen'd to the second, and the third, and so on to the seventh.
22.27: last of all the woman died too:
22.28: now if there be another life after this, whose wife shall she be of the seven? for they all married her.
22.29: Jesus answered them, you are mistaken, for want of a true notion of the scriptures, and of the divine power.
22.30: for in the other life after this, there will be no such thing as marriage; but they will be as the angels of God in heaven.
22.31: now as to the state of life after death, have ye not read that expression of God himself,
22.32: " I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?" God is not a benefactor to the dead, but to the living.
22.33: when the people heard this, they were astonished at his doctrine.
22.34: but the Pharisees hearing that he had dumb-founded the Sadducees, they met together in council.
22.35: In the mean time one of them, a Doctor of the law, to try him, started this question, master,
22.36: which is the most important commandment of the law?
22.37: Jesus said to him, "thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind."
22.38: this is the first and most important precept,
22.39: and the second has an affinity with it, "thou shalt love thy neighbour as thy self."
22.40: these two precepts comprehend the substance of all the law and the prophets.
22.41: While the Pharisees were still assembled, Jesus asked them,
22.42: what think ye of Christ? whose son is he to be? they answered, David's.
22.43: how comes it then, said he, that David by inspiration calls him Lord, in these words,
22.44: " the Lord said unto my Lord, sit thou on my right hand, till I make thine enemies thy footstool?"
22.45: why then does David call him Lord, if He be David's son?
22.46: but not a man was able to answer him a word, and from that time there was no body so hardy as to ask him any more questions.

23.1: Then Jesus addressing himself to the people, and to his disciples,
23.2: said, the Scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses's chair.
23.3: therefore whatever moral precepts they bid you observe, those observe and practise; but don't follow their example: for they preach one thing, and practise another.
23.4: for they load men with intolerable impositions, and will not take the least pains to ease them of the burthen: they do nothing but out of ostentation,
23.6: they affect the uppermost place at feasts, the principal chair in the synagogues,
23.7: to be saluted in publick places, and to have men address to them with the title of Doctor Doctor.
23.10: neither take the title of masters, for you have but one master, who is the Messias.
23.11: he that is greatest among you shall be your servant.
23.12: for whosoever exalts himself, shall be abased; and he that humbles himself, shall be exalted.
23.14: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites, who shut up the kingdom of heaven against men: for ye not only refuse to go in your selves, but hinder those that would.
23.15: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites, who ransack sea and land to make one proselyte, and when he is gain'd, ye make him deserve Gehenna much more than your selves.
23.16: wo unto you, ye blind guides, who say, if any man swear by the temple he is under no obligation: but if he swear by the gold of the temple, he is bound by his oath.
23.17: ye blind fools, which is most sacred, the treasure of the temple, or the temple that makes the treasure sacred?
23.18: again, if any one swear by the altar he is under no engagement but if he swear by the gift that is upon it, he is bound thereby.
23.19: ye blind fools, which is most sacred, the gift, or the altar that makes the gift sacred?
23.20: whoever swears by the altar, swears not only by the altar, but by every thing upon it.
23.21: and whoever swears by the temple, swears by it, and by him that dwelleth therein.
23.22: and he that swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God, and by him that sitteth thereon.
23.23: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites, who pay tithe of mint, anise, and cummin, but neglect those more important matters of the law, justice, mercy, and fidelity: these were the things ye ought to have practis'd, without neglecting however the other matters.
23.24: ye blind guides, who strain your liquor for a gnat, and swallow a beetle.
23.25: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; for ye clean the outside of the cup, and of the plate, but within they are full of rapine and impurity.
23.26: thou blind Pharisee, cleanse first the inside of the cup and plate, that the outside may be likewise clean.
23.27: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; for ye are like whited sepulchres, which to outward appearance are fine, but within are full of dead mens bones, and all sort of filth.
23.28: just so ye put on an air of probity in the sight of men, but within are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.
23.29: wo unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because ye build the tombs of the prophets, and garnish the sepulchres of the just,
23.30: and say, if we had liv'd in the time of our forefathers, we would not have been accessory with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.
23.31: whereby you yourselves own that ye are indeed the children of those who killed the prophets,
23.32: children that can't fail to fill up the measure of your fathers iniquities.
23.33: ye serpents, ye brood of vipers, how can ye escape the punishment of Gehenna?
23.34: wherefore I shall send you prophets, and wise men, and Scribes; you will kill some, and crucify others, many will ye scourge in your synagogues, and persecute them from city to city.
23.35: so that you maybe charg'd with all the innocent blood shed upon earth, from the blood of Abel the just, unto the blood of Zacharias, the son of Barachias, whom ye slew between the temple and the altar.
23.36: I declare unto you, all these things shall befall this generation.
23.37: O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who killest the prophets, and stonest them that are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered thy children together, even as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, but ye would not!
23.38: know, that your habitation shall be soon turned into a desert.

24.1: As Jesus was going from the temple, his disciples came and desired him to take a view of the buildings.
24.3: And when he was upon the mount of Olives, the disciples came to him in private, and said, tell us when shall these things be? and what shall be the sign of thy coming, and of the end of this age?
24.4: Jesus answered them, take care not to be deceived by any one:
24.5: for many shall come in my name, saying, I am the Christ: and shall deceive many.
24.6: ye shall hear likewise of wars, and rumours of wars: take care not to be disturb'd: for these things must happen, but the end of the Jewish age is not yet.
24.7: for nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be famines, and pestilences, and earthquakes in divers places.
24.8: yet all this is but the beginning of sorrow.
24.9: then shall they deliver you up to torments, and to death: and ye shall be hated by all nations upon my account.
24.10: then shall many relapse, and shall pursue one another with mutual treachery and hatred.
24.11: many false prophets shall rise, and shall deceive many.
24.12: and as iniquity becomes more flagrant, the zeal of many will grow cool.
24.13: but he that shall persevere unto the end, shall be preserved.
24.14: and this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world, to testify to all nations, that the end will then come.
24.15: When ye therefore shall see the abomination of desolation, mention'd by Daniel the prophet, stand about the holy place, (let him that readeth,
24.16: consider it well) let those who are then in Judea, flee into the mountains,
24.17: he that is on the battlements, let him not venture to go in to take any thing out of his house.
24.18: if any man be in the field, let him not return back to take his coat.
24.19: unhappy will they be that are with child, and they that give suck in those days.
24.20: be sure to pray that your flight be not in the winter, nor on the sabbath-day:
24.21: for the desolation will be so dreadful, the like was never seen since the beginning of the world, no, nor ever shall be again.
24.22: for unless the time was to be short, very few could escape, but for the sake of the converts the time shall be short.
24.23: Then if any shall cry, the Messiah is here, or he is there: give no credit to it.
24.24: for there shall arise false Messiahs, and false prophets, and shall shew such astonishing miracles and prodigies, as to deceive, if that can do it, the very converts themselves.
24.27: for as the lightning darts from the east in an instant to the west: such shall the advent of the son of man be.
24.28: for whereever the carcase is, there will the eagles be assembled.
24.29: Immediately after the tribulation of those days, the sun shall be darkned, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken.
24.30: then shall that sign, the son of man in the clouds of heaven, appear: and all the tribes of the land shall mourn, and they shall see the son of man coming in the clouds of heaven, with power and great glory.
24.31: and he shall send his messengers, who with the shrill sound of a trumpet, shall gather together his select from the four winds, from one end of the heaven to the other.
24.32: this may be illustrated by a comparison taken from a fig-tree: when the branches become tender, and push out their leaves, ye know that summer is nigh:
24.33: in like manner, when ye shall see all these things happen, know that he is come to your very doors.
24.34: I declare unto you, the present generation shall not cease, till all these things are pass'd.
24.35: heaven and earth may fail, but my words shall never fail.
24.37: as the days of Noe were, so shall also the advent of the son of man be.
24.38: for as at the time that usher'd in the deluge, they were eating and drinking, marrying themselves and their children, till the day that Noe entred into the ark,
24.39: having no thoughts of the flood till it came, and swept them all away; so shall also the advent of the son of man be.
24.40: of two persons, who shall be then in the field, one shall be taken, and the other left.
24.41: two women shall be grinding at the mill, the one shall be taken, and the other left.
24.42: watch therefore, for ye know not at what hour your Lord shall come.
24.43: but this you conceive, that if a man knew at what hour of the night the thief would come, he would set a watch, and not suffer his house to be broke open.
24.44: therefore be ye also prepar'd: for the son of man may come at an hour you least expect.
24.45: If then there be a servant, appointed by his master to take care of his family, who faithfully and prudently distributes their allowance according to the establishment: happy is the servant,
24.46: who shall be found so employed, at his master's return.
24.47: I tell you, he shall make him steward of all his estate.
24.48: but if he be dishonest, and says to himself, my Lord delays coming,
24.49: and shall pretend to assault his fellow-servants, and spend his time with sots:
24.50: the master of that servant will come in a day when he least expects it, and at an hour he is not aware of;
24.51: and shall turn him out of the family, and give him the reward due to such behaviour: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

25.1: The kingdom of the Messiah will then be such, as when ten virgins took their lamps, and went out to meet the bridegroom.
25.2: five of them were wise, and five were foolish.
25.3: they that were foolish took their lamps, and took no oil with them:
25.4: but the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.
25.5: while the bridegroom tarried, they were drowsy and slept.
25.7: then the virgins all arose, and trimmed their lamps.
25.8: and the foolish said to the wise, give us of your oil, for our lamps are going out.
25.9: but the wise answered, for fear there should not be enough for us and you, go rather to those that sell; and buy for your selves.
25.11: afterwards came the other virgins likewise, and cry'd,
25.13: watch therefore, for ye know neither the day nor the hour.
25.15: to one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one, to every man according to his respective ability, and then set out on his journey.
25.16: now he that had received five talents, immediately employed them in trade, and gain'd five talents more.
25.17: so he that had received two, gained likewise other two.
25.18: but he that had received one, went to dig a hole in the ground, and hid his lord's money.
25.20: accordingly he that had received five talents, came and brought other five talents, saying, Lord, you delivered to me five talents: besides those, there's five talents more, which I have gain'd.
25.21: his lord said to him, well done, thou art an honest faithful servant; thou hast been faithful in a small trust, I will give thee a much larger trust; go in and partake of thy master's diversions.
25.22: he also that had received two talents, came and said, Lord, you delivered to me two talents: here are two other talents which I have gain'd besides them.
25.23: his lord said to him, well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful in a small trust, I will give thee a much larger trust: go in and partake of your master's joy.
25.24: then came he who had received the one talent, and said, Lord, I knew that you were a hard man, reaping where you have not sown, and gathering where you have not scattered:
25.25: fear made me hide the talent under ground: but there you have what is your own.
25.27: should not you then have lodged my money at the banker's, and so at my return I should have received my own with interest.
25.28: here, take the talent from him, and give it to him that has the ten.
25.29: for he that makes use of what he has, shall have more; but if he makes no improvement thereof, it shall be taken from him.
25.30: take then that worthless fellow, turn him out in the dark, there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
25.31: When the son of man shall come in his majesty, accompanied with all his holy angels, he shall sit upon the throne of his glory.
25.32: then all nations shall be assembled before him, and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd separates his sheep from the goats.
25.33: and he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left.
25.35: for I was prest with hunger, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in:
25.36: naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye took care of me: I was in prison, and ye visited me.
25.37: then will the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when did we see thee in hunger, and fed thee? or thirsty, and gave thee drink?
25.38: when did we see thee a stranger, and took thee in? or naked, and clothed thee?
25.39: or when did we see thee sick, or in prison, and visited thee?
25.40: and the king will reply, I declare unto you, your having done this for one of the least of these my brethren, is the same thing as doing it for me.
25.42: for I was prest with hunger, and ye gave me no meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink:
25.43: I was a stranger, and ye took me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not.
25.44: then will they answer, Lord, when did we see thee in hunger, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee?
25.45: to this he will reply, I declare unto you, your not doing this for one of the least of these, is the same thing as not doing it for me.
25.46: and these shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal.

26.1: Now when Jesus had finished these discourses, he said to his disciples,
26.2: ye know that in two days the feast of the passover will begin, and the son of man be delivered up to be crucified.
26.3: About this time the chief priests, and the elders of the people, assembled in the palace of the high priest, whose name was Caiaphas,
26.4: and consulted how to seize Jesus by surprize, and take away his life.
26.5: but they said, this must not be done on the feastday, for fear the people rise.
26.6: Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon who had been a leper,
26.7: there came to him a woman with an alabaster-box of very precious ointment, and poured it on his head, while he was at table.
26.8: one of his disciples seeing this, with indignation said, to what purpose is this waste?
26.9: for this could have been sold for a great price, which might have been given to the poor.
26.10: Jesus perceiving this, said to them, why do you trouble the woman? for what she has done is out of regard to me.
26.11: ye have the poor always with you, but me ye have not always.
26.12: for her pouring this ointment on my body, is preparative to my burial.
26.13: I declare unto you, in whatever quarter of the world, this part of the gospel-history shall be related, what this woman has now done shall be there mentioned to her praise.
26.14: Then one of the twelve, Judas Iscariot by name, went to the chief priests,
26.15: and said, what will ye give me, and I will deliver him to you? and they promised him thirty pieces of silver.
26.16: from which time he watched a favourable opportunity to deliver him.
26.17: Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread, the disciples came to Jesus, and said, where would you have us make the preparations for the paschal-supper?
26.18: and he said, go into the city to such a man, and say to him, the master sends you word that his time is at hand, and he designs to keep the passover now at your house with his disciples.
26.19: the disciples then did as Jesus appointed, and made ready the passover.
26.20: The even being now come, he sat down with the twelve.
26.21: and as they were eating, he said, 'tis indeed true that one of this company shall betray me.
26.22: at which they were exceedingly concern'd, and began every one of them to ask, Lord, is it I?
26.23: to this he answered, he that has his hand in the dish with mine, he it is that will betray me.
26.24: the son of man is going to die, pursuant to the scripture: but wo to that man by whom the son of man is betrayed: it had been better for that man, if he had never been born.
26.25: then Judas, he who was to betray him, said, master, is it I? Jesus replied, yes.
26.26: While they were yet eating, Jesus took bread, and having given thanks, he brake it, and gave it to the disciples, saying, take, eat; this represents my body.
26.28: for this represents my blood, the blood of the new covenant which is shed for mankind for the remission of sins.
26.29: but this I tell you, I shall not drink any more wine with you from this time forth to the day, when I shall drink with you, of the spiritual wine, in my father's kingdom.
26.30: And when they had sung an hymn, they went to the mount of Olives.
26.31: then said Jesus to them, I shall be the occasion of your revolting all from me this night: for it is written, "I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered."
26.32: but after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.
26.34: Jesus replied, I tell you for certain, that this night before the time of cock-crowing, thou shalt abjure me thrice.
26.36: After this, Jesus went with them to a place called Gethsemani, and said to the disciples, stay here, while I go there and pray.
26.37: but he took with him Peter, and the two sons of Zebedee, and began to be in a very great agony of grief.
26.38: and he said to them, "my soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death:" stay here and watch by me.
26.39: Then advancing a little further, he fell prostrate in prayer, and said, "O my father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me: nevertheless not mine, but thy will be done."
26.40: then returning to the disciples, and finding them asleep, he said to Peter, what, could ye not watch by me one hour?
26.41: watch and pray that ye may not sink under the trial: the mind indeed is vigorous, but the flesh is weak.
26.42: again, he went away the second time, and prayed thus, "O my father, if I cannot avoid drinking this cup, thy will be done."
26.43: then returning, he found them asleep again: for their eyes were heavy.
26.44: then he left them once more, and went to prayers the third time, using the same words.
26.46: rise, let us be gone, there he is, the traytor is just upon us.
26.47: And before he had done speaking, Judas one of the twelve appear'd, with a numerous retinue, arm'd with swords and staves, being sent by the chief priests and elders of the people.
26.48: now he that was to betray him, gave them this signal, the person I shall kiss, is the very man, be sure to secure him.
26.49: and immediately advancing to Jesus, he said, master, I salute you, and kissed him.
26.51: At which, one of Jesus's company laying his hand upon his sword, drew it, and striking at a servant of the high priest's, took off his ear.
26.52: but Jesus said to him, put up your sword in its place: for all that take to the sword, shall perish by the sword.
26.53: do you think my father, if I should now desire it of him, would not instantly send me more than twelve legions of angels?
26.54: but how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, which say, that thus it must happen?
26.55: At the same time Jesus said to the company, you come to apprehend me with swords and clubs, as if in pursuit of a robber; I was every day with you teaching in the temple, and ye did not then seize upon me.
26.56: but all this was to be done, in pursuance of what the prophets had predicted, then all the disciples abandon'd him, and fled.
26.57: And they that had apprehended Jesus, led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the Scribes and the senators were assembled.
26.58: but Peter followed him at a distance to the high priest's palace, and going in, he sat with the officers to see the event.
26.59: Now the chief priests, the senators and the whole council, endeavour'd to get false evidence against Jesus, that he might be condemn'd to die.
26.60: but they found none: and though many false witnesses came, it was not found sufficient, at last there came two false witnesses, who charg'd him with saying,
26.61: "I am able to destroy the temple of God, and to build it in three days."
26.63: but Jesus made no reply, and the high priest said to him, I conjure thee by the living God, to tell us, are you the Christ the son of God?
26.65: then the high priest rent his clothes, saying, he has spoke blasphemy; what further need have we of witnesses? you yourselves have now heard his blasphemy.
26.66: what is your opinion? they reply'd, he deserves to die.
26.67: then they spit in his face, some beat him on the head, others slapt him on the cheeks,
26.68: crying now Christ divine, who 't is that struck you?
26.69: In the mean time Peter was sitting without in the court: and a servant maid came to him, and said, you likewise was one of Jesus the Galilean's comrades.
26.70: but he denied it before them all, saying, I know nothing of the matter.
26.71: and when he was going out at the porch, another maid saw him, and said to those that were by, this fellow was also with Jesus of Nazareth.
26.72: but he denied it again, and swore I don't know the man.
26.73: soon after they that stood by coming up, said to Peter, certainly you are one of them, for thy speech bewrays thee.
26.74: then he fell to solemn imprecations, and swore, "I don't know the man." and immediately the cock crew:

27.1: As soon as it was day, all the chief priests and senators of the people consulted measures against Jesus how they might put him to death.
27.2: and when they had bound him, they led him away, and delivered him to Pontius Pilate the governor of Judea.
27.3: At the same time, Judas who had betrayed him, finding that he was condemned, repented, and carried back the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and senators, saying,
27.4: I have sinned in betraying the blood of the innocent: and they said, what is it to us? you must look to that.
27.5: then throwing down the pieces of silver in the temple, he departed, and went and hanged himself.
27.6: but the chief priests took the silver pieces, and said, it is not lawful to put them into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.
27.7: and having consulted together, they laid out the money in buying the potter's field, to serve for a burying place for strangers.
27.8: for this reason the field is called the field of blood to this day.
27.9: then was fulfilled what Jeremy the prophet said, "and they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price at which he was valued, by the children of Israel,
27.10: and gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed me."
27.12: but when he was accused by the chief priests and elders, he return'd no answer.
27.14: but he made no answer to any thing he said, so that the governor was very much surpriz'd.
27.15: Now it was customary at that feast for the governor to release a prisoner, such as the people should nominate.
27.16: there happen'd to be then in custody a notorious criminal, nam'd Barabbas.
27.17: therefore when they were assembled, Pilate said to them, who would you have releas'd? Barabbas, or Jesus, who is called Christ?
27.18: for he was sensible that they had delivered him up out of meer envy.
27.19: Whilst he was sitting on the tribunal, his wife sent this message to him, pray, have nothing to do with that just man: for to-day I have suffered very much on his account in a dream.
27.20: but the chief priests and senators persuaded the people to demand Barabbas, and put to death Jesus.
27.24: Pilate perceiving he was so far from prevailing, that they were more tumultuous, he took water, and washed his hands before all the people, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this just person: you are answerable for it.
27.25: at this all the people cry'd out, "his blood be on us, and on our children."
27.26: Then he released to them Barabbas: but he order'd Jesus to be scourged, and delivered up to be crucified.
27.27: after this the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the common hall, and gathered all the foot-guards about him.
27.28: and having stripp'd him, they put on him a scarlet robe.
27.29: then pleating a crown of thorns, they set it on his head, and a reed in his right hand: and they bowed the knee before him, in mockery, saying, hail king of the Jews.
27.30: and they spit upon him, and took the reed, and smote him on the head.
27.31: and after they had thus insulted him, they took the robe off, and put his own raiment on him, and led him away to crucify him.
27.32: As they were going along, they met a man of Cyrene, Simon by name: and compelled him to carry the cross.
27.33: when they were come to a place called Golgotha, a word which signifies a skull,
27.34: they gave him a mixture of wine and gall: but when he had tasted it, he refused to drink.
27.35: after they had crucified him, they shared his clothes among them by casting losts:
27.36: and they took their post to watch him there.
27.37: and they set an Inscription over his head, denoting the reason of his execution, THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
27.38: At the same time, two robbers were crucified with him: one on his right hand, the other on his left.
27.39: the passengers all the while reviling him, shook their heads at him,
27.40: and cry'd, you that could destroy the temple, and rebuild it in three days, now save thy self: if thou art the son of God, come down from the cross.
27.41: the chief priests, with the scribes and senators, derided him in like manner.
27.42: he saved others, said they, but cannot save himself: if he be the king of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, and we will believe him.
27.43: he relied upon God; if he be such a favourite, let God then deliver him: for he us'd to say he was the son of God.
27.44: one of the robbers too, who were crucified with him, treated him with the same reproach.
27.45: Now from the sixth hour to the ninth, the whole land was cover'd with darkness.
27.47: some of the standers by, when they heard that, said, he calls upon Elias.
27.48: immediately one of them ran to fetch a spunge, which they steep'd in vinegar, and fastning it to the end of a stick, they presented it to him, to drink:
27.49: while the rest cry'd, now let us see whether Elias will come to save him.
27.50: but Jesus cried out again with a loud voice, and then expir'd.
27.51: Immediately the vail of the temple was rent in two, from the top to the bottom; the earth trembled, the rocks split,
27.52: the graves opened, and the bodies of many saints who slept arose,
27.53: and came out of the graves after his resurrection, and went into the holy city, and appeared to many.
27.54: now the centurion, and they that were with him, to guard Jesus, having observ'd the earthquake, and all that had happened, were under great apprehensions, and said, certainly this was the son of God.
27.55: And several women were there who look'd on at a distance, and had followed Jesus from Galilee, to assist him with their service.
27.56: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and of Joses, and the mother of Zebedee's children.
27.57: In the evening a rich man of Arimathea, named Joseph, who himself was Jesus's disciple,
27.58: went to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus; which Pilate ordered to be delivered to him.
27.59: Joseph then having taken the body, wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,
27.60: and laid it in a monument which he had lately caused to be hewn out in the rock: and having rolled a large stone to the door of the sepulchre, he went away.
27.61: in the mean time Mary Magdalene, and the other Mary were sitting over against the sepulchre.
27.62: Now the next day after the preparation of the sabbath, the chief priests and Pharisees went together to Pilate,
27.64: pray therefore order a guard to be posted at the sepulchre till the third day, for fear his disciples should come and steal him away, and then tell the people, "he is risen from the dead:" for this last imposture would be of worse consequence than the first.
27.65: to whom Pilate replied, you have a guard, go then, and make it as secure as you can.
27.66: accordingly they went, and having clapt a seal upon the stone, they posted a guard to secure the sepulchre.

28.1: The sabbath being over, and the first day of the week beginning to dawn, Mary Magdalene, and the other Mary, came to see the sepulchre.
28.2: now there had been a great earthquake; for an angel of the lord descending from heaven, was come, and had rolled away the stone from the door, and was sitting upon it.
28.3: his aspect was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow.
28.4: for fear of whom the keepers shook, and were almost struck dead.
28.6: he is not here: he is risen according to his word: come, see the place where the Lord was laid.
28.7: then go immediately to tell his disciples that he is risen from the dead; and that, he goes before you into Galilee, there shall ye see it is him; 'tis I that say it.
28.8: And they instantly left the sepulchre, with fear and joy, and ran to carry his disciples this good news.
28.9: as they were making the way to his disciples, Jesus himself met them, and said, I salute you, and they came, and embraced his feet, and worshipped him.
28.11: Now when they were gone, some of the guards went into the city, and informed the chief priests of all that had happened.
28.12: and when they were assembled with the senators, and had consulted together, they gave a large sum of money to the soldiers, thus instructing them;
28.13: do you say "his disciples came by night, and stole him away while we slept.
28.14: if this come to the governor's ears, we will appease him, and secure you."
28.15: so they took the money, and did as they were directed: and this report is still current among the Jews at this day.
28.16: In the mean time the eleven disciples went into Galilee, to a mountain where Jesus had appointed them.
28.17: and when they saw him, they worshipped him: but some doubted.
28.19: go and instruct all nations, baptizing them in the name of the father, and of the son, and of the holy ghost:
28.20: teaching them to observe every thing which I have enjoin'd you: and be assured I shall be always with you to the end of the world.

1.1: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ the son of God.
1.2: It is written in the prophet, "behold, I send my messenger before thy face, who shall prepare thy way before thee.
1.3: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight."
1.4: accordingly, John baptized in the desart, and preach'd the baptism of repentance, for the remission of sins.
1.5: all Judea, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, went out to meet him, and having confess'd their sins, he baptized them in the river Jordan.
1.6: now John was clothed with camels hair, with a leathern girdle about his waist: and his food was locusts and wild honey.
1.8: I indeed have baptized you with water, but he shall baptize you with the effusion of the holy Ghost.
1.9: At that time Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee, and was baptized by John in Jordan.
1.10: and as soon as he was got out of the water, he saw the heavens open, and the spirit lighting upon him, like a dove.
1.11: when this voice from heaven was heard, "thou art my beloved son, in whom I am well pleased."
1.12: presently after the spirit convey'd him into the desart.
1.13: where he continued forty days, being tempted by Satan: and when he was among the wild beasts, angels ministred unto him.
1.14: But after John was put in prison, Jesus came into Galilee, spreading the good news of the kingdom of the Messiah.
1.15: "the time, said he, is accomplish'd, and the kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel."
1.16: Now as he walked by the sea of Galilee, he saw Simon, and Andrew his brother, casting their net into the sea:
1.18: immediately they quitted their nets, and followed him.
1.19: when he had gone a little further, he saw James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in the bark mending their nets, whereupon he called them:
1.20: and they left their father Zebedee in the ship with the people he had hired, and went after him.
1.21: As soon as they were come to Capernaum, he entred into the synagogue, and it being the sabbath, instructed them.
1.22: and they were astonished at his manner of preaching: for he spoke with an air of authority, and not as the Scribes.
1.23: now there was in their synagogue a demoniack, who cried out, ah,
1.24: what have we to do with thee, Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to torment us? I know thee who thou art, the holy one of God.
1.26: and when the unclean spirit had thrown him into convulsions, with a loud cry, he came out of him.
1.27: at which they were all so amazed, that they ask'd one another, what's the meaning of all this? what new doctrine is here? for he commands with authority even the unclean spirits, and they obey him.
1.28: upon this his fame immediately spread abroad over all the region of Galilee.
1.29: As soon as they were come out of the synagogue, they went with James and John into the house of Simon and Andrew,
1.30: where Simon's wife's mother lay sick of a fever, who presently acquainted Jesus with it.
1.31: and he came, and taking her by the hand, lift her up; upon which the fever immediately left her, and she served them at table.
1.32: In the evening, when the sun was set, they brought to him many diseased, and several demoniacks.
1.33: the whole town being assembled before the door.
1.34: and he healed many that were variously affected with diseases, and cast out many demons, not allowing them to say that they knew him.
1.35: On the morrow rising up, while it was yet dark, he went out, and retired into a solitary place, where he prayed.
1.36: Simon, and the rest of his company, followed after him.
1.38: and he said unto them, let us go into the neighbouring villages, that I may preach there likewise, for that was the design of my coming.
1.39: and he preached in their synagogues throughout all Galilee, and cast out demons.
1.40: And there came a leper to him, who fell on his knees, and thus address'd him, "if you will, you can heal me."
1.42: and while he was speaking, the leprosy left him in an instant, and he was cur'd.
1.43: immediately Jesus sent him away, severely charging him, have a care,
1.44: said he, how you take the least notice of this to any man: but go, show your self to the priest, and offer for your cure what Moses commanded, that this may serve as a testimony against them.
1.45: but as soon as he was gone, he began freely to talk of it, and blazed it about every where, so that Jesus could not go publickly into the city any more, but stay'd in the out parts, which were not much frequented, where people came to him from every quarter.

2.1: Some time after he returned to Capernaum; upon the rumour that he was there,
2.2: so great a company assembled, that there was no room for them in the house, nor even about the door: and he preached the word unto them.
2.3: then they came and presented to him a paralytic, who had four men to carry him.
2.4: who finding it impossible to come nigh Him because of the press, uncovered the roof where He was: and when they had broken it up, they let down the cradle wherein the paralytic lay.
2.5: Jesus perceiving their faith, said to the sick of the palsy, son, thy sins are forgiven.
2.6: but there were certain of the Scribes sitting there, who were dissatisfied in their own minds, and said to themselves,
2.7: why doth this man speak such blasphemies? who can forgive sins but God?
2.8: and immediately Jesus perceiving by his spirit, that they made these secret reflections, said, why do you entertain such suggestions?
2.9: is it not as easy to say to the paralytic, thy sins are forgiven: as to say, arise, and take up your bed and walk?
2.10: however, to let you see that the son of man has power on earth to forgive sins, rise, said he, to the sick of the palsy,
2.11: 'tis I command you, take up thy bed, and go to your home.
2.12: instantly he arose, took up the bed, and went out in the presence of them all; insomuch that they were all amazed, and glorified God, saying, we never saw any thing like this.
2.13: Another time as he was by the sea-side, the people came all crowding to him, and he instructed them.
2.15: at length as Jesus sat at table in Levi's house, several publicans and loose people sat down likewise in company with Jesus, and his disciples: for a good number of them had followed him.
2.16: when the Scribes and Pharisees saw him eating with such a crew, they ask'd his disciples, what's the meaning that he is so familiar with people of such a wretched character?
2.17: Jesus hearing this, said to them, they that are in health, have no need of a physician, but they that are sick: I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners.
2.18: It was customary for the Pharisees, and the disciples of John, to fast; they came therefore and ask'd him, why do John's disciples, and the Pharisees fast so frequently, and not your disciples?
2.19: Jesus answered, can the bridemen fast, while the bridegroom is with them? as long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.
2.20: but the time will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away from them, and then shall they fast.
2.21: indeed no man ever sews a piece of new cloth on an old garment: because the new piece that is patch'd on, draws the old, and rends it still worse.
2.22: so no man pours new wine into old skins, for that would burst them, and then both would be lost: but new wine must be put into new skins.
2.23: Another time, as he was going through the corn-fields on the sabbath-day, his disciples as they pass'd along began to pluck the ears of corn.
2.24: upon which the Pharisees said to him, pray observe how they trespass on the sabbath-day.
2.25: but he replied, have ye never read what David, and the rest of the company did, when they were press'd with hunger?
2.26: how he went into the house of God in the days of Abiathar, who was afterwards high-priest, and did eat the shew-bread, giving some of it likewise to the company, though the law allow'd no body to eat of it but the priests.
2.27: adding this observation, "the sabbath was made for man, and not man for the sabbath."
2.28: therefore the son of man has a power of dispensing with the law of the sabbath.

3.1: Another time he entred into the synagogue, when a man was there who had a withered hand.
3.2: the Pharisees watched Jesus, to see if he would heal him on the sabbath-day, that so they might accuse him.
3.3: he said then to the man who had the withered hand, rise and stand there in the midst.
3.4: and he ask'd them, is it allowed to do good, or to do mischief on the sabbath-days? to save life, or to kill? but they were very silent.
3.5: then he looking with indignation at those about him, being concern'd at their disingenuous perverse temper, he said to the man, stretch out your hand, which he did, and his hand become sound.
3.6: upon this the Pharisees withdrew, and immediately enter'd into a conspiracy with the Herodians to take away his life.
3.7: But Jesus retired with his disciples towards the sea: where a great multitude followed him from Galilee, from Judea,
3.8: from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and the territory about Jordan, a considerable number of the inhabitants about Tyre and Sidon having heard of his great actions, came likewise to meet him.
3.9: wherefore, to avoid the inconveniences of the crowd, he order'd his disciples to get a small vessel ready to attend him.
3.10: for having healed abundance of people, all that were afflicted with any grievous distemper pressed upon him to touch him.
3.11: and when the impure spirits saw him, they threw themselves at his feet, crying out, "thou art the son of God."
3.12: but he strictly charged them, not to make him known.
3.13: At length he went up a mountain, and having appointed a select company to attend him, they came to him.
3.14: then he chose twelve of them to be near his person, and afterwards to be gospel-missionaries.
3.15: with full power to heal diseases, and dispossess demons.
3.16: these were Simon, whom he sirnam'd Peter, James the son of Zebedee,
3.17: and John the brother of James, (whom he had named Boanerges, that is to say, sons of thunder.)
3.18: Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alpheus, Thaddeus, Simon the Canaanite,
3.19: and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed him.
3.20: After this they went into an house, and the crowd press'd again upon them, so as to hinder them from taking their meal.
3.21: when his relations heard of this, they went to his relief, for it was said, he fainted away.
3.22: Some Scribes, who were come from Jerusalem, said, he is confederate with Beelzebub, the prince of the demons enables him to dispossess demons.
3.23: but calling them to him, he said by way of similitude, how can satan dispossess satan?
3.24: if a kingdom be divided against it self, that kingdom cannot last.
3.25: if a family be divided against it self, it is impossible for it to subsist.
3.26: so if satan rise up in opposition to his own interest, his power cannot subsist, but must entirely cease.
3.27: no one can enter into a strong man's house, and plunder his goods, unless the man be first secur'd.
3.28: I declare unto you, all the sins which men may commit, and whatsoever blasphemies they may utter, may be forgiven them.
3.29: but he that shall blaspheme against the holy Ghost, shall never be pardoned, but shall be obnoxious to eternal punishment.
3.30: this was in answer to their saying, he was influenc'd by an impure spirit.
3.31: In the mean time his brothers and his mother came there, and not being able to get within hearing,
3.32: for the crowd about him, they sent him word to come to them, and when they told him, your mother and brothers and sisters are here without enquiring for you,
3.33: He answer'd, who is my mother? who are my brothers?
3.34: and casting his eyes round the company, there, said he, are my mother and my brothers.
3.35: for he that does the will of God, he is my brother and sister and mother.

4.1: He began again to teach by the sea-side: but there was so great a crowd gathered about him, that he was oblig'd to go into a ship, where he sat down, and stay'd on board while the people stood on the shore.
4.2: then he addressed himself to them in many parables, and thus began his instructions.
4.3: give your attention to what I say, a sower went out to sow: as he sowed,
4.4: some of the seed happened to fall by the wayside, which the birds light upon, and devoured.
4.5: some fell on stony ground, where it had not much earth, and it soon sprang up, for want of a sufficient depth of earth.
4.6: but when the sun was up, it was scorched, and for want of root, withered away.
4.7: some fell among thorns, and the thorns grew up, and choaked it, so that it yielded no fruit.
4.8: but part of it fell on good ground, which sprang up, and grew so fruitful, that some grains produced thirty, others sixty, and some an hundred.
4.9: he that hath ears to hear, said he, let him hear.
4.10: And when he was in private, the twelve, and some of his disciples asked him the meaning of the parable.
4.11: he answered, you are admitted into the secret of the gospel-dispensation: but to unbelievers every thing is couch'd in parables; because,
4.12: tho' they see, they will not perceive, and tho' they hear they will not understand: as if they were afraid of parting with their vices, in order to be pardoned.
4.14: the sower is he that soweth the word.
4.15: they who receiv'd seed by the wayside, are those in whom the word is sown, who no sooner have heard it, but satan comes and takes away the word that was sown in their hearts.
4.16: in like manner, they who receive seed on stony-ground, are such as upon hearing the word, do immediately receive it with joy.
4.17: but having no root at the bottom, they are only occasional professors, for if they meet with any trouble or persecution upon account of the word, immediately they revolt.
4.18: as for those, who receive seed as among thorns: they are such as hear the word.
4.19: but the cares of this life, the deceitful love of riches, and a crowd of different passions, stifle the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
4.20: they who receive seed as on good ground, are such as hear the word and entertain it, and bring forth fruit, some in one degree, and some in another.
4.22: for there is nothing conceal'd but what shall be made manifest: nor was any thing kept secret, but in order to be divulged.
4.23: if any man have ears to hear, let him hear.
4.24: And consider, said he, how you hear; for in proportion as you weigh what is communicated to you, new light shall be given:
4.25: for he that makes use of what he has shall have more, but he that does not, shall be stript of what he has.
4.26: Again, he said, the state of the gospel is like that of the grain, which a man sows in his land:
4.27: however he takes his repose by night, or is employ'd by day, the grain shoots up and grows without his inspection.
4.28: for the earth spontaneously produces, first the blade, then the ear, after that the grain of corn in the ear.
4.29: but as soon as the fruit is ripe, the sickle is applied, because the harvest is come.
4.30: Again he said, to what shall we compare the state of the gospel? or by what parable shall we represent it?
4.31: it is like a grain of mustard-seed, which when sown in the earth, is less than any other grain that is sown there.
4.32: but after it is sown, it grows up, and becometh larger than other plants of the pulse kind, and shooteth out its branches so high, that the fowls of the air may lodge under its shadow.
4.33: Thus he instructed them by such a variety of parables as were adapted to their capacity.
4.34: his stile in publick was figurative, but he explain'd every thing to his disciples in private.
4.35: The same day in the evening, he said to them, let us cross over to the other side of the lake.
4.36: when they had dismiss'd the people, the bark he was in, set sail, in company with other small barks.
4.37: at length a violent storm ensued, and the waves beat into the ship, that it began to fill,
4.38: whilst Jesus was at the stern, asleep on a pillow: upon which they awak'd him, crying out, master, have you so little concern to let us sink? then he rose,
4.39: and rebuked the wind, hush, said he, and be still, immediately the wind subsides, and a settled calm ensued.
4.40: why, said he, are ye so frighted? are ye still so void of faith?
4.41: and they were exceedingly afraid, and said to one another, who can this be, that even the wind and the sea obey him?

5.1: They arrived then to the other side of the sea, in the country of the Gadarenes.
5.2: and as soon as Jesus was come out of the ship, he met a demoniack, who came from among the tombs, where he haunted,
5.3: no man being able to confine him, no not with chains:
5.4: for having been often bound with fetters and chains, he had wrench'd his chains, and broke his fetters, so that no body could tame him.
5.5: night and day he was in the mountains, howling among the tombs, and hacking his flesh with flints.
5.6: but when he saw Jesus afar off, he ran and prostrated himself before him.
5.7: and crying with a loud voice, said, "what injury have I done you, Jesus, thou son of the most high God? I adjure thee by God, not to torment me."
5.10: and he was very importunate with Jesus not to drive them away from that country.
5.11: now there was a great herd of swine feeding upon the mountain;
5.12: and all the demons intreated him, saying, "send us to the swine, that we may enter into them."
5.13: Jesus immediately gave them leave, and the impure spirits quitting the possessed, entred into the swine, and the whole herd, which were about two thousand, ran down a precipice into the sea, and were there stifled.
5.14: then they that fed the swine fled, and told the news to town and country, and they went out to see what had been done.
5.15: when they were come to Jesus, and saw him that had been possessed with the legion of demons, sitting in his clothes, and in his right mind, they were afraid.
5.16: and when the eye-witnesses had related what had pass'd with respect to the demoniack, and to the swine:
5.17: they intreated him to withdraw from their territories.
5.18: as he was embarking, the late demoniack desired, that he might be with Jesus.
5.19: however, Jesus refused him, and said, go home to thy friends, and tell them what great things the Lord hath done for thee, and how he hath had compassion on thee.
5.20: and he departed, and published in Decapolis, what Jesus had done for him: and all were filled with admiration.
5.21: When Jesus had repassed in the vessel to the other side, a crowd of people gathered about him, while he was nigh the sea.
5.22: when one of the rulers of the synagogue, Jairus by name, came, and as soon as he saw him, fell at his feet,
5.23: and earnestly intreated him, saying, "my little daughter is at the last extremity, pray come and lay thy hands on her, that she may be healed, and live."
5.24: so Jesus went with him, attended by a great crowd, that press'd about him.
5.25: Now there was a woman, who had been affected with an hemorrhage twelve years:
5.26: having suffered much from several physicians, she had spent all her fortune, and instead of being any thing the better, she rather grew worse.
5.27: but having heard of Jesus; she came behind him in the crowd, and touched his garment.
5.28: for said she, if I do but touch his clothes, I shall be cured.
5.29: and immediately the source of her disorder was dried up: and she sensibly perceived she was healed of that indisposition.
5.30: Jesus conscious of the influence he had exerted, immediately turned towards the crowd, and said, who touched my clothes?
5.31: his disciples replied, you see the multitude press about you, and do you ask, who touched you?
5.32: however, he looked about to see who it was.
5.33: then the woman, conscious of what had been effected in her, came trembling with fear, and falling down before him, confess'd the whole truth.
5.35: Before he had done speaking, messengers came from the ruler of the synagogue's house, who said, "your daughter is dead, why do you give the master any further trouble?"
5.37: and he suffered no man to follow him, except Peter, and James, and John the brother of James:
5.38: being come to the house of the ruler of the synagogue, and seeing a tumultuous crowd of people weeping and howling,
5.39: at his going in he said to them, what's the meaning of this uproar, what do you weep for? the damsel is not dead, but asleep.
5.40: upon which they fell a laughing: however, having turned them all out, and taking with him the father and the mother of the damsel, and those that had accompany'd him, he entred in where the damsel was lying.
5.41: then taking her hand, he said to her, Talitha cumi, that is to say, damsel, arise, 'tis I command you.
5.42: immediately the damsel arose, and walked, for she was twelve years of age: and they were struck with astonishment.
5.43: but he strictly charged them not to mention it to any one, and order'd something should be given her to eat.

6.1: Jesus leaving that place, went into his own country, attended by his disciples.
6.2: when the sabbath was come, he preach'd in the synagogue, to the great astonishment of many, who upon hearing his discourse, said, how came he by all this? what strange endowment of knowledge is this, that he should work such miracles?
6.3: is not he the carpenter, the son of Mary, the brother of James and Joses, of Juda and Simon? are not these his sisters, who are here with us? and they were scandalized at him.
6.5: so that excepting the cure of a few sick by the imposition of hands, he would not work any miracle there,
6.6: they were so marvellously incredulous, so that He went all about to teach in the neighbouring villages.
6.7: Now having called the twelve, he sent them out by two and two, giving them power to exorcize spirits:
6.8: he order'd them to take nothing for their journey, but a single staff, no scrip, no bread, nor money in their purse:
6.9: to have but one pair of shoes, and but one coat.
6.10: whatever house you enter into, said he, there abide, till you leave the place.
6.11: wherever they shall refuse to entertain you, or to hear you, at your departure shake off the dust of your feet, as a testimonial against them. I assure you, the people of Sodom and Gomorrha shall be treated with less severity in the day of judgment, than that city.
6.12: then they departed, and call'd upon all to repent.
6.13: they dispossess'd a great number of demons, many, that were sick, they anointed with oil, and restor'd their health.
6.14: In the mean time king Herod heard of Jesus, whose name was now celebrated, and he said, John the Baptist is risen from the dead, no wonder then that he works miracles.
6.15: others said, 'tis Elias, others, 'tis a prophet, or one equal to a prophet.
6.16: but Herod, from what he had heard, said, 'tis John himself, whom I caused to be beheaded, who is risen from the dead.
6.17: for Herod had given orders to seize John, and had confin'd him in prison, to gratify Herodias, his brother Philip's wife, whom he had married;
6.18: upon which John told him, "it is not lawful for you to have your brother's wife."
6.19: which Herodias resented, and form'd a design against his life, but could not execute it;
6.20: because Herod had a respect for John, knowing him to be a very honest good man, and therefore protected him; having reform'd many things upon his remonstrances, which he us'd to receive very graciously.
6.21: however, a favourable opportunity happen'd for her, upon Herod's making an entertainment the birth-night, for all the great officers of the court, and army, and persons of the first distinction in Galilee.
6.23: nay, he ratified his promise with an oath, "I will give you whatever you require, said he, tho' it be even the half of my kingdom."
6.24: then she withdrew, and said to her mother, what shall I ask? the head of John the Baptist, said she.
6.25: upon which she instantly fled to the king, and said, I desire to have John the Baptist's head brought hither immediately in a charger.
6.26: at this the king was exceedingly concern'd; however, in regard to his oath, and to those who were at table with him, he would not refuse her;
6.27: but immediately dispatch'd the proper officer with orders to bring the head of John the Baptist.
6.28: accordingly he went, and beheaded him in the prison, and bringing the head in a charger, he presented it to the young lady, who gave it to her mother:
6.29: of which John's disciples being inform'd, they came to fetch his corps, which they laid in a sepulchre.
6.30: Now the apostles met together in a body before Jesus, and gave him a full account, both of what they had done, and what they had taught.
6.32: so they privately set sail for the desart (of Bethsaida.)
6.33: but the people saw them embark, and many perceiving where they were bound, they ran thither a foot from all parts: and arrived at the place, before the passengers were come.
6.34: so that when Jesus landed, he found there a numerous assembly: which rais'd his compassion, because they were like so many sheep straggling without a pastor, whereupon he gave them various instructions.
6.35: but as the day was far advanc'd, his disciples came to him, and said, this is a desart place, and it is now late.
6.36: dismiss the company, that they may go to the neighbouring farms and villages to buy provisions, for they have nothing to eat.
6.37: Jesus replied, do you your selves give them something to eat, shall we go then, said they, to purchase bread, to the value of two hundred denarii, for them to eat?
6.39: then he order'd the people to sit down in distinct companies upon the green grass.
6.40: and they sat down in several divisions, some consisting of an hundred, and some of fifty.
6.41: Jesus then having taken the five loaves and the two fishes, look'd up to heaven and gave thanks; then breaking the loaves, he gave them to his disciples to distribute among the people: for whom he likewise divided the two fishes.
6.42: so that they all eat a sufficient share,
6.43: though the fragments of bread they took up, with what remain'd of the fishes, amounted to twelve baskets full;
6.44: the company that were entertain'd being about five thousand men.
6.45: Soon after Jesus obliged his disciples to embark for Bethsaida, on the opposite shore, while he was dismissing the people.
6.46: and when they had taken their leave, he retired to a mountain to pray.
6.47: It was now late in the evening, and the bark in full sea, when Jesus, who was ashore all alone,
6.48: perceived his disciples had much ado to bear up against the wind, which was contrary; about the fourth watch of the night, he came up, and would have pass'd by them.
6.49: when they saw him walking upon the sea, they thought it was an apparition,
6.50: for they all saw him, and were greatly terrified, but at the instant Jesus spoke to them, and said, take courage, it is I, don't be afraid.
6.51: and as soon as he was got aboard, the wind ceased; which still encreas'd their astonishment and admiration:
6.52: for they were so stupid, they did not comprehend the miracle of the loaves.
6.53: Being got to the other side of the lake, they came to the country of Gennasereth, where they landed.
6.54: no sooner were they ashore, but the people, who presently perceiv'd it was Jesus,
6.55: came flocking from all quarters, carrying their sick on their beds to the places where they heard he was:
6.56: and to whatever cities, towns, or villages he went, they expos'd the sick in the publick streets, entreating him, they might but touch the border of his garment; for as many as did so, were recover'd.

7.1: The Pharisees, and certain Scribes from Jerusalem, came in a body to Jesus;
7.2: when observing that some of his disciples were eating with profane hands, that is, without having wash'd them, they found fault.
7.3: for the Pharisees, and the Jews in general, in pursuance of their antient traditions, never eat till they have wash'd their hands up to their elbows.
7.4: nay, when they have been at any publick place, they never eat till they have washed, they observe besides several traditions, such as the washing of cups, pots, brass vessels, and beds.
7.5: the Pharisees, and Scribes therefore ask'd Jesus, why don't your disciples observe the tradition of the antients? why do they take their meals without washing their hands?
7.6: Jesus answered, to such hypocrites as you may well be applied those words of the prophet Esaias, "this people honour me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.
7.7: in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the institutions of men."
7.8: for laying aside what is of divine appointment, you stick to their human traditions, about the washing of pots, and cups, and many other the like practices.
7.9: You are in the right, said he, to abolish the laws of God, to make way for such traditions.
7.11: but your doctrine is this, if any one shall tell his father or his mother, that what he could bestow for their relief, is corban, that is, to be given to the temple;
7.12: you discharge him from the obligation of doing any thing for his father or his mother.
7.13: by such traditions, and such a number of practices, as you have settled, the word of God is stript of all its authority.
7.14: Then Jesus having called all the people to him, said, attend every one of you, and understand.
7.15: there is nothing from without, that entring into a man can defile him: but that which originally proceeds from the man, is what defiles him.
7.16: he that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
7.17: When he withdrew from the people into the house, his disciples ask'd him the meaning of that maxim.
7.19: because that does not enter into his heart, but into the belly, whence it is discharg'd, the purest part of the food being left for nutrition.
7.20: but, said he, that which proceeds from a man, is what defiles him:
7.21: for from within, from the heart of man proceed wicked designs, adulteries, fornications, murders; thefts,
7.22: avarice, malice, fraud, impudence, envy, scandal, pride, vanity.
7.23: all these vices come from within, and are what defile the man.
7.24: Jesus leaving that place, went towards the frontiers of Tyre and Sidon; and entring into a house, desired to let nobody know it; but he could not be conceal'd.
7.25: for a woman, whose child was possess'd with an impure spirit, having heard of him, found him out, and throwing herself at his feet,
7.26: entreated him to force the demon out of her daughter; now the woman was a Greek, a Syrophenician by nation.
7.28: she answer'd, true, Lord, yet puppys eat of the crumbs, which children drop under the table.
7.30: accordingly she went home, where she found that the demon was indeed gone out of her daughter, and she was lying on the bed.
7.31: Jesus then quitting the confines of Tyre and Sidon, and passing to the confines of Decapolis, came back to the sea of Gallilee.
7.32: and they presented to him a deaf man, that had an impediment in his speech, desiring he would lay his hands upon him.
7.33: Jesus taking him aside from the crowd, spit upon his fingers, and applied them to the ears and to the tongue of the deaf man.
7.35: and his Ears were instantly opened, his tongue was loosen'd, and he spoke freely.
7.36: and Jesus charg'd them not to mention it to any one; but the more be enjoin'd them, the more they publish'd it.
7.37: for they were transported with admiration, and said, all his actions are beneficent! he gives hearing to the deaf, and speech to the dumb.

8.1: At that time, as the company were very numerous, and had nothing to eat, Jesus called his disciples, and said,
8.2: I am concern'd for this people, they have been with me now three days without having had any thing to eat.
8.3: if I send them home fasting, they will faint by the way: for some of them are come very far.
8.4: his disciples answer'd, how is it possible here in the desart to furnish bread enough for all this company?
8.5: he ask'd them, how many loaves have ye?
8.6: seven, said they, then he order'd the people to sit down on the ground: and taking the seven loaves, he gave thanks, then broke them and gave them to his disciples to distribute among the people, which they accordingly did.
8.7: and there being a few small fishes, he gave thanks, and order'd them to be distributed.
8.8: so they all eat and were satisfied, the broken meat that was left amounting to seven baskets.
8.9: now they that had eaten were four thousand: and then he dismissed them.
8.10: Soon after he and his disciples embark'd, and arrived in the district of Dalmanutha.
8.11: there the Pharisees being come, they began to dispute with him, and to try him, desir'd he would work some miracle in the sky.
8.12: but Jesus fetching a deep sigh, said, why does this generation require a sign? I assure you, they shall have none.
8.13: then leaving them he went aboard again, and pass'd to the other side.
8.14: Now the disciples had forgot to take bread, and had but one loaf aboard with them.
8.15: as he was then directing them diligently to beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, and of the leaven of Herod,
8.16: they said to one another, this is because we did not take bread: which Jesus perceiving,
8.17: said, why do you trouble your heads about your having no bread? are you yet so void of sense, and understanding? are your minds so blinded?
8.18: have you eyes, and yet don't see? have you ears, and yet not hear? have you lost your memory too?
8.19: when I divided the five loaves among five thousand people, how many baskets full of fragments did you take away? they answer'd, twelve.
8.20: and when I divided the seven loaves among four thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you carry away? they answered, seven.
8.22: Afterwards Jesus went to Bethsaida, where they presented to him a blind man, whom they entreated Jesus to touch.
8.24: so looking up, he said, I see men; for by their walking I distinguish them from trees.
8.25: then he put his hands upon his eyes, and made him look again, and his sight was so well recovered, he could see distinctly.
8.27: From thence Jesus went attended with his disciples to the villages of Cesarea Philippi, and ask'd them by the way, who do they say I am?
8.28: they answered, some say you are John the Baptist; others, Elias; and others, one of the prophets.
8.30: upon which he gave them a severe charge, not to say that of him to any man.
8.31: At length he began to inform them, that the son of man should suffer many indignities, be rejected by the chief priests, Scribes, and senators, be even put to death, and after three days should rise again.
8.32: and this he said in such an undisguised manner, that Peter took him aside, and pretended to reprimand him.
8.33: but Jesus return'd, and looking upon his disciples, he gave Peter this rebuke, be gone, thou adversary, your views are all worldly, regardless of what is divine.
8.34: Then addressing himself to the people, and his disciples, he said, he that desires to be under my conduct, let him renounce himself, and follow me.
8.35: for he that would save his life, shall lose it; and he that would lose his life out of love to me and the gospel, he shall save it.
8.36: what advantage is it for a man to gain the whole world with the loss of his life?
8.37: or what would not a man bestow to preserve himself?
8.38: whosoever therefore shall be asham'd of me, and of my doctrine in this degenerate and corrupted age, of him likewise shall the son of man be asham'd, when he shall come with the glory of his father, accompanied with holy angels.

9.1: I declare unto you, said he, that some of you here present shall not die, till they see the kingdom of the Messiah usher'd in with power.
9.2: Six days after Jesus took Peter, James and John, and accompanied them up a high mountain in private; and was transfigured in their presence.
9.3: his raiment was of an exceeding bright whiteness, like that of snow, and such as no fuller upon earth could imitate.
9.4: Moses and Elias likewise appear'd, and were in conference with Jesus.
9.5: then Peter thus address'd himself to Jesus, master, it is proper for us to be here: let us make therefore three tabernacles, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elias.
9.6: for he knew not what he said, they were all so frightned.
9.7: then a cloud surrounded them, and a voice from the cloud, said, "this is my beloved son, hear him."
9.8: and instantly looking round about, they did not see any other person but Jesus with them.
9.9: as they were going down the mountain, he order'd them not to tell any body what they had seen, till the son of man was raised from the dead:
9.10: an expression which they dwelt upon, asking one another the meaning of "till he was raised from the dead."
9.11: At length they started this question, why do the Scribes say, that Elias must first come?
9.13: but I tell you, that Elias is already come, as it was foretold; and they have treated him at their discretion.
9.14: When he was come to the other disciples, he found a great crowd about them, and the Pharisees disputing with them.
9.15: as soon as they saw him, they were over-joyed, and ran to salute him.
9.16: then he ask'd the Scribes, what were you debating with them?
9.17: and one of the crowd answer'd, master, I have brought to you my son, who is possess'd with a dumb spirit,
9.18: which no sooner comes on him, but it throws him down: then the child foams, gnashes his teeth, and grows meager.
9.19: then said Jesus, incredulous people, how long shall I be with you? must I be always assisting you? bring him before me.
9.20: so he was brought to him, and as soon as he saw him, the spirit threw him into convulsions, and he fell upon the ground, where he wallowed foaming.
9.22: it has frequently thrown him into the fire, and into the water, to the hazard of his life; if therefore you can do any thing, have compassion on us, and help us.
9.23: Jesus said to him, provided you can believe, there is nothing but what may be effected for those that believe.
9.24: immediately the child's father cryed out with tears, I do believe, oh supply the defect of my faith.
9.25: Jesus observing the people came crowding to him, rebuked the evil spirit, saying, thou dumb and deaf spirit come out of the child, never to enter more, it is I command it.
9.26: and the spirit came out of him, having made him roar, and thrown him into such agonies, that he became like one that was dead, and many were of opinion he actually was so.
9.27: but Jesus taking him by the hand, raised him up, and he was perfectly recovered.
9.28: now when Jesus was retired to his own house, his disciples asked him in private, why could not we cast this spirit out?
9.29: Jesus answered, such a miracle is not effected but by prayer and fasting.
9.30: Having left that place, they went a private way through Galilee: for he was willing to be conceal'd.
9.31: in the mean time he gave his disciples this intimation, "the son of man is going to be delivered up into the hands of men, who will put him to death, and three days after he is put to death he shall rise again."
9.32: but they did not comprehend the meaning, and were ashamed to ask him about it.
9.33: At length, he arrived at Capernaum, where being in his own house, he asked his disciples, what were you disputing about by the way?
9.34: at which they were silent, for upon the road they had disputed about precedency.
9.35: then sitting down, he address'd himself to the twelve, saying, he that would be the first, must be the last of all, and the servant of all.
9.36: then taking a little child, he set him down before them; and embracing him in his arms, he said to them,
9.37: whoever receives such a child as this upon my account, receives me; and he that receiveth me, does not so properly receive me, as the commands of him that sent me.
9.38: Upon this occasion John address'd himself to Jesus, saying, master, we saw a man casting out demons in your name, tho' he did not belong to us, for which reason we opposed him.
9.40: such a one is not against us, but for us.
9.41: and whoever he be that shall give you a cup of water, as being the disciples of Christ, I assure you, he shall not lose his reward.
9.42: but if any one shall cause the meanest of those, who believe in me, to transgress, it had been better for him that a milstone were hanged about his neck, and he were thrown into the sea.
9.43: if even thy hand should make thee transgress, saw it off, and cast it away, it is better for thee to enter into life maimed, than to have both hands and go into Gehenna, the unextinguishable fire:
9.44: where their worm does not die, and the fire is not extinguished.
9.45: and if thy foot make thee transgress, saw it off, it is better for you to enter into life, tho' lame, than to have both feet, and be thrown into Gehenna, the unextinguishable fire:
9.46: where their worm does not die, and the fire is not extinguished.
9.47: and if your eye make you transgress, pull it out; it is better for you to enter into the kingdom of God, with but one eye, than to have two, and be thrown into the Gehenna of fire: where the worm does not die,
9.48: and the fire is not extinguished.
9.49: such a one shall be consumed by fire, but the offering that is salted shall be preserv'd from corruption.
9.50: salt is good, but if the salt become insipid, how shall it recover its savour? don't lose your seasoning, nor your peaceable behaviour to one another.

10.1: Jesus departed from thence, and went towards the confines of Judea, thro' the country beyond Jordan: where the people resorting to him again, he renewed his instructions to them as usual.
10.2: then the Pharisees came and propos'd to him this insnaring question, is it lawful for a man to repudiate his wife?
10.3: to which he answered, what direction did Moses give you?
10.4: Moses, said they, allowed a bill of divorce, and so to dismiss her.
10.5: but Jesus answered them, it was out of regard to your untractable temper, that Moses gave you this permission.
10.7: "wherefore, 'tis said, a man shall leave his father and mother, and cleave to his wife, and they two shall be one flesh."
10.8: consequently they are no longer two, but one person.
10.9: let no man therefore separate what God has designed to be one.
10.10: When they were in the house, the disciples asked him again concerning this matter, and he said to them,
10.11: whoever repudiates his wife and marries another, commits adultery against her:
10.12: and if a woman quits her husband and is married to another, she committeth adultery.
10.13: Then they brought young children to him, that he might lay his hands upon them: but his disciples rebuked those that presented them.
10.14: which Jesus observing was much displeas'd with them, and said, suffer little children to come unto me, do not hinder them: for of such is the kingdom of God.
10.15: I declare unto you, he that shall pretend to be admitted into the kingdom of God, and has not the temper of a little child, shall not enter therein.
10.16: then he embraced them, and laying his hand upon them, he gave them his blessing.
10.17: When he was set out upon his journey, there met him one, who kneeling down before him, said, good master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?
10.18: Jesus said to him, why do you call me good? there is but one, who is good, that is God.
10.19: you know the commandments, "do not commit adultery, do not kill, do not steal, do not bear false witness, defraud not, honour your father, and mother."
10.20: to which he answered, master, said he, all these precepts have I observed from my youth.
10.21: then Jesus looking upon him with a favourable eye, said, there is one thing still to be done; go, sell all your estate, and give it to the poor, and you shall have treasure in heaven; then come, take up the cross, and follow me.
10.22: but he was troubled at this answer, and went away very sorrowful, for he had a great estate.
10.23: then Jesus looking round about, said to his disciples, how difficult a thing is it for those who have riches to enter into the gospel kingdom!
10.25: it is easier for a cable to pass thro' the eye of a needle, than for such a rich man to enter into the divine kingdom.
10.26: at this they were more amazed than before, and said to one another, how then can such a man be saved?
10.27: but Jesus casting his eye upon them, said, what is impossible to men, is not so to God; for to God all things are possible.
10.28: Then Peter thus address'd himself to Jesus, you see we have left every thing to follow you.
10.29: Jesus answered him, I declare unto you, there is not a man who has forsaken his house, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, out of love to me and to the gospel,
10.30: but shall receive at present in this age, what will be a hundred times better to him, than houses, and brethren, and sisters, and mothers, and children, and lands, tho' with persecution: and in the age to come eternal life.
10.31: but they that are first shall be last, and the last shall be first.
10.32: When they were on the road to Jerusalem, Jesus led the way, and they followed behind full of apprehension and fear, then Jesus calling the twelve apostles to him again, acquainted them with what should befal him.
10.34: they will treat him with ignominy, subject him to the lash, spit upon him, and at last put him to death, but on the third day he will rise again.
10.35: Then James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came to him, and said, we desire you would grant us what we request.
