10.36: what, said he, would you have me do for you?
10.37: they replied, when you are in your glory, grant that we may sit, the one on your right hand, and the other on your left.
10.38: but Jesus said to them, you know not what you ask, can you drink the cup, that I must drink, and be baptized with the baptism with which I must be baptized?
10.39: and they said, we can, but Jesus replied, you shall indeed drink of the cup, that I must drink of, and be baptized with the baptism, with which I must be baptized; but to sit on my right hand,
10.40: or on my left, is not in my power to grant, except to those for whom it was designed.
10.41: but the other ten, when they heard this, were fill'd with indignation against James and John.
10.42: So that Jesus called them to him, and said, you know that the rulers of the Gentiles domineer over them, and their great ones treat them in an imperious manner;
10.43: but it shall not be so among young you: on the contrary, whoever would be great among you, he must be your servant;
10.44: and whoever would be the chief, he must be the slave of all the rest.
10.45: for the son of man himself is not come to receive the services of men, but to do them service, and to lay down his life a ransom for many.
10.46: At length they came to Jericho, and as he was leaving Jericho, accompanied by his disciples, and a great number of people, a blind man called Bartimeus sat begging in the high-way.
10.47: when he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he cried out, and said, Jesus, son of David, have pity on me.
10.48: but many of the company rebuk'd him, in order to silence him, at which he cry'd out with more earnestness, son of David have pity on me.
10.50: upon which he threw off his loose coat, and went to Jesus;
10.51: who thereupon spoke to him, and said, what would you have me do for you? the blind man replied, Lord, I desire to have my sight.
10.52: and Jesus said to him, go your way, your faith has cur'd you, and immediately he had sight, and followed Jesus in the road.

11.1: As they came near to Jerusalem, about Bethphage and Bethany, by the mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of his disciples, and said to them:
11.2: go to yonder village that faces you, and upon your entrance into it, you will find a colt tied, that never was yet backed; loose him, and bring him to me.
11.3: if any one should ask you, why you do so? tell him, the Lord has occasion for it, and immediately he will send it hither.
11.4: accordingly they went, and finding the colt tied before a door, where two ways met, they untied it.
11.5: upon which some people there said to them, what do you mean by untying the colt?
11.6: and they answered as Jesus had directed, so they let them go.
11.7: then they brought the colt to Jesus, and throwing their garments upon it, he mounted thereon.
11.8: many spread their clothes in the way, others lopt down the branches of trees to strew them in the road.
11.9: the crowd that march'd before and behind crying out, Hosanna, blessed be he that comes in the name of the Lord;
11.10: blessed be the kingdom of our father David, which is now come, Hosanna in the highest heavens.
11.11: Jesus having made his entrance into Jerusalem, went into the temple, and after he had survey'd the whole, it being then late, he departed with the twelve to Bethany.
11.12: On the morrow when they had left Bethany, he was press'd with hunger.
11.13: and observing at a distance a fig-tree full of leaves, he went up to it to see if he could find any fruit upon it, but when he came to it, he found it had nothing but leaves, (for it was not the season for that sort of fig.)
11.14: thereupon Jesus said to the fig-tree, "no one shall ever eat any fruit of yours." and his disciples took notice of it.
11.15: Being arrived at Jerusalem, Jesus went into the temple, and began to turn out those that bought and sold there; he overthrew the table of Money-changers, and the stalls of those that sold doves.
11.16: nor would he suffer any baggage to be carried thro' the temple.
11.17: at the same time he explained himself to them in these words, is it not written, "my house shall be called a house of prayer to all nations?" but ye have made it a harbour for thieves.
11.18: the Scribes and Pharisees upon hearing this consulted together how to destroy him; but they stood in awe of him, because all the people were strangely affected with his doctrine.
11.19: but at night Jesus withdrew from the city.
11.20: In the morning as they were coming back, they saw the fig-tree withered away to the very roots.
11.21: Peter remembring the tree, said, master, see the fig-tree, which you cursed, is quite withered.
11.22: but Jesus replied, and said to them, rely upon God.
11.23: for I assuredly tell you, that whoever shall say to this mountain, be removed, and cast into the sea, having no doubt in his mind, but believing what he says shall be effected, what he pronounces shall actually be accomplished.
11.24: therefore whenever you pray, be fully persuaded of obtaining your request, and I assure you it shall be granted, whatever it be.
11.25: only when you are dispos'd to prayer, if you have any cause of complaint against any one, forgive him, that your heavenly father may forgive you your offences.
11.26: but if you do not forgive others, neither will your heavenly father forgive you.
11.27: Then they entred again into Jerusalem: and as he was walking in the temple, the chief priests, the Scribes, and rulers of the Jews came about him,
11.29: Jesus replied to them, if you will answer one question, that I shall propose to you, then I will tell you by what authority I act thus.
11.30: the baptism of John, was it of divine, or of human institution?
11.33: they therefore gave Jesus this answer, we cannot tell, neither do I, said Jesus, acquaint you by what authority I act thus.

12.2: at the time of vintage he sent his servant to the vine-dressers to receive the profits of his vineyard.
12.3: but they seized on him, and beat him, and sent him home empty.
12.4: after this he sent another servant to them, him they assaulted with stones and cudgels, and sent him back with contempt.
12.5: then he sent another, whom they killed: and of several more, some they beat, some they killed.
12.6: at last, having one only son, whom he loved, he sent him to them; surely, said he, they will reverence my son.
12.8: so they seized upon him, and dragg'd him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
12.9: now what will the master of the vineyard do? on his return, said they, he will destroy those vine-dressers, and give his vineyard to others.
12.10: have you not read, said he, this passage of scripture, "the stone which the builders rejected, is become the principal stone of the angle.
12.11: it is the Lord, that has done this, and it is marvellous in our eyes."
12.12: then they contriv'd how they might seize him, for they perceived, that he applied the parable to them; but for fear of the people they left him, and went away.
12.13: Then they sent some of the Pharisees, and of the Herodians to insnare him in his discourse.
12.14: when they were come, they said to him, master, we know that you are sincere, that you are not influenced by any one, for you have no regard to the person of men: but teach us the way of God according to truth, now should we pay tribute to Cesar, or no? shall we pay, or shall we not pay?
12.15: but he, perceiving their hypocrisy, said to them, why do you lay snares for me?
12.17: to which Jesus reply'd, render to Cesar what belongs to Cesar, and to God what belongs to God, and they were surprized at the answer.
12.18: Then the Saducees, who deny the resurrection, came and asked him,
12.19: saying, master, Moses has left it us in writing, that if a man dies, and leaves his wife without any children, his brother should marry his widow, in order to perpetuate his name.
12.20: now there were seven brothers: the first married a wife and died, leaving her without any children.
12.21: the second married her, and he died too without leaving her any children: the third did the same.
12.22: so that all the seven married her, but left no children, last of all she died.
12.23: at the time therefore of the resurrection, when they shall rise, whose wife shall she be of the seven?
12.25: for when they shall rise from the dead, they neither will marry, nor be given in marriage, but be immortal like the angels in heaven.
12.26: and as for the dead, that they will actually rise, have you not read in the book of Moses those words, which God pronounc'd out of the bush to him, "I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?"
12.27: he is not the God of the dead, but the God of the living: and therefore you greatly mistake the meaning.
12.28: One of the Scribes, that had heard their dispute, observing the propriety of his answers, propos'd this question to him, which is the principal commandment of all?
12.29: Jesus answer'd him, the first of all the commandments is thus deliver'd, "hear, o Israel, the lord our God is the only lord.
12.30: you shall therefore love the lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, to the utmost of your understanding, and all your faculties." this is the first commandment.
12.31: and the second, which has an affinity to it, is this: "you shall love your neighbour as yourself." there is no other commandment greater than these.
12.32: the Scribe replied, what you have said, master, is very true, there is one God, and no other but he.
12.33: and to love him with all the heart, with all the understanding, with all the soul, with all its faculties, and to love one's neighbour as one's self is more acceptable than all the offerings and sacrifices in the world.
12.34: Jesus observing he answer'd so discreetly, said to him, you are not far from the kingdom of God, and no man after that was so hardy as to ask him any question.
12.35: As Jesus was teaching in the temple, he address'd himself to them, saying, why do the Scribes maintain that Christ is the son of David?
12.36: for David himself, who was inspired by the holy spirit, has this expression, "the Lord said to my Lord, sit thou at my right hand till I make thy enemies thy foot-stool."
12.37: now since David himself calls him Lord, how can he be David's son? and the common people heard him with pleasure.
12.39: and to have the first seats in their synagogues, and at their feasts:
12.40: who yet devour widows estates under the shew of making long prayers, such shall receive greater condemnation.
12.41: At length, as Jesus was sitting over-against the treasury, he observed the peoples throwing money into the chest; when many of the rich gave large sums.
12.42: and there came a certain poor widow, who threw in two mites, to the value of a farthing.
12.43: upon which he call'd to his disciples, and said to them, I declare unto you, that this poor widow has given more than any of those, who have given to the treasury.
12.44: for all the rest contributed out of their superfluous substance; but she has contributed what she wanted for her bare subsistence.

13.1: As Jesus was going out of the temple, one of his disciples said to him, see, master, what stone-work, and buildings are here.
13.3: and when he was sitting upon the mount of Olives over-against the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew said to him in private, tell us,
13.4: when shall this happen? and what will be the sign that this is going to be accomplished?
13.5: Jesus answer'd by saying, take care not to let any one impose upon you;
13.6: for many shall come in my name, and say, I am the Messiah; and deceive many.
13.7: but when ye shall hear the talk of wars, and the noise of wars, be not alarm'd; for that must happen; but the end is not yet.
13.8: for nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: there shall be earthquakes in divers places, famines and commotions.
13.10: but the gospel must first be published among all nations.
13.11: now when they shall lead you to deliver you up, be not sollicitous about your defence, don't premeditate upon it; but what shall be suggested to you at the very occasion, that deliver: for it is not you that will plead, but the holy spirit.
13.13: you will be the object of universal hatred upon my account; but he that shall persevere unto the end, shall be saved.
13.14: Now when you shall see the-abomination of desolation, mentioned by the prophet Daniel, establish'd where it ought not to be (let the reader observe) then let those, who are in Judea, flee to the mountains:
13.15: he that is upon the battlements let him not descend into the house, nor enter therein to take any thing away: let
13.16: not him that is in the field return back to fetch his garment.
13.17: unhappy the women who are pregnant, and those who nurse children at such a time.
13.18: pray that your flight be not in the winter.
13.19: for the distress of that time will be such as never happen'd since the beginning of the world, which God created, to this present, nor ever shall be.
13.20: so that if the Lord should suffer it to last, no man could escape: but he will not suffer the time to last long, out of regard to his elect.
13.22: for false Christs, and false prophets shall rise, and shall shew signs and prodigies, so as to seduce, if it were possible, even the very elect.
13.23: be you therefore upon your guard: remember I have forewarned you against all events.
13.25: the stars of heaven shall fall, and the powers that are in heaven shall be shaken.
13.26: then shall they see the son of man coming in the clouds with power and great glory.
13.27: then will he send his angels, and gather his elect from the four winds, from the remotest part of the earth, to the remotest part of heaven.
13.28: Consider this similitude taken from a fig-tree: when its branch is yet tender, and pushes out its leaves, you know that summer is near:
13.29: so when you shall see these things happen, know that he is nigh, even at your doors.
13.30: I declare unto you, this generation shall not be extinct, till all these things be transacted.
13.31: heaven and earth shall fail, but my words shall never fail.
13.33: be circumspect, be vigilant, and devout: because you are uncertain when that time will be.
13.34: when a man travels into foreign parts, he leaves his goods in charge to his servants, he appoints to every one his task, and orders the porter to be vigilant,
13.35: watch ye therefore (for you don't know when the master of the house will return; whether at evening, or at midnight, or at the cock-crowing, or in the morning)
13.36: for fear by his sudden return he should surprize you sleeping.
13.37: what I say to you, I say to all, be vigilant.

14.1: Within two days was the feast of the passover, and of unleavened bread, and the chief priests, with the Scribes, contriv'd how they might seize Jesus by surprize, and put him to death.
14.2: but they objected, it could not be during the festival, for fear of a popular insurrection.
14.3: now being at Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, while he was at table, there came a woman with a viol full of the perfume of spikenard, which was very costly; and she opened the viol, and poured it upon his head.
14.4: but some had a secret indignation, and said, why must the perfume be so wasted?
14.5: for we could have sold it for above two hundred denarys, and given them to the poor: and they inveighed against her.
14.6: but Jesus said, let her alone, why do you disquiet her? it is commendable, what she has done out of respect to me.
14.7: the poor you have always with you, and you may relieve them whenever you please: but me you will not always have.
14.8: she has done what she could: she has perfum'd my body previously to my burial.
14.9: I declare unto you, in whatever quarter of the world this part of the gospel-history shall be related, this action of hers shall be mention'd to her praise.
14.10: Then Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went to the chief priests, in order to betray him to them.
14.11: they were glad to hear him, and promis'd to give him money, upon which he contriv'd the most favourable occasion to betray him.
14.12: On the first day of unleavened bread, when the paschal lamb is kill'd, his disciples said to him, where would you have us go and prepare for your eating the paschal lamb?
14.13: upon which he dispatch'd two of his disciples, and said to them: go into the city, and you will meet a man carrying a pitcher of water; follow him.
14.14: and wherever he enters, say to the master of the house: "thus saith our master; where is the chamber, where I shall eat the passover with my disciples?"
14.15: and he will shew you a large upper room ready furnished: there make preparation for us.
14.16: his disciples therefore went away, and being come into the city, they found every thing, as he had told them; and they prepared the paschal lamb.
14.17: There he came in the evening with the twelve.
14.18: and as they sat eating, Jesus said, verily I say unto you, one of you that is eating with me, will betray me.
14.19: and they were seized with sorrow, all successively asking him, is it I?
14.20: but he answered them, saying, it is one of the twelve, he that eats of the same mess with me.
14.21: the son of man is going indeed, according to what is written of him: but wo to that man, by whom the son of man is betrayed: it would be better for that man, if he had never been born.
14.22: When they had been eating, Jesus took bread, and having given thanks, he brake it, and gave it to them, and said, take it, this represents my body.
14.23: and he took the cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, and they all drank of it.
14.24: and he said to them, this represents the effusion of my blood (the sanction of the new covenant) for mankind.
14.25: but this I tell you, I will never more drink of this fruit of the vine, from this time forth to that day, when I shall drink with you of the spiritual wine in the kingdom of God.
14.26: Then, having sung an hymn, they went out towards the mount of Olives.
14.28: but after I am risen, I will go before you into Galilee.
14.30: Jesus said to him, verily I tell thee, to-day, even this night, before the cock crow twice, you will renounce me thrice.
14.32: At length they came to a place call'd Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples, stay here, whilst I shall be at prayer.
14.33: but he took with him Peter, James, and John, then he began to be in a great consternation and anguish of mind, and he said to them; my soul is exceeding sorrowful,
14.34: even unto death: tarry ye here, and watch.
14.35: then advancing a little further, he fell on the ground, and prayed, that this anxiety might pass from him.
14.38: watch and pray, that you may not yield to temptation: the mind indeed is vigorous, but the body is weak.
14.39: Again he retired, and prayed, uttering the same words.
14.40: then he return'd and found them still sleeping, for their eyes were heavy, and they did not know how to give an answer.
14.42: rise, let us be going: see, the traitor is just upon us.
14.43: All of a sudden, while he was yet speaking, appear'd Judas, one of the twelve, attended by a great number of people with swords and clubs, who were sent by the chief priests, the Scribes, and rulers.
14.44: now he that betrayed him, had given them this signal, you will see me salute one with a kiss, that's he: seize him, and don't let him escape.
14.45: then advancing, he went directly up to him, saying, master, master, and kissed him.
14.46: and they violently laid hands on him and secured him.
14.47: but one of those that stood by, drew his sword against a servant of the high priest, and struck off his ear.
14.48: but Jesus addressing himself to them, said, why do you come with swords and clubs against me, as if you were to apprehend some robber?
14.49: I was daily among you, teaching in the temple, and you did not then seize upon me, but the scriptures are thereby accomplished.
14.50: then all his disciples abandon'd him and fled.
14.51: But a certain youth, that was stript to his inmost vest, followed him, and was seized by the soldiers.
14.52: but he slipt from his vest, and fled away naked.
14.53: Jesus they led away to the high priest's, where all the chief priests, the rulers and Scribes, were assembled.
14.54: Peter followed at a distance, even into the palace of the high priest: where he sat down among the servants to warm himself at the fire.
14.55: Now the chief priests, and the whole council endeavour'd to get evidence against Jesus, to condemn him to die; but they found none.
14.56: there were indeed several, who depos'd what was false against him: besides, what they deposed was insufficient.
14.57: at last there appear'd some, who gave in false evidence against him,
14.58: saying, we heard him say, "I will pull down this temple that is made with hands, and within three days I will build another made without hands."
14.59: but neither did this evidence appear sufficient.
14.63: then the high priest rent his robes, and said to the council, what occasion is there for any more witnesses?
14.64: you have heard the blasphemy, what is your opinion? and they all pronounc'd, that he deserved to die.
14.65: then some began to spit on him, others cover'd his face and struck him on the head, crying out, divine, who it is, and the domestics slapt him on the cheeks.
14.66: In the mean time Peter was in the entry of the hall, where one of the maids belonging to the high priest came:
14.67: and seeing Peter warming himself, she looked earnestly upon him, and said, you too was with Jesus the Nazarene.
14.68: but he denied it, saying, I don't know him, neither am I acquainted with any such you mention, and he went out into the porch, when the cock crow'd.
14.69: the maid saw him a second time, and said to the standers-by, this is one of them:
14.70: but he denied it again, a little time after, they that stood by, still urg'd Peter, saying, you are certainly one of his disciples, for your speech shows you to be a Galilean.
14.71: but he fell a cursing, and swore, I don't know the man you mention,

15.1: Early in the morning the chief priests, the rulers, and Scribes, even the whole council, after having deliberated together, caus'd Jesus to be bound, then led him away and deliver'd him to Pilate.
15.3: the chief priests continuing to accuse him with much clamour,
15.5: but Jesus still made no answer; so that Pilate was much amaz'd.
15.6: Now during the feast, it was customary to release a prisoner, to be nominated by the people.
15.7: Barabbas lay then confin'd with other seditious, who had committed murder in an insurrection.
15.8: the populace therefore fell a roaring, and desired him to do as was always practis'd.
15.10: for he perceived plainly, it was out of malice, that the chief priests had prosecuted him.
15.11: but the chief priests incited the people to demand, that he would rather release Barabbas.
15.12: Pilate still urg'd them again, and said, what then would you have me do with him, that you stile king of the Jews?
15.15: Pilate therefore willing to humour the people, released to them Barabbas, and having caused Jesus to be scourg'd, he deliver'd him to be crucified.
15.16: Then the soldiers took Jesus away into the hall, call'd Pretorium; and summon'd their whole company together.
15.17: and they put on him a purple cloth, and set a wreath of thorns upon his head for a crown;
15.18: then they began to salute him, saying, "Hail king of the Jews!"
15.19: and they struck him on the head with a cane, spit upon him, and bowing their knees, made a show of reverence.
15.20: Their mockery ended, they stript him of his purple, and put his own cloaths on him; then led him away to be crucified.
15.21: one Simon of Cyrene, the father of Alexander and Rufus, as he pass'd by in his return out of the country, was compell'd to carry the cross.
15.22: so they brought him to a place called Golgotha, that is, the place of a skull.
15.23: there they offered him myrrhed wine to drink, but he did not take it.
15.24: after they had crucified him, they shared his garments, by casting lots for them: to determine what each of them should take.
15.25: now it was the third hour of the day, when they crucified him,
15.26: and the inscription of the charge against him was thus express'd, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
15.27: at the same time they crucified two robbers, one on his right hand, the other on his left.
15.28: so that this passage of scripture was fulfill'd, "and he was numbred with the transgressors."
15.29: besides the people that pass'd by, shook their heads, and impiously said: ah, you that can destroy the temple, and rebuild it in three days,
15.30: save your self, and come down from the cross.
15.31: in like manner the chief priests and the Scribes in derision said to one another: he pretended to save others, himself he cannot save.
15.32: let the Messiah, the king of Israel, descend now from the cross: let us see that, and we will believe on him, and they that were crucified with him, threw their reproaches at him.
15.33: Now from the sixth hour the whole land was cover'd with darkness until the ninth hour.
15.35: some there present upon hearing that, said: observe, he calls upon Elias.
15.36: then one of the soldiers ran and dipp'd a spunge in vinegar, which he fastned to a stick, and offered him to drink, now let us, said they, see whether Elias will come to take him down.
15.37: then Jesus cry'd with a loud voice, and expired.
15.38: Immediately the veil of the temple was rent in two, from the top to the bottom.
15.39: and the Centurion who stood over-against him, observing that he expired with so great a cry, said, certainly this man was the son of God.
15.40: there were likewise several women, who were spectators at a distance: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the minor, and of Joses and Salome:
15.41: who had attended Jesus, and supply'd him with necessaries when he was in Galilee: besides many other women, who came up with him to Jerusalem.
15.42: Now, as soon as the evening was come; because it was then the preparation, that is, the day before the sabbath,
15.43: one Joseph of Arimathea, an honourable senator, who was himself in expectation of the kingdom of God, ventur'd to come and wait upon Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus.
15.44: Pilate surpriz'd that he should be dead so soon, sent for the Centurion, and ask'd him, if he had been dead any time.
15.45: and being satisfied of it, he granted the body to Joseph;
15.46: who taking down the body, wrapped it in a fine linnen cloth, which he had bought, and laid it in a sepulchre, which was hewn out of a rock, and roll'd a stone for a door to the sepulchre: and Mary Magdalene,
15.47: and Mary the mother of Joses, took notice where he was laid.

16.1: When the sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome, after having bought aromatic drugs to embalm him,
16.2: went to the sepulchre very early in the morning, the first day of the week, at sun-rising.
16.3: and they said to one another, who will remove the stone from the mouth of the sepulchre for us?
16.4: (for it was very great.) but when they were near in view, they perceiv'd that the stone was roll'd away.
16.5: upon their entring into the sepulchre, they saw a young man sitting towards the right, cloathed in a long white garment: at which they were frighted.
16.7: go, tell Peter and the rest of his disciples, that he is gone before you into Galilee: there you will see him, as he foretold you.
16.8: at this they started out, and fled from the sepulchre in a violent consternation, without speaking a word to any by the way: they were so frighted.
16.9: Now Jesus being risen early on the first day of the week, he appear'd first to Mary Magdalene, whom he had dispossess'd of seven demons.
16.10: immediately she went to those who frequented Jesus, and were then bemoaning themselves in tears, and acquainted them with it.
16.11: but though they heard that he was alive, and had appear'd to her, they did not believe.
16.12: after that, he appear'd under another form to two of them, as they were taking a walk into the country.
16.13: and they went and acquainted the rest: but neither did they believe them.
16.14: afterwards he appear'd to the eleven, as they were all sitting at table, and he reproved them for their incredulity and obstinacy in not giving credit to those, who had seen him after his resurrection.
16.15: Then he said to them, go ye into all parts of the world, and preach the gospel to all mankind.
16.16: he that believeth, and is baptized, shall be saved; but he that disbelieves, shall be condemned.
16.17: they that believe shall be endued with these miraculous gifts: in my name they shall cast out demons: they shall speak new languages:
16.18: they shall handle serpents, and if they drink any mortal poison, it shall do them no hurt: they shall lay hands on the sick, and the sick shall recover.
16.19: Now after the Lord had convers'd with them, he was assum'd up to heaven, where he sat on the right hand of God.
16.20: as for the disciples, they went and preached the gospel in all parts: the Lord co-operating with them, and confirming their doctrine by the miracles that accompany'd it.

1.1: Whereas several have undertaken to draw up a narrative of those transactions, which pass'd among us;
1.2: according as they were delivered to us by persons, who were all along eye-witnesses, and had a share in the transactions themselves:
1.3: I have likewise thought proper; most excellent Theophilus, to write to you a particular account; having made a very diligent inquiry into the whole matter,
1.4: that you may have a distinct view of those things about which you have been inform'd.
1.5: In the time of Herod, the king of Judea, there was a certain priest, named Zacharias, of the family of Abia, whose wife; nam'd Elizabeth, was of the race of Aaron:
1.6: they were both of them sincerely pious; observing all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord; with unspotted reputation.
1.7: they had no children, because Elizabeth was steril, and they were both advanced in years.
1.8: now Zachary was to officiate in divine service, in the order of his family,
1.9: and according to the custom of distributing the parts, it fell to his lot to burn incense in the sanctuary.
1.10: and all the congregation of the people stood praying without, at the time of offering incense,
1.11: when there appear'd to him an angel of the Lord standing on the right side of the incense-altar.
1.12: Zacharias startled at the sight and was seized with fear.
1.14: he shall be your joy and transport, and numbers shall rejoice at his birth.
1.15: he shall appear as a divine messenger, he shall drink neither wine, nor any other strong liquor: he shall be filled with the holy spirit, even from his infancy:
1.16: he shall convert many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God.
1.17: and he shall march before him, in the spirit and power of Elias, to reconcile parents and children together, and the unruly to the practice of justice, that the people may be duly dispos'd to receive the Lord.
1.18: But Zacharias said to the angel, by what sign shall I know this? for I am old, and my wife is of a great age.
1.19: the angel replied, I am Gabriel, who attend in the presence of God, and am sent to communicate to you this agreeable message.
1.20: you shall now become dumb and not recover your speech, till the very day when these things shall happen; because you distrusted my words, which in due time shall have their effect.
1.21: In the mean time the people were waiting for Zacharias, and wonder'd at his tarrying so long in the temple.
1.22: but when he came out, he could not speak to them: and they perceived that he had seen a vision in the temple; for he intimated it to them by signs, and continued dumb.
1.23: and the time of his officiating being ended, he departed to his own house.
1.24: Some time after, Elizabeth his wife was pregnant, and went into retirement for five months.
1.25: it is the Lord, said she, who has thus favour'd me, at the time when he took care to remove the reproach I was under among men.
1.26: In the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee, named Nazareth,
1.27: to a virgin contracted to a man; whose name was Joseph, of the house of David, and the virgin's name was Mary.
1.28: the angel, upon his arrival, said to her; "Hail, favorite of heaven, the Lord is with thee: thou happiest of thy sex."
1.29: Mary was surpriz'd at the voice of such an appearance, and wonder'd what the meaning of this salutation should be.
1.31: you shall be now pregnant, and be delivered of a son, whom you shall name JESUS.
1.32: he shall be great, he shall be the son of the most high, the Lord God shall give him the throne of his father David.
1.33: he shall reign over the house of Jacob, and of his kingdom there shall be no end."
1.34: Then said Mary to the angel, what shall this be without any intercourse with man?
1.35: the angel answered her, "the holy spirit shall descend upon thee, and the power of the most high shall over-shadow thee: wherefore thy holy offspring shall be called the son of God.
1.36: even your cousin Elizabeth, as old as she is, is become pregnant with a son: she, who was stiled barren, is now in her sixth month;
1.37: for nothing is impossible to God."
1.38: then said Mary, "behold the servant of the Lord, be it unto me according to thy word." upon which the angel disappeared.
1.39: Soon after this, Mary departed, and made an expeditious journey to a city of Juda, in the mountains:
1.40: where entring into the house of Zacharias, she saluted Elizabeth.
1.41: no sooner had Elizabeth heard the salutation of Mary, but the babe leap'd within her:
1.43: "Blessed mother of the most blessed offspring! what an honour is this, that I should be visited by the mother of our Lord!
1.44: no sooner did the sound of your salutation strike mine ear, than the babe leap'd within me for joy.
1.45: blessed is she that has believed; for what she has heard from the Lord, shall be accomplished."
1.46: Then Mary said, "my soul doth magnify the Lord,
1.47: and my spirit hath rejoiced in God my saviour,
1.48: for he hath regarded the low estate of his servant: and future ages shall proclaim me blessed.
1.49: the almighty hath distinguish'd me by the greatest marks of favour: his name be for ever reverenc'd.
1.50: his mercy is on them that fear him, from generation to generation.
1.51: he hath displayed the strength of his arm, and has confounded the proud by the devices of their hearts.
1.52: he has cast down princes from their thrones, and exalted those of low degree,
1.53: the needy he has furnished with plentiful enjoyments, and the rich he has reduced to poverty.
1.54: he has taken Israel his servant into his protection, in pursuance of the mercy,
1.55: which he promised to our forefathers, to Abraham, and to his posterity for ever."
1.56: Now Mary stay'd about three months with Elizabeth, and then return'd to her own house.
1.57: When Elizabeth had gone her full time, she was delivered of a son.
1.58: her neighbours and her relations having heard how the Lord had heap'd his favours upon her, they congratulated with her:
1.59: and on the eighth day were present at the circumcision of the child, but upon their proposing to call him by his father's name, Zacharias: his mother objected to it,
1.60: and said, no, he shall be called John.
1.61: they answered her, there is not any of your family of that name.
1.62: they therefore ask'd his father to signify how he would have him call'd.
1.63: then he made signs for a writing-book, and writ these words, "his name is John:" at which they were all surprized.
1.64: immediately he had the use of his speech: and he uttered himself in praises to God.
1.65: All the neighbourhood were struck with reverence, and the rumour of these events ran thro' all the mountains of Judea,
1.66: and made an impression upon all that heard of them, what a child will this be? said they, for the divine influence does attend him.
1.67: Then Zacharias his father, inspired by the holy spirit, vented his divine enthusiasm in these words.
1.68: "blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, for he hath regarded and wrought a deliverance for his people:
1.69: he hath rais'd up a powerful saviour for us, in the family of his servant David,
1.70: according to the antient promise he made by the mouth of the holy prophets,
1.71: to deliver us from our enemies, and from the power of all that hate us:
1.72: to show regard to our forefathers, in performing his holy covenant,
1.73: the oath which he made to our father Abraham, to grant us this favour,
1.74: that we should be delivered from the power of our enemies, and serve him with security,
1.75: in the sincere practice of holiness and justice, all our days.
1.76: and you, dear babe, you shall be the prophet of the most high: for you shall go before the Lord, in order to prepare his way,
1.77: by acquainting his people how they may be saved by the remission of their sins,
1.78: through the tender mercy of our God, by which the rising sun has visited us from on high,
1.79: to enlighten those, who are in darkness, and in the shadow of death, and to direct our steps into the ways of peace."
1.80: Now the child continued to grow, and greatly improv'd in sense; and was in the desarts till the time, when he was to be manifested to Israel.

2.1: At that time, Cesar Augustus published an edict, to make a register of the Roman empire.
2.2: (this register was made before Quirinus was prefect of Syria.)
2.3: all went to be registred, every one to his native city.
2.4: so Joseph departed from Nazareth in Galilee, and went into Judea to the city of David, called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and linage of David,
2.5: in order to be registred with Mary, his espoused wife, who was then big with child.
2.6: now while they were there, the time came for her to be delivered.
2.7: and being brought to bed of her first born, she swathed him, and laid him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the inn.
2.8: In that country there were shepherds lying in the open fields, taking their turns to watch the stock in the night;
2.9: when all of a sudden an angel of the Lord appear'd to them, and a heavenly light shone about them, at which they were greatly affrighted.
2.11: for the Lord Messiah your saviour is this day born, in the city of David:
2.12: and by this sign shall you know him; you will find the babe swathed, lying in a manger.
2.13: All of a sudden an army of celestial beings join'd the angel, singing praises to God, and saying,
2.14: "glory to God in the heavens, and to men on earth felicity in the divine favour."
2.15: As soon as the angels retired back to heaven, the shepherds said to one another, let us go to Bethlehem, to see the fact, of which the Lord inform'd us.
2.16: accordingly they hasted thither, and found Mary and Joseph with the babe lying in the manger.
2.17: when they had seen him, they divulged what the angel had told them concerning this child.
2.18: and all that heard of it, were surprized at what the shepherds related.
2.19: but Mary considered these things very attentively, and weigh'd every circumstance in her mind, while the shepherds return'd,
2.20: glorifying and praising God, for having heard and seen every thing exactly as the angel inform'd them.
2.21: The eighth day, when the child was to be circumcised, being come, he was named Jesus, the name, which the angel had given before his conception.
2.22: At length the time appointed by the law of Moses for the purification of women being accomplish'd, they carried the infant to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord, according as his law directs,
2.25: At that time there dwelt at Jerusalem one Simeon, an honest, religious man, one who expected the appearance of the Messiah, and was endued with the spirit of prophecy.
2.26: to him it was revealed by the holy spirit, that he should not die till he had seen the Messiah of the Lord.
2.27: by the divine direction he came into the temple, just as the parents of Jesus were bringing in the child to perform what the law required in his behalf.
2.28: then he took him up in his arms, and returned thanks to God in these words, "now,
2.29: Lord, thou wilt grant thy servant a happy death, according to thy promise.
2.30: for mine eyes have beheld the saviour,
2.31: whom thou hast provided for all mankind, a light to lighten the Gentiles,
2.32: and the glory of thy people Israel."
2.33: Joseph and the mother of Jesus were surprized to hear such things pronounc'd concerning him.
2.34: then Simeon gave them his benediction, and said to Mary his mother, "the child you now see, shall occasion many in Israel to fall and rise again; he will be the Object of calumny,
2.35: which like a dart will pierce even thro' your own soul, that thereby the sincerity of many may be revealed."
2.36: There was likewise one Anna a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aser; she was of a great age, and had liv'd in a married state but seven years ever since she was a virgin:
2.37: being then a widow of about fourscore and four years old: she was assiduously in the temple, night and day religiously employ'd in fastings and prayers:
2.38: and happening to come in just at the same time, she likewise express'd her thanks to the lord, and spoke of Jesus to all those, who expected deliverance in Jerusalem.
2.39: and when they had performed every thing required by the divine law, they returned into Galilee, to Nazareth their city.
2.40: and the child grew in stature and in all the improvements of the mind; he was stor'd with wisdom, and was the object of divine favour.
2.41: Now his parents went every year to Jerusalem at the paschal feast.
2.42: when Jesus therefore was twelve years old they went thither, as was customary at the time of that festival.
2.43: when that was expired, they returned, but the young Jesus staid behind in Jerusalem, without being miss'd either by Joseph or his Mother.
2.44: so that they went a whole day's journey, imagining he was somewhere among the company, and then they look'd for him among their relations and acquaintance; but not finding him,
2.45: they turn'd back to Jerusalem to enquire for him there.
2.46: three days after they found him in the temple, sitting near the doctors, attending to them and asking them questions.
2.47: and all that heard him were astonish'd at his understanding and answers.
2.48: when Joseph and his mother saw him, great was their surprize: and his mother said to him, son, why did you leave us thus? your father and I have been looking for you with great concern.
2.50: but they did not comprehend the meaning of that expression.
2.51: However Jesus went down with them to Nazareth, and was subject to them: and his mother kept all these things in her heart.
2.52: in the mean time Jesus increas'd in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man.

3.1: In the fifteenth year of the emperor Tiberius, when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea; Herod tetrarch of Gallilee: Philip his brother tetrarch of Iturea and Trachonitis: and Lysanias the tetrarch of Abilene:
3.2: under the pontificate of Annas and Caiaphas, JOHN, the son of Zacharias, received his divine commission in the wilderness.
3.3: in pursuance of which, he went into all the country about Jordan, exhorting all to repent and be baptized, in order to obtain the remission of their sins.
3.4: as it is written in the book of the prophecies of Esaias, "the voice of one crying in the desart, prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths clear.
3.5: every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be level'd: the crooked shall be made strait, and the rough ways shall be made smooth,
3.6: and all men shall behold the divine saviour."
3.7: he said therefore to the people that crowded to be baptized by him, ye brood of vipers, who has prompted you to flee from approaching wrath?
3.8: let your actions therefore show your repentance, and don't pretend to say within yourselves, "we have Abraham for our father:" for I tell you that God is able of these stones to raise up children to Abraham.
3.9: the ax is already laid to the root of the trees: every tree then, which does not produce good fruit, shall be hewn down, and cast into the fire.
3.10: Upon which the people asked him, what then shall we do?
3.11: he answer'd them, let him that hath two coats give one to him that hath none; and let him that has plenty of provisions act in like manner.
3.12: the Publicans likewise came to be baptized, and said to him, master, how are we to act?
3.15: As the people were in suspence, every man imagining in his own mind that John might be the Messiah;
3.16: he address'd himself to them all, saying, I indeed baptize you with water; but there is one coming, who is superiour to me, whose shoes I am unworthy to untie: he shall baptize you with the holy spirit, under the appearance of fire.
3.17: and with the fan in his hand he will thoroughly cleanse his floor, and will lay up the wheat in his grainery: but the chaff he will burn with inextinguishable fire.
3.18: many other things he delivered to the people in his exhortations.
3.19: but having reproved Herod the tetrarch upon account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip, and for all the mischiefs that Herod had done;
3.20: to compleat all the rest, Herod confin'd John in prison.
3.21: When all the people were baptizing, Jesus was likewise baptized, and whilst he was praying, the clouds opened,
3.22: and the holy spirit descended upon him in a corporeal form like a dove, and a voice came from heaven, which said, thou art my beloved son, in thee I am well pleased.
3.23: Jesus was then about thirty years of age, being, as was suppos'd, the son of Joseph,
3.24: son of Heli, son of Matthat, son of Levi, son of Melchi, son of Janna, son of Joseph,
3.25: son of Mattathias, son of Amos, son of Naum, son of Esli, son of Nagge,
3.26: son of Maath, son of Mattathias, son of Semi, son of Joseph, son of Juda, son of Joanna,
3.27: son of Rhesa, son of Zorobabel, son of Salathiel,
3.28: son of Neri, son of Melchi, son of Addi, son of Cosam, son of Elmodam, son of Er,
3.29: son of Jose, son of Eliezer, son of Jorim, son of Matthat, son of Levi, son of Simeon,
3.30: son of Juda, son of Joseph, son of Jonan, son of Eliakim,
3.31: son of Melea, son of Menan, son of Mattatha, son of Nathan, son of David,
3.32: son of Jesse, son of Obed, son of Booz, son of Salmon,
3.33: son of Naasson, son of Aminadab, son of Aram, son of Esrom, son of Phares, son of Juda,
3.34: son of Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham, son of Thara, son of Nachor, son of Saruch,
3.35: son of Ragau, son of Phalec, son of Heber, son of Sala,
3.36: son of Cainan, son of Arphaxad, son of Sem, son of Noe, son of Lamech, son of Mathusala,
3.37: son of Enoch, son of Jared, son of Maleleel,
3.38: son of Cainan, son of Enos, son of Seth, son of Adam, the son of God.

4.1: Now Jesus being full of the holy spirit, return'd from Jordan, and was led by the spirit into the desart,
4.2: being forty days tempted by the devil, without eating any thing all that while: but that time expired, he at last was seiz'd with hunger.
4.3: then the devil said to him; if you are the son of God, command this stone to become bread.
4.4: but Jesus answered him, it is written, "man shall not live by bread alone, but by every thing that God appoints."
4.5: then the devil took him to the top of a high mountain, and in an instant represented to him all the kingdoms of the world.
4.6: all this power, said he, will I give thee, and the glory of them: for they are at my disposal, and where I please, I bestow them.
4.7: if therefore you will worship me, they shall be all your own.
4.8: but Jesus answered him, avant, satan, for it is written, "thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve."
4.9: next, the devil brought him to Jerusalem, and setting him on the battlements of the temple, said to him, if you be the son of God, throw your self down from this height,
4.10: for it is written, "he shall charge his angels to watch for your preservation:
4.11: and they shall bear you up in their hands, for fear your foot should hit against a stone."
4.12: but Jesus replied, it is said, "thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God."
4.13: and when the whole temptation was ended, the devil left him for a time.
4.14: Jesus return'd by the influence of the spirit into Galilee, where his same quickly spread over all the country;
4.15: for he preach'd in their synagogues with universal applause.
4.16: being come to Nazareth, where he had been brought up; according to his custom, he went into the synagogue on the sabbath-day, and standing up to read,
4.17: they delivered to him the book of the prophet Esaias, and upon opening the book, that passage occurr'd, where it is written,
4.18: "the spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath anointed me to preach the gospel to the poor, he hath sent me to heal the broken hearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovery of sight to the blind, to set at liberty them that are bruised,
4.19: to proclaim the favourable year of the Lord."
4.20: then he closed the book, and returning it to the minister, he sat down: and as the eyes of the whole synagogue were fix'd with attention upon him,
4.21: he undertook to show them, how the passage they had heard, was actually then accomplished.
4.22: They all applauded him, and were surprized, that what he said, was delivered with so much grace, but they objected, is not this the son of Joseph?
4.23: upon which he said, no doubt you will urge me with this proverb, "physician heal thy self, what we have heard you perform'd in Capernaum, do likewise here in your own country."
4.24: but in truth, added he, no prophet was ever well received in his own country.
4.25: I assure you, though there were many widows in Israel, when the heaven had furnished no rain for three years and a half, and a great famine spread through all the land:
4.26: yet to none of them was Elias sent, except to one widow in Sarepta, a city of Sidon.
4.27: and there were many lepers in the time of Elisha the prophet: yet none of them obtain'd a cure, except Naaman the Syrian.
4.28: upon hearing this, the whole synagogue were incensed against him.
4.29: and breaking up the assembly, they drove him out of the city, to the precipice of the hill, upon which it was built, in order to throw him headlong down.
4.30: but he pass'd thro' the midst of them and went away.
4.31: At length he went to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and taught them on the sabbath-days.
4.32: and they were astonished at his doctrine, for he spoke with authority.
4.33: now there was in the synagogue a man possess'd with the spirit of an impure demon, who roar'd out, in these words, let us alone;
4.34: what business have you with us, Jesus of Nazareth? are you come to destroy us? I know who you are; the saint of God.
4.36: and they were all amazed, and said to one another, what's the meaning of this? with authority and power he commands the impure spirits, and they come out!
4.37: and his fame spread through all the neighbouring country.
4.38: When Jesus came out of the synagogue, he went to Simon's house, whose mother-in-law was seized with a violent fever, and they desired him to relieve her.
4.39: so approaching near her, he order'd the fever to leave her, and it left her, upon which she immediately arose, and waited upon them at table.
4.40: As soon as the sun was set, all sorts of diseased persons were brought before him by their friends, and he healed them all, by laying his hands upon them.
4.41: many were dispossess'd of the demons, who cried aloud, you are the Messiah, the son of God, but he rebuked them, and would not suffer them to declare, that they knew him to be the Messiah.
4.42: When it was day, he retired into a desart place, where the people searching for him, found him out, and as they earnestly press'd him not to leave them,
4.43: he said to them, I must likewise proclaim the kingdom of God in other cities; for to that end am I sent.
4.44: accordingly he went preaching in the synagogues through all Galilee.

5.1: One day, as the people press'd after him to hear his divine preaching, he came near the lake of Gennesereth,
5.2: where he saw two vessels lying near shore: but the fishermen were gone out of them, and were washing their nets.
5.3: he went therefore aboard one of the vessels, which was Simon's, and desired him to bear away a little from land, then he sat down, and preached to the people from the ship.
5.4: having finished his sermon, he said to Simon, row into deep water, and throw out your nets for a draught.
5.5: master, said Simon, we have toil'd all the night, without any prize: however, since you give the word, I will throw the net.
5.6: which being done, they enclosed such a multitude of fish, the net began to break:
5.7: so they made a signal to their partners in the other ship to come and help them, accordingly they came, and loaded both the boats so with fish that they began to sink.
5.8: at sight of this, Simon Peter fell on his knees before Jesus, and said, Lord, withdraw from such a sinful man as I:
5.9: for he, and all the company were frightned at the draught of fish they had taken:
5.11: then having brought their boats to shore, they left every thing, and followed him.
5.12: As he was going to one of the cities in that country, a man cover'd all over with leprosy happen'd to meet Jesus, and prostrating himself before him, thus address'd him, Lord, if you will, you can cure me.
5.13: then Jesus stretch'd out his hand, and touched him, saying, I will; be thou cured, and immediately the leprosy disappear'd:
5.15: in the mean time his fame spread so much the more, and a vast multitude flock'd to hear him, and to be cured of their diseases,
5.16: so that he retired into places of solitude, for the convenience of prayer.
5.17: At another time, as he was teaching, it happened that some Pharisees, and doctors of the law were sitting by, who came from the several towns of Galilee and Judea, and from Jerusalem: when the power of the Lord appear'd in their relief.
5.18: for instance, they brought a man in his bed lying sick of the palsy: and try'd to, bring him directly into his presence.
5.19: but when they found it impracticable to bring him in through the crowd, they went up the gallery to the leads, and let him down through the ceiling in his bed among the company, where Jesus was,
5.21: upon which the Scribes and Pharisees objected among themselves, saying, what a man is this to blaspheme thus? who can forgive sins but God alone?
5.22: but Jesus perceiving their reflexions, said to them, what do you mean by such insinuations?
5.23: which is easier, to say, your sins are forgiven you, or to say, rise up, and walk?
5.24: but that ye may know, that the son of man hath power to forgive sins, rise, said he, to the paralytick, 'tis I command you, take up your bed, and go home.
5.25: immediately he started up before them all, took up the bed, where he lay, and went home, glorifying God.
5.26: at this they were all seized with astonishment, and gave thanks to God, crying out with great reverence, what a wonderful instance of power have we seen this day!
5.28: immediately he rose up, left all his affairs, and became his disciple.
5.29: Levi having prepared a handsom entertainment in his own house for him, a great number of publicans, and others, were likewise at table.
5.30: but the Scribes and Pharisees of that place reproach'd his disciples, and said, why do ye eat and drink with publicans and scandalous people?
5.31: but Jesus replied, they that are in health don't want a physician: but they that are sick.
5.32: I came not to call saints, but sinners to repentance. Then they ask'd him, how comes it that John's disciples,
5.33: and likewise those of the Pharisees, are frequently fasting and praying, while yours are employed in eating and drinking?
5.34: to which he answered, would you have the bridemen fast, while the bridegroom is with them?
5.35: however, the time will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away from them, and then they will have occasions enow of fasting.
5.36: Besides, he applied this similitude to them, no man, said he, puts a piece of new cloth upon an old coat: if he does, the new will strain the old, and they will by no means suit one another.
5.37: nor will any one put new wine into old skins: if they do, the new wine will burst the skins, and wine and skins be all lost.
5.38: but new wine must be put into new skins, and both will be preserv'd.
5.39: so no-body that has been drinking old wine, will immediately call for new: for 'tis his maxim, "the old is best."

6.1: On the second-prime sabbath, as Jesus was passing through the corn-fields, his disciples happen'd to pluck the ears, and rubbing out the corn with their hands began to eat.
6.2: upon which some of the Pharisees said to them, why do you do what is not allowed to be done on the sabbath-day?
6.3: but Jesus replied, have you never read what David did, when he and his company were press'd with hunger?
6.4: how he went into the court of the tabernacle, took and eat the shew-bread, and distributed it likewise to the company, which the law allowed the priests only to eat?
6.5: the son of man, said he, may dispense even with the sabbath.
6.6: On another sabbath-day it happen'd, that he went into the synagogue to preach, where a man was present, who had the palsy in his right hand.
6.7: now the Scribes and Pharisees were upon the watch to see if he would work a cure upon the sabbath-day, and so have matter of accusation against him.
6.8: but as he knew their thoughts, he said to the man, whose hand was paralytic, rise up, and stand there in the middle, and he arose, and stood before him.
6.9: then said Jesus to them, I will ask you one question, which is the most allowable on the sabbath-day, to do good, or to neglect it? to save a man's life, or to let him perish?
6.10: then casting his eyes round the company, he said to the man, stretch out your hand, and he did so: and that hand was as sound as the other.
6.11: whereupon they fell into a rage, and consulted together, what measures to take against Jesus.
6.12: About that time, Jesus retired to a mountain to pray, and spent the whole night in an oratory.
6.13: when it was day, he called his disciples: and of them he chose twelve, whom he stiled missionarys: Simon,
6.14: (to whom he gave the name of Peter) and Andrew his brother, James and John, Philip and Bartholomew,
6.15: Matthew and Thomas, James the son of Alpheus, and Simon surnamed the Zelot,
6.16: Jude the brother of James, and Judas Iscariot, who prov'd the traitor.
6.17: At length he came down the hill with them, and stayed with the rest of his disciples in the plain, where a great multitude of people from all Judea, from Jerusalem, and the maritime country of Tyre and Sidon, came to hear him, and to have their diseases cured.
6.18: many that were tormented by evil spirits came likewise, and were cured.
6.19: so that all the people strove to touch him: for a divine virtue flowed from him, which healed them all.
6.21: blessed are ye that hunger now: for ye shall be satisfied, blessed are ye that weep now: for ye shall find matter of mirth.
6.22: blessed are you, when men shall hate you, discard you, reproach you, and treat you as infamous, for your attachment to the son of man.
6.23: then you may triumph with joy; secure of being greatly rewarded in heaven: for such was the treatment the prophets received from their forefathers.
6.25: wo unto you that are full: for you shall be in want, wo unto you that indulge in present pleasure: for mourning and sorrow shall attend you.
6.26: wo unto you when the generality of men shall applaud you: for so did their forefathers behave to the false prophets.
6.28: and pray for those, who maliciously abuse you.
6.29: if any one strike you on one cheek, present to him the other likewise: or if any one seize your cloak, surrender your coat also.
6.30: give to all that ask: and if a man takes away your goods, don't demand them again.
6.31: behave to others in the same manner, as you desire they would behave to you.
6.32: for if you only love those, who love you, where's the obligation? the very heathen return love for love.
6.33: if you return one kind office by another, where's the obligation? the heathen themselves do as much.
6.34: if you lend with the expectation of gaining by it, where's the obligation? for the heathen lend to one another, for the prospect of an equivalent.
6.35: but as for you, love your enemies, do good, and lend without expecting any advantage from it: so shall your reward be great, in acting like the children of the most high: for he is kind to the most ungrateful wretches.
6.36: be ye therefore merciful, as your father is merciful.
6.38: give and you shall receive: they shall pour into your lap good measure, well pressed, heap'd up, and running over, for in the measure you deal with others, you shall be dealt with yourselves.
6.40: The disciple is not above his master: but every one that is perfect shall be as his master.
6.41: How comes it, that you can see the mote in your brother's eye, and not see the beam that is in your own eye?
6.44: for every tree is known by its fruit: it is not on thorns that men gather figs, nor do they gather grapes on a bramble bush.
6.45: a good man out of the good treasure of his heart produces what is good: and an evil man out of the evil treasure of his heart produces what is evil: for 'tis from the abundance of the heart, that the mouth speaketh.
6.46: Why do you call me Lord, Lord, and do not observe what I say?
6.47: I will show you, who that man is like, who comes to me, and practises what I prescribe.
6.48: he is like a man who in building a house, digg'd deep, and laid the foundation on a rock: an inundation came, the current beat impetuously upon that house, but could not shake it: for it was founded upon a rock.
6.49: but he that does not practise what he hears, is like a man who built his house upon the loose earth without any foundation: the current beat impetuously against it: in the instant down it fell, and great were its ruins.

7.1: When he had finished this discourse to the populous audience, he entred into Capernaum,
7.2: where a certain centurion had a servant whom he greatly valued, lying sick and ready to die.
7.3: this centurion having heard of Jesus's fame, sent several elders of the Jews to intreat him to come, and recover his servant.
7.4: accordingly they came to Jesus and earnestly pressed him, saying, he very well deserves you should do him this favour; for he loves our nation,
7.5: and hath built us a synagogue at his own charge.
7.6: then Jesus went with him, and when he was advanced near the house, the centurion sent some of his friends to him, saying, "Lord, don't give yourself the trouble of coming, I don't deserve you should honour my house with your presence.
7.7: nor did I think myself worthy to attend you: speak but the word, and my servant shall be cured.
7.9: when Jesus heard this, he admired the man, and turning about, he said to the people, that followed him, I assure you, I have not met with such an instance of faith even among the Jews themselves.
7.10: and they that were sent, being return'd to the house, they found the servant, who had been sick, in good health.
7.11: The day following, he went into a city called Nain, accompanied by many of his disciples, and a great crowd of people.
7.12: as he drew near the gate of the city, there was a dead man just then carrying out to be buried, who was his mother's only son, and she a widow: and many people of the town came with her.
7.14: then advancing, he touch'd the bier, and the bearers standing still, he said, young man, arise, I command you.
7.15: and the deceased sat up, and began to speak, and Jesus delivered him to his mother.
7.17: and his fame spread over all Judea and the neighbouring countrys.
7.18: John was soon inform'd of these transactions by his disciples,
7.21: at that very time, he cured several of their diseases and distempers, dispossessing evil spirits, and restoring sight to many that were blind.
7.22: then he gave them this answer, go, and tell John what you have seen, and heard: that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are healed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, the gospel is proclaim'd to the poor.
7.23: and blessed is he, who does not make me the occasion of his fall.
7.24: When the messengers of John were departed, he address'd himself to the people, and said with relation to John, what did you go to see in the desart? a reed shaken with the wind?
7.25: or did you go to see a man richly apparelled? for magnificent dress and splendid living, you must look into the courts of princes.
7.26: what then did you go to see? a prophet? yes, I say it, and more than a prophet.
7.27: he it is, of whom it is written, "behold, I send my messenger before you, who shall prepare the way for you."
7.28: I declare unto you, among the whole race of mankind, there is not a prophet, who is superiour to John the Baptist: yet he that is most inferiour in the kingdom of the Messiah, is greater than he.
7.29: all the people, even the publicans, upon hearing him, gave glory to God, by receiving the baptism of John;
7.30: but the Pharisees and the doctors of the law rejected the divine offers made to them, refusing to be baptized by John.
7.31: To what therefore shall I compare the men of this generation? who are they like?
7.32: they are like children playing together in the street, who cry, we have play'd to you on the flute, but you have not danced: we have sung mournful dittys, but you have not lamented.
7.33: for John the Baptist, when he came, abstain'd from bread and wine; yet you say, he is possess'd with a demon.
7.34: the son of man appears indifferent to any kind of meat or drink: yet you say, he is a glutton and a tipler, a friend of publicans and loose people.
7.35: "but wisdom is justified by all her different followers."
7.36: Jesus being invited to dinner at a certain Pharisee's house, he went home with him, and sat down to table.
7.37: when a woman of that city, one that had led a loose life, knowing that Jesus was at table in the Pharisee's house, came in with a vial of odoriferous liquor,
7.38: and stood behind at his feet weeping, bath'd them with her tears, wiped them with her hair, kissed his feet, and poured the perfume upon them.
7.39: which the Pharisee, who had invited him, observing, he thus argued with himself, if this man were a prophet, he could not but know that the woman, who is so busy with him, is a person of a loose character.
7.40: in answer to his doubts, Jesus said, Simon, I have something to say to you, master, said he, lets hear it.
7.42: having not wherewithal to pay it, he freely discharged them both of the debt, tell me now, which of the two will love him most?
7.43: I think, said Simon, he that had the greatest debt remitted to him, you are in the right, said Jesus.
7.45: you did not salute me, but this woman, since she came in, has been continually kissing my feet.
7.46: you did not bestow any oil upon my head; but she has poured her rich perfume upon my feet.
7.47: wherefore, I tell you, her sins, which are numerous, are forgiven; and that is the reason of all this love: but his love is less, to whom less is forgiven.
7.48: then he said to her, your sins are forgiven.
7.49: but they who sat at table with him, began to ask one another, who is this, that pretends even to forgive sins?
7.50: but he said to the woman, your faith hath saved you: go in peace.

8.1: After this Jesus went about, preaching to every city and village, proclaiming the reign of the Messias, attended by his twelve apostles,
8.2: and several women, who had been delivered from evil spirits and cured of their diseases: particularly Mary Magdalene, who had been dispossess'd of seven demons:
8.3: Joanna the wife of Chuza Herod's high-steward: Susanna, and several others, who assisted him with their fortunes.
8.4: A vast number of people being assembled, and crowding to him from all quarters, he thus address'd himself to them by way of parable.
8.6: some fell upon very stony ground, which no sooner sprung up, but it wither'd away, for want of moisture:
8.7: some fell among thorns; but the thorns over-grew it, and starv'd it.
8.8: but some of the corn fell into good soil, and grew up, yielding a hundred grains for one, then raising his voice he concluded with these words, he that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
8.9: But his disciples having ask'd him the meaning of this parable;
8.10: he answered, the secret circumstances of the divine dispensation may be clearly revealed to you, but to others only in parables, so that they don't observe what they see, nor comprehend what they hear.
8.11: now the meaning of the parable is this: the seed sown signifies the word of God.
8.12: by the beaten road is meant, they who only hear: the word, by the lurking wiles of the devil, being hinder'd from taking root in their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved.
8.13: by the stony ground is understood such persons as receive indeed the doctrines they hear, with joy: but for want of resolution, believe only occasionally, and desert when the trial comes.
8.14: the ground over-run with thorns denotes such as have embraced the doctrine, but are so immerst in the business, enjoyments, and pleasures of life, as not to improve it to any real advantage.
8.15: but by the good ground is meant such persons as have received the doctrine with simplicity and sincerity, abide by it, and practise it with perseverance.
8.16: Now, no one lights a lamp to hide it under a vessel, or under a bed: but sets it on a stand, to give light to all the company.
8.17: whatever is now obscure, shall hereafter be made clear; whatever is now conceal'd, shall then be publickly known.
8.18: improve therefore what you hear: for he that improves what he has, shall have more; but he that does not, shall lose even that, which he thinks he possesses.
8.19: One day the mother of Jesus, and his brethren came to speak with him, but could not get near by reason of the crowd.
8.20: so some of the company said to him, your mother and brethren are waiting without, desiring to see you.
8.21: but he answered them, my mother and brethren are these, who attend to the word of God, and practise it.
8.22: The same day Jesus went on board a vessel with his disciples, and said to them, let us pass over to the other side of the lake: and so they put off to sea.
8.23: while they were rowing, Jesus fell asleep: when there blew such a storm of wind upon the lake, as fill'd the boat with water, and endanger'd their lives.
8.24: then they came to wake him, crying, master, master, we are sinking, then he rose up, and rebuked the wind, and the waves: and both subside to a calm.
8.25: but to his disciples he said, where is your faith? while they, seiz'd with fear and admiration, said to one another, who can this man be, that he commands even the winds, and the waves, and they obey?
8.26: Then they arrived at the country of the Gadarenes, which lies opposite to Galilee.
8.27: when he was landed, there met him a man, who belong'd to the city Gadara, and had been for a long time possessed by demons, he did not wear any cloaths, nor dwell in any house, but among the tombs.
8.28: upon seeing Jesus, he set up a great cry, fell down before him, and roar'd out, what business have you with me, Jesus son of the most high God? I beseech you torment me not.
8.29: for he had commanded the impure spirit to quit the man, he had so long possessed: who, tho' bound in chains, and fastned with fetters, broke thro' all restraints, and was hurry'd by the demon into the desarts.
8.30: upon Jesus's saying to him, what is your name? he answer'd, legion, (for many demons were enter'd into him.)
8.31: and they entreated him not to condemn them to the abyss.
8.32: but there being a numerous herd of swine feeding on the mountain, they desired he would permit them to enter into the swine, which he granted.
8.33: accordingly the demons quitted the man, and enter'd into the swine: immediately the herd ran headlong down a precipice into the lake, and were drowned.
8.34: the keepers seeing this, ran about and spread it, both in town,
8.35: and country, whence numbers went to see the fact: being come to Jesus, they found the man, who had been dispossess'd of the demons, sitting at Jesus's feet, cloathed, and in his right senses: at which they were much surpriz'd,
8.36: being inform'd by those that were present, by what means the demoniac had been cured.
8.37: then the Gadarenes of the adjacent parts unanimously desired him to leave their country: for they were greatly allarm'd, so he embark'd to cross over the lake.
8.38: now the man, who had been dispossess'd, begg'd to take him with him, but Jesus dismissed him,
8.39: saying, go home, and relate, what great things God hath done for you, whereupon he departed, and published through all the city, what a wonderful deliverance Jesus had wrought for him.
8.40: Jesus upon his return was received by a great number of people, who expected him.
8.41: Some time after, a person nam'd Jairus, a ruler of the synagogue, came to Jesus, and upon his knees desired him to come to his house:
8.42: for he had an only daughter, about twelve years of age, who lay a dying, as he was on the way, the crowd press'd after him,
8.43: and among the rest a woman, who had been troubled with an hemorrhage twelve years, having consum'd her whole fortune upon physicians, who could none of them cure her; she getting behind him,
8.44: touched the border of his garment: and immediately her indisposition was removed.
8.45: upon which Jesus said, who was it that touch'd me? they being all at a loss, what to answer, at length Peter, and the others with him, said, master, the crowd are squeezing and pressing about you, and yet you cry, "who touch'd me?"
8.46: but Jesus said, somebody has touched me: for I know what influence my power has had.
8.47: then the woman finding she could not conceal herself, came trembling, and kneeling down before him, confess'd before all the people, why she had touch'd him, and how she was instantly cured.
8.49: While he was speaking, somebody came from the ruler of the synagogue's house, who said to him, your daughter is dead; 'tis in vain to importune the master any farther.
8.51: being come to the house, he suffer'd nobody to go into the room with him, except Peter, John and James, and the young woman's father and mother.
8.52: the company there were all in tears lamenting for her: but he said don't weep; she is not dead, but asleep.
8.53: upon which, they knowing she was really dead, treated him with derision.
8.55: immediately she came to life, and rose up: and he order'd, that something should be given her to eat.
8.56: and her parents were seized with astonishment: but he charg'd them not to let the fact be known to any one.

9.1: After this he assembled the twelve apostles, and gave them authority over all sorts of demons, and the power of curing all diseases:
9.2: then sent them to proclaim the reign of the Messiah, and to heal the sick.
9.3: and he said to them make no provision for your journey: take neither staff, nor sack, nor bread, nor money; and but one coat for each.
9.4: when you are lodg'd in any house, there stay, till you leave the place.
9.5: if any refuse to entertain you, when you leave that city, shake off the dust from your feet, as a sign of their being abandon'd.
9.6: accordingly they departed, and travell'd thro' the towns, preaching the gospel, and performing cures every where.
9.7: Now Herod the tetrarch was inform'd of all his transactions: and was perplex'd at the relation of some, that John was risen from the dead: whilst others said, Elias appear'd:
9.8: and others, that one of the old prophets was come to life again.
9.9: but Herod said, John was beheaded by my order, who then can this be, who, they say, performs such strange things? and he desired to have a sight of Jesus.
9.10: The Apostles, upon their return to Jesus, acquainted him with what they had done, and taking them with him, he retired into a desart place over-against the city of Bethsaida:
9.11: where the people, who were inform'd of it, followed him: which he did not discountenance, but explained to them the reign of the Messiah, and relieved those, who wanted to be cured.
9.12: As the day began to decline, the twelve came to him, and said, dismiss the multitude, that they may go to the nearest towns and villages for lodging and provisions: for here we are in a desart place.
9.13: and he said to them, do you yourselves give them something to eat, they replied, we can furnish only five loaves and two fishes, unless we go and buy provisions for all this people:
9.14: for they were about five thousand, but Jesus said to his disciples, make them sit down by fifties in a company.
9.15: accordingly they ranged them, and made them all sit down.
9.16: then he took the five loaves, and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he ask'd blessing: then divided them, and gave them to his disciples to be distributed among the people:
9.17: and tho' they all eat sufficiently, there was a surplusage of twelve baskets full of fragments carried away.
9.18: One day having retired alone to prayer, he came to his disciples, and ask'd them, saying, whom do the people judge me to be?
9.19: they answered, some say you are John the Baptist: others, Elias: and others, that you are one of the old prophets appearing again.
9.21: however, Jesus strictly charged them not to say so much to any body; adding,
9.22: the son of man must suffer many indignities: be rejected by the rulers, the chief priests, and Scribes: be put to death: and the third day be raised again.
9.23: Then he said to the whole company, if any one will be my follower, let him renounce himself, take up his cross daily, and follow me.
9.24: for whoever would save his life, shall lose it: and he that would lose his life, out of love to me, shall save it.
9.25: what advantage is it for a man to have gain'd the whole world, if he himself runs into utter loss and ruin?
9.26: for whoever shall be ashamed of me, and of my doctrine, of him shall the son of man be ashamed, when he shall come in his own glory, and in the glory of his father, and of the holy angels.
9.27: I declare unto you, there are some here present, who shall not die, till they see the Messiah reign.
9.28: About eight days after this discourse, he took with him Peter, John, and James, and went up a mountain to pray.
9.29: as he was praying, the appearance of his countenance was quite chang'd, and his raiment was of a splendid white:
9.30: two persons of a glorious form were seen talking with him; they were Moses, and Elias,
9.31: who discours'd about the exit, he was to make at Jerusalem;
9.32: while Peter, and the others with him, were overwhelm'd with sleep: but when they wak'd, they observed his glory, and the two persons present with him,
9.33: who were just departing from him, when Peter said to Jesus, master, it is best for us to stay here: let us build three apartments, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elias: not knowing well what he said.
9.34: while he was speaking, there came a cloud and over-shadowed them, who were seized with fear, at their vanishing in the cloud,
