9.35: from whence a voice issued out, saying, "this is my beloved son, obey him."
9.36: and before the sound was gone, Jesus was left alone: this they kept secret, and for some time did not acquaint any one in the least with what they had seen.
9.37: The next day, when they were come down from the mountain, a multitude of people happen'd to meet him:
9.38: when one of the company cry'd out, master, I beseech you, cast your eyes upon my son, for he is my only child:
9.39: he is frequently seized by a spirit, which makes him immediately roar, then throws him into convulsions with foaming, and never leaves him, but with difficulty and bruises.
9.40: I desired your disciples to cast out this spirit; but they were not able.
9.41: then said Jesus, O incredulous, and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you, and suffer you? bring hither your son.
9.42: as the child was advancing, the demon threw him down, into convulsions: but Jesus rebuked the impure spirit, cured the child, and delivered him to his father.
9.43: and all the people were astonished at such an instance of divine power: and as they were admiring whatever Jesus did, he said to his disciples,
9.44: give attention to what I now say, namely, that the son of man is to be delivered into the hands of men.
9.45: but they did not comprehend that expression: it was as a riddle, which they could not understand, and they were afraid to desire him to explain the meaning of that expression.
9.46: At length they enter'd into a debate, which of them should be the greatest.
9.47: but Jesus perceiving what they thought, took a child and set him before him: then said to them,
9.48: whoever receives such a child in my name, receives me: and he that receives me, receives him that sent me, for he that is least among you all, he shall be greatest.
9.49: Then said John to Jesus, master, we saw one casting out demons in your name, and we oppos'd it, because he does not follow you with us.
9.51: Now the time of his assumption drawing nigh, he was fix'd in his resolution to go to Jerusalem:
9.52: and he sent messengers before, who went to a town of the Samaritans, to prepare a lodging for him.
9.53: but they would not entertain him, because he appear'd to them, as if he was going to Jerusalem.
9.54: his disciples James and John observing this, said, Lord, shall we command fire to descend from heaven, as Elias did, in order to consume them?
9.55: but Jesus turn'd, and rebuked them, saying, you don't know by what spirit you are moved.
9.56: for the son of man is not come to destroy men's lives, but to save them, and they went to another village.
9.57: At another time, as they were walking in the road, a man said to him, I will be your follower, wherever you go.
9.60: Jesus said to him, let the dead bury their dead; but do you go and preach the kingdom of God.
9.61: another likewise said, I will be your follower; but let me first go home, and settle the affairs of my family.
9.62: Jesus answered him, whoever puts his hand to the plough, and looks back, is not fit to be employ'd in the kingdom of God.

10.1: After this the Lord nominated seventy disciples more, and sent them before by two and two, into all the cities, and towns, where he himself design'd to go.
10.2: and he said to them, the harvest indeed is great, but the labourers are few: intreat therefore the Lord of the harvest to send forth labourers into his harvest.
10.3: go then: I send you as lambs among wolves.
10.4: carry neither purse, nor bag, nor shoes; neither salute any man by the way.
10.5: at your entrance into any house, first say, prosperity be to this family.
10.6: if any be there, who deserve your benediction, it shall have its effect upon them; otherwise, it shall redound to your own advantage.
10.7: continue in the same house, and eat and drink whatever it affords: for a labourer deserves his wages: therefore don't shift from family to family.
10.8: when you come to any city, where they receive you, eat without scruple, whatever food is set before you,
10.9: and heal the sick you find there, tell the inhabitants the kingdom of God is drawing nigh unto them.
10.10: but when you enter into any city, and they refuse to entertain you, go through the streets,
10.11: and cry, "we shake off the dust, that sticks to our feet, against you: but take notice, the kingdom of God has been near you."
10.12: I declare unto you, that the people of Sodom shall be treated with less severity in the day of judgment, than that city.
10.13: wo unto thee Chorazin; wo unto thee Bethsaida: for if the miracles, which have been wrought among you, had been wrought in Tyre and Sidon, they would long since have lain repenting in sackcloth and ashes.
10.14: therefore Tyre and Sidon shall be treated with less severity in the day of judgment, than you.
10.15: and thou, Capernaum, which art exalted to the sky, shall be plung'd into an abyss.
10.16: he that adheres to you, adheres to me; he that rejects you, rejects me: and he that rejects me, rejecteth him that sent me.
10.17: At length the seventy return'd with great joy, saying, Lord, even the demons have been made subject to us by virtue of your name.
10.18: upon which he said to them, I beheld satan falling, like lightning, from heaven.
10.19: I have authoriz'd you to trample upon serpents and scorpions, and triumph over all the power of the enemy; so that nothing shall be capable of doing you any mischief.
10.20: however, let not this be the matter of your rejoicing, that the spirits are subject to you: but rejoice, that you have a title to the joys of heaven.
10.21: At that very time Jesus fell into a divine transport, and said, "I magnify thee, O father, the Lord of heaven and earth, for having conceal'd these things from the artful and the crafty, whilst thou hast reveal'd them to the unskilful, justly, O father, hast thou thus dispens'd thy favour."
10.24: for I assure you, that many prophets and princes have desired to see what you now behold, but they never saw it; and to hear what you have heard, which they never did.
10.25: Then a doctor of the law stood up to try him, saying, master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?
10.26: to whom he answered, how does the law run in that case? what do you find?
10.27: he replied, 'tis thus, "thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, with all thy soul, with all thy strength, and with all thy understanding; and thy neighbour as thy self."
10.31: a certain priest happen'd to be travelling that way, who look'd upon him, and then pass'd on.
10.32: a Levite too came to the same place, gave him a look, and pass'd on.
10.33: but a certain Samaritan being on the road, came where he was, and when he saw him, he took compassion on him,
10.34: went up to him, dress'd his wounds by applying oil and wine, then set him upon his own mule, and brought him to an inn, where he took care of him.
10.35: upon his departure the next day, he took out two denarii, and gave them to the master of the house, take care of him, said he, and I will repay you all the charges you are at, upon my return.
10.36: which now of the three do you think was neighbour to the man that was robb'd.
10.37: he, reply'd the doctor, who took pity on him, then said Jesus to him, go then, and imitate his example.
10.38: Another time, as they were on a journey, Jesus enter'd into a village, where a woman, named Martha, entertain'd him at her house.
10.39: now she had a sister, named Mary, who placed herself at the feet of Jesus, to attend to his discourse.
10.40: but Martha perplex'd with the hurry of her affairs, came to him, and said, Lord, don't you observe my sister has left me to serve all alone: direct her therefore to give me some assistance.
10.41: but Jesus replied to her, Martha, Martha, you trouble yourself about a world of cares:
10.42: but the best and the most necessary concern is, what Mary has pitch'd upon, of which she shall never be deprived.

11.1: One day Jesus had been praying in a certain place, and as soon as he had done, one of his disciples said to him, instruct us about prayer, as John the baptist instructed his disciples.
11.3: give us every day our portion of bread.
11.4: and forgive us our sins: since we forgive every one that has offended us, and leave us not under temptation, but deliver us from the evil one."
11.6: for a friend of mine, a traveller, is come to my house, and I have nothing to entertain him with.
11.8: I tell you, tho' he will not rise, to supply him, out of friendship: yet out of regard to his importunity, he will rise, and lend him whatever he has occasion for.
11.9: I tell you likewise, ask, and it shall be given: seek, and ye shall find: knock, and the door shall be opened.
11.10: for every one that asketh, receives: he that seeketh, finds: and he that knocks has admittance.
11.11: what father among you would give his son a stone, when he asketh for bread? or if for a fish, instead of a fish would he give him a serpent?
11.12: or instead of an egg will he offer him a scorpion?
11.13: if ye then, wicked as ye are, know how to give what is proper to your children: how much more shall your heavenly father give the holy spirit to them that ask him?
11.14: At another time Jesus was casting out a demon, that was dumb: and as soon as the demon was gone out, the dumb man spoke: and the people wondred.
11.15: but some of them said, he casteth out demons by Beelzebub the prince of the demons.
11.16: others, to try him, desir'd he would show some miraculous sign in the heaven.
11.18: so if satan be divided against himself, how can his kingdom subsist?
11.19: for you assert, that I cast out demons by Beelzebub, but if I cast out demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your sons cast them out? wherefore they shall be your judges.
11.20: but if I cast out demons by the finger of God, it follows, that the reign of the Messiah is now begun among you.
11.21: when a man that is stout and well arm'd guards his palace, his possessions are safe.
11.22: but if a stronger than he should assault, and overcome him, he will strip him of all his furniture on which he relyed, and divide the plunder.
11.23: He that does not join with me, is against me: and he that is not active for me, is a deserter.
11.24: When the impure spirit is gone out of a man, he wanders about the wilds in quest of some repose: but finding none, I will return, says he, to the abode I have quitted.
11.25: and at his return he findeth it swept and garnished.
11.26: then he goes and takes with him seven other spirits more wicked than himself: they all enter in and dwell there, and the last state of that man becomes worse than the first.
11.29: and as the crowd grew more numerous, he thus began, this is a degenerate race of men: they demand a miracle: but no miracle shall be exhibited, but such as happen'd in the person of Jonas the prophet.
11.30: for as the case of Jonas was a miraculous instance to the Ninevites, so shall the son of man be to this generation.
11.31: the queen of the south shall rise up in the day of judgment against this generation, and condemn it: for she came from the remote parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; but now, a greater than Solomon is here.
11.32: the people of Nineve shall rise up in the day of Judgment, and shall condemn it: for they repented at the preaching of Jonas; but now, a greater than Jonas is here.
11.33: However, when a man has once lighted his lamp, he does not hide it in a by-place, or under a bushel; but sets it on a stand, that all who come in may have light.
11.34: the eye is the light of the body: if therefore your eye be clear, every member of your body will have the benefit of the light: but if it be spoil'd, they must all rest in darkness.
11.35: take care therefore, that the light which is in thee do not become darkness.
11.36: for if thy whole body be enlightned, and no part dark, your whole conduct will be regulated, just as the light of a lamp directs all your motions.
11.37: While he was speaking, a Pharisee invited him to dine his house, where he went, and sat down at table.
11.38: but the Pharisee was surprized to see that he did not wash before dinner.
11.39: upon which the Lord said to him, you Pharisees won't leave any filth upon the outside of a cup or a platter: while your consciences are abandon'd to rapine, and sensuality.
11.40: do you stupidly imagine that he, who made the outward man, did not make the inward too?
11.41: be but charitable to the utmost of your ability, and every thing will be pure to you.
11.43: wo unto you Pharisees, for you affect to have the first rank in the synagogue, and to be complimented in publick places.
11.44: wo unto you: for you resemble subterraneous monuments, which men walk over, without perceiving them.
11.45: Then a doctor of the law objected to him, saying, master, your discourse is an insult upon us also.
11.46: but Jesus said, wo unto you likewise, doctors of the law; for you load men with insupportable burthens, the least part of which you will not yourselves bear:
11.47: wo unto you, for you rebuild the sepulchres of those prophets, whom your fathers put to death:
11.48: they were guilty of slaughter, and you raise monuments to their memory.
11.49: agreeably to this, in the Wisdom of God 'tis said, "I will send them prophets and apostles: some they will kill, and others they will persecute:
11.50: " so that the blood of all the prophets, which has been shed since the creation of the world, may be required of this generation,
11.51: from the blood of Abel to that of Zacharias, who perished between the altar and the temple: yes, I assure you, this generation shall be responsible for it all.
11.52: wo unto you, doctors of the law; for after having taken the key of knowledge, you remain still in the dark, and hinder others, who desire to have light.
11.53: As he was pursuing his discourse, the Scribes and Pharisees passionately urg'd him with many captious questions, in order to ensnare him,
11.54: and draw something from his own mouth, that might be brought as evidence against him.

12.2: for there is nothing conceal'd, which shall not be disclos'd; nothing secret, which shall not be made publick.
12.3: whatever you have utter'd in the dark, shall be brought to light: and what you have whisper'd in a closet, shall be proclaim'd upon the house top.
12.4: As for you, my friends, be not afraid of those, who can kill the body, and after that can effect nothing more.
12.5: but I will inform you whom you should fear: fear him, who after he has kill'd, has power to precipitate into hell; yes, I advise you, fear him.
12.6: are not five sparrows sold for two pence? however the divine providence extends to each of them.
12.7: nay, the very hairs of your head can't fall without being number'd: be not then afraid; there is no comparison between you and sparrows.
12.9: but whoever shall renounce me before men, he shall be renounc'd before the angels of God.
12.10: and whoever shall cast a reflection upon the son of man, it shall be forgiven him; but as for him, that shall blaspheme the holy spirit, it shall not be forgiven.
12.11: when you are brought into the synagogues, and before magistrates and rulers, be not sollicitous what to say in your own defence;
12.12: for the holy spirit shall instruct you on the very occasion, what is proper to be said.
12.13: Then one of the company said to him, order my brother to give me my share of our inheritance.
12.14: but Jesus answer'd him, who made me a judge, or an arbitrator between you?
12.15: then he said to them, take care to be clear of all avarice: for the enjoyment of life does not depend upon the having large possessions.
12.16: to which purpose he propos'd to them this parable: a rich man had some land that was very fruitful.
12.17: and thus he reason'd with himself, what shall I do for want of room to store up my crop?
12.18: this will I do, said he, I will pull down my barns, and build greater: and there I will bestow all my rich product.
12.19: then I will say to my soul, soul, you have many enjoyments in reserve for a number of years; take your ease, eat, drink, and be merry.
12.21: such is he, who heaps up his treasure here, and makes no provision for another world.
12.22: Wherefore (said he to his disciples,) be not sollicitous for your life, what ye shall eat; nor for the body, what ye shall put on.
12.23: the life is more than meat, and the body is more than raiment.
12.24: consider the ravens: for they neither sow nor reap: nor have cellar or barn: are not you of much greater value than the fowls?
12.25: but which of you, with all his disquietude, can add one moment to the period of his life?
12.26: if then you can't effect so small a matter, why are you disquieted about a much longer time?
12.28: now if God thus cloaths the flowers, which exist to-day in the field, and to-morrow are thrown into the oven: how much more will he cloath you, O distrustful men?
12.29: therefore don't be concern'd about what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; but lay aside all your anxiety:
12.30: for it is enough that the Gentiles are so concern'd about these things: as for you, your father is acquainted with all your wants.
12.33: sell your possessions and give alms, lay up for yourselves a stock not subject to decay, a treasure in the heavens that will never fail, where no thief can approach, nor moth can spoil.
12.34: for where your treasure is, there likewise will your affections be.
12.36: imitate those servants who stand waiting for their master's return from the wedding, to let him in as soon as he comes to the door.
12.37: happy those servants, whom the master at his arrival shall find thus watching: I assure you, he shall gird himself, and make them sit at table, and will come to serve them.
12.38: happy are the servants he finds in such a state, whether it be at the second or at the third watch of the night, when he comes.
12.39: if the master of a house knew at what hour the thief would come, no doubt he would be on his guard, and not suffer him to break into his house.
12.40: be ye therefore likewise prepar'd; for the son of man will come, when you least expect him.
12.41: then Peter said to him, Lord, do you apply this similitude to us, or to all in general?
12.42: Jesus answered, if there be a faithful prudent steward, appointed by his master to give his domesticks their stated allowance; happy is such a servant,
12.43: whom his master at his return shall find so employ'd.
12.44: I assure you, he will intrust him with the management of his whole estate.
12.45: but if the servant should say within himself, my master delays his return; and fall a beating his fellow-servants, indulging himself in eating and drinking to excess.
12.46: his master will return on a day he does not expect him, and a an hour he is ignorant of; he will separate him from the rest, and give him a treatment answerable to his infidelity.
12.47: but the servant, who knows his master's will, and prepares not himself, nor executes his orders, shall receive many stripes.
12.48: whereas he that does not know it, and does things worthy of chastisement, shall receive fewer stripes, for to whom much is given, of him shall much be required, and the more a man has been trusted, the greater will be the demand.
12.49: I am come to purify the earth with fire, and how do I wish it were already kindled?
12.50: the baptism, which I am to undergo, how do I long till it be accomplished?
12.51: do you imagine that my coming will produce peace on the earth? I tell you, no; but rather division.
12.52: for the future, if there are five persons in one family, they will be divided; three against two, and two against three.
12.53: the father will be at variance with his son, and the son with the father: the mother with the daughter, and the daughter with the mother: the mother-in-law with the daughter-in-law, and the daughter-in-law with the mother-in-law.
12.54: Then he said to the people, when you see a cloud rise out of the west, you say, it is just going to rain; and so it happens.
12.55: and when the south wind blows, you say, there will be heat; and so it happens.
12.56: Hypocrites, you can judge of the phoenomena of the earth, and of the sky, but why can't you discern the present times?
12.57: why can't you judge what is proper to be done in your own affairs.
12.58: When you are going with your adversary before the magistrate, pay the interest, and get your discharge, while you are on the way; for fear he should bring you before the judge, and the judge deliver you to the officer, and the officer throw you into jail.
12.59: I tell you, you will not get out, till you have paid to the last farthing.

13.1: At the same time, there were some present, who gave Jesus an account of the Galileans, whose blood Pilate had mingled with their sacrifices.
13.3: I tell you, no: and except you repent, you shall all likewise perish.
13.4: or those eighteen, upon whom the tower of Siloam fell, and slew them, do you think they were greater criminals than the other inhabitants of Jerusalem?
13.5: I tell you, no: and except you repent, you shall all likewise perish.
13.9: perhaps it may bear fruit: if not, you may after that hew it down.
13.10: As he was teaching in a synagogue on the sabbath-day, a woman was present,
13.11: who had been kept infirm by a spirit eighteen years: and stooped in such a manner, she was not able to hold up her head strait.
13.12: Jesus seeing her, called her to him, and said, woman you are freed from your disorder.
13.13: then he laid his hands upon her: and instantly she stood upright, and glorified God.
13.14: but the ruler of the synagogue being highly incensed at Jesus's healing on the sabbath-day, said to the people, there are six days for work, you should come therefore for cure on those days, and not on the sabbath.
13.15: to which Jesus replied, thou hypocrite, who is there among you that scruples to untie his ox or his ass, and lead him from the stall to water on the sabbath-day?
13.16: and must not this daughter of Abraham, whom satan has held bound these eighteen years, be disengag'd from this bond, on a sabbath-day?
13.17: at which all his adversaries were confounded, but the people were highly pleased, at the glorious actions which he perform'd.
13.18: Then he said, what does the kingdom of God resemble? to what shall I compare it?
13.19: it is like a grain of mustard-seed, which a man took, and sowed in his garden: it grew, and became so large, that the birds of the air built their nests in its boughs.
13.20: again he said, to what shall I compare the kingdom of God?
13.21: it is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leaven'd.
13.22: Afterwards he pass'd thro' several citys and villages, where he taught the people, on his journey to Jerusalem.
13.23: and somebody ask'd him, Lord, will there be but few people saved? to which he answered,
13.24: strive to enter in at the narrow gate: for I declare unto you, that many shall try to get in, and shall not be able.
13.25: when once the master of the family is enter'd in, and has fastned the door, you will stand without beating at the door, and cry, Lord, Lord, let us in: but he will answer, you are strangers to me.
13.26: then you will say, we have eat, and drank with you, and you have taught in our streets.
13.27: but he will answer, I tell you, you are strangers to me: depart from me, ye workers of iniquity.
13.28: there will be weeping, and gnashing of teeth, when ye shall see Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and you yourselves thrust out.
13.29: yet some shall come from the east, and from the west, from the north, and from the south, and shall be entertain'd in the kingdom of God.
13.30: then you will see those, who were last, become first: and those who were first, become last.
13.31: At the same time, some of the Pharisees came to him, and said, get away, retire from hence, for Herod designs to take away your life.
13.32: but he answered them, go, tell that fox, that to-day and to-morrow I am casting out demons, and performing cures, and the third day my course will be finished:
13.33: till then I must be stirring about, to-day, and to-morrow, and the next day: for a prophet cannot be put to death any where, but at Jerusalem.
13.34: "O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, that killest the prophets, and stonest those, who are sent unto thee: how often would I have gather'd thy children together, as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and ye would not?"

14.1: One sabbath-day, Jesus went to dine with a Pharisee of the first distinction, where he was strictly observ'd.
14.2: now there happen'd to be a man just by him, who had a dropsy.
14.3: Jesus therefore addressing himself to the doctors of the law, and to the Pharisees, said, is it allowable to perform a cure on the sabbath-day? to which they made no answer.
14.4: but he laid his hand upon the man, cured him, and dismissed him.
14.5: Then continuing his discourse, which of you, said he, if his child or his ox fell into a pit, would not immediately draw him out, though it were on the sabbath-day?
14.6: and they could not tell what to reply to it.
14.7: Afterwards observing how eager the guests were for the first places, he gave them this instruction:
14.8: when any one invites you to a wedding, don't put yourself in the highest seat: for fear some person of greater distinction should be a guest,
14.9: and he that invited you both, should come and bid you give place to him; and you should have the disgrace of taking the lowest seat.
14.11: for he that exalteth himself, shall be humbled, and he that humbleth himself, shall be exalted.
14.12: Then he said to the Pharisee, that had invited him, when you give a dinner, or a supper, don't call your friends, or your brethren, or kinsmen, or wealthy neighbours; lest they invite you again, and make you a requital.
14.13: but when you make a feast call the poor, and maimed, the lame and blind:
14.14: and you shall be happy in not receiving a requital: for you shall be recompenc'd at the resurrection of the just.
14.21: so the servant return'd, and related the whole matter to his master, who in resentment said to his servant, go immediately into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring hither the poor, the maimed, the halt, and the blind.
14.22: at length the servant said, sir, your orders have been executed, and still there is room.
14.23: the master reply'd, go then to the high-ways and by-paths, and compel them to come in, that my house may be full.
14.24: for I tell you that not one of those, who were invited, shall taste of my supper.
14.25: After this a great multitude being gather'd about him, he address'd himself to them,
14.26: and said, he that can't abandon his father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brethren, and sisters, nay, even his own life, cannot be my disciple.
14.27: and he that does not bear his cross, and tread in my steps, cannot be my disciple.
14.29: for fear he should be made the jest of every spectator, for laying the foundation, without being able to carry it on.
14.30: this man, will they say, began to build, but wanted stock to finish.
14.31: or where is the king, that will march to give battle to another king, without setting himself first to deliberate, whether he is strong enough with ten thousand to withstand an army of twenty thousand?
14.32: that in case he is not, he may send an embassy, and desire conditions of peace, before the other approaches.
14.33: in like manner every one of you must count upon renouncing all that he has, otherwise he cannot be my disciple.
14.34: salt is good, but if the salt has lost its savour, with what shall it be recovered?
14.35: it would be fit neither for the land, nor for the dunghil, but only to be thrown away, he that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

15.1: Then many of the Publicans, and people of a bad reputation gather'd about Jesus to hear him;
15.2: at which the Pharisees and Scribes murmured, saying, this man gives access to men of bad character, and eats with them.
15.3: but he propos'd to them this parable.
15.4: who of you that has an hundred sheep, will not, upon losing one, leave the ninety nine in the desart, to go after that which is lost, till he finds it?
15.5: and when he hath found it, joyfully lay it upon his shoulders?
15.6: and when he comes home, call his friends and neighbours together, and say to them, rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep, that was lost?
15.7: I tell you, that there shall likewise be greater joy in heaven for one sinner that repents, than for ninety nine just persons, that need no repentance.
15.8: or if a woman, that has ten pieces of money, should lose one of them, will she not light a lamp, sweep the house, and carefully search, till she find it?
15.9: and when 'tis found, will she not call her friends aud neighbours together, and say, rejoice with me, for I have found the piece, I had lost?
15.10: even so, I assure you, the angels in heaven rejoice, when any one sinner becomes a penitent.
15.13: a little while after the younger son turn'd all he had into money, and travell'd into a foreign country, where he squander'd away his fortune in luxurious living.
15.14: when he had spent all, there happen'd to be a severe famine in that country;
15.15: and he was reduced to want, which forc'd him to make his application to one of the inhabitants there, who sent him to his farm to look after his swine.
15.16: for he would have been contented to have liv'd upon the carruways, with which they usually fed the swine: but nobody would supply him.
15.17: at length coming to himself, how many, said he, does my father keep in pay, who have bread in abundance, whilst I am dying here with hunger?
15.18: I will depart, and go to my father, and say to him, father, I have sinned against heaven, and against thee;
15.19: I am no longer worthy to be called your son: treat me as one of your hir'd servants.
15.20: so he departed and went to his father, but while he was yet at a distance, his father saw him, and mov'd with compassion, ran and threw himself upon his neck, and kissed him.
15.23: take the fatted calf, and kill it: let us eat and be merry:
15.24: for this son of mine was dead, and is come to life: he was lost, and is found again, and then they began their feast.
15.25: In the mean time his elder son was in the country, at his return, when he came near home, he heard the musick and dancing:
15.26: and calling one of the servants, he ask'd what was the occasion of it,
15.28: upon this he was full of resentment, and refused to go in: and when his father came out to persuade him, he replied to his father,
15.29: how many years have I serv'd you, without having ever disobey'd your orders? and yet you never bestow'd a kid upon me, to make merry with my friends:
15.30: whereas this son of yours, who has eat up his fortune among a pack of loose creatures, is no sooner come but you must kill the fatted calf for him.
15.31: son, said he to him, you shall continue to be with me, and all that I have shall be thine.
15.32: but it was necessary to feast and rejoice, because your brother here was dead, and is again alive: he was lost and is now found.

16.1: Jesus said likewise to his disciples, a certain rich man had an information against his steward, for making havock of his estate.
16.2: upon making him appear, he said to him, what information is this, I hear against thee? give an account of your administration, for you must not be my steward any longer.
16.3: upon which the steward said in himself, what shall I do, now my master strips me of my employment? dig I cannot: and 'tis shameful to beg: I see it now,
16.4: I must do something that will secure me a reception in other families, when I have lost my place in this.
16.5: so he sent for every one of his master's debtors in private, he ask'd the first, how much do you owe my master?
16.8: and this unfaithful steward was commended by his master for being so provident, for they who look to this world, manage their affairs with more prudence, than those who have a prospect of a better.
16.9: I advise you in like manner to lay out your fallacious treasure in acts of charity, that when you die, they may secure to you everlasting habitations.
16.10: He that is faithful in a small trust, will be faithful in a greater: and he that is unfaithful in a little, will be unfaithful in much.
16.11: if therefore your fidelity has not appear'd in the use of these transitory enjoyments, how can you be trusted with what is more lasting?
16.12: if you have imbezel'd what another gave you in trust, how can he give you an estate in perpetuity?
16.13: a servant cannot serve two masters: for either he will neglect the one, and attend the other; or he will be attached to the first, and misbehave to the last, you cannot serve God and mammon.
16.14: The Pharisees too, who were noted for avarice, heard all this discourse, and treated him with derision.
16.15: but he said to them, you pretend to piety before men, which, however they may admire, is an abomination to God, who knows your real temper.
16.16: the law and the prophets were the only rule till John's time: since when, the kingdom of God has been proclaim'd, and all sorts of people strive to be members.
16.17: yet heaven and earth may sooner pass away, than any part of the law be unaccomplish'd.
16.19: There was a rich man, who used to dress in purple and fine linnen, and pass his days in pomp and luxury.
16.20: a certain beggar named Lazarus, was lying at his gate, and tho' cover'd with ulcers, the very dogs came and fawned upon him.
16.21: but he wanted to be fed with the crumbs, that fell from the rich man's table.
16.22: at length the beggar died: and was conveyed by the angels to Abraham's bower, the rich man died too, and was buried.
16.23: and being in the infernal regions of torments, he lift up his eyes, and saw Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bower.
16.26: besides this, there is an unalterable chasm between us and you, so that the passage from one place to the other is impracticable to those who should attempt it.
16.28: to give them warning, lest they also come into this place of torment.

17.1: Then said Jesus to his disciples, it is impossible but that discouragements should come: but wo to him, who is the occasion of them.
17.2: it were better for him that a milstone were hang'd about his neck, and he were thrown into the sea, than that he should occasion any innocent person to relapse.
17.3: take care of your conduct, if your brother offend you, rebuke him, and if he repent, forgive him.
17.4: tho' he should offend you seven times in a day, and seven times in the day return to you, saying, I repent, you must forgive him.
17.5: The Apostles having said to the Lord, increase our faith, he answer'd them,
17.8: won't he rather say, get ready my supper, dress yourself, and wait upon me, till I have done eating and drinking; after that, take your meal?
17.9: will he think himself oblig'd to that servant for doing what he was order'd? I believe not.
17.10: so when you have done all that you were commanded to do, say, we are unprofitable servants; we have only done what was our duty to do.
17.11: As Jesus was going to Jerusalem, he happen'd to pass between Samaria and Galilee.
17.12: and as he entered into a certain village, there met him ten lepers, who stood at a distance, and cry'd out aloud,
17.13: Jesus our master, take pity on us.
17.14: as soon as he perceiv'd them, he said to them, go shew yourselves to the priests, and on the way they found themselves cured.
17.15: one of them perceiving he was healed, turn'd back, praising God aloud.
17.16: then prostrating himself at the feet of Jesus, he gave him thanks, now this man was a Samaritan.
17.17: and Jesus said to him, were not all the ten healed? where then are the other nine?
17.18: is no body return'd to glorify God, but this alien only?
17.19: and he said to him, rise, go your way, your faith has sav'd you.
17.20: Upon the Pharisees asking him, when the kingdom of God should come, he answer'd them, the kingdom of God is not usher'd in with pomp and exclamations,
17.21: as see here! or see there! for even now the kingdom of God is commenc'd among you.
17.22: At length he said to his disciples, the time will come, when ye will wish to see the son of man appear, and shall not see him.
17.23: they will tell you, here he is, or, he is there: but don't go out to follow them;
17.24: for as the lightning flashes from one extremity of the sky to the other, so shall the appearance of the son of man be.
17.25: but before this, he must undergo many sufferings, and be rejected by this generation:
17.26: the same thing shall happen in the son of man's time as did in Noah's days.
17.27: eating and drinking, marriages and matches was the business till the very day that Noah entred into the ark, when the flood came and overwhelm'd them all.
17.28: and as it was in the days of Lot, they were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building:
17.29: but the very day that Lot went out of Sodom, a storm of lightning and thunder fell from heaven and destroy'd them all.
17.30: even thus shall it be in the day when the son of man shall appear.
17.31: then let not him that is on the house-top venture down to secure his furniture: and he that is in the field, let him not return back.
17.33: he that seeks to save his life, will expose it; and he that exposes his life, will preserve it.
17.34: I tell you, that of two persons lying in the same bed that night, the one shall be taken, and the other left.
17.35: two women shall be grinding together, the one shall be taken, and the other left:
17.36: two men shall be in the field, the one shall be taken, and the other left.
17.37: then they ask'd him, where, Lord, will this happen? he reply'd, wherever the carcase is, there will the eagles hover together.

18.1: Jesus propos'd likewise this parable to them, to show that they should persevere in prayer, and not be discouraged.
18.2: saying, in a certain city there was a judge, who neither feared God, nor regarded man.
18.3: a widow was likewise there, who frequently came to him, saying, do me justice against my adversary.
18.5: yet, because this widow importunes me, I will do her justice, that she may'nt be continually coming to teaze me.
18.6: observe, said Jesus, that language of this unrighteous judge.
18.7: and will not God avenge his own elect, who cry to him night and day? will he delay their cause?
18.8: I tell you, he will speedily avenge them, however, when the son of man comes, how few of the faithful will he find in the land?
18.9: Then he propos'd this parable, concerning those who had a great opinion of their own justice, and look'd with contempt upon others.
18.10: two men went to the temple to pray; the one a Pharisee, the other a Publican.
18.11: the Pharisee in a standing posture pray'd thus by himself, O God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men, a robber, a cheat, an adulterer, or like that Publican.
18.12: I fast twice a week, and I pay the tythe of all I possess.
18.14: I tell you this man went home approv'd as just, and not the other, for whoever exalteth himself shall be humbled, and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted.
18.15: And as they were presenting children to him, for the imposition of hands, his disciples observing it, rebuk'd those that brought them.
18.16: but Jesus called the children to him, and said to his disciples, let the children come to me, without any hindrance, for they who belong to the kingdom of God, must be like them.
18.17: I declare unto you, he that does not come with the disposition of a child shall not enter into the kingdom of God.
18.18: Then a person of distinction ask'd him this question, good master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?
18.19: Jesus replied, why do you call me good? there is but one who is good, that is God.
18.20: you know the commandments, "do not commit adultery, do not kill, do not steal, do not bear false witness, honour thy father and mother."
18.22: upon hearing that, Jesus said to him, one thing you have yet to do: sell all you have, and give it to the poor, and you shall have treasure in heaven: then come, and follow me.
18.23: upon hearing this he was very sad: for he had a large estate.
18.24: Jesus perceiving him so very dejected, said, how difficult is it for those, who have riches, to enter into the kingdom of God!
18.25: it is easier for a cable to pass through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
18.26: upon which the audience said, who then can be saved?
18.27: Jesus answer'd, by divine assistance men may do that which would be otherwise impossible.
18.28: Then said Peter, you see that we have left every thing to follow you.
18.29: Jesus answer'd, I declare unto you, no one has ever quitted house or parents, or brethren, or wife, or children, upon account of the gospel-dispensation,
18.30: who shall not receive abundantly more even in this age, and everlasting life in the age to come.
18.31: Afterwards Jesus took the twelve aside, and said to them, now we are going to Jerusalem where all that the prophets have writ concerning the son of man shall be accomplished.
18.32: for he shall be delivered to the Gentiles by the Jews, who will treat him with mockery,
18.33: insult him, spit in his face, scourge him, and put him to death; and the third day he shall rise again.
18.34: but they comprehended nothing of all this: his discourse was a riddle to them, and they could not find out the meaning.
18.35: As they were near Jericho, a blind man happen'd to sit begging by the road,
18.36: who hearing the noise of a crowd passing by, ask'd what the matter was.
18.37: they told him, Jesus the Nazarene is passing by.
18.38: then he cry'd out, Jesus son of David, have pity on me.
18.39: those who led the way bid him hold his tongue, but he bawl'd out the louder, son of David have pity on me.
18.40: then Jesus stopp'd, and order'd them to bring the man to him, who being come nigh, he ask'd him,
18.41: what would you have me do for you? he said, Lord, I desire to have sight.
18.42: have sight, said Jesus, your faith has obtain'd you a cure.
18.43: and immediately he saw: and followed Jesus, glorifying God: and all the people, who were eye-witnesses, gave praise unto God.

19.1: As Jesus was pursuing his journey from Jericho,
19.2: one Zaccheus, a rich man, and collector-general of the customs,
19.3: was very desirous to see the person of Jesus, but could not for the crowd, he being of a low stature.
19.4: so he ran before, and climb'd up a mulberry-tree to view him; for he was to pass that way.
19.5: as soon as Jesus came at the place, he look'd up, and seeing him, Zaccheus, said he, make haste down; for I intend to dine at your house to-day.
19.6: so down he came in great haste, and gave Jesus a joyful reception.
19.7: upon seeing this, they all murmur'd, saying, he is going to be treated by a dissolute person.
19.8: but Zaccheus address'd himself to Jesus, and said, Lord, half my estate I give to the poor; and if I have wrong'd any man, I will give him four times the value.
19.9: then said Jesus, speaking of him, this day is salvation come to this family, since he is now become a true son of Abraham.
19.10: for the son of man is come to seek, and to save that which was lost.
19.11: Their attention being raised by this, Jesus pursued his discourse with a parable, occasion'd by their thinking, that, because he was advanc'd so nigh to Jerusalem, the kingdom of God would immediately commence.
19.15: upon his return, being confirm'd king, he order'd the servants, he had trusted with the money, to appear, and inform him, what improvement each of them had made.
19.16: the first came and said, Lord, your one pound has gained ten more.
19.18: then the second came, and said, Lord, your pound has produc'd five more.
19.21: for I was in fear of you, knowing you to be a hard master, who exact what you never gave, and reap where you have never sown.
19.22: wicked slave, said he, from your own mouth will I convict thee. "you knew I was a hard master, exacting what I never gave, and reaping where I never sowed:
19.23: " why then did you not lodge my money in the bank, that on my return I might have drawn it out with interest?
19.24: then he said to his attendants, take the one pound from him, and give it him, that gain'd ten.
19.26: I tell you, said he, that to every one who improves, more shall be given: and he that makes no improvement, shall be stript of what he has.
19.27: as for those enemies of mine, who would not have me for their king, bring them here, and slay them in my presence.
19.28: After this discourse, Jesus pursued his journey towards Jerusalem.
19.29: when he was advanc'd near Bethphage, and Bethany, to the mountain call'd the Olives, he sent two of his disciples,
19.30: saying to them, go to the village opposite to you: at your entrance there, you will find a colt ty'd, that was never yet back'd: untie it and bring it here.
19.31: if any one should ask you, why you untie it, let this be your answer, because the Lord has occasion for it.
19.32: Accordingly the messengers went, and found the colt, as Jesus had told them.
19.33: as they were untying the colt, the owners said, why do you untie the colt?
19.34: they answer'd, because the Lord has occasion for it.
19.35: so they brought it to Jesus, and throwing their garments upon the colt, they mounted Jesus thereon.
19.36: and all the way, as he marched, they strewed with their clothes.
19.37: Just as he advanc'd to the declivity of the mountain of Olives, the whole troop of disciples began to express their joy in loud acclamations, praising God, for the many miracles they had seen.
19.39: upon this some of the Pharisees, who were in the crowd, said to him, master, rebuke your disciples.
19.40: but he answer'd them, if they should be silent, the stones would exclaim.
19.41: as he drew nigh, he beheld the city, and bewail'd its fate,
19.42: in these words, "O that thou hadst consider'd, at least in this very day, the opportunity you had of being happy! but now alas! it is vanish'd from your eyes."
19.43: for the time will shortly come, when your enemies shall open their trenches before thee, hem you in, and closely besiege you:
19.44: they will level you to the ground, extirpate your inhabitants, and bury your buildings in ruins: because you have not consider'd the overtures I made you.
19.45: As soon as he entred into the temple, he drove out the sellers and buyers there: telling them it is written,
19.47: and he instructed the people daily in the temple, while the chief priests, the Scribes, and the rulers of the people, were contriving to take away his life.
19.48: but they could not find the means of effecting it; for all the populace were strongly attach'd to his doctrine.

20.1: One day, as he was instructing the people in the temple, and preaching the gospel, the chief priests, and the Scribes, with the rulers came up to him,
20.2: and thus accosted him, tell us by what authority do you act thus? and whence do you derive that authority?
20.3: Jesus answer'd, I will ask you one question;
20.4: tell me, the baptism of John, was it a divine or a human institution?
20.7: they answer'd then, they did not know which it was.
20.8: Jesus replied, neither will I tell you by what authority I act thus.
20.10: at vintage, he sent a servant to the husbandmen, to demand the profits of the vineyard, but they beat him and sent him away empty.
20.11: again he sent another servant, him they likewise beat, insulted, and sent away empty.
20.12: he still sent a third, whom they wounded and drove away.
20.13: upon which the master of the vineyard said, what shall I do? I will send my beloved son: perhaps his presence will engage their respect.
20.15: so they kill'd him, and threw him out of the vineyard, what punishment now will the master inflict upon them?
20.16: he will come and destroy these husbandmen, and give his vineyard to others, but they, taking the hint, cried out, God forbid.
20.17: then Jesus looking upon them, said, what is the meaning then of that expression, "the stone, which the builders rejected, is become the chief stone of the angle."
20.18: whoever falls upon that stone shall be bruised, but on whom it falls, it will crush him to pieces.
20.19: The chief priests, and the Scribes perceiving that he had applied this parable to them, were eager to seize upon him at that very time; but they were afraid of the people.
20.20: they watch'd then, and suborn'd spies, who under pretence of their tender consciences, might ensnare him in his discourse, and so betray him to the civil power and jurisdiction of the governor.
20.21: they address'd him therefore in this manner; master, we know that what you say and teach is all right, you are not influenc'd by the quality of men, but explain the divine law with sincerity:
20.22: should we pay tribute to Cesar, or no?
20.23: but Jesus perceiving their malicious design, said to them, why do you practise upon me?
20.25: render then, said he, to Cesar, what belongs to Cesar, and to God, what belongs to God.
20.26: so not being able to take any advantage from his words, before the people, they said no more, being surpriz'd at his answer.
20.27: Afterwards some of the Pharisees, who deny there is any resurrection, accosted him with this question,
20.28: master, said they, Moses left it in writing, if any man has a brother, who dies in marriage without leaving children, he is obliged to take the widow, to perpetuate his brother's line.
20.29: now there were seven brothers, the first of which marry'd, and died without children.
20.30: the second after marrying the widow, died likewise without children.
20.31: then the third took her, and so she was married to all seven, who all died without leaving any children.
20.32: at last the woman died too.
20.33: at the resurrection therefore, to which of them will she be wife? for she had been married to all the seven.
20.34: Jesus answered, in this life men and women marry.
20.35: but they, who shall be accounted worthy to obtain the resurrection to an eternal life, shall have no concern in marriage, as being immortal:
20.36: for by the resurrection they will inherit a nature truely angelical and divine.
20.37: now that the dead are raised, may be inferr'd from Moses's relation concerning the bush, where he stiles the Lord, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.
20.38: for he is not the God of the dead, but of the living, they are all then alive with respect to him.
20.39: which some of the Scribes approving, said to him, master, what you maintain is very just:
20.40: and after that they did not venture to ask him another question.
20.41: But Jesus said to them, you affirm the Messiah must be descended from David, how can that be?
20.42: for in the book of Psalms David himself says, "the Lord said to my Lord, sit on my right hand,
20.43: till I make thine enemies thy footstool."
20.44: if then David stiles the Messiah his Lord, how can he be descended from David?
20.45: then in the audience of all the people, he said to his disciples,
20.47: who under the pretext of their long prayers devour the fortunes of widows, wherefore they shall be punish'd with greater severity.

21.1: As Jesus was observing the rich casting their offerings into the treasury,
21.2: he saw a poor widow throwing in the value of a farthing.
21.3: and he said, I declare unto you, that this poor widow has thrown in more than they all.
21.4: for they have offer'd only part of their superfluous wealth; but she has given all that was then left for her subsistence.
21.5: Some having said of the temple, that the stone-work was fine, and the furniture magnificent:
21.7: thereupon they said to him, master, when shall this happen? and by what sign shall we know that the event is coming?
21.8: he answered, take care, that you be not seduced: for many shall come in my name, saying, I am the Christ, it won't be long e'er this happens, therefore do not follow them.
21.9: And when ye shall hear of wars, and seditions, be not alarm'd, for these must first happen: but the end will not be so soon.
21.10: then nation, said he, shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
21.11: great earthquakes, and famines, and pestilences shall happen in divers places: terrible appearances and surprizing prodigies shall be in the heavens.
21.13: and that shall be one proof of the truth of your profession.
21.14: fix it therefore in your mind, not to think beforehand about your defence.
21.15: for I will make you speak with such strength of argument, as all your adversaries shall not be able to contradict or withstand.
21.16: you will be betrayed even by your very parents, and brethren, and kindred, and friends, nay, some of you they will prosecute even to death.
21.17: you will be hated by all mankind for professing my name,
21.18: however a single hair of your head shall not be lost.
21.19: by your perseverance you will save your souls.
21.20: Now when you shall see Jerusalem invested by an army, then be assured that the desolation of it is nigh.
21.21: then let those, who are in Judea, fly to the mountains: let those, who are in the city, march out, and those, who are without not venture in.
21.22: for this is the time of vengeance, when all that is writ, shall be accomplished.
21.23: wo to them that are with child, or to them that give suck in those days: for this will be a region of great distress, and wrath will pour down upon this people.
21.24: by the destructive sword shall they fall, and be led into captivity among all nations: and Jerusalem shall be kept waste by the nations, as long as those nations shall subsist.
21.25: there shall be signs in the sun, and in the moon, and in the stars: and upon the earth distress of nations under confusion, the sea and the waves roaring.
21.26: men dying with fear under the apprehension of those calamities, which are coming upon the earth: for the powers of heaven shall be shaken.
21.27: and then shall they see the son of man come on a cloud, with power and great glory.
21.28: now when these things begin to appear, then lift up your heads, and behold your redemption drawing nigh.
21.29: Then by way of similitude, consider, said he, the fig-tree, and all the other trees;
21.30: when they shoot out their buds, you know for certain that summer is coming on:
21.31: in like manner, when you shall see these events, be assur'd that the kingdom of God is nigh.
21.32: I tell it you for certain, this generation shall not pass away, till all these things are accomplished.
21.33: heaven and earth shall fail sooner than my predictions shall fail.
21.35: for like a snare, it shall surprize all the inhabitants of the earth.
21.36: be therefore upon your guard, be constant in prayer, that you may be accounted worthy to escape all those future ills, and be able to stand in the presence of the son of God.
21.37: Thus Jesus used to teach in the temple by day, and retir'd to the mountain of Olives by night.
21.38: and every morning the people went to the temple to hear him.

22.1: Now the feast of unleaven'd bread, which is call'd the passover,
22.2: being nigh, the chief priests consulted with the Scribes, how they might put Jesus to death; for they were afraid of the people.
22.3: now satan had inspired Judas surnam'd Iscariot, one of the twelve, what to do.
22.4: accordingly he went and conferr'd with the chief priests and officers of the temple, about the method of seizing him.
22.5: they were pleas'd with his proposal, and agreed to give him a certain sum.
22.6: Judas accepted the bargain, and sought an opportunity to secure him, without alarming the people.
22.7: The day of unleaven'd bread being come, when the paschal-lamb was to be sacrific'd,
22.8: Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, go, and make provision for our eating the paschal-lamb.
22.9: they ask'd him, where would you have us prepare it?
22.10: he answered, when you are in the city, you will meet a man with a pitcher of water; follow him to the house, where he goes in:
22.11: and say to the man of the house, our master sent to ask for a room, where he may eat the passover with his disciples.
22.12: and he will show you a large upper room ready fitted: there prepare the supper.
22.13: so they went, and having found every thing as Jesus had said, they made ready the passover.
22.14: The hour of eating being come, he, and the twelve apostles sat down to table.
22.15: and he said to them, I have ardently desired to eat this passover with you, before I suffer.
22.16: for I declare unto you, I shall not celebrate this passover with you any more, to the time, when it shall have its accomplishment in the kingdom of the messiah.
22.17: having then taken the cup, and given thanks, he said, take this, and distribute it to one another.
22.18: for I tell you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine to the time when the kingdom of God shall come.
22.19: then he took bread, and having given thanks, he brake it, and gave it to them, saying, this represents my body which is given for you: do this in remembrance of me.
22.20: and after supper he likewise gave the cup, saying, this cup is the new testament sealed by my blood, which is shed for you.
22.21: yet there's the hand that is to seize me, now upon the table.
22.22: the son of man indeed must die, as it was decreed: but wo to that man by whom he is betrayed.
22.23: upon this they began to enquire of one another, which of them it was that should do such an action.
22.24: Now there had been a dispute among the disciples, which of them should be accounted the greatest.
22.26: but you must not be such: the greatest of you must be as the junior, and he that governs as he that serves.
22.27: for who is greatest, he that sits at table, or he that waits? is it not the person at table? yet I am among you as one that serves.
22.28: but since you did not abandon me in my trials,
22.29: I commit the kingdom to you, as my father committed it to me;
22.30: that you may eat and drink at my table, in my kingdom, and seated on thrones may judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
22.31: Then said Jesus, Simon, Simon, satan has demanded to shake you, and my disciples, like wheat in a sieve.
22.32: but as for thee, I have pray'd that you faith may not fail, do you in return establish thy brethren.
22.33: Peter answer'd, Lord, I am ready to accompany you both to prison, and to death.
22.34: but Jesus said, before the cock proclaims the day, you will thrice deny that ever you knew me.
22.35: When I sent you, added Jesus, without either purse, or bag, or shoes, was you in any want? not at all, answer'd they.
22.38: Lord, said they, you see, we have two swords, he reply'd, that's enough.
22.39: Then he went out, and retired as usual to the mountain of olives, where his disciples followed him.
22.40: at his arrival there, he said to them, pray that you may withstand the trial.
22.41: At length he withdrew from them about a stone's cast, where falling upon his knees,
22.43: then an angel from heaven appear'd to him, and comforted him.
22.44: and being in an agony he prayed more earnestly: and his sweat was like grumes of blood falling to the ground.
22.45: then rising from prayer, he came to his disciples, and finding them asleep, oppress'd with grief, why do you sleep?
22.46: said he, rise, and pray that you may withstand the trial.
22.47: Before he had done speaking, the company appears, Judas one of the twelve marching in front, who advanc'd to Jesus to give him a kiss.
22.48: but Jesus said to him, Judas is it thus you betray the son of man, with a kiss?
22.49: they who were about him seeing what would happen, said to him, shall we smite with the sword?
22.50: and one of them struck a servant of the high priest, and slash'd off his right ear.
22.51: but Jesus oppos'd, and said, forbear, stop there, and having touch'd his ear, he healed him.
22.52: then said Jesus to the chief priests, the officers of the temple, and the rulers, who were come to take him, are you come here with swords and staves as in pursuit of a robber?
22.53: I was daily with you in the temple, and you never offer'd to seize me: but now you have your hour, and the prince of darkness his day.
22.54: Then they seized him and carried him away to the high priest's house, and Peter followed at a distance.
22.55: now as they had made a fire in the middle of the hall, and people were sitting all round it, Peter too sat down among them.
22.56: but one of the servants seeing him by the fire, star'd him in the face, and said, this man was with him too.
22.57: but he renounc'd Jesus, saying, woman, I don't know him.
22.58: a little while after another seeing him, said, you are even one of them, but Peter said to him, man, I am not.
22.60: Peter reply'd, man, I don't know what you would say, and immediately while he was yet speaking, the cock crew.
22.62: and Peter went out, and wept bitterly.
22.63: In the mean time, they who held Jesus, treated him with insults and buffoonry.
22.64: they made him blind-fold, they slapt him on the face, and cry'd out, divine who it was that smote thee.
22.65: and besides all this, they loaded him with the most impious invectives.
22.66: As soon as it was day, the rulers of the people, the chief priests and the Scribes being assembled, they order'd him to be brought before their council,
22.67: and said to him, if you are the Christ, say so, but he answer'd, if I should tell you so, you will not believe it.
22.68: and if I should argue it with you, you will neither answer me, nor let me go.
22.69: but in a little time the son of man shall be seated on the powerful right hand of God.
22.71: upon this they cry'd, what occasion have we for further evidence? for we ourselves have heard enough from his own mouth.

23.1: At length the whole assembly broke up, and Jesus was conducted to Pilate:
23.2: and thus they began their charge, we found this man subverting our nation, opposing the giving tribute to Cesar, asserting that he himself is Christ the king.
23.4: at last Pilate said to the chief priests, and to the people, I don't find any crime in this man.
23.5: but they were the more vehement, saying, he promotes sedition by speading such doctrine thro' all Judea, from Galilee to this place.
23.6: when Pilate heard of Galilee, he ask'd whether the man were a Galilean.
23.7: and finding that he belong'd to Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who was then likewise at Jerusalem.
23.8: When Herod saw Jesus he was extremely pleased; for he had long desired to see him, having heard much of him, and hoped to see him perform some miracle.
23.9: he plyed him therefore with many interrogatories,
23.10: but Jesus made him no answer, tho' the chief priests and Scribes maintain'd their charge with vehemence.
23.11: then Herod and his retinue treated him with contempt, and in derision sent him back magnificently dress'd to Pilate.
23.12: and from that day the enmity that had been between Pilate and Herod ended in friendship.
23.13: Pilate having order'd the chief priests, the senators, and people to appear, he said to them,
23.14: you have represented this man to me as one that was stirring up the people to a revolt: you see I have examin'd him in your presence; yet I don't find he is guilty of the crimes you have laid to his charge: no, nor even Herod;
23.15: for I referr'd you to him, and you see nothing that is capital, has been made out against him.
23.16: I will therefore order him to be whipp'd, and then release him.
23.17: now as it was customary for the governor to release one of the prisoners at the feast;
23.19: Barabbas had been imprison'd for murder in a riot he had rais'd in the city.
23.20: Pilate therefore, desirous to release Jesus, expostulated with them again.
23.22: however he urg'd it a third time, why, what crime has he done? I don't find he has done any thing that deserves death: I will therefore order him to be whipp'd, and so dismiss him.
23.23: but they persisted with great clamour in their demands, to have him crucified: and as the people and chief priests redoubled their clamours,
23.24: Pilate determin'd to grant their request.
23.25: accordingly he discharg'd the prisoner they desired, him that was committed for riot and murder; but he abandon'd Jesus to their discretion.
23.26: As they were conducting him to execution, they seiz'd upon one Simon of Cyrene, who was coming to town, and oblig'd him to carry the cross after Jesus,
23.27: who was followed by a great crowd of people, and several women, who beat their breasts and lamented him.
23.31: for if the green wood burn thus, how will the dry wood flame?
23.32: At the same time, two malefactors were led along to be crucified with Jesus.
23.33: accordingly, when they came to the place call'd Calvary, they crucified him there, and the two malefactors; the one at his right, the other at his left.
23.35: while the people who stood looking on, and the senators themselves contemptuously said, he sav'd others; if he be Christ, the elect of God, let him save himself.
23.36: the soldiers too, who came to bring him vinegar, insulted him,
23.37: saying, if thou art the king of the Jews, save thy self.
23.38: they likewise put the following inscription over his head, in Greek, in Latin, and in Hebrew, THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
23.41: as for us, it is with justice, that we suffer the penalty due to our crimes: but as for him, what misdemeanour has he been guilty of?
23.42: then said he to Jesus, Lord, remember me when you enter into your kingdom.
23.43: Jesus answer'd, verily I tell you, this day thou shalt be with me in paradise.
23.44: About the sixth hour, it was dark all over the land till the ninth hour.
23.45: the sun was obscured, and the veil of the temple was rent in two.
23.47: The centurion upon seeing what had happen'd, gave glory to God, and said, certainly this was a righteous man.
23.48: and all the people that had crowded to that sight, went home striking their breasts at the thoughts of those events.
23.49: As for his acquaintance, they all stood at a distance, with the women that followed him from Galilee, and were spectators during the whole transaction.
23.50: There was likewise present a counsellor, named Joseph, a man of probity and justice, one who had never abetted the contrivances and proceedings of the Jews.
23.51: he was of Arimathea, a city of Judea, and one of those, who were in expectation of the Messiah's reign.
23.52: this very man went to Pilate, and begg'd the body of Jesus.
23.53: and he took it down, and wrapp'd it in linnen, and laid it in a sepulchre, hewn out of a rock, wherein nobody had ever yet been deposited.
23.54: now that day was the preparation, and the sabbath then drew on.
23.55: the women therefore, who had accompanied Jesus from Galilee, followed Joseph, to the sepulchre, to see how the body was disposed of.
23.56: then they went home, and provided spices and perfumes: after which they rested the sabbath-day, as the law appointed.

24.1: On the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they went to the sepulchre with the spices they had provided, accompanied by several others.
24.2: and having found that the stone had been remov'd from the sepulchre, they entred in,
24.3: but did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
24.4: whilst they were in great perplexity about it, all of a sudden, two men appear'd before them in robes of light.
24.5: upon which they were frightned, and bowed themselves to the very ground: but the men said to them, why do you look among the dead for one that is alive?
24.6: he is not here, but is risen: remember what he told you, when he was yet in Galilee,
24.7: that the son of man must be deliver'd into the hands of sinful men; be crucified; and the third day rise again.
24.9: and upon their return from the sepulchre, they related the whole matter to the eleven, and all the other disciples.
24.10: it was Mary Magdalene and Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and others with them, who gave the apostles this relation:
24.11: which however appear'd to them such a delirious tale, they could not give credit to any of them.
24.12: yet Peter got up, and ran to the sepulchre, where stooping down he saw nothing but the linnen lying there: upon which he went away wondring with himself at such an event.
24.13: The same day two of them went to a village named Emmaus, which was distant about threescore furlongs from Jerusalem:
24.14: and their conversation ran upon all that had lately happened.
24.15: now while they were conferring and debating together, Jesus himself join'd them and walk'd along with them.
24.16: but their eyes were affected so as not to discern who he was.
24.17: and he said to them, what is the subject of your debate in the way, and why do you look so sad?
24.19: what about? said he, why, about Jesus the Nazarean, said they, who was a prophet, eminently recommended, by his doctrine and his works, to the approbation of God and of all the people;
24.20: and of his being deliver'd up by our chief priests and magistrates to be condemn'd to die, whom they actually crucified:
24.21: though we expected he would have been the Messiah, that was to deliver Israel: and besides all this, it is now three days since these things were done.
24.22: 'tis true, some women of our company threw us into a surprize: for going to the sepulchre early in the morning,
24.23: and not finding his body there, they came to tell us, that they had seen a vision of angels, who said that he was alive.
24.24: whereupon some of us went to the sepulchre, and found matters just as the women had related; but him they did not see.
24.25: then Jesus said to them, how stupidly incredulous are you not to believe things that have been all predicted by the prophets!
24.26: was not the Messiah to have suffer'd thus, and after that enter into his glory?
24.27: then beginning at Moses he explain'd all the passages there, and in all the prophets, which related to himself.
24.28: and they drew nigh the village where they were going: and he seemed as if he would have pass'd on further.
24.29: but they press'd him, saying, stay with us, for it is late and begins to be dark, so he went in to tarry with them.
24.30: and as he was at table with them, he took bread, and gave thanks, then brake it and gave it to them;
24.31: when looking upon him more intently, they perceiv'd that it was Jesus, but he vanish'd out of sight.
24.32: Upon this, they said to one another, to what ardor did not our affections rise, while he talk'd with us by the way, and while he expounded to us the scriptures?
24.33: and immediately they set out, and return'd to Jerusalem, where they found the eleven, and the rest of their company, all assembled, who said,
24.34: the Lord is actually risen, and hath appeared to Simon.
24.35: Thereupon the two disciples related what had hapned on the road, and how they first discover'd who Jesus was at his breaking of bread.
24.36: While they were thus talking, Jesus himself appear'd in the midst of them, and said to them, peace be with you.
24.37: but they were in a consternation and fright, imagining, that they saw a spirit.
24.38: upon which he said to them, why are you in this confusion? what is it, that your minds are so perplex'd?
24.39: behold my hands, and my feet, for I am bodily present, touch me and consider me; for a spirit has not flesh and bones, as you see me have:
24.40: all the while holding out his hands and his feet, as he was speaking.
24.42: and they gave him a piece of broil'd fish, and of a honey-comb;
24.43: which he took, and did eat in their presence.
24.44: then he said, this is what I told you, while I was yet with you, that what has been written concerning me in the law of Moses, in the prophets, and in the psalms, must be all accomplished.
24.45: then he open'd their minds to make them understand the scriptures, and said to them,
24.46: thus it is written, and thus it behov'd Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day:
24.47: and that repentance and remission of sins should be preach'd in his name, among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
24.48: you are witnesses of these things.
24.49: and I am going to send you what my father has promis'd you, but continue in the city of Jerusalem, until you shall be endued with power from on high.
24.50: At length he led them out as far as Bethany; and stretching out his hands, he gave them his benediction.
24.51: and while he was blessing them, he was taken from them, and carried up into heaven.
24.52: and they worship'd him, and with great joy return'd to Jerusalem,
24.53: where they daily praised and blessed God in the temple.

1.1: In the beginning was the Logos, and the Logos was with God, and the Logos was God.
1.2: the same was in the beginning with God.
1.3: all things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made.
1.4: the Life was produc'd in him, and the Life was the Light of men.
1.5: and the Light shineth in darkness, but the darkness did not receive it.
1.6: There was a man sent from God, whose name was John.
1.7: he came as a witness, to represent what he knew of the light, that by his means all might be convinc'd.
1.8: he was not that Light, but was sent to testify of that light.
1.9: HE was the true Light who came into the world, to enlighten every man.
1.10: he was in the world, even the world that had been made by him, but the world knew him not.
1.11: he came unto his own, and his own received him not.
1.12: but to as many as received him, and believed on him, he granted the privilege of being the sons of God.
1.13: a birth which they had not from circumcision, nor from the constitution of the body, nor the institution of man, but from God.
1.14: The Logos became incarnate, and had his tabernacle among us, being full of grace and truth; and we contemplated his glory, such glory as the Monogenes derived from the father.
1.15: it was of him that John bare witness, when he made this declaration, "this was he of whom I said, he that cometh after me, was before me; for he did indeed exist before me."
1.16: and of his Plenitude have we all received, even abundant grace.
1.17: the law indeed was delivered by Moses, but grace and truth was the dispensation of Jesus Christ.
1.18: no man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten son, who is intimate with the father, hath made him known.
1.19: This is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem, to ask him, who he was.
1.20: he own'd it, and did not deny it; but made this protestation, I am not the Christ.
1.22: said they to him, who then art thou? that we may give an answer to those that sent us: what sayst thou of thy self?
1.23: "I am, said he, the voice of one crying in the wilderness, clear the way of the Lord," as said the prophet Esaias.
1.24: Now the messengers were of the sect of the Pharisees, and they asked him,
1.25: "why then do you baptize, if you are not the Christ, nor Elias, nor any other prophet?"
1.26: John answered them, I baptize with water: but there is one among you, whom ye know not; he it is who coming after me,
1.27: is preferred before me, the latchet of whose sandals I am not worthy to unloose.
1.28: these things were transacted at Bethabara, near Jordan, where John used to baptize.
1.29: The next day John saw Jesus coming to him, and said, "behold the lamb of God, who taketh away the sin of the world."
1.31: I knew him not: but therefore am I come baptizing with water, that he might be manifest to Israel.
1.32: and John testified, saying, I saw the spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and it abode upon him.
1.33: I had not known him: but he that sent me to baptize with water, had told me, "upon whom thou shalt see the spirit descending and remaining on him, the same is he who baptizeth with the holy spirit."
1.34: this I saw, and testify'd, that he is the son of God.
1.35: The next day after, John was again there with two of his disciples:
1.36: and seeing Jesus as he walked, he said, "behold the lamb of God."
1.37: the two disciples hearing this, followed Jesus.
1.38: then Jesus turned about, and seeing them following, said, what do you seek? they answered him, rabbi, that is to say master, where do you dwell?
1.40: Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, was one of the two disciples, who had followed Jesus, after they had heard what John had said.
1.41: the first he met was his own brother Simon, to whom he said, "we have found the Messias," that is to say, the Christ.
1.42: and he brought him to Jesus, and when Jesus beheld him, he said, "thou art Simon the son of Jona: thou shalt be called Cephas," which is by interpretation, a stone.
1.44: now Philip was of Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.
1.45: Philip meeting with Nathanael, said to him, we have found him of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets did write, Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.
1.47: Jesus seeing Nathanael coming, said of him, there's a true Israelite, in whom is no guile, how do you know me?
1.49: Nathanael answered, rabbi, thou art the son of God, thou art the king of Israel.
1.51: and he said to him, I declare unto you, hereafter you shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending, and descending upon the son of man.

2.1: Three days after, there was a wedding at Cana in Galilee; where the mother of Jesus was present.
2.2: as likewise Jesus and his disciples, who were all invited to the feast.
2.3: now when the wine was out, the mother of Jesus said to him, they have no wine.
2.4: Jesus answer'd her, woman, leave that affair to me, is not that my concern?
2.5: upon which his mother bid the servants do whatever he should order.
2.6: now there were six cisterns of stone plac'd there for the use of the Jews in their purifications, containing two or three firkins a-piece.
2.8: now fill out, said he, and carry it to the steward of the feast, which accordingly they did.
2.9: as soon as the steward had tasted the water that was made wine, (for he did not know whence it came, but the servants who drew the water knew it,) he called the bridegroom,
2.11: thus was the first miracle of Jesus wrought at Cana in Galilee, by which he displayed his power; and his disciples believed on him.
2.12: After this he went down to Capernaum, in company with his mother, his brethren, and his disciples: but they stay'd there only a few days.
2.13: for the Jews passover being nigh, Jesus went up to Jerusalem,
2.14: where he found in the temple those that sold oxen, sheep, and doves, besides the changers of money, who were sitting there.
2.15: upon which he made a whip of small cords, and drove them all out of the temple, with their sheep, and oxen; and threw about the changers money, and over-set the tables; and said to the dove-sellers,
2.16: away with these things; make not my father's house a market-house.
2.17: which put his disciples in mind of that passage, "my zeal for thine house does prey upon me."
2.18: whereupon the Jews said, what miracle can you show to justify your behaviour?
2.20: to this said the Jews, forty and six years was this temple in building, and wilt thou rear it up in three days?
2.21: but by the temple he meant his body.
2.22: and when he was risen from the dead, his disciples remembred that expression of his: and they believed the scripture, and what Jesus had said.
2.23: Now whilst he was in Jerusalem at the feast of the passover, many believed in him when they saw the miracles which he did.
2.24: but Jesus did not trust his person with them, because he knew them all.
