2.25: and he did not want any information concerning man: for he knew of himself the secret of their hearts.

3.1: Now one of the Pharisees, named Nicodemus, was there, a ruler of the Jews:
3.2: who came to Jesus by night, and said to him, rabbi, we know that thou art a teacher sent from God: for no man can perform the miracles that you do, except God be with him.
3.3: Jesus answered him, I declare unto thee, except a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.
3.4: Nicodemus replied, how can a man be born when he is old? can he enter into his mother, and be born a second time?
3.5: Jesus answered, I tell thee, except a man be renewed by the spiritual baptism, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.
3.6: the cleansing of the body is only external, but the purification of the spirit is spiritual.
3.7: be not surprized that I said to thee, you must be born again.
3.8: the wind bloweth where it listeth, and you hear the sound thereof, but cannot tell whence it comes, or whither it goes: such is the change in every one that is renewed by the spirit.
3.9: Nicodemus answered, how can that be?
3.11: I declare unto thee, we speak what we know, and testify what we have seen; but you do not receive our testimony.
3.12: if you don't believe when I tell you what is plain, how should you believe, if I tell you of things more sublime?
3.13: for no man hath penetrated into the secrets of heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the son of man, who is in heaven.
3.14: but as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, even so must the son of man be lifted up:
3.15: that whosoever believeth in him, should not perish, but have eternal life.
3.17: for God sent not his son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved.
3.18: he that believeth on him, shall not be condemned: but he that believeth not, is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the only begotten son of God.
3.19: and this is the subject of their condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men have loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.
3.20: for every one that doth evil, hateth the light, and shunneth the light, lest his deeds should be reproved.
3.21: but he that doth right, cometh to the light, that his deeds may be made manifest, because they are agreeable to the will of God.
3.22: After this Jesus went with his disciples into Judea, where he stay'd with them for some time,
3.23: and baptized, while John was likewise baptizing in Enon, near Salim, it being a place abounding with water: so that people came to be baptized there.
3.24: for John was not yet cast into prison.
3.25: Now there happen'd to be a dispute about baptism between a Jews, and some of John's disciples:
3.26: who thereupon went to John, and said, master, he that was with you beyond Jordan, to whom you bore testimony, he himself does now baptize likewise, and the people flock to him.
3.28: you yourselves can bear me witness, that I said, I am not the Christ, but was only sent before him:
3.29: the bridegroom is he that hath a right to the bride: as for the friend of the bridegroom, who is nigh his person and heareth him, he greatly rejoyces at the voice of the bridegroom: upon this account my joy is compleat.
3.31: but I must decline, he that cometh from above, is above all: he that is from the earth, is earthly, and his language is likewise earthly: he that cometh from heaven is above all.
3.32: and what he hath seen and heard, that he testifieth; but his testimony doth no man receive.
3.33: he that hath received his testimony, hath set his seal to this, that God is true.
3.34: for he whom God hath sent, saith nothing but what is divine: for God hath given him the spirit without restriction.
3.35: the father loveth the son, and hath given all things into his hand.
3.36: he that believeth on the son, hath a right to everlasting life: and he that disobeys the son, shall not enjoy life; but be expos'd to divine wrath.

4.1: Jesus therefore knowing the Pharisees had heard that he made more disciples, and baptized more than John,
4.2: (though Jesus himself did not baptize, but only his disciples) he left Judea,
4.4: but being obliged to pass through Samaria,
4.5: he came to a city of Samaria, called Sychar, near the piece of ground that Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
4.6: now Jacob's well was there. Jesus therefore being wearied with his journey, sat him down by the well: it being about the sixth hour.
4.7: where a woman of Samaria being come to draw water, Jesus said to her, give me to drink.
4.8: for his disciples were gone away to the city to buy provisions.
4.9: but the woman of Samaria said to him, how is it that you who are a Jew, ask drink of me, who am a Samaritan? (for the Jews have no friendly intercourse with the Samaritans.)
4.10: Jesus answered her, if you knew the dispensation of God, and who it is that says to you, give me to drink; you would have asked of him, and he would have given you living water.
4.11: sir, said the woman, you have nothing to draw with, and the well is deep: whence then can you get that living water?
4.12: are you wiser than our father Jacob, who gave us the well, and drank thereof himself, as well as his children, and cattle?
4.14: but whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him, shall never thirst: for the water that I shall give him, shall be in him a fountain springing up to everlasting life.
4.15: sir, replied the woman, give me this water, that I may never be adry, nor come hither to draw more.
4.16: go, call your husband, said Jesus, and come again.
4.17: the woman answered, I have no husband. Jesus replied, you were in the right to say you have no husband:
4.18: for you have had five husbands, and he whom you now have, is not your husband: in that you said true.
4.19: the woman said to him, sir, I perceive that you are a prophet.
4.20: our fathers worshipped upon this mountain; and you say, that Jerusalem is the place where we ought to perform our worship.
4.22: ye worship ye know not what: we know what we worship: for salvation is from the Jews.
4.23: but the time is coming, nay, is very nigh, when the true worshippers shall worship the father in spirit and in truth: for they are the worshippers which he requires.
4.24: God is a spirit, and they that worship him, must worship him in spirit and in truth.
4.25: then said the woman to him, I know that the Messias (that is to say the Christ) is to come, and when he is come, he will tell us all things.
4.26: Jesus said to her, I that am talking with you am he.
4.27: Upon this his disciples came, and were surpriz'd at his conversing with the woman: yet none of them said, what did you ask her? or, why do you talk with her?
4.28: the woman then left her water-pot, and went away into the city, and said to the people, come,
4.30: so they went out of the city, and came to him.
4.31: In the mean while his disciples invited him, saying, pray master, eat.
4.32: but he answered them, I have meat to eat that ye know not of:
4.34: Jesus said to them, my meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work.
4.36: he that reapeth, receiveth wages, by gathering fruit unto life eternal: that the sower, and the reaper, may both rejoice together.
4.37: upon this occasion, that saying is verified, "one soweth, and another reapeth."
4.38: I sent you to reap where you bestowed no labour: other men laboured, and you are entred into their labours.
4.39: Now many of the Samaritans of that city believed on him, for that testimony which the woman gave him, "he told me all that ever I did."
4.40: so that when the Samaritans were come to him, they desired him to stay with them: and he stay'd there two days.
4.41: and many more believed, for having heard him speak himself: and said to the woman,
4.42: now it is not for what you have said, that we believe: for we have heard him ourselves, and know that this is indeed the saviour of the world, the Christ.
4.43: Two days after, he departed thence, and went into Galilee:
4.44: (tho' Jesus himself had declared, that a prophet is not honoured in his own country.)
4.45: when he was come into Galilee, he was well received by the Galileans, who had seen all that he did at Jerusalem during the feast: for they likewise went to the feast.
4.46: Jesus went therefore a second time to Cana in Galilee, where he had changed the water into wine, now a certain nobleman was there, whose son was sick at Capernaum.
4.47: who having heard that Jesus was come out of Judea into Galilee, he went there to desire him to come down, and heal his son: for he was at the point of death.
4.48: but Jesus said to him, except you see signs and miracles, you will not believe.
4.49: the nobleman said to him, sir, pray come down before my child be dead.
4.50: go thy way, said Jesus: thy son is well, and the man believed what Jesus had said to him, and went his way.
4.51: as he was upon the road, his servants met him, and acquainted him, that his son was well.
4.52: then he enquired of them the hour when he began to mend: and they answered, yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.
4.53: so the father knew that it was at the very same hour, at which Jesus said to him, thy son is well, and he himself believed, and all his family.
4.54: Jesus did this second miracle when he return'd from Judea to Galilee.

5.1: Some time after this the feast of the Jews being come, Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
5.2: now there was at Jerusalem by the sheep-gate a bath, called in Hebrew, Bethesda, which had five portico's.
5.3: where a great number of infirm, blind, lame, and paralytic people lay waiting for the moving of the water:
5.4: (for a messenger went down at certain times into the pool, and agitated the water: the first then that stepped in after this commotion of the water, was cured of whatever disease he had.)
5.5: now a certain man was there, who had been sick eight and thirty years.
5.7: the sick man answered him, sir, I have nobody to put me into the pool when the water has been agitated: but while I am coming, another steppeth down before me.
5.8: rise, said Jesus to him, take up thy bed, and go your way.
5.9: and immediately the man was healed, and took up his bed, and went his way: but that day being the sabbath,
5.10: the Jews said to him that was cured, it is the sabbath-day; it is not lawful for you to carry your bed.
5.11: he answered them, he that cured me said to me, take up your bed and walk.
5.12: then they asked him, who is he that said to you take up your bed and walk?
5.13: and he that was healed, did not know who it was: for Jesus had slip'd away, by favour of the crowd that was there.
5.14: sometime after Jesus met him in the temple, and said to him, you see you were cured: sin no more, lest you suffer something worse.
5.15: then the man departed to acquaint the Jews, that it was Jesus who had cured him.
5.16: upon which occasion the Jews persecuted Jesus, and sought to slay him, because he did such things on the sabbath-day.
5.17: But Jesus answered them, my father works without intermission, and so do I.
5.18: therefore the Jews were the more eager to kill him, because he had not only violated the sabbath, but likewise, because he had said that God was his proper father, making himself equal with God.
5.19: upon which Jesus said to them, verily, verily I say unto you, the son can do nothing of himself, except he sees the father do it: for whatever he doth, that the son does likewise.
5.20: for the father loveth the son, and sheweth him all that he himself doth: and he will shew him greater works than these, so that you will be surprized.
5.21: for as the father raiseth up the dead, and restores them to life: even so the son gives life to whom he will.
5.22: besides, the father judgeth no man; but hath committed the full power of judging unto the son:
5.23: that all men should honour the son, even as they honour the father, he that honoureth not the son, honoureth not the father who hath sent him.
5.24: I declare unto you, he that heareth my doctrine, and believeth on him that sent me, hath everlasting life, and shall not come under condemnation; but is passed from death unto life.
5.25: I declare unto you, the time is coming, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the son of God: and they that hear shall live.
5.26: for as the father hath life in himself; so hath he given to the son, to have life in himself;
5.27: and hath given him authority to execute judgment also, because he is the son of man.
5.29: shall rise to the possession of life; and they that have done evil, shall rise to their condemnation.
5.30: Of my self I can do nothing: according to my instructions I judge: and my judgment is just; because I do not consult my own will, but the will of the father who hath sent me.
5.31: if I testified of my self, my testimony would be suspected.
5.32: there is another who testifies of me, and I know that the testimony which he gives of me, is true.
5.33: you yourselves sent to John, and he bore witness to the truth.
5.34: not that I need the testimony of men: but this I tell you, for your own security.
5.35: he was a burning and a shining light: and you were willing to be entertain'd for a while with his light.
5.37: and the father who sent me, hath himself born witness of me, his voice you have never heard, nor ever seen his appearance,
5.38: nor will his Logos abide among you: for tho' he hath sent him, you do not believe him.
5.39: You search the scriptures, for you think by their means to have eternal life, and they are the very writings which do testify of me.
5.40: yet you will not come to me, that ye may have life.
5.41: I do not by this seek your applause.
5.42: for this I know of you, that you are not possess'd with any love for God.
5.43: I am come in my father's name, and you receive me not: if another should come in his own name, him you will receive.
5.44: how can you believe, who are catching at honour one from another, regardless of that glory that comes from God only?
5.46: for had you believed Moses, you would have believed me: since he has spoke of me in his writings.
5.47: but if you don't believe what he has writ, how should you believe what I say?

6.1: At length Jesus passed over the sea of Galilee, which is the sea of Tiberias;
6.2: where a great multitude followed him, invited by the miraculous cures which they saw him perform.
6.3: Jesus therefore went up a mountain, where he sat down with his disciples.
6.4: for it was just before the passover, which is a feast of the Jews.
6.5: Jesus then lifting up his eyes, and seeing a great company coming to him, said to Philip, where can we buy bread to feed this people?
6.6: (this he said to prove Philip: for he himself knew what he had to do.)
6.7: Philip answered him, two hundred penny-worth of bread is not sufficient to furnish every one of them a little.
6.8: one of his disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, said to him,
6.9: there is a lad here, who hath five barley-loaves, and two small fishes: but what are they among so many?
6.10: but Jesus said, make the men sit down, and as there was much grass in the place, they sat down to the number of about five thousand.
6.11: then Jesus took the loaves, and when he had given thanks, he distributed to them that were sate down; and likewise of the fishes, as much as they would.
6.12: when they were filled, he said to his disciples, gather up the fragments that remain, that nothing be lost.
6.13: they gathered them therefore, and filled twelve baskets with the fragments of the five barley-loaves, which remained after they all had been eating.
6.14: The people, when they had seen the miracle that Jesus did, cry'd out, this is of a truth that prophet who was to come into the world.
6.15: but Jesus perceiving they designed to come and take him by force to make him a king, retired again upon a mountain all alone.
6.16: When even was come, his disciples went to the sea, and going on board a ship,
6.17: they cross'd the sea to Capernaum: now when it was dark, Jesus was not come to them:
6.18: but the sea ran high, by reason of the wind that blew hard.
6.19: so when they had rowed about five and twenty, or thirty furlongs, seeing Jesus walking on the sea, and drawing nigh to the ship, they were frightned.
6.20: but he said to them, it is I, be not afraid.
6.21: then they readily received him into the ship: and immediately the ship was at the land whither they were bound.
6.22: The day following, the people who stay'd on the other side of the sea, perceiving that there had been only that single vessel in which his disciples were embark'd, that Jesus did not embark with his disciples, but that his disciples were gone away alone: (however,
6.23: there came other barks from Tiberias, nigh the place where they had eaten bread, after the Lord had given thanks.)
6.24: the people likewise seeing that Jesus was not in those barks, nor his disciples, went on board them, and cross'd to Capernaum in quest of Jesus.
6.25: And when they had found him on the other side of the sea, they said unto him, master, when did you arrive here?
6.26: Jesus answered them, I declare unto you, you seek me, not because ye saw the miracles, but because ye had loaves to eat, and were filled.
6.27: work not for the food which perisheth, but for that which endureth unto everlasting life, and which the son of man shall give unto you, for to him it is that the father, that is God, has given his credentials.
6.28: then said they to him, what shall we do, that our works may he agreeable to God?
6.29: Jesus answered them, the work which God requires is to believe on him whom he hath sent.
6.30: but said they, what miracle then will you let us see to make us believe you? what strange work will you perform?
6.31: our fathers did eat manna in the desert; as it is written, "he gave them bread from heaven to eat."
6.32: Jesus answer'd, I assure you, Moses did not give you the celestial bread; but my father gives you the true celestial bread.
6.33: for he who is descended from heaven, and gives life to the world, is the bread that is truely divine.
6.34: then said they, Lord, evermore give us this bread.
6.35: Jesus answer'd, I am the bread of life: he that cometh to me, shall never hunger; and he that believeth on me, shall never thirst.
6.36: but I have already told you, that tho' you have seen me, you do not believe.
6.37: all those whom my father gives me, shall come to me; and I will not reject any that come to me.
6.38: for I came down from heaven, not to do my own will, but the will of him that sent me.
6.39: and the will of him who sent me is this, that I should not lose any one of those he has given me, but should raise them again at the last day: this,
6.40: I say, is the will of him that sent me, that every one who observes the son, and believeth on him, should have everlasting life: and I will raise him up at the last day.
6.41: The Jews then murmured against him, for having said, "I am the bread which came down from heaven."
6.42: is not this, said they, Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? how comes he then to say, I came down from heaven?
6.43: Jesus therefore replied, murmur not among your selves.
6.44: no man can come to me, except the father who hath sent me, conduct him: and I will raise him up at the last day.
6.45: it is written in the prophets, "they shall be all taught of God." every man therefore that hath heard the father, and been instructed by him, cometh unto me.
6.46: not that any man hath seen the father, except him who is come from God, he hath seen the father.
6.47: I declare unto you, he that believeth on me hath everlasting life.
6.48: I am the bread of life,
6.49: your fathers did eat manna in the wilderness, and there they died.
6.50: but this is the bread which came down from heaven, that he who eats thereof should not die.
6.51: I am the living bread, that is come down from heaven: whosoever shall eat of this bread, shall live for ever: and the bread that I will give, is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.
6.52: Upon this the Jews disputed among themselves, saying, how can this man give us his flesh to eat?
6.53: but Jesus answer'd, I assure you, except ye eat the flesh of the son of man, and drink his blood, ye will have no life in you.
6.54: he that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, hath eternal life, and I will raise him up at the last day.
6.55: for my flesh is meat indeed, and my blood is drink indeed.
6.56: he that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, dwelleth in me, and I in him.
6.57: as the father who is the source of life hath sent me, and I live by the father: so he that eateth me, even he shall live by me.
6.58: this is that bread which came down from heaven: very different from that manna, which your fathers did eat but died nevertheless: he that eateth of this bread, shall live for ever.
6.59: These things said Jesus in the synagogue, as he taught in Capernaum.
6.60: when many of his disciples, who heard him, said, this is strange doctrine, who can hear it?
6.62: what if you should see the son of man ascend up where he was before?
6.63: it is the action of the mind that vivifies, that of the body profits nothing: the words that I have delivered to you, spiritually understood, give life.
6.64: but there are some of you who do not believe. (for Jesus knew from the beginning, who they were that did not believe, and who should betray him.)
6.65: and he said, therefore said I unto you, that no man can come unto me, except it were given unto him of my father.
6.66: From that time many of his disciples withdrew, and associated no longer with him.
6.67: upon which Jesus said to the twelve, will not ye likewise go away?
6.68: but Simon Peter answered, Lord, to whom shall we go? you have the words of eternal life.
6.69: and we have believed and we have acknowledged that you are the Christ, the son of God.
6.71: meaning Judas Iscariot the son of Simon: for he it was that would betray him, altho' he was one of the twelve.

7.1: After this Jesus resided in Galilee: for he would not be in Judea, because the Jews sought to kill him, now the
7.2: Jews feast of the tabernacles drawing nigh,
7.3: his relations said to him, retire hence, and go into Judea, that your disciples there may also see the works that you do.
7.4: for no body acts in private, that designs to distinguish himself: since you do such things, shew yourself to the world.
7.5: for even his brethren did not believe in him.
7.6: but Jesus said to them, my time is not yet come: but any time is equally proper for you.
7.7: the world cannot hate you; but me it hateth, because I plainly show, that their works are evil.
7.8: do you go up to this feast, as for me I do not go with you to it, because my time is not yet accomplished.
7.9: thus he delivered his mind, and stay'd himself in Galilee.
7.10: but when his brethren were gone, he went likewise to the feast, not openly, but in secret.
7.11: during the feast the Jews were in search of him, and said, where can he be?
7.12: and the people were much divided about him: for some said, he is a good man: others said, not at all; but he seduces the people.
7.13: However, no body talk'd openly in favour of him, for fear of the Jews.
7.14: but about the middle of the feast, Jesus went publickly into the temple, and taught.
7.15: at which the Jews were surprized, saying, how came be acquainted with the scriptures, a man of no education?
7.16: Jesus answered them, the doctrine I deliver is not my own, but his that sent me.
7.17: if any man is inclin'd to do his will, he shall know whether the doctrine be from God, or whether I speak from my self.
7.18: he that speaks from himself, has a view to his own glory: but he that has a view to his glory that sent him, deserves credit, and is a stranger to all imposture.
7.19: was it not Moses who gave you the law, and yet none of you observe that law?
7.20: for what do ye attempt to kill me? the people answered, saying, you are mad: who attempts to kill you?
7.21: Jesus answered them, I perform'd one single miracle on the sabbath, and does that alarm you?
7.23: if to avoid the violation of the Mosaic law, a man be exposed to circumcision on the sabbath-day, are ye angry at me, because I cured a man, whose whole body was indisposed on the sabbath-day?
7.24: judge not according to appearances, but judge according to equity.
7.25: Then some that belong'd to Jerusalem, said, is not this he whom they seek to kill?
7.26: yet there he is talking publickly without any opposition: are not the rulers convinc'd that he is the Messiah?
7.27: however, we know from what quarter this man comes: but when Christ comes it will be unknown whence he came.
7.28: Jesus then pursuing his discourse in the temple, rais'd his voice, and said, you know both who I am, and whence I am: however, I am not come of my self, but he that sent me is worthy of belief, him you are unacquainted with.
7.29: but I know him, for I am from him, and he hath sent me.
7.30: then they design'd to seize him: but no man laid hands on him, because his hour was not yet come.
7.31: besides many of the people believed on him, and said, when Christ comes, will he do more miracles than this man hath done?
7.32: (the Pharisees being inform'd what the people rumour'd concerning him, they and the chief priests sent their officers to seize him.)
7.33: then said Jesus, I shall be with you but for a little time, and then I shall go to him that sent me.
7.34: ye shall seek me, but shall not find me: and where I shall go, thither ye cannot come.
7.35: upon which the Jews said among themselves, whither will he go, that we cannot find him? will he go to the dispersed Jews among the Greeks, and instruct the Greeks?
7.36: what does he mean by saying, "ye shall seek me, and shall not find me: and where I go, thither ye cannot come?"
7.37: In the last day, the most solemn day of the feast, Jesus being there, raised his voice, and said, if any man thirst, let him come to me, and drink.
7.38: he that believeth on me, as the scripture hath said, out of his heart shall flow rivers of living water.
7.39: (but this he meant of the spirit, which they that believed on him, should receive: for the spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.)
7.40: many of the people therefore, who heard this discourse, said, this man is certainly a prophet.
7.41: some said, this is the Messias, but said others, shall the Messias come out of Galilee?
7.42: hath not the scripture said, that the Messiah is to rise out of the family of David, and out of Bethlehem, the village where David was born?
7.43: so that the people were divided in their opinions about him.
7.44: and some of them had a mind to seize him; but nobody laid hands on him.
7.45: when the officers return'd to the chief priests and Pharisees, they asked them, why have ye not brought him?
7.46: the officers answered, never did man speak like this man.
7.47: upon which the Pharisees answered, are ye also seduced?
7.48: have any of the rulers, or of the Pharisees believed on him?
7.49: but the populace, who are ignorant of the law, are such wretches.
7.50: thereupon Nicodemus, he that came to Jesus by night, and was then present,
7.51: said to them, said to them, doth our law condemn any man before he is heard, without knowing the fact?
7.52: they answered him, are you also of Galilee? search the scriptures, and you will not find that a prophet did ever arise out of Galilee.
7.53: and every man went to his own house.

8.1: Then Jesus went to the mount of olives.
8.2: but early in the morning he return'd to the temple, where all the people came to him; and being sat down, he instructed them.
8.3: then the Scribes and Pharisees brought a woman surprized in adultery; and when they had set her in the middle of the assembly,
8.4: they said to him, master, this woman was actually taken in adultery.
8.5: now Moses has ordain'd in the law, that such criminals should be stoned: but what is your opinion?
8.6: they said this only to ensnare him, that they might have some accusation against him, but Jesus stooped down, and with his finger wrote on the ground.
8.7: and as they pressed him to answer, he rais'd himself, and said to them, he that is without sin among you, let him be the first that throws a stone at her.
8.8: then stooping down again, he wrote on the ground.
8.9: but they who heard that, being convicted by their own conscience, they all went old and young one after another, so that Jesus was left alone with the woman, who still kept her place.
8.10: then Jesus raising himself, and seeing none but the woman there, he said to her, woman, where are your accusers? hath no man condemned thee?
8.11: Lord, said she, no man, and Jesus said to her, neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more.
8.12: Jesus then having reassumed his discourse, said to them, I am the light of the world: he that followeth me, shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.
8.13: the Pharisees therefore said to him, you give a testimony of your self, your testimony is not valid.
8.15: you pass sentence according to your passions: I pass sentence on no man;
8.16: and yet if I did judge, my judgment is true: for I am not alone, but I am with the father who has sent me.
8.17: now it is written in your law, that the testimony of two men is valid.
8.18: I indeed do bear testimony of my self, but the father, who has sent me, beareth witness of me likewise.
8.19: then said they to him, where is thy father: Jesus answered, ye neither know me, nor my father: if ye knew me, ye would have known my father also.
8.20: Jesus delivered this discourse in the treasury, when he taught in the temple: and no man laid hands on him, for his hour was not yet come.
8.21: Jesus therefore repeated what he had said, "I go my way, and ye shall seek me, and shall die in your incredulity, so that whither I go, ye cannot come."
8.22: then said the Jews, what, will he kill himself? that he says, "whither I go, you cannot come."
8.23: and he said to them, ye are from beneath, I am from above: ye are of this world, I am not of this world.
8.24: therefore I said to you, that ye shall die in your sins: for if you don't believe me to be what I am, ye shall die in your sins.
8.25: then said they to him, what art thou? and Jesus answered them, I am what I just now told you.
8.26: I have many things to say against you: but I only say He that sent me is worthy of belief; and what I have heard of Him, that only I publish to the world.
8.27: but they did not perceive that he meant the father.
8.28: Jesus said therefore to them, when ye have lift up the son of man, then shall ye know what I am, and that I do nothing of my self, but speak as my father hath instructed me.
8.29: he that sent me, is with me: the father hath not left me alone, for I always do what is agreeable to him.
8.30: upon this discourse many believed on him.
8.31: Jesus said therefore to those Jews who believed on him, if you adhere to my doctrine, then will you be my disciples indeed; and ye shall know the truth,
8.32: and the truth shall make you free.
8.33: they answered him, we are Abraham's offspring, and were never slaves to any man: why then do you say, "ye shall be made free?"
8.34: Jesus answered them, I declare unto you, whosoever committeth sin, is a slave to sin.
8.35: a slave has no right to be in the house for life: but the son is settled there.
8.36: if the son therefore shall make you free, you will be free indeed.
8.37: I know you are Abraham's offspring; but ye seek to kill me, because my doctrine doth not penetrate into you.
8.38: what I have learnt from my father, that I tell: and what you have learnt from your father, that you do.
8.40: but now ye seek to kill me, the man who has told you the truth, such as I have learnt it of God: Abraham did not act thus.
8.41: your actions are like your father, at this they reply'd, we are no bastards; we have but one father, even God.
8.42: Jesus said to them, if God were your father, ye would love me: for I was commissioned by God to come; I did not come of my self, but he sent me.
8.43: why do not you understand my language? unless because ye cannot bear my doctrine?
8.44: you, who have the devil for your father, will execute the designs of your father: he was a murderer from the beginning, and deserted the truth, since he has no love for the truth: when he lyes, he speaks like himself: for he is a lyar, and the father of a lyar.
8.45: but as to me, because I tell you the truth, you do not believe me.
8.46: which of you can convict me of sin? if then I say the truth, why don't you believe me?
8.47: he that is of God, does therefore observe what God says: which you do not observe, because ye are not of God.
8.49: Jesus answered, I am not mad; but I honour my father, and you dishonour me.
8.50: I do not consult my own glory: there is one that will consult that, and judge accordingly.
8.51: verily, verily, I say unto you, whoever observes my doctrine, shall never die.
8.52: upon this said the Jews to him, now we plainly perceive you are mad. Abraham is dead, and the prophets too; and yet you say, if a man observes your doctrine, he shall never die.
8.53: are you greater than our father Abraham, who is dead? the prophets likewise are dead: pray, what do you then pretend to be?
8.54: Jesus answered, if I honour'd my self, my honour would be vain: it is my father that honoureth me, of whom ye say, that he is your God.
8.55: yet ye have not known him, but I know him: and if I should say, I know him not, I should be a lyar like you: but I know him, and observe his commands.
8.56: your father Abraham long'd to see my day: and he saw it, and was glad.
8.57: then said the Jews to him, you are not yet fifty years old, and have you seen Abraham?
8.58: Jesus said to them, verily, verily I say unto you, before Abraham was I AM.
8.59: then took they up stones to cast at him: but Jesus was conceal'd by the crowd which he pass'd thro', and so got out of the temple.

9.1: As Jesus passed by, he saw a man that was born blind.
9.2: and his disciples propos'd to him this question, master, was it for his own sins, or for the sins of his parents, that he was born blind?
9.3: it was not for any sin of his, said Jesus, or of his parents: but that the works of God might be displayed thro' him.
9.4: I must perform the works of him that sent me, while it is day: the night is coming, when no man can work.
9.5: while I am in the world, I am the light of the world.
9.6: having said this, he spit on the ground, which by means of his saliva he made into clay, wherewith he anointed the eyes of the blind man,
9.7: and said to him, go wash in the pool of Siloam (a word which signifies sent.) so he went and washed, and came seeing.
9.8: the neighbours therefore, and they who before had seen him begging, said, is not this he that used to sit begging?
9.9: this is he, said some; he is like him, said others: but he said, I am the man.
9.10: thereupon they said to him, how did you come to your sight?
9.11: he answered, a man call'd Jesus made clay, and anointed my eyes, and said to me, go to the pool of Siloam, and wash: I went, and washed, and so I saw.
9.12: then said they to him, where is he? I don't know, said he.
9.13: This very man that had been blind, was at length brought to the Pharisees.
9.14: now it was the sabbath-day when Jesus made the clay, and gave him his sight.
9.15: the Pharisees therefore ask'd him likewise, how he had received his sight, he told them, he put clay upon mine eyes, and I washed, and now see.
9.16: thereupon some of the Pharisees said, this man has no divine mission, because he does not observe the sabbath, but said others, if he be an impostor, how can he do such miracles? and there was a schism among them.
9.17: they therefore question'd the blind man again, what do you say of the man that made you see? he is a prophet, said he.
9.18: but the Jews were so incredulous about his having been blind, and obtain'd sight, that they sent for his parents,
9.19: and ask'd them, is this your son, who you say was born blind? how came it then that he now sees?
9.20: his parents answered, that this is our son, and that he was born blind: we are very certain.
9.21: but by what means it was that he now sees, that we know not; or who made him see, we know not: he is of age, ask him, he will answer for himself.
9.22: his parents said this, because they were afraid of the Jews: for the Jews had agreed in this, that if any man did own him for the Messias, he should be excommunicated.
9.23: it was this made his parents say, "he is of age, ask him."
9.24: They therefore again call'd the man that had been blind, and said to him, in the name of God tell the truth: for we know that this man is an impostor.
9.25: whether he be so or not, said he, I don't know: one thing I very well know, that once I was blind, and now I see.
9.26: they still urg'd the same question, what did he do to thee? how did he make you see?
9.27: I have already told you that, said he, and did you not hear it? why would ye hear it over again? have you likewise a mind to be his disciples?
9.28: then they reviled him, and said, thou art his disciple; but we are Moses disciples.
9.29: we know that God commission'd Moses: as for this fellow, we don't know who sent him.
9.30: the man replied, that's very strange that he should make me see, and you should not know who sent him.
9.31: now 'tis certain, that God does not countenance impostors: but regards him only that is religious, and executes his commands.
9.32: It was never heard since the world began, that any man gave sight to one that was born blind.
9.33: if this man had not his mission from God, he could do nothing.
9.34: they answered, you were a vicious fellow from your very birth, and do you pretend to preach to us? and then they excommunicated him.
9.36: he answered and said, who is he, Lord, that I may believe on him?
9.37: Jesus said to him, not only thou hast seen him, but it is he himself that is talking with thee.
9.38: then said he to Jesus, Lord, I believe: and prostrated himself before him.
9.40: some of the Pharisees who were then present hearing this, said to him, are we likewise blind?
9.41: Jesus said to them, if you were blind, you would be excusable; but since you own that you see, you stand convicted.

10.1: I assure you, he that entreth not by the door into the sheep-fold, but climbeth up some other way, is a thief and a robber.
10.2: but he that enters in by the door, is the pastor of the sheep.
10.3: the porter lets him in, and the sheep know his voice: he calls his own sheep by name, and leads them out to pasture.
10.4: when he lets out his own sheep, he goes before them, and the sheep follow him: because they know his voice.
10.5: a stranger they will not follow, but flee from him: for they know not the voice of strangers.
10.6: Jesus talk'd to them in this figurative way: but they did not understand the meaning of his discourse.
10.7: Jesus therefore subjoin'd, I declare unto you, I am the door of the sheep-fold.
10.8: they who have personated me, are all thieves and robbers: but the sheep did not follow them.
10.9: I am the door: by me if any man enter in, he shall be saved; he shall go in and out, and find pasture.
10.10: the thief comes only to steal, to kill, and destroy: but I am come that they might have life, and have it with all its advantages.
10.11: I am the true pastor: the true pastor exposes his life for the sheep.
10.12: but the hireling, who is not the pastor, nor has the property of the sheep, seeing the wolf come, leaves the sheep, and flies away: so the wolf seizes some, and disperses the flock.
10.13: the hireling flies, because he is an hireling, and is under no concern for the sheep.
10.14: I am the true pastor, I know my sheep, and my sheep know me,
10.15: (as the father and I are known to one another:) and I lay down my life for them.
10.16: other sheep I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring; they will hear my voice; and so there shall be but one fold, and one pastor.
10.17: therefore doth my father love me, because I lay down my life, but I shall reassume it.
10.18: no man can take it from me, but I voluntarily lay it down: I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again, this is the order I have received from my father.
10.19: There was another schism therefore among the Jews, occasion'd by this discourse.
10.20: for many of them said, he is possess'd with a demon, and is mad; why do you mind him?
10.21: others said, this is not the language of one possess'd: can a demon give sight to the blind?
10.22: At length the feast of the dedication was kept at Jerusalem, when the weather happen'd to be foul.
10.23: as Jesus therefore was walking in the temple in Solomon's portico,
10.24: the Jews came about him, and said, how long will you keep us in suspense? if you are the Messiah, tell us plainly.
10.25: Jesus answered them, I told you, and ye did not believe me: the works that I do in my father's name, they testify of me.
10.26: but, as I said before, you do not believe; because ye are not of my sheep.
10.27: my sheep hear my voice, I know them, and they follow me.
10.28: it is I that give them eternal life, and they shall never perish, neither shall any one force them out of my hand.
10.29: my father who gave them me, is greater than all: so that no one is able to force them out of my father's hand.
10.30: I and my father are one.
10.31: then the Jews took up stones again to stone him.
10.32: Jesus answered them, many good works have I shewed you from my father; for which of those works would you stone me?
10.34: Jesus answered them, is it not written in your law, "I said ye are Gods?"
10.35: if the law stiles them Gods, who received the orders of God, and if the scripture is of any authortiy,
10.36: how can you say that I blaspheme, I whom the father hath sanctified, and sent into the world, because I said I am the son of God?
10.37: if I do not the works of my father, believe me not.
10.38: but if I do, though ye believe not me, believe the works: that ye may know and believe that the father is in me, and I in him.
10.39: Thereupon they again endeavour'd to seize him: but he escaped out of their hands, and retir'd beyond Jordan,
10.40: to the place where John at first baptized; and there he abode.
10.41: and many resorted unto him, and said, John did no miracle: but every thing that he said concerning this man, was true.
10.42: so that many people there believed on him.

11.1: Now a certain man was sick, named Lazarus, who was of Bethany, the town of Mary, and of Martha her sister.
11.2: (it was that Mary who perfum'd the Lord with ointment, after having wiped his feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.)
11.3: his two sisters therefore sent this message to Jesus; he, Lord, whom you love, is sick.
11.4: when Jesus heard that, he said, the disease is not to be mortal, but is design'd for the glory of God, that the son of God might be glorified thereby.
11.5: now Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus.
11.6: however, he stay'd in the place where he was, even two days after he had heard that Lazarus was sick.
11.7: and then he said to his disciples, let us return to Judea.
11.10: but if a man travels by night he stumbles, because there is no light for him.
11.11: thus he entertain'd them: and after that, he said to them, our friend Lazarus is asleep; but I am going to awake him.
11.12: then said his disciples, Lord, if he sleep, he will recover;
11.13: though Jesus meant it of Lazarus's death: but they understood it of the natural rest in sleep.
11.14: then Jesus told them plainly, Lazarus is dead.
11.15: and I am glad for your sakes that I was not there (to the intent you may believe) but now, let us go to him.
11.16: then said Thomas, that is, Didymus, to his fellow-disciples, let us also go, that we may die with him.
11.17: When Jesus was arriv'd, he found that Lazarus had been then four days in the grave.
11.18: now Bethany being distant from Jerusalem but about fifteen furlongs,
11.19: many of the Jews came to Martha and Mary, to condole with them upon the loss of their brother.
11.20: Martha, as soon as she heard that Jesus was coming, went to meet him: but Mary stay'd at home.
11.21: Lord, said Martha to Jesus, if you had been here, my brother had not been dead.
11.22: but yet even now whatever you shall ask of God, I know God will grant it to you.
11.23: Jesus said to her, your brother shall rise again.
11.24: Martha said to him, I know that he shall rise again at the resurrection of the last day.
11.25: Jesus said to her, I am the resurrection, and the life: he that believeth in me shall live even though he were dead:
11.26: and no man living that believeth in me, shall ever die.
11.27: do you believe this? yes, Lord, said Martha, I believe that thou art the Messiah the son of God, who was to come into the world.
11.28: When she had said this, she went privately to call Mary her sister, saying, the master is come, and calls for you.
11.29: no sooner she heard that, but she arose with all speed, and came to him.
11.30: for Jesus was not yet arrived in the town, but staid at the place were Martha met him.
11.31: the Jews then who were with Mary in the house to comfort her, when they saw that she rose in such haste, and went out, followed her, saying, she is going to the grave to weep there.
11.32: Mary being come to the place where Jesus was, as soon as she saw him, she fell down at his feet, saying, Lord, if you had been here, my brother had not been dead.
11.33: when Jesus therefore saw her weeping, and the Jews also weeping who came with her, he sighed from his heart, and was troubled,
11.36: upon which the Jews said, see how he loved him.
11.38: Jesus then again sighing, came to the sepulchre which was a cave, shut up by a stone.
11.42: I know that thou hearest me always: but I say this, because of the people here present, that they may believe that thou hast sent me."
11.43: when he had spoke this, he cried with a loud voice, Lazarus, come forth.
11.44: and he that was dead came forth, his body wrapt in a winding sheet: and his face bound about with a napkin, loose him, said Jesus, and let him go.
11.45: many therefore of the Jews who came to see Mary, and had seen what Jesus had done, believed on him.
11.46: But some of them went to the Pharisees, and told them what Jesus had done.
11.47: upon this the chief priests and the Pharisees being assembled in council, said, what shall we do? for this man performs many miracles.
11.48: if we let him go on at this rate, all will believe on him; and the Romans will come, and destroy both our temple and nation.
11.49: but one of them named Caiaphas, being the high priest at that time, said to them, ye don't know what you are about.
11.50: you little consider it is our interest, that one man should die for the people, to prevent the destruction of the whole nation.
11.51: now this he did not say from his own motion: but being high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus should die for the nation:
11.52: and not for that nation only, but likewise to reassemble the dispersed children of God into one body.
11.53: from that day therefore, they consulted together to put Jesus to death.
11.54: For which reason he did not afterwards appear publickly among the Jews; but retir'd into the country near the desart, to a city called Ephraim, and there continued with his disciples.
11.55: now the passover of the Jews being nigh: the people of that country went in great numbers to Jerusalem before the passover, in order to purify themselves.
11.56: when they were in the temple, they enquired for Jesus, and said to one another, do you think he will not be at the feast?
11.57: now both the chief priests and the Pharisees had publish'd an order, that if any man knew where he was, he should give information in order to have him seized.

12.1: Six days before the passover Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus was, who had been dead, and raised to life again.
12.2: there a supper was provided for him; Martha was in waiting: but Lazarus was one of the guests that sat at table with him.
12.3: but Mary taking a pound of the oil of spikenard which was very costly, anointed the feet of Jesus, and wiped them with her hair: so that the house was filled with the odour of the perfume.
12.4: whereupon one of his disciples, Judas Iscariot, Simon's son, who was to betray him,
12.5: said, why was not this ointment sold for three hundred pence, to be given to the poor?
12.6: this he said, not out of any concern for the poor; but because being purse-bearer he used to pilfer what was in bank.
12.7: then said Jesus, let her alone: against the day of my burial hath she kept this.
12.8: the poor you will always have with you; but me you will not always have.
12.9: a great multitude of Jews knowing that Jesus was there, went thither, not for his sake only, but likewise to see Lazarus, whom he had raised from the dead.
12.10: for the chief priests had resolved to put even Lazarus to death;
12.11: because he was the occasion that many of the Jews left them, and believed on Jesus.
12.12: The next day, a crowd of people that were come to the feast, hearing that Jesus was on the road to Jerusalem, took branches of palm-trees,
12.14: now Jesus was riding upon a young ass, which he got by the way; as it is written,
12.16: this passage his disciples did not understand at the first: but when Jesus was glorified, they remembred how they had mounted him, and perceiv'd that those words related to him.
12.17: the people that were present testified, that he called Lazarus out of his grave, and raised him from the dead.
12.18: and it was upon the rumour of this miracle, that the people crowded to him.
12.19: the Pharisees therefore said among themselves, don't you perceive we lose ground? you see what a world of followers attend him.
12.20: In the mean time, among the rest that came to worship at the feast,
12.21: there were certain Greeks, who address'd themselves to Philip, who was of Bethsaida in Galilee, saying, sir, we would fain see Jesus.
12.22: Philip went to tell Andrew: and then both of them mention'd it to Jesus.
12.23: but Jesus answered them, saying, the time is come, when the son of man is to be glorified.
12.24: verily, verily I say unto you, when a corn of wheat is thrown into the ground, there it lies a single grain unless it dies: but if it die, it becomes very fruitful.
12.25: he that loveth his life, shall lose it: but he that sacrifices his life in this world, shall preserve it to eternity.
12.26: if any man would serve me, let him follow me; and where I am, there also shall my servant be: whoever serves me, him will my father reward.
12.28: father, glorify thy name." then there came this voice from heaven, "I have glorified it, and will glorify it again."
12.29: the people therefore present who heard the noise, said it was thunder: others said, an angel spake to him.
12.30: Jesus said, this voice came not for my sake, but for yours.
12.31: now is this world condemn'd: now shall the prince of this world be cast out.
12.32: as for me, when I shall be lifted up from the earth, I will draw all men unto me.
12.33: (this he said to signify what death he should die.)
12.34: Upon which the people said to him, we have learnt from the law, that the Messiah is to live for ever: why do you say then, the son of man must be lift up? who is this son of man?
12.35: Jesus answer'd them, yet a little while is the light with you: walk while ye have the light, lest darkness surprize you: for he that walketh in darkness, does not know whither he goes.
12.36: while ye have the light, believe in the light, that ye may be the children of light, after having said these things, Jesus retir'd, and conceal'd himself from them.
12.37: But though he had done so many miracles in their presence, yet they did not believe on him:
12.38: so that the passage of Esaias the prophet was fulfilled, where he says, "Lord, who hath believed our report? and to whom hath the arm of the Lord been revealed?
12.39: therefore they could not believe, according to what Esaias said in another place, "he hath blinded their eyes,
12.40: and hardned their heart; that they should not see with their eyes, nor understand with their heart, and be converted, and I should heal them."
12.41: these things said Esaias, when he saw his glory, and spake of him.
12.42: nevertheless there were many even among the chief rulers, who believed on him; but they did not own it publickly for fear the Pharisees should excommunicate them.
12.43: for they preferr'd their own reputation to the glory of God.
12.44: Then Jesus rais'd his voice, and said, he that believeth on me, does not so much believe on me, as on him that sent me.
12.45: and he that contemplates me, contemplates him that sent me.
12.46: I am come a light into the world, that whosoever believeth on me, might not abide in darkness.
12.47: but if any man hear my words, and does not believe them, it is not I that condemn him: for I came not to condemn the world, but to save the world.
12.48: he that rejecteth me, and does not embrace my doctrine, hath one that condemns him: the doctrine that I have delivered, that shall condemn him in the last day.
12.49: for I have not spoken for my self; but the father who sent me, he commission'd me, what I should teach, and what I should speak.
12.50: and I know that it is a commission of eternal life: whatever therefore I say, I deliver just as the father directed me.

13.1: Now before the feast of the passover, Jesus perceiving that his hour was come, when he was to pass out of this world, and go to the father, having loved his own which were in the world, he loved them unto the end.
13.2: while they were at supper, (the devil having now put it into the heart of Judas Iscariot, Simon's son, to betray him) Jesus,
13.3: though he knew that the father had given all things into his hands, and that he was come from God, and was going to God,
13.4: rose from supper, laid aside his garment, and took a towel to wrap about him.
13.5: after that, he poured water into a bason, and began to wash the disciples feet, and to wipe them with the towel wherewith he was girded.
13.6: then coming to Simon Peter, Peter said to him, Lord, what! would you wash my feet?
13.7: Jesus answered him, you don't at present comprehend what I am about: but hereafter you shall.
13.8: Peter said to him, you shall never wash my feet. Jesus answered, if I do not cleanse thee, you cannot partake with me.
13.9: Simon Peter said to him, Lord, not my feet only, but also my hands and my head.
13.10: Jesus said to him, he that comes out from bathing has occasion only to wash his feet, the rest of his body being clean: so you are clean, but not every one of you.
13.11: for he knew who would betray him; therefore, said he, you are not every one of you clean.
13.13: you call me master, and lord: and you are in the right; for so I am.
13.14: if I then, tho' lord and master, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another's feet.
13.15: for I have given you example, that you might behave to one another, as I have to you.
13.16: I declare unto you, the servant is not greater than his lord, neither he that is sent, greater than he that sent him.
13.17: if ye comprehend these things, happy are ye if ye put them in practice.
13.18: I say not this of you all; for I know whom I have chosen: and that passage of the scripture must be fulfilled, "He that eateth bread with me, hath lift up his heel against me."
13.19: I tell it you now before it happens, that when it is come to pass, you may believe that I am the Messias.
13.20: I declare unto you, he that receiveth him that I send, receiveth me: and he that receiveth me, receiveth him that sent me.
13.21: When Jesus utter'd these words, he was troubled in spirit, and said without disguise, I assure you, that one of you shall betray me.
13.22: then the disciples looked one on another, being in pain to know who he meant.
13.23: now the favourite disciple of Jesus sat next to him at table.
13.24: Simon Peter therefore beckoned to him, to ask who it was he meant.
13.25: then accordingly bending his head to Jesus's ear, he whisper'd, Lord, who is it?
13.26: Jesus answered, he it is, to whom I shall give a sop, when I have made it, and when he had made the sop, he gave it to Judas Iscariot, the son of Simon.
13.27: and after he had taken the sop, Satan entred into him, then said Jesus to him, what you do, do quickly.
13.28: but the company at table did not know what he meant by saying so.
13.30: Judas then having received the sop, immediately went out: and it was night.
13.31: When he was gone, Jesus said, now is the son of man glorified, and God is glorified by him.
13.32: as God is glorified by him, so God will glorify him in himself, and will immediately glorify him.
13.33: my dear children, I am with you but for a little while, you shall seek me: but as I said to the Jews, so now I say to you, "where I am going you cannot come."
13.35: by this mutual love shall all men know that you are my disciples.
13.36: Simon Peter said to him, Lord, where are you going? Jesus answered him, you cannot at present follow me, where I am going; but hereafter you shall.
13.37: Peter said to him, Lord, why can't I follow you now? I will lay down my life for your sake.
13.38: Jesus answered him, you lay down your life for my sake! Verily, verily I say unto thee, the cock shall not crow, till thou hast denied me thrice.

14.2: in my father's house are many mansions; however, I have told you, I am going to prepare a place for you:
14.3: and when I am gone, and have prepar'd a place for you, I will come again, to take you with me, that where I am there ye may be also.
14.4: and where I am going you know, and the way ye know.
14.5: Thomas said to him, Lord, we know not whither you are going, how then can we know the way?
14.6: Jesus said to him, I am the way, and the truth, and the life: no man can come to the father, but by me.
14.7: if you had known me, you would likewise have known my father: and from henceforth you shall know him, nay, you have seen him.
14.8: Philip said to him, Lord shew us the father, and we are satisfied.
14.9: Jesus said to him, have I been with you so long, and don't you know me yet? Philip, he that hath seen me, hath seen the father; why then do you say, shew us the father?
14.10: don't you believe that I am in the father, and the father in me? the words that I speak unto you, I speak indeed, tho' not from my self; but as to the works, the father, who dwells in me, he is the agent.
14.11: believe me, I am in the father, and the father in me: at least believe me upon account of the very works.
14.12: I assure you, he that believeth on me, shall likewise perform the works that I do; nay, greater works than these shall he do; because for that end am I going to my father.
14.13: and if in my name ye shall ask any thing of the father, whereby he may be glorified by the son, I will effect it.
14.14: when ye shall ask any thing in my name, I will do it.
14.15: if ye love me, keep my commandments.
14.16: and I will pray the father, and he shall give you another advocate, to abide with you for ever;
14.17: even the spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees nor knows him: but ye shall know him, for he shall dwell with you, and shall be in you.
14.18: I will not leave you orphans; I will come again to you.
14.19: yet a little while, and the world shall see me no more: but ye shall see me: because I shall live again, and ye shall live also.
14.20: then shall you know, that I am in my father, and you in me, and I in you.
14.21: he that hath received my commandments, and keeps them, he it is that loves me: and he that loves me, shall be beloved by my father, and I will love him, and shew my self unto him.
14.22: Judas (not Iscariot) said to him, why Lord, will you show your self to us, and not to the world?
14.23: Jesus answered him, he that loves me, will observe my precepts: and my father will love him, and we will come unto him, and make our abode with him.
14.24: he does not love me, who does not observe my precepts: for the doctrine which you have heard, is not mine, but the father's who sent me.
14.25: this is what I have to tell you, for the little time that I am with you.
14.26: but the advocate, the holy spirit, whom the father will send for my sake, he will explain every thing to you, and make you remember, all that I have told you.
14.27: I bid you farewell! I give you my last farewell; but I do not give it out of common formality: don't be concern'd for me, or apprehensive for your selves.
14.28: ye have heard me say, "I am going away, and shall come again unto you." if ye loved me, ye would rejoice at my going to the father: for the father is greater than I.
14.29: this I have told you now, before it come to pass, that when it is come to pass, ye may believe, my conversation will now be but short with you,
14.30: for the prince of the world is coming:
14.31: not that he has any thing against me, but that the world may know that I love the father, by my executing the commands which my father gave me: arise, let us go hence.

15.1: I am the genuine vine, and my father is the vintager.
15.2: every branch in me that beareth not fruit, he takes away: as for the branch that bears fruit, he prunes it clean, to make it more fruitful.
15.3: you are already clean by the instructions I have given you.
15.4: be attach'd to me, and I shall be so to you, as the branch cannot bear fruit of it self, except it be attach'd to the vine: so neither can you, except you continue attach'd to me.
15.5: I am the vine, you are the branches: he that abideth in me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit: for independent of me ye can do nothing.
15.6: if a man abide not in me, he is cast away as withered branches that are gather'd up to be thrown into the fire, where they are burned.
15.7: if ye abide in me, and my words abide in you, ask what ye will, and you shall obtain it.
15.8: my father will be honour'd by your bearing much fruit, and you will have the honour of being my disciples.
15.10: your love to me will be in keeping my commandments: even as I love my father by keeping his commandments.
15.11: These things have I spoken to you, that you might have some present comfort, and that hereafter your joy might be compleat.
15.12: this is my commandment, that ye love one another, as I have loved you.
15.13: there cannot be greater love than that of a man, who lays down his life for his friends.
15.14: you will be my friends, if you do what I have commanded you.
15.15: henceforth I do not treat you as servants; for the servant is unacquainted with his master's affairs: but I have treated you as friends; for what I have learnt of my father, I have communicated to you.
15.16: it was not you that chose me, but I that chose you, and establish'd you, that your travels may be fruitful, and your fruit be lasting: so that whatever ye shall ask of the father for my sake, he will give it you.
15.17: Above all I enjoin you, to love one another.
15.18: if the world hate you, consider that it hated me before it hated you.
15.19: if you were of the world, the world would love its own: but because you are not of the world, but I have chosen you out of the world, therefore the world does hate you.
15.21: but all these things will they do unto you, out of hatred to my name, because they know not him that sent me.
15.22: if I had not appear'd, and inform'd them, they would have been innocent: but now they have no excuse for their sin.
15.23: he that hateth me, hateth my father also.
15.24: if I had not done among them such works as no other ever did, they had been innocent: but though they have seen them, yet they hate both me and my father.
15.25: so that the passage is fulfilled that is written in their law, "they hated me without a cause."
15.26: but when the advocate is come, whom I will send to you from the father, even the spirit of truth, which proceedeth from the father, he shall testify of me.
15.27: and ye also shall bear witness, because ye have been with me from the beginning.

16.1: I have told you these things that ye may not be discouraged.
16.2: they shall expel you out of the synagogues: yea, the time is coming, when it will be thought an agreeable sacrifice to God for any one to take away your lives.
16.3: and thus will they treat you, because they have not known the father, nor me.
16.4: but these things have I told you, that when the time shall come, ye may remember what I now tell you. I did not tell you so much at the beginning, because, I was then to be with you.
16.6: are your minds so overwhelm'd with sorrow at what I told you?
16.7: nevertheless, I tell you the truth; it is expedient for you that I go away: for if I do not go away, the advocate will not come unto you; but if I depart, I will send him to you.
16.8: and when he is come, he will convince the world of sin, of justice, of judgment:
16.9: of sin, because they believ'd not on me;
16.10: of justice, because I shall be with my father, and ye shall see me no more expos'd:
16.11: of judgment, because the prince of this world is condemn'd.
16.12: I have yet many things to tell you, but ye cannot bear them now;
16.13: but when he, the spirit of truth shall come, he will inform you of all those truths: for he will not speak from himself; but the information he shall receive will he communicate: and acquaint you with what is to come.
16.14: he shall glorify me: for he will commuincate to you, the information, which I shall give him.
16.15: all that the father has is mine: that is the reason of my saying, "he shall communicate to you the information that I shall give him."
16.20: verily, verily I say unto you, that ye shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice: ye shall be sorrowful, but your sorrow shall be turned into joy.
16.21: a woman when she is in travail, is afflicted at the approach of her pains: but as soon as she is delivered of the child, the remembrance of her anguish, is lost in her joy, that a man is born into the world.
16.22: so you are afflicted at present: but I will see you again, and then shall your hearts be affected with joy, and your joy shall no one wrest from you.
16.23: tho' then you cannot ask any thing of me in person, whatever ye shall ask the father in my name, I assure you he will grant it.
16.24: hitherto have ye asked nothing in my name: ask, and ye shall receive, that your joy may be compleat.
16.25: These things have I express'd in a figurative way: the time is coming when my language will be no longer enigmatical, but I shall give you a plain account relating to my father.
16.26: though then ye shall ask in my name: I need not promise, that I will pray the father for you;
16.27: for the father himself loveth you, because ye have loved me, and have believed that I had my mission from God.
16.28: I was sent by the father, and am come into the world: but now I leave the world, and am going to my father.
16.29: His disciples said to him, what you say now is plain, and not enigmatical.
16.30: now we are convinc'd that you know all our difficulties, and have no occasion that any man should propose them to you: by this we believe that you were sent from God.
16.33: these things I have appriz'd you of, that ye might repose your confidence in me, the world shall give you trouble: but take courage, I have overcome the world.

17.2: for thou hast given him power over all men, that he might give eternal life to as many as thou hast given him.
17.3: and this is life eternal, to acknowledge thee to be the only true God, and Jesus to be the Messiah whom thou hast sent.
17.4: I have glorified thee on the earth: I have finished the work which thou gavest me to do.
17.5: and now, O father, glorify me in heaven, with the glory which I had before the creation of the world.
17.6: I have displayed thy name among those whom you have chosen out of the world for me: thine they were, and you gave them me; and they have kept thy word.
17.7: now they believe that the instructions you gave me came from thee.
17.8: for I have given to them the instructions which you gave me; and they have received them; and have sincerely believ'd that I came from thee, and are persuaded that thou didst send me.
17.9: "It is for them I pray: I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast given me, because they are thine.
17.10: for every thing that is mine is thine, and what is thine is mine, and I am glorified by them.
17.11: and now I shall be no more in the world, but they will be in the world, when I am come to thee, holy father keep them by that authority, with which thou hast invested me, that they may be one, as we are.
17.12: by your authority I have kept them, during my being with them in the world: those that you gave me I have kept, and not one of them is lost, except the son of perdition: according as the scripture foretold.
17.13: now that I am coming to thee, while I am here, I make these requests for them, that their joy in me may be compleat.
17.14: I have given them thy word; and the world hath hated them, because they are not of the world, even as I am not of the world.
17.15: I do not pray you to take them out of the world, but to keep them from the malignity of it.
17.16: they are not of the world, even as I am not of the world.
17.17: sanctify them by the truth: thy word is truth.
17.18: as thou hast sent me into the world, even so have I also sent them into the world.
17.19: and for their sakes I consecrate myself, that they also might be consecrated by the truth.
17.20: neither pray I for these alone, but for those also who shall believe on me through their preaching.
17.21: that they all may be one, as thou, father, art in me, and I in thee; that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me.
17.22: and the glory which thou gavest me, I have given them: that they may be one, even as we are one.
17.23: I in them, and thou in me, that they may have a perfect union, and that the world may know that thou hast sent me, and hast loved them, as thou hast loved me.
17.25: O righteous father, the world hath not known thee; but I have known thee, and these have known that thou hast sent me.
17.26: to them I have declared thy name, and will declare it: that thou mayst love them as thou hast loved me, and I have loved them."

18.1: When Jesus had spoken these words, he pass'd with his disciples over the brook Cedron, where was a garden, into which he entred with them.
18.2: now Judas, who was to betray him, knew the place: for Jesus and his disciples had frequently assembled there.
18.3: Judas then having got a company of soldiers, and officers, by order of the chief priests and Pharisees, came thither with lanterns, torches, and with arms.
18.4: but Jesus who knew every thing that should happen to him, advanc'd, and said to them, who do you look for?
18.5: they answered him, Jesus of Nazareth. I am he, said Jesus, and Judas who was to betray him, was also with them.
18.6: upon Jesus his saying to them, I am he, they fell backward to the ground.
18.7: then he asked them again, who do you look for? and they said, Jesus of Nazareth.
18.8: Jesus answered, I have told you that I am he. "if therefore it is me you look for, let these go their way."
18.9: so that what he said was accomplished, "of those which thou gavest me, have I lost none."
18.10: but Simon Peter drew his sword, and struck off the right ear of Malchus, a servant belonging to the high priest.
18.11: then said Jesus to Peter, sheath thy sword: the cup which my father hath given me, shall I not drink it?
18.12: Then the soldiers, the captain, and the officers of the Jews seized on Jesus, and having bound him,
18.13: they brought him first to Annas; for he was father-in-law to Caiaphas, who was the high priest at that time:
18.14: the same Caiaphas, who in council told the Jews, "it was expedient that one man should die for the people."
18.15: Simon Peter followed Jesus, with another disciple, who being known to the high priest, was admitted into his palace at the same time with Jesus,
18.16: whilst Peter stood without at the door, but that other disciple, who was known to the high priest went out, and spoke to her that kept the door, who let Peter in.
18.17: then said the damsel, that kept the door, to Peter, are you also one of this man's disciples? I am not, said he.
18.18: now the servants and officers that were there, had made a coal-fire, for it was cold, to warm themselves: and Peter stood warming himself among them.
18.19: In the mean time, the high priest having question'd Jesus about his disciples, and his doctrine.
18.20: Jesus answered him, I spoke openly to the world; I was continually teaching in the synagogue, and in the temple, whither all the Jews resort, and in secret have I said nothing.
18.21: why do you question me? ask those who heard me, what discourse I had with them: they know very well what I said.
18.22: Upon his expressing himself thus, one of the officers there present, struck Jesus on the face, saying, answerest thou the high priest so?
18.23: Jesus replied, if I have said any thing injurious, show then wherein; but if I said right, why do you smite me?
18.24: now Annas had sent him bound to Caiaphas the high priest.
18.25: as Simon Peter then stood there warming himself: they said to him, art not thou also one of his disciples? which he denied, and said, I am not.
18.27: but Peter denied this too, and immediately the cock crew.
18.28: Then they led Jesus early in the morning from Caiaphas, to the Pretorium: but the Jews themselves did not enter into the Pretorium, lest they should be defiled: and so not be in a condition to eat the passover.
18.29: Pilate therefore went out to them, and said, what crime do you object to this man?
18.30: they answered him, if he were not a malefactor, we would not have delivered him to you.
18.31: Pilate then said to them, take him your selves, and judge him according to your law, but the Jews said to him, it is not lawful for us to put any man to death.
18.32: so that what Jesus had said, to signify the death he should die, was actually accomplished.
18.35: Pilate answered, am I a Jew? your own nation, and the chief priests have delivered thee up to me: what hast thou done?
18.36: Jesus answered, my kingdom is not of this world: if my kingdom were of this world, I should have had my guards to prevent my falling into the hands of the Jews: whereas my kingdom is of another nature.
18.37: upon this Pilate said to him, you are then a king? Jesus answered, you say right, for I am a king, to this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, to persuade mankind of the truth, every one that loves truth is observant of my directions.
18.38: what is truth? said Pilate, and upon saying this, he went out again to the Jews, and said to them, I don't find he is guilty of any crime.
18.39: but as it is customary with you to get me to discharge some prisoner at the time of the passover, would you have me release the king of the Jews?
18.40: upon which they all cried out again: not him, but Barabbas, now Barabbas was a robber.

19.1: Then Pilate order'd Jesus to be scourged.
19.2: and the soldiers having made a crown of thorns, they put it on his head, and threw a purple robe about him.
19.3: hail king of the Jews! said they, and struck him on the cheeks.
19.4: Pilate therefore went out again, and said to them, observe, I bring him out to you, to acquaint you that I find no fault in him.
19.5: so Jesus marched out wearing the crown of thorns, and the purple robe, and Pilate said to them, here's the man.
19.7: the Jews answered him, we have a law, and by our law he ought to die, because he pretended to be the son of God.
19.8: Pilate upon hearing that, was still more apprehensive.
19.9: and went again into the Pretorium, and said to Jesus, who was your father? but Jesus gave him no answer.
19.11: Jesus answered, you could not have any power over me, except you deriv'd it from above: therefore they who delivered me into your hands are the most culpable.
19.12: upon this, Pilate propos'd to release him: but the Jews cried out, if you let this man go, you are not Cesar's friend: he that sets up for king, opposes Cesar.
19.13: Pilate therefore hearing them talk at this rate, order'd Jesus to be brought forth, and then sat down in a place of Mosaic work on his tribunal, in Syriac call'd Gabbatha.
19.14: it was then about the sixth hour of the day before the sabbath of the passover: and he said to the Jews, behold your king.
19.15: but they cried out, away with him, away with him, crucify him. Pilate said to them, shall I crucify your king? the chief priests answered, we have no king but Cesar.
19.16: upon which he delivered him up to them to be crucified. So the soldiers took Jesus and led him away.
19.17: and he bearing his cross, marched out to a place called the skull, which is in the Syriac, Golgotha: where they crucified him,
19.18: and two others with him, one on each side, and Jesus in the middle.
19.19: and Pilate caused an inscription to be put over the cross, in these words, JESUS OF NAZARETH THE KING OF THE JEWS.
19.20: now this inscription was read by many of the Jews: for Jesus was crucified nigh the city: and it was written in Syriac, Greek, and Latin.
19.22: Pilate answered, what I have writ, I have writ.
19.23: The soldiers, after they had crucified Jesus, took his garments (and made four parts, to every soldier a part) and also his coat: now the coat was without seam, woven from the top throughout.
19.24: they said therefore among themselves, let us not rent it, but cast lots for it, whose it shall be: so that the scripture was fulfilled, which said, "they parted my raiment among them, and for my vesture they did cast lots." this was what the soldiers actually did.
19.25: In the mean time the mother of Jesus, and her sister Mary, the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene, were standing by the cross.
19.26: when Jesus therefore saw his mother, and the disciple whom he loved standing by, he said to his mother, woman, behold thy son.
19.27: then he said to the disciple, behold thy mother, and from that time the disciple took her to his own home.
19.28: after this, Jesus knowing that all things were now accomplished, that the scripture might be be fulfilled, said, I thirst.
19.29: now there was set a vessel full of vinegar: and they filled a spunge with vinegar, and put it upon a stick of hyssop, and held it to his mouth.
19.30: when Jesus therefore had received the vinegar, he said, it is finished: and bowing his head, he expir'd.
19.31: Now for fear the bodies should remain upon the cross on the sabbath-day, for it was then the eve of the pascal-sabbath, a day of high solemnity, the Jews desired Pilate that their legs might be broke, and that they might be taken away.
19.32: accordingly the soldiers came, and broke the legs of the first, and of the other who was crucified with him.
19.33: then they came to Jesus, and finding that he was already dead, they did not break his legs.
19.34: but one of the soldiers with a spear pierced his side, and immediately blood and water issued out.
19.35: he that relates this, was an eye-witness of it, and his relation is true: and he is so assured, what he says is true, that you may rely upon it.
19.36: for these things were done, that the scripture should be fulfilled, "a bone of him shall not be broken."
