19.37: and again the scripture saith elsewhere, "they shall look on him whom they pierced."
19.38: after this, Joseph of Arimathea, who was a disciple of Jesus, but for fear of the Jews a conceal'd one, pray'd Pilate to let him take away the body of Jesus: and Pilate gave him leave: so he went and took the body of Jesus.
19.39: Nicodemus, who formerly went to Jesus by night, came likewise and brought a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about an hundred pound weight.
19.40: they took therefore the body of Jesus, and wound it in linen clothes with the spices, according to the manner of burial among the Jews.
19.41: now near the place where he was crucified, there was a garden; and in the garden a new sepulchre, in which no body had ever yet been laid.
19.42: as this sepulchre was nigh at hand, they laid Jesus therein, because the time of the preparation of the Jews was expiring.

20.1: The first day of the week early in morning Mary Magdalene, when it was yet dusky, came to the sepulchre, and found the stone was taken away from the sepulchre.
20.2: upon this she went in great haste to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and said to them, they have taken away the Lord out of the sepulchre, and we know not where they have laid him.
20.3: Peter immediately departed, and that other disciple, to go to the sepulchre.
20.4: they both set out together: but the other disciple out-ran Peter, and came first to the cave,
20.5: where stooping down he saw the linen clothes lying; but did not go in.
20.6: Simon Peter who followed him, being come, went into the cave, and saw the linen clothes lying there;
20.7: as for the napkin that had been put about his head, it was not in the same place as the linen clothes, but lay folded up by it self.
20.8: then the other disciple, who arriv'd first, went into the cave likewise, and he saw, and believed what Mary had said.
20.9: for as yet they did not understand from the scripture, that he was to rise again from the dead.
20.10: After this the disciples return'd to their own home.
20.11: but Mary stood at the entrance of the cave weeping: and as she wept, she stooped down to look into the sepulchre,
20.12: and saw two angels in white, sitting where the body of Jesus had lain, the one at the head, the other at the feet.
20.14: having thus said, she turned about, and saw Jesus standing, but knew not that it was Jesus.
20.15: Jesus said to her, woman, why do you weep? who do you look for? she supposing him to be the gardener, said to him, sir, if it be you that have convey'd him away; tell me where you have laid him, and I will take care to have him remov'd.
20.16: Jesus said to her, Mary! she bowing her self, cry'd rabboni!
20.18: so Mary Magdalene went and told the disciples, that she had seen the Lord, and that he had said these things to her.
20.19: The same day at evening, being the first day of the week, the doors of the house where the disciples were, being shut, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in the midst, and said to them, peace be with you.
20.20: and when he had so said, he show'd them his hands and his side, the disciples were therefore extremely glad when they saw it was the Lord.
20.21: then said Jesus to them again, "peace be with you: as my father hath sent me, even so send I you."
20.22: and when he had said this, he breathed on them, and said to them, "receive ye the holy spirit.
20.23: whose soever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them; and whose soever sins ye leave unpardoned, they are lest unpardoned."
20.24: But Thomas, that is, Didymus, one of the twelve, was not with them when Jesus came.
20.25: the other disciples therefore said to him, we have seen the Lord, but he said to them, except I shall see in his hands the print of the nails, and put my finger into the place of the nails, and thrust my hand into his side, I will not believe.
20.26: Eight days after, when his disciples were again in private, and Thomas with them: Jesus came, the doors being shut, and stood in the midst, and said, peace be with you.
20.27: then said he to Thomas, reach hither thy finger, and examine my hands; and reach hither thy hand, and thrust it into my side: and be not faithless, but believing.
20.28: Thomas answered, and said to him, my Lord and my God!
20.30: Jesus perform'd many other miracles in the presence of his disciples, which are not written in this book.
20.31: but these are written, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Messias, the son of God, and that believing ye might have life through his name.

21.1: At length Jesus shewed himself again to the disciples upon the sea-coast of Tiberias; and the manner of his appearance was thus.
21.2: Simon Peter, Thomas, otherwise Didymus, Nathanael of Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two other disciples of Jesus were all together.
21.3: when Simon Peter said to them, I am going a fishing, they reply'd, we likewise will go with you, so they departed and went on board a vessel,; but that night they caught nothing.
21.4: as soon as it was morning, Jesus stood on the shore: but the disciples did not know that it was Jesus.
21.7: thereupon the favourite disciple of Jesus said to Peter, "it is the Lord." as soon as Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he girt on his coat, (for he was stript) and threw himself into the sea.
21.8: as for the other disciples, they came in the bark dragging the net full of fish, for they were but about two hundred cubits distant from land.
21.9: assoon as they were come to land, they saw fish frying upon a fire of coals there, and bread.
21.11: Simon Peter therefore went aboard, and drew the net to land loaded with an hundred and fifty three great fish: and notwithstanding the number, the net did not break.
21.13: Jesus then advanc'd, and taking bread, he gave them some, and fish likewise.
21.14: this was the third time that Jesus appear'd to his disciples, after he was risen from the dead.
21.16: then he ask'd him the second time, Simon son of Jonas do you love me? yes, Lord, said he; you know that I love you. Jesus reply'd, feed my sheep.
21.18: I tell you for certain, tho' when you was a youth you girded your self, and rambled where you had a mind: yet when you are old, your hands shall be stretch'd out, and another shall gird thee, and lead thee where you will be unwilling to go.
21.20: Then Peter turning about, saw the favourite disciple of Jesus was behind; the same who leaned next to Jesus at supper, and said, Lord, which is he that is to betray you?
21.21: upon seeing him, Peter said to Jesus, Lord, and what shall become of him?
21.22: Jesus said, if I will have him stay till I come, what have you to do with that? do you follow me.
21.23: which occasion'd a flying rumour among the brethren, that John should not die: tho' Jesus had not said, he shall not die: but, if I will have him stay till I come, what have you to do with that?
21.24: This is the disciple who testifieth of these things, and wrote these things: and we know that his testimony is true.
21.25: the other transactions of Jesus are so numerous, that if these were to be particularly descried, I imagine the world would be overwhelm'd with the books that should be written.

1.1: In my former treatise, I gave an account, O Theophilus, of all the actions and doctrine of Jesus, to the time of his assumption,
1.2: after he had given the apostles he had chosen, the orders they were to execute by the holy spirit.
1.3: to whom also he shewed himself alive after his passion, of which they had many proofs, during the forty days he appear'd to them, and inform'd them about the reign of the Messias:
1.4: being with them when they were assembled, he order'd they should not depart from Jerusalem, but wait for what the father had promis'd, which, said he, I mention'd.
1.5: " for John indeed baptized with water; but ye shall be baptized with the holy ghost, not many days hence."
1.6: Being therefore in his presence, they asked him, saying, Lord, is this the time when you will restore again the kingdom to Israel?
1.7: and he said to them, it is not for you, to know the times or the seasons, which the father hath reserv'd in his own disposal.
1.8: but ye shall receive the influence of the holy spirit, which will descend upon you: and ye shall be witnesses for me, in Jerusalem, in all Judea, and in Samaria, and to the remotest part of the earth.
1.9: After this discourse, while they beheld, he was taken up, and a cloud received him out of their sight.
1.10: and as they were looking stedfastly toward heaven, as he mounted up, on a sudden, two men appear'd before them robed in white, who said,
1.11: "ye men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up to heaven? this same Jesus who is taken up from you into heaven, shall descend in the same manner as ye have seen him ascend thither."
1.12: then they returned to Jerusalem, from the mountain of olives, which is a sabbath-day's journey from it.
1.13: When they were arrived there, they went up into an upper room, where Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James the son of Alpheus, Simon the Zelot, and Judas the brother of James used to resort,
1.14: and unanimously persevere in prayer with the women, Mary the mother of Jesus, and his brethren being present.
1.15: At that time the disciples being assembled, to the number of about an hundred and twenty, Peter rose up in the midst of them,
1.17: he was of our number, and shared in the functions of this ministry.
1.18: but after he had purchased a field with the reward of his iniquity, he fell down, his belly burst, and all his bowels gushed out:
1.19: a fact so generally known to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, that they called the field in their tongue, Aceldema, that is to say, the field of blood.
1.21: wherefore of those who have accompanied us all the time that the Lord Jesus convers'd among us,
1.22: from his baptism by John, to the day of his assumption, we should chuse one to be a witness with us of his resurrection.
1.23: accordingly they presented two, Joseph called Barsabas, who was sirnamed Justus, and Matthias, and they prayed,
1.24: saying, "thou Lord, who knowest the hearts of all men, show us which of these two thou hast chosen,
1.25: that he may be admitted to this apostolick ministry which Judas abandoned, to go to his own place."
1.26: and having drawn lots; the lot fell upon Matthias, who was added to the eleven apostles.

2.1: When the day of pentecost was come, they all met together with one accord.
2.2: when all of a sudden there came a sound from heaven, like that of an impetuous wind, which filled all the house where they were.
2.3: and there appeared several little flames, and sat upon each of them:
2.4: and they were all filled with the holy ghost, and began to speak in different languages, as the spirit gave them utterance.
2.5: now many devout Jews were residing at Jerusalem, who came from all quarters of the world.
2.6: and upon the rumour of this event, the multitude came together, and were confounded, every man hearing the disciples speak in his own language.
2.7: struck with astonishment and admiration, they said to one another, are not these men who are speaking, all Galileans?
2.8: how comes it then that we hear every man talking in our own native tongue?
2.9: Parthians, Medes, Elamites, the inhabitants of Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus,
2.10: Asia, Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, the parts of Libya about Cyrene, foreigners from Rome, Jews, and proselytes,
2.11: Cretes, and Arabians, we hear them all proclaiming in our tongues the wonderful works of God.
2.12: and they were all amazed, and perplex'd, saying one to another, what can the meaning of this be?
2.13: others in derision said, these men are full of sweet wine.
2.14: But Peter standing up with the eleven, and raising his voice, said to them, ye men of Judea, and all ye that dwell at Jerusalem, be this known to you, and observe what I say.
2.15: these are not drunk, as you suppose, since it is but the third hour of the day.
2.16: but this is the accomplishment of what was said by the prophet Joel,
2.17: "it shall come to pass in the last days (saith God) I will pour out of my spirit upon all flesh: and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, and your young men shall see visions, and your old men dream dreams:
2.18: and on my servants, and on my handmaidens I will pour out of my spirit in those days, and they shall prophesy:
2.19: and I will shew prodigies in the heavens, and signs on the earth; blood, and fire, and vapour of smoke.
2.20: the sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before that great and illustrious day of the Lord shall come.
2.21: and then whoever shall call on the name of the Lord, shall be saved."
2.22: ye men of Israel attend to what I say; Jesus of Nazareth was a man whom God distinguished among you, by miracles, by prodigies, and signs, which God did by him in the midst of you, as you your selves also know:
2.23: him, being delivered by the determinate counsel and foreknowledge of God, ye have taken, and by means of the wicked, have crucified and slain: whom God hath raised up,
2.24: having delivered him from the pains of death: because it was not possible that he should be overpower'd by it.
2.25: for David says concerning him, "I had the Lord always present before me, he is on my right hand, that I should not be moved.
2.26: therefore did my heart rejoice, my tongue was glad: and my body shall rest in hope.
2.27: because thou wilt not leave my soul in the grave, nor wilt thou give thine holy one a prey to corruption.
2.28: thou hast made known to me the ways of life; thou shalt make me full of joy by thy presence."
2.30: that, as he was a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn to him, to place the fruit of his loins upon his throne: foreseeing this,
2.31: he spoke of the resurrection of Christ, when he said, "that his soul was not lest in the grave, neither did his body undergo corruption."'
2.32: 'tis this Jesus whom God hath raised up, of which we all are witnesses.
2.33: therefore being by the right hand of God exalted, and having received of the father the promise of the holy spirit, he has diffused that spirit, the effects of which ye now see and hear.
2.34: for David is not ascended to heaven: yet he saith himself, "the Lord said to my Lord, sit thou on my right hand,
2.35: until I make thy foes thy footstool."
2.36: therefore let all the house of Israel know assuredly, that God hath made that same Jesus whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ.
2.38: Peter replied, repent, and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ, for the remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the holy spirit.
2.39: for the promise is to you, and to your children, and to all that are afar off, even as many as the Lord our God shall call.
2.41: then they that embraced his doctrine, were baptized: and there were about three thousand converts made that very day.
2.42: they continued stedfastly in the apostolical doctrine of a community, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers.
2.43: and all the people were allarm'd at the many prodigies and miracles which were done by the apostles.
2.44: All that believed were united together, and had all things in common,
2.45: so that they sold their possessions and goods, and distributed the money to every one as his occasions required.
2.46: and continuing daily with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread from house to house, they did eat their meals with gladness, and simplicity of heart,
2.47: praising God, and showing benevolence to all the people, and the Lord encreased the church daily with new converts.

3.1: One day as Peter and John were going together to the temple, at the ninth hour, which was the hour of prayer,
3.2: they were carrying a man who had been lame from his birth, one whom they daily laid at the gate of the temple called, Beauty-gate, to ask alms of those that pass'd into the temple.
3.3: he seeing Peter and John going into the temple, asked alms of them.
3.4: Peter and John having their eyes upon him, Peter said, look on us.
3.5: at which he look'd very attentively, expecting to receive something of them.
3.6: then Peter said, silver and gold have I none; but such as I have I give thee: in the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, rise up and walk.
3.7: and taking him by the right hand, he lift him up; and immediately his feet and ancle-bones received strength.
3.8: so that he fell a leaping, and walking, and entred with them into the temple, walking, and leaping, and praising God.
3.9: all the people saw him walking and praising God.
3.10: and knowing it was he who us'd to sit begging at the Beauty-gate of the temple, they were filled with wonder and amazement at such an event.
3.11: As the lame man who was cured, held Peter and John, the people all in surprize ran to Solomon's porch, where they were.
3.12: which Peter observing, thus addressed them, ye men of Israel, why are ye so surprized at this event? or why do you look so earnestly on us, as though by our own power or piety, we had caus'd this man to walk?
3.13: the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, the God of our fathers, hath glorified his son Jesus; whom ye delivered up, and renounced in opposition to Pilate, who was determined to let him go.
3.14: but ye renounced him that was holy and just; you interceeded for the life of a murderer,
3.15: but killed the prince of life, whom God hath raised from the dead; whereof we are witnesses.
3.16: it is the faith which we have in him, that has procured strength to this man whom ye see and know: yea, the faith which is by him, hath given him this perfect soundness in the presence of you all.
3.17: and now, brethren, I know it was through ignorance, that both you and your rulers, have acted thus.
3.18: but thus it is that God has accomplished what he had foretold by the mouth of all his prophets, that Christ should suffer.
3.19: repent therefore, and be converted, that your sins may be blotted out, when the times of refreshment shall come from the presence of the Lord, who shall send Jesus Christ,
3.20: who has been beforehand prepar'd thereto,
3.21: but must reside in heaven, till the time of the restitution of all things, of which God has spoken from the beginning by the mouth of his holy prophets.
3.22: for Moses said to the fathers, "a prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you, of your brethren, like unto me; observe whatever he shall say to you.
3.23: and whoever he be that will not hear that prophet, shall be destroyed from among the people."
3.24: afterwards Samuel and all that prophesied after him, have likewise foretold these times.
3.25: ye are the children of the prophets, and of the covenant which God made with our fathers, when he said to Abraham, "all the families of the earth shall be blessed in your posterity."
3.26: it is to you that God first of all sent his son Jesus, having raised him up to bless you, provided you all renounce your iniquities.

4.1: While they were speaking to the people, the priests, the captain of the temple, and the Sadduces came upon them,
4.2: being displeas'd that they taught the people, and maintain'd the resurrection from the dead in the person of Jesus.
4.3: and they laid hands on them, and put them in prison, till the next day: for it was now evening.
4.4: however, many who heard Peter's discourse, believed, to the number of about five thousand people.
4.5: On the morrow, the rulers, senators, and doctors of the law, then at Jerusalem, assembled,
4.6: with Annas the high priest, Caiphas, John, and Alexander, and as many as were of the pontifical family.
4.8: then Peter filled with the holy spirit, said to them, Rulers of the people, and senators of Israel,
4.9: since we are this day to be examined about the cure of a cripple, and by what means he was recovered; be it known to you all,
4.10: and to all the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, whom ye crucified, whom God raised from the dead, even by him doth this man stand here before you entirely recover'd.
4.11: this is the stone which was rejected by you builders, but is become the chief of the angle.
4.12: salvation is not to be had by any other: for there is no other name under heaven given to men whereby we can be saved.
4.13: Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and perceived that they were illiterate, and of the lower rank of men, they were surpriz'd; but tho' they knew that they had been Jesus's disciples,
4.14: yet seeing the man who was cured standing with them, they could not tell what to reply.
4.15: having therefore order'd them to withdraw from the council, they conferred among themselves,
4.16: saying, what shall we do to these men? for that indeed a notable miracle hath been done by them is manifest to all that dwell in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.
4.17: but to prevent its spreading any further among the people, let us charge them with threats not to speak for the future to any man in that name.
4.18: so they called them in, and commanded them not to speak or teach upon any account, in the name of Jesus.
4.19: but Peter and John made answer, do you yourselves judge, whether it be right in the sight of God, to obey you rather than God.
4.20: for we cannot avoid publishing what we have seen and heard.
4.21: so when they had further threatned them, they let them go, not finding it practicable to punish them, because of the people, who all glorified God for that which was done.
4.22: for the man who was so miraculously cured, was above forty years old.
4.23: As soon as they were discharg'd, they went to their brethren, and reported all that the chief priests and senators had said to them:
4.24: at the relation of which they unanimously lift up their voice to God, and said, Lord, thou art the God who hast made the heaven, the earth, the sea, and all that is therein:
4.25: who by the mouth of thy servant David hast said, "why did the heathen rage, and the people imagine vain things?
4.26: the kings of the earth stood up, and the rulers were gathered together against the Lord, and against his Christ."
4.27: for it was truly against thy holy child Jesus, whom thou hast anointed, that Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles, and the people of Israel, united themselves in this city,
4.28: to effect what thy power and thy wisdom pre-determined to be done.
4.29: and now, Lord, behold their threatnings: and enable thy servants to deliver thy word with freedom,
4.30: by displaying thine hand in miraculous cures, and prodigies, which by the name of thy holy child Jesus shall be done.
4.31: When they had prayed, the place where they were assembled, trembled; they were all filled with the holy spirit, and they spake the word of God with boldness.
4.32: Now the whole body of believers were but one heart, and one soul: no one look'd upon what he possessed, as his own, but every thing was held in common.
4.33: Great was the power by which the apostles attested the resurrection of the Lord Jesus: and they were all greatly favoured by the people.
4.34: for there was no poor among them, because as many as bad lands or houses, sold them, and brought the value,
4.35: which they laid down at the apostles feet: and they distributed it to every man as his occasions required.
4.36: among the rest one Joseph, who by the apostles was surnamed Barnabas (that is to say, the son of consolation) a Levite, and a native of Cyprus,
4.37: sold an estate he had, and brought the money, and laid it at the apostles feet.

5.1: Now there was a certain man named Ananias who with Sapphira his wife, sold a possession,
5.2: and kept back part of the price, his wife also being privy to it, and brought the rest which he laid at the apostles feet.
5.4: was not the estate your own estate? and was not the price for which it was sold, all in your own hands? how came such a design as this in your heart? thou hast not lyed unto men, but unto God.
5.5: at these words Ananias fell down dead upon the spot: which struck the minds of all that heard of it with great dread.
5.6: and some young men came and wound him up, then carried him out, and buried him.
5.7: about the space of three hours after, his wife, not knowing what had happen'd, came in.
5.9: then Peter said to her, how comes it that you have conspir'd together, to tempt the spirit of the Lord? see there at the door the men that are come from burying thy husband, and they shall carry thee out likewise.
5.10: in the instant she fell down dead at his feet: and the young men came in, found her dead, carried her out, and buried her by her husband.
5.11: which affected the whole assembly, and all that heard of it with great dread.
5.12: Thus were many signs and wonders wrought among the people, by the apostles, who us'd to meet in Solomon's porch with great unanimity:
5.13: but the people who reverenc'd them,
5.14: did not venture to approach near them, the number of those who believed in the Lord, both men and women, increas'd more and more.
5.15: insomuch that they brought the sick into the streets, and laid them on beds and couches, that at the least, the shadow of Peter might cover some of them, as he pass'd by.
5.16: multitudes came likewise from the neighbouring cities to Jerusalem, bringing their sick, and those who were tormented with impure spirits: who were all cured.
5.17: Then the high priest, and all that accompanied him, who were of the sect of the Sadducees, being filled with indignation,
5.18: went and seized on the apostles, and put them in the common prison.
5.19: but an angel of the Lord opened the prison-doors by night, and having brought them out, said to them,
5.20: go, stand in the temple, and declare to the people, the whole doctrine of life.
5.21: when they heard that, they entred into the temple early in the morning, and taught, in the mean time, the high priest, and those of his party, being arrived at the council-chamber, summon'd all the Jewish senate to meet, and sent to the prison to bring the apostles before them.
5.22: but the officers who went there not finding them in the prison, returned, and made this report,
5.23: the prison we found shut very secure, and the keepers posted before the doors: but when we had opened it, we found no body within.
5.24: Upon hearing this, the high priest, the captain of the temple, and the chief priests wonder'd bow this could be.
5.25: when somebody came and told them, the men whom ye order'd to prison, are standing in the temple, and teaching the people.
5.26: upon which the captain went with his officers, and brought them, without offering any violence, for fear of being stoned, he and his men by the people.
5.27: when they had brought them, they set them before the council: and the high priest asked them,
5.28: saying, did not we strictly command you, not to teach in this name? and yet you have spread your doctrine through Jerusalem, and you endeavour to make us responsible for this man's blood.
5.29: then Peter and the other apostles made answer, we ought to obey God rather than men.
5.30: the God of our fathers raised up Jesus, whom ye slew, and hanged on a tree.
5.31: him hath God rais'd by his power to be the author of salvation, by giving repentance to Israel, and the remission of their sins.
5.32: and we are his witnesses in what we say, and so is the holy spirit, whom God hath given to those that obey him.
5.33: When they heard that, they were so enraged, they consulted to take away their lives.
5.34: when a Pharisee, named Gamaliel, a doctor of law, who was respected by all the people, rose up in the council, and moved the apostles might withdraw for some time.
5.35: and then he said, "ye men of Israel, be cautious how you proceed with regard to these men.
5.36: for some time ago one Theudas started up, pretending to be something extraordinary, who was join'd indeed by about four hundred men: but he was no sooner put to death, than his followers all dispers'd, and were reduc'd to nothing.
5.37: after this man, Judas of Galilee appear'd, at the time of the registry, and seduc'd many people: he also perished, and all his followers were dispersed.
5.38: my opinion therefore is, not to meddle with these men, but to let them go on: for if the design be a human project, it will fall of it self, but if it be from God,
5.39: you cannot defeat it; perhaps you may be found warring against heaven." To him they agreed: and
5.40: after the apostles were called in, and scourged, they charged them not to speak in the name of Jesus, and then releas'd them, out they went from the council,
5.41: full of joy, that they were counted worthy to suffer shame for the name of Jesus.
5.42: and every day either in the temple or in private houses they continued to preach and proclaim Jesus to be the Christ.

6.1: At that time, as the number of the disciples was multiplied, the Hellenists murmured against the Hebrews, because their widows were neglected in the distribution that was made daily.
6.2: the twelve therefore assembled all the disciples, and said, it is not fit that we should leave the word of God, to mind what relates to your meals.
6.3: wherefore, brethren, chuse out of your number seven persons of good reputation, full of the holy spirit and wisdom, who may have the management of this affair:
6.4: whilst we shall continue our applications to prayer, and to preaching.
6.5: this proposition pleased the whole assembly: and they chose Stephen, a man full of faith and of the holy spirit, Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas a proselyte of Antioch.
6.6: these they presented to the apostles: who after prayer gave them imposition of hands.
6.7: thus the word of God was spread; and the number of disciples encreased very much at Jerusalem; and a numerous body of priests embrac'd the faith.
6.8: Now Stephen full of grace and power, did great wonders and miracles among the people.
6.9: when some out of the several synagogues, belonging to the freed men, to the Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and to those of Cilicia, and of Asia, came to dispute with Stephen.
6.10: but as they were not able to withstand the force of that sublime knowledge which appeared in his discourse,
6.11: they suborned men, who said, we have heard him speak irreverently of Moses, and of God.
6.12: and they stirred up the people, the senators, and the doctors of law, who came and seiz'd him, and brought him to the council,
6.13: where they produc'd false witnesses, who said, this man is continually inveighing against the holy place, and against the law.
6.14: for we have heard him say, that Jesus the Nazarene shall destroy this place, and change the customs which Moses delivered us.
6.15: and all that sat in the council, looking stedfastly on him, saw an air of majesty in his aspect.

7.2: Stephen answer'd, my brethren, and you my fathers, lend your attention. The God of glory appeared unto our father Abraham, when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran,
7.3: and said to him, quit your country, and your kindred, to go to the land which I shall shew thee.
7.4: thereupon he went out of Chaldea, and dwelt in Charran: from thence, after his father's death, he removed him to this very country where you now dwell.
7.5: he gave him no inheritance in it, not even a foot of land: yet he promised to give it to him for a possession, and to his posterity after him, tho' he had then no child.
7.8: at length he gave him the covenant of circumcision: accordingly Abraham circumcised his son Isaac eight days after he was born, Isaac was father of Jacob, who was father of the twelve patriarchs.
7.9: the patriarchs being jealous of Joseph, sold him into Egypt: but God was with him,
7.10: he delivered him out of all his afflictions, and gave him wisdom to become acceptable to Pharaoh king of Egypt; who made him governor of Egypt, and all his houshold.
7.11: in the mean time a famine spread over all the land of Egypt and Chanaan, so that our fathers did not know where to get provisions.
7.12: but when Jacob heard there was corn in Egypt, he sent our fathers there.
7.13: at the second voyage Joseph discover'd himself to his brethren; and Joseph's kindred were made known to Pharaoh.
7.14: after this, Joseph sent to invite his father Jacob to come with all his kindred, being threescore and fifteen persons.
7.15: so Jacob went down into Egypt, and died, he and our fathers,
7.16: and were transported to Sychem, and laid in the sepulchre that Abraham bought for a sum of money of the sons of Emmor the father of Sychem.
7.18: till another king arose who knew not Joseph.
7.19: this prince employ'd all his arts against our nation, and persecuted our fathers, by obliging them to expose their young children, in order to extirpate the race.
7.20: in which time Moses was born, who was exceeding fair, and nourished in his father's house three months:
7.21: and when he was exposed, Pharaoh's daughter caused him to be taken up, and maintain'd for her adopted son.
7.22: at length Moses was instructed in all the sciences of the Egyptians, and had great influence by his counsels and actions.
7.23: when he was full forty years old, he took the resolution to visit his brethren the children of Israel.
7.24: and seeing one of them abus'd, he defended him, and avenged the injury by killing the Egyptian:
7.25: for he supposed his brethren would have perceiv'd by this, that God design'd to make him the instrument of their deliverance; but they did not perceive it.
7.26: the next day seeing some that were fighting, he would have persuaded them to agree, saying, sirs, ye are brethren; why do ye injure one another?
7.28: will you kill me as you kill'd the Egyptian yesterday? at these words Moses fled,
7.29: and went to reside in the land of Madian, where he became the father of two sons.
7.31: Moses was astonished at this vision: and as he drew near to observe it, he heard the voice of the Lord, which said to him,
7.32: "I am the God of thy fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob." and Moses trembled so, he durst not observe any longer.
7.33: then said the Lord to him, "put off thy shoes from thy feet: for the place where thou standest is holy ground.
7.34: I have seen, I have seen the affliction of my people which is in Egypt; I have heard their groaning, and am come down to deliver them, come immediately, and I will send you into Egypt."
7.35: this Moses whom they refused, saying, who made thee a ruler and a judge? the very same did God send to be a ruler and a deliverer by the hands of the angel that appeared to him in the bush.
7.36: he it was, who delivered them by doing prodigies and miracles in the land of Egypt, in the red sea, and in the wilderness for forty years.
7.37: this is that Moses who said to the children of Israel, "a prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shall ye hear."
7.38: 'twas he that was in the assembly with our fathers in the wilderness, and with the angel that spoke to him on mount Sina: and delivered the oracles to him by word of mouth for our use.
7.39: him our fathers would not obey, but rejected him, and they return'd to their Egyptian disposition.
7.40: "make us gods, said they to Aaron, to be our guides: for as for this Moses, who brought us out of the land of Egypt, we know not what is become of him."
7.41: 'twas then they made a calf, and offered sacrifice to the idol, triumphing in the works of their own hands.
7.43: on the contrary, ye carried the tabernacle of Moloch, and the star of your god Remphan, figures which ye made to worship them: wherefore I will transport you beyond Babylon."
7.44: our fathers had the tabernacle of witness in the wilderness, as he had appointed, ordering Moses to make it according to the model that he had seen.
7.45: which our fathers and Joshua having receiv'd, they carry'd it into the territory of those nations whom God drove out upon their arrival: where it staid to the time of David, who was favoured by God,
7.46: and desired to have a settled tabernacle for the God of Jacob.
7.47: it was Solomon however that built him a temple.
7.48: altho' the most high does not dwell in temples made with hands; as the prophet said, "heaven is my throne,
7.49: and earth is my footstool: what house will ye build me? saith the Lord: or what is the place of my rest?
7.50: hath not my hand made all these things?"
7.51: stubborn people, whose hearts and ears like the uncircumcised, are always averse to the holy spirit: as your fathers did, so do ye.
7.52: was there ever any prophet whom your fathers did not persecute? have they not slain those who predicted the coming of that just person whom you have so lately betrayed and murder'd?
7.53: you, I say, who received the law by the administration of angels, but have not however observ'd it.
7.54: When they heard these things, they were transported with rage, and gnashed their teeth against him.
7.55: but he, full of the holy spirit, fix'd his eyes towards heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.
7.56: and he said, there I see the heavens open, and the son of man standing on the right hand of God.
7.57: then they broke out into a loud cry, and stopping their ears, fell upon him all at once.
7.58: then they dragg'd him out of the city, and stoned him: the false witnesses having laid down their clothes at a young man's feet, whose name was Saul.
7.59: Thus they stoned Stephen, while he was calling upon God, and saying, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit."
7.60: and on his knees he cried with a loud voice, "Lord, lay not this sin to their charge." and having said this, he expired.

8.1: and Saul was accessory to his death. At that time the persecution was so violent against the church at Jerusalem, they were all dispers'd through the regions of Judea and Samaria, except the apostles,
8.2: and some devout men who carried Stephen to his burial, making great lamentation over him.
8.3: as for Saul, he made havock of the Church, entring into their houses, whence he dragg'd away both men and women, to throw them into prison.
8.4: but they that were dispers'd, preach'd the gospel wherever they went.
8.5: Philip being arrived at Samaria, preached Christ to them.
8.6: the people attended with great unanimity, hearing his discourses, and observing the miracles he wrought.
8.7: for the impure spirits, with great outcries, came out of many that were possessed: many paralytic, and lame people were cured.
8.8: which caused great joy in that city.
8.9: One Simon was then resident in that place, who pretended to be something extra-ordinary, and by his magical practices had so enchanted the people of Samaria,
8.10: that they all followed him, both old and young, this man, said they, is the plenipotentiary of God.
8.11: no wonder they were so attach'd to one, who had for a long time infatuated them with his arts.
8.12: but when they had embraced the doctrine of Philip, concerning the kingdom of the Messias, and the authority of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
8.13: nay, Simon himself became a proselyte: and after he was baptized, he continued with Philip, and was transported at the sight of the miracles and prodigies which he perform'd.
8.14: Now when the apostles who were at Jerusalem, heard that the Samaritans had embraced the word of God, they sent Peter and John,
8.15: who upon their arrival, prayed for them that they might receive the holy spirit.
8.16: (for as yet he had not descended on any of them: they having only been baptized in the name of the Lord
8.17: Jesus) the apostles therefore gave them imposition of hands, and they received the holy spirit.
8.18: when Simon saw that the holy spirit was given by imposition of the hands of the apostles, he offered them money, saying,
8.19: give me too this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands he may receive the holy spirit.
8.20: but Peter said unto him, thy money perish with thee, for thinking that the gift of God may be purchased with money.
8.21: thou hast no manner of share in this gift: for thy heart is not right in the sight of God.
8.22: repent therefore of this thy wickedness, and pray to God, to forgive, if it be possible, this suggestion you have entertain'd.
8.23: for I perceive you are upon the brink of misery, led captive by your sin.
8.24: Simon answered, do you pray to the Lord for me, that nothing like what you mention may befall me.
8.25: after this the apostles having certified and preached the word of the Lord, returned to Jerusalem, preaching the gospel by the way in many villages of the Samaritans.
8.26: Now an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, arise, and go toward the south, by the way that leads from Jerusalem to Gaza, in the desart.
8.27: accordingly he departed: and met a man of Ethiopia, an eunuch of great authority under Candace queen of the Ethiopians, and was her high-treasurer: he had been at Jerusalem, to perform the duties of a proselyte,
8.28: but was now upon his return, and sat in his chariot, reading the prophet Esaias.
8.29: then the spirit said unto Philip, go near, and advance to his chariot.
8.31: how can I, answer'd he, without some expositor? and he desired Philip to mount, and sit with him.
8.32: the passage of the scripture which he read, was this, "he was led as a sheep to the slaughter, and like a lamb before his shearer, was dumb, so opened he not his mouth:
8.33: in his humiliation he was judged, he was taken off: and who shall describe the men of his time? for the land has taken away his life."
8.34: and the eunuch answered Philip, and said, pray, of whom does the prophet say this? of himself, or of some other?
8.35: then Philip enter'd upon the subject, and show'd how the whole passage was applicable to Jesus.
8.36: as they pursued their journey, they came to a place of water: and the eunuch said, see, here is water; what should hinder my being baptized?
8.37: [and Philip said, if you believe with all your heart, you may, and he answered, I do believe that Jesus Christ is the son of God.]
8.38: so he order'd the charioteer to stop: and they went down into the water, both Philip and the eunuch; and he baptized him.
8.39: when they were come out of the water, the spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, that the eunuch saw him no more: and he pursued his way with joy.
8.40: but Philip was found at Azotus: and passing on, he preached in all the cities, till he came to Cesarea.

9.1: Saul still breathing out nothing but threats and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord,
9.2: went to the high priest, and demanded letters for the synagogues of Damascus, that if he found any of this sect, whether men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
9.3: As he was on his journey, and near Damascus, on a sudden, a light from heaven surrounded him,
9.4: and he fell to the ground, and heard a voice which said to him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
9.5: and he said, who art thou, Lord? and the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: [it is hard for thee to kick against the goad. Then trembling with the fright Saul said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? and the Lord said to him,]
9.6: but rise, and go into the city, and you shall be told what you must do.
9.7: the mean while the men who accompany'd him, remain'd astonish'd, hearing a voice, but seeing no one.
9.8: at length Saul rose from the ground; and when he opened his eyes, he could not see: so that they led him by the hand, and brought him to Damascus,
9.9: where he was three days without sight, and did neither eat nor drink.
9.11: and the Lord said unto him, arise, and go to the street called Straight, and enquire at the house of Judas, for one Saul of Tarsus: for he is there at prayer.
9.12: (at that very instant Saul saw in a vision the said Ananias come in, and put his hand on him, to restore his sight.)
9.13: then Ananias answered, Lord, I have heard from many that this man has done a world of mischief to thy saints at Jerusalem: he is now here,
9.14: and is impower'd by the chief priests, to imprison all that make profession of thy name.
9.15: go, said the Lord to him: for he is the instrument I have chosen, to bear my name to the Gentiles, to kings, and to the children of Israel.
9.16: for I will make him see how much he must suffer for my name.
9.18: immediately there fell from his eyes something like scales, and he recover'd his sight; upon which he instantly arose, and was baptized.
9.19: and when he had taken some food, he was refresh'd, after which Saul staid some time with the disciples at Damascus.
9.20: Immediately he maintained in the synagogues, that Jesus was the son of God.
9.21: the audience were all amazed, and said, is not this he that persecuted the professors of this doctrine at Jerusalem, and came here on purpose to carry them prisoners to the chief priests?
9.22: however Saul still gain'd ground, and confounded the Jews of Damascus, proving that Jesus was the Messias.
9.23: A good while after, the Jews conspir'd to kill him:
9.24: but Saul was appriz'd of their plot, and as they were night and day upon the watch at the gates, in order to kill him,
9.25: the disciples took him by night, and let him down the wall in a basket.
9.26: when Saul was come to Jerusalem, he try'd to associate himself with the disciples: but they were all afraid of him, and could not be persuaded that he was a disciple.
9.27: thereupon Barnabas took him with him to the apostles, and related to them how the Lord had appear'd to him on his journey, and had spoken to him, and how publickly Saul had preach'd at Damascus in the name of Jesus.
9.28: then he convers'd freely with the apostles at Jerusalem:
9.29: and he openly preach'd in the name of the Lord Jesus, and disputed against the Hellenists, who therefore plotted against his life:
9.30: which when the brethren knew, they brought him down to Cesarea, and sent him away to Tarsus.
9.31: Then the churches in all Judea, Galilee, and Samaria, were unmolested and establish'd, and by their religious conduct, and the assistance of the holy spirit, grew more extensive.
9.32: now as Peter was making a general visitation, he went to Lydda to see the converts in that city,
9.33: where finding a man named Eneas, a paralytic, who had kept his bed eight years,
9.35: and all that dwelt at Lydda, and Saron, saw him, and became converts to the Lord.
9.36: At Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha, that is in Greek, Dorcas: this woman was very active in all the offices of benevolence and charity.
9.37: she happen'd to fall sick at that time, and died: after they had bath'd her body, they laid her out in an upper chamber.
9.39: Peter immediately went with them, and when he was come, they conducted him to the upper chamber: and all the widows advanc'd to him weeping, and shew'd the robes and garments which Dorcas made while she was with them.
9.40: but Peter turn'd them all out, and kneeled down and prayed, then turning towards the body, Tabitha, said he, arise immediately, she opened her eyes: and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
9.41: Peter lent her his hand, and lift her up; and having called the saints and widows, he presented her alive.
9.42: this was soon spread thro' all Joppa; and many believed in the Lord.
9.43: so that Peter staid there a considerable time with one Simon a tanner.

10.1: In Cesarea there was a centurion of a cohort in the Italic legion, whose name was Cornelius, a religious man,
10.2: and was a proselyte, together with all his family: he gave much alms to the people, and was assiduous in his prayers to God.
10.4: and when he looked on him, he was afraid, and said, what is it, Lord? and he said to him, thy prayers and thine alms have been observ'd and approv'd by God.
10.5: send messengers immediately to Joppa, for one Simon, whose sirname is Peter:
10.6: he lodges with one Simon a tanner, whose house is by the sea-side.
10.7: As soon as the angel that spoke to Cornelius was departed, he called two of his domesticks, and a devout soldier, one of those that were in waiting:
10.8: and after he had related to them the whole affair, he sent them to Joppa.
10.9: On the morrow as they were on their journey, and drew nigh the city, Peter went upon the leads to pray, about the sixth hour.
10.10: and being seiz'd with hunger, he would have had something to eat: but while they were making it ready, he fell into a trance,
10.11: when he saw the heaven open, and something descending in the form of a great sheet, ty'd at the four corners, and let down to the earth:
10.12: in it were all sorts of quadrupeds, reptiles, and birds.
10.13: and a voice said to him, rise, Peter; kill and eat.
10.15: and the voice spake to him again the second time, don't call that common, which God calls clean.
10.16: this was done thrice: and then the sheet was taken up into heaven.
10.17: While Peter was perplexed about the signification of this vision, the messengers from Cornelius having enquir'd out Simon's house, arriv'd at the gate,
10.18: and calling somebody, ask'd, whether Simon Peter lodg'd there.
10.19: As Peter was still pondering upon the vision, the spirit said to him, there are people below, who enquire for you.
10.20: rise therefore, get thee down, and go with them, without hesitating: for I have sent them.
10.21: then Peter went down to the messengers; and said, I am the person you look for: what occasion brought you hither?
10.23: then he invited them in, and they lodged there. On the morrow, Peter departed with them, and some of his brethren from Joppa accompanied him.
10.24: the next day they arriv'd at Cesarea: where Cornelius expected them, having invited his kinsmen and intimate friends, to his house.
10.25: as Peter was coming in, Cornelius met him, and prostrated himself at his feet,
10.26: but Peter rais'd him, saying, stand up; I am but a man, as well as you.
10.27: and as he discours'd with him, he went in, where finding many persons assembled; you know,
10.28: said he, how unlawful it is for a Jew, to frequent a stranger, or even to go to his house: but God hath shewed me, that I should not look upon any man as common and unclean.
10.29: for which reason I came without demur, as soon as I knew your message: I ask therefore upon what account you sent for me?
10.32: send therefore to Joppa, for one Simon, whose surname is Peter; he is lodged in the house of one Simon a tanner, by the sea-side, who, when he is arriv'd, will give you information."
10.33: immediately I sent to you; and you have done well to come, now here we are all in the presence of God, to hear whatever he has given you in charge.
10.34: then Peter thus began, now I plainly perceive that God is no respecter of persons:
10.35: but in every nation, he that feareth him, and acts justly, is acceptable to him.
10.36: this was what he communicated to the children of Israel, proclaiming salvation by Jesus Christ, who is the Lord of all mankind.
10.37: you know, how his fame spread from Galilee through all Judea, after the baptism which John had preach'd:
10.38: how Jesus of Nazareth divinely inspired by the holy spirit, and with miraculous power, went about doing good, and healing all that were under the oppression of the devil: because God was with him.
10.39: we are witnesses of all his transactions, both in Judea, and at Jerusalem, however, they put him to death, even that of the cross.
10.40: but God raised him up the third day, and shewed him openly,
10.41: not to all the people, but to those witnesses, which God had before chosen: to us, I say, who did eat and drink with him after he rose from the dead.
10.42: and he commanded us to publish, and to testify to the people, that he was the person whom God had constituted to be the judge of the living, and of the dead.
10.43: he is the person to whom all the prophets give this attestation, that all who believe in him, shall receive remission of sins, by his authority.
10.44: Peter was yet speaking, when the holy spirit descended on all that heard him.
10.45: all the Jewish converts, who came with Paul, were astonished to see that the gift of the holy spirit was diffused likewise among the Gentiles.
10.46: for they heard them express their praises to God in divers languages.
10.47: then Peter said, can we refuse the water of baptism to such as have received the holy spirit as well as we?
10.48: so he directed they should be baptized in the name of the Lord, after which they desired him to stay some time with them.

11.1: In the mean time, the apostles, and the brethren, who were in Judea, heard that the Gentiles had likewise receiv'd the word of God.
11.2: and when Peter was return'd to Jerusalem, the Jewish converts objected to his conduct,
11.3: and ask'd him, why did you go to eat with the uncircumcised?
11.4: but Peter represented the whole affair to them,
11.5: saying, as I was at prayers in Joppa, I saw something like a great sheet, tied at the four corners, which descended from heaven, and came just to me.
11.6: as I was considering it very attentively, I saw several quadrupeds, wild beasts, reptiles and birds.
11.7: then I heard a voice, which said, rise, Peter; kill and eat.
11.10: this was done three times, and then the whole scene was mounted to heaven.
11.11: at that very instant three men, dispatch'd from Cesarea to me, were just arrived at the house, where I was.
11.12: and the spirit bid me make no difficulty of going with them, these six brethren accompany'd me, and we went together to the man's house.
11.13: he told us how he had seen an angel, who had presented himself to him, and had said, send to Joppa, to fetch Simon, surnam'd Peter:
11.14: who will give you such instructions, as will be the means of saving both you and all your family.
11.16: then I remember'd that expression of the Lord, "John baptized with water, but ye shall be baptized with the holy spirit."
11.17: if therefore God has bestow'd the same favour upon them, as on us, after we had believed on the Lord Jesus Christ, how could I make any opposition to the divine will?
11.18: Having heard this, they were appeas'd, and glorified God, saying, God has then granted salvation likewise to the gentiles, on the terms of their repentance.
11.19: In the mean time they who were dispers'd upon the persecution that arose after Stephen's time, had travell'd as far as Phenicia, Cyprus and Antioch, without preaching the gospel to any, but Jews only.
11.20: some of them were of Cyprus and Cyrene, and upon their arrival at Antioch they address'd themselves to the Greeks, and preach'd to them the Lord Jesus.
11.21: and as the divine assistance accompany'd them, a great number of persons believed and became converts.
11.22: Of this the church at Jerusalem being appriz'd, they order'd Barnabas to go to Antioch;
11.23: who upon his arrival there, was glad to see such effects of the divine grace, and exhorted them all to remain firmly attach'd to the christian profession:
11.24: for he was a good man, and full of the holy spirit and of faith: so that many converts were added to the church.
11.25: at length Barnabas departed to Tarsus in quest of Saul, and having found him, he conducted him to Antioch:
11.26: where they resided a whole year with that church, and instructed abundance of disciples, and these disciples were the first that were denominated Christians.
11.27: About that time some prophets came from Jerusalem to Antioch:
11.28: and one of them named Agabus foretold by the spirit, that there should be a great famine, thro' all the world: which accordingly happen'd in the reign of Claudius Cesar.
11.29: then the disciples determin'd to send, each of them answerably to his abilities, some relief to the brethren residing in Judea: which they actually perform'd,
11.30: and sent it by the hands of Saul and Barnabas to the presbyters at Jerusalem.

12.1: About that time, king Herod Agrippa began to persecute some of the church.
12.2: he caus'd James the brother of John to be beheaded.
12.3: and perceiving that the Jews were pleas'd with this, he proceeded to secure Peter during the feast of unleavened bread:
12.4: having apprehended Peter, he put him into prison, appointing a detachment of sixteen soldiers to guard him, intending to have him brought to publick execution, after Easter.
12.5: thus Peter was kept in prison, but the Church prayed to God, without ceasing, for him,
12.6: now the very night preceding the day which Herod design'd for his execution, Peter bound with two chains, was sleeping between two soldiers, while the other guards secured the prison door; when an angel of
12.7: the Lord suddenly appear'd and fill'd the room with light, and touching Peter on the side, awak'd him, saying, rise, be quick, and immediately his chains fell from his hands.
12.9: so he went out after the angel without knowing that what the angel had done, was real; but thinking it was all a vision.
12.10: when they had pass'd the first and second guard, they came to the iron-gate that leads to the city, which open'd to them of itself: so they went out and pass'd together thro' one street: when all of a sudden the angel quitted Peter. Then coming to himself; now,
12.11: said he, I know for certain, that the Lord has sent his angel, and has deliver'd me from the hands of Herod, and from what the Jews were in expectation of.
12.12: then recollecting where he was, he went to the house of Mary the mother of John, surnam'd Mark, where many were assembled at prayers.
12.13: when he had knock'd at the door of the gate, a servant named Rhoda came to ask who was there.
12.14: upon hearing Peter tell his name, instead of opening the gate, she ran, out of joy, to tell them, that Peter was there.
12.15: are you mad? said they, but she persisting that it was even so, they reply'd, it is then his angel.
12.16: as Peter still continued knocking, they let him in, and seeing it was he, they were extremely surpriz'd:
12.17: but he made a sign to them with his hand, to be silent: and related to them, how the Lord had brought him out of the prison, go, said he, and acquaint James and the other brethren with this affair, after which he departed and went to another place.
12.18: As soon as it was day, the soldiers were in a world of confusion to know what was become of Peter.
12.19: Herod having caus'd diligent search to be made, without being able to find him, after examining the guards, he order'd them to execution, after which he departed from Judea, and went to Cesarea, where he resided.
12.20: Herod was then making warlike preparations against the Tyrians, and Sidonians: but they unanimously sent a deputation to court: where having gain'd Blastus the king's chamberlain, they brought matters to an accommodation: for their country was subsisted by the king's territorys.
12.21: one court-day, Herod array'd in his robes of state, and seated upon the throne, made a publick oration:
12.22: at which the people gave a shout, saying, it is the voice of a God, and not of a man.
12.23: but at the instant an angel of the Lord smote him, because he did not glorify God: so that he became a prey to worms and died. In the mean time, the
12.24: word of God made continual progress, and after Barnabas
12.25: and Saul had executed their commission, they return'd to Jerusalem, and took with them John who was surnam'd Mark.

13.1: Now there were several prophets and teachers in the church of Antioch, as Barnabas, Simeon surnam'd Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
13.2: as they were ministring to the Lord, and fasting, the holy spirit said to them, separate me Barnabas and Saul, for the work to which I have destin'd them.
13.3: accordingly, after having fasted and prayed they gave them imposition of hands, and dismiss'd them.
13.4: being thus appointed missionarys by the holy spirit, they went to Seleucia, where they embark'd for Cyprus.
13.5: when they were arrived at Salamis, they preach'd the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews, and had John for their assistant.
13.6: Having travers'd the isle as far as to Paphos, they found a Jew there nam'd Barjesus, who was a false prophet and magician:
13.7: he was with the proconsul Sergius Paulus, a man of prudence: who sent for Barnabas and Saul, desiring to hear the word of God.
13.8: but Elymas (a name which signifies Magus) opposed them, endeavouring to seduce the proconsul from the faith.
13.9: then Saul, who was nam'd likewise Paul, full of the holy spirit, look'd fixedly upon him,
13.10: and said, "thou heap of imposture and mischief, offspring of the devil, and enemy to all justice, wilt thou not cease to pervers men from the right ways of the Lord?
13.11: his hand is falling upon thee, thou shalt be blind, and not see the sun for some time." immediately his eyes were covered with obscurity and darkness; so that he grop'd about for somebody to lead him by the hand.
13.12: the proconsul seeing the fact, embraced the faith, being struck with admiration of the christian doctrine.
13.13: after which Paul and his company set out from Paphos to Perga in Pamphilia, where John quitted them in order to return to Jerusalem.
13.14: From Perga they went to Antioch in Pisidia, and going to the synagogue on the sabbath-day, they took their places,
13.16: thereupon Paul stood up, and having made sign with his hand for their attention, he said, men of Israel, and ye that fear God, give audience.
13.17: the God of Israel made choice of our fathers, and exalted the people when they sojourn'd in Egypt, from whence he conducted them by the terror of his arm.
13.18: for forty years he maintain'd them in the wilderness.
13.19: after that he distributed to them by lot the territorys of seven nations, which he destroyed in Canaan.
13.21: when having demanded a king, God gave them Saul the son of Cis, of the tribe of Benjamin: the government of both having lasted forty years,
13.22: God removed Saul, and rais'd up David to be their king, to whom he gave this testimonial, " I have found David the son of Jesse: he is a man most acceptable to me, and he will execute all my orders."
13.24: before his appearance, John had preach'd the baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
13.25: and in the discharge of his mission, he said, "who do you think I am? I am not the Messias, but there comes another after me, whose shoes I am not worthy to untie."
13.27: as for the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and their senators, by their not knowing who he was, and by condemning him, they have accomplished the declarations of the prophets, which are read every sabbath-day:
13.28: although they could not convict him of any thing capital, yet they demanded of Pilate, that he should be put to death.
13.29: after they had accomplished all that was written concerning him, he was taken down from the cross, and laid in a sepulchre:
13.30: but God raised him from the dead:
13.31: and for many days he was seen by those, who had accompany'd him from Galilee to Jerusalem: and they are now his witnesses to the people.
13.32: to you therefore we declare, that the promise which God had made to the fathers, he has now perform'd to us, who are their children, by his having raised up Jesus again.
13.33: agreeable to what is written in the first psalm, "thou art my son, this day have I begotten thee."
13.34: and to show that he rais'd him from the dead, never more to return to corruption, he said thus, "I will faithfully perform the promises, which I made to David."
13.35: wherefore in another place he says, "thou shalt not suffer thy holy one to see corruption."
13.36: for David, after he had serv'd in his time the designs of providence, died and was buryed with his fathers, and was subject to corruption.
13.37: but he, whom God hath raised, was not subject to corruption.
13.38: know then, my brethren, it is by him, that the remission of sins is offer'd to you:
13.39: by him, every one who believes, is purged from all that guilt, for which the law of Moses had made no such provision.
13.40: take care then, that what the prophets predicted may not happen to you,
13.41: "consider you despisers, be surpriz'd and turn pale, for I shall perform a work in your days, which you will not believe, whoever shall declare it unto you."
13.42: When Paul and Barnabas were gone out of the Jewish synagogue, the Gentiles desired them to entertain them on the same subject, the following sabbath.
13.43: when the assembly was separated, many Jews and religious proselytes followed after, to whom the apostles address'd themselves, and exhorted them to persevere in the divine dispensation.
13.44: The next sabbath-day almost the whole city assembled to hear the word of God.
13.45: when the Jews saw such a crowd, they were fill'd with resentment, and oppos'd what Paul had advanc'd, even to blasphemy.
13.46: but Paul and Barnabas told them boldly, you indeed were the first, to whom the word of God was to be preach'd: but since you reject it, and judge your own selves unworthy of eternal life, be assur'd, we shall make the same offer to the Gentiles:
13.47: for thus has the Lord commanded us, "I have appointed you to be a light to the Gentiles, that you should bring salvation to the remotest parts of the earth."
13.48: when the Gentiles heard this, they received the word with joy, glorifying the Lord: and as many as were dispos'd to eternal life, believed.
13.49: and the word of the Lord spread through the whole country.
13.50: but the Jews having animated the women of quality of their religion, and the leading men of the city, raised a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and banish'd them from their territorys.
13.51: so they shook off the dust of their feet against them, and went to Iconium.
13.52: and the disciples were filled with joy, and with the holy spirit.

14.1: Being arriv'd at Iconium, they went both together to the Jewish synagogue, where they discours'd in such a manner, that a great number both of Jews and of Greeks believed.
14.2: but the disbelieving Jews practis'd upon the Gentiles, and inflam'd their minds against the brethren.
14.3: however the apostles stay'd there a considerable time, being inspir'd with great resolution by the Lord, who gave his attestation to the evangelical doctrine, by the prodigys and miracles, which he did by their hands.
14.4: so that the people of the city were divided, some siding with the Jews, and others with the apostles.
14.5: upon this the Gentiles and the Jews, supported by their magistrates, made an insurrection in order to use violence against them, and even to stone them:
14.6: of which they were appriz'd, and fled to Lystra and Derbe, citys of Lycaonia, and to the adjacent country,
14.8: Now at Lystra there was a man, who could not stand upon his feet, he was born a cripple, and had never walked about.
14.9: one day he heard Paul preach, who fixing his eyes upon him, and perceiving that he expected to be cured,
14.10: he said to him aloud, rise and stand right upon your feet: upon which he leap'd up and walk'd.
14.11: When the people saw what Paul had done, they cry'd out in the Lycaonian tongue, the Gods have assum'd a human form, and are descended among us.
14.12: Barnabas, they stiled Jupiter; and Paul, Mercury, because he was the chief speaker.
14.13: even the priest of Jupiter, whose statue was at the city-gates, brought oxen and garlands there, and together with the people, would have offer'd sacrifice to the apostles.
14.14: but Paul and Barnabas being appriz'd of it, tore their clothes, and throwing themselves among the crowd,
14.15: cry'd out, "sirs, what are you going to do? we are but men as well as you, and we exhort you to renounce these vanities, and turn to the living God, who made the heaven, the earth and the sea, and all that they contain:
14.16: who in past ages has let all Nations proceed in their own ways.
14.17: nevertheless he sufficiently display'd himself by his beneficence to mankind, in giving us rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, replenishing our hearts with food and gladness."
14.18: but whatever they could say, it was with difficulty that they restrain'd the people from sacrificing to them.
14.19: Now some Jews being arriv'd from Antioch and Iconium, work'd so upon the people, that they stoned Paul, and dragg'd him out of the city, supposing he had been dead.
14.20: but the disciples being gather'd about him, he rose up and went into the city, from whence he departed the next day with Barnabas to go to Derbe.
14.21: After they had preach'd the gospel in that city, and made many disciples, they retook the road to Lystra, Iconium and Antioch,
14.22: encouraging the disciples, exhorting them to persevere in the faith, representing that it is thro' much tribulation that we must enter into the kingdom of God.
14.23: and after they had by prayers and fastings establish'd Pastors for them in every church, they recommended them to the Lord in whom they had believed.
14.24: at length they pass'd thro' Pisidia, and came to Pamphilia:
14.25: and having preach'd the word in Perga, they went to Attalia:
14.26: from thence they sailed to Antioch, where they had been recommended to the favour of God, for the commission, which they had now discharg'd.
14.27: when they were arrived, and had assembled the Church, they related what great things God had wrought by them, and how he had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles:
14.28: and they resided there a considerable time with the disciples.

15.1: However some that arrived from Judea, told the Gentile converts, unless you are circumcised agreeably to the law of Moses, you cannot be saved.
15.2: upon which Paul and Barnabas having warmly contested the point with them, it was resolved, that Paul and Barnabas and some others should go to Jerusalem to consult the apostles upon this question.
15.3: so they set out, accompanied part of the way by the church, and pass'd thro' Phenicia and Samaria, relating the conversion of the Gentiles, which gave great joy to all the brethren.
15.4: and being arrived at Jerusalem, they were receiv'd by the church, by the apostles, and presbyters, to whom they related all that God had done by them.
15.5: but some of the sect of the Pharisees who had embraced the faith, started up, pretending that the Gentiles ought to be circumcised, and observe the law of Moses.
15.6: The apostles therefore, and the presbyters assembled to deliberate upon this affair.
15.8: God who knows their hearts has granted them a testimonial, by giving them the holy spirit, even as he did to us:
15.9: making no difference between us and them, having purified their hearts by the faith.
15.10: why therefore do you tempt God to put a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither we nor our forefathers were able to bear?
15.11: but we believe that it is by the favour of the Lord Jesus Christ, that we are to be sav'd, as well as they.
15.12: The whole assembly were very silent, whilst Barnabas and Paul related what miracles and prodigies God had wrought among the Gentiles by their ministry.
15.14: Simon has related how God began to visit the Gentiles, to chuse from among them a people consecrated to his name.
15.15: and this is agreeable to the oracles of the prophets: as it is written,
15.17: I will repair its ruins, and raise it up: that the rest of mankind, even all the nations, that profess my name, may seek the Lord.
15.18: he that does all these things, is the Lord himself that has said it." for the works of God are all known to him from the beginning of the world.
15.19: wherefore my opinion is not to disquiet the Gentile converts: but only to write to them,
15.20: that they abstain from the pollutions of idols, from fornication, from animals that are strangled, and from their blood.
15.21: for as to the law of Moses, that has been published in every city a considerable time, being read in the synagogues every sabbath-day.
15.22: Then the apostles, the presbyters, and the whole church thought it proper to select some out of their own body to accompany Paul and Barnabas to Antioch: such as Judas surnam'd Barsabas, and Silas, leading men among the brethren,
15.23: whom they charg'd with this letter. The apostles, the presbyters, and the brethren, to the Gentile brethren at Antioch, in Syria, and Cilicia, send greeting.
15.24: Whereas we have been appriz'd, that some who went from us, have embarass'd you with their discourse, and unsettled your minds, maintaining, that you ought to be circumcised, and to observe the law, though we gave them no such injunction: after having been assembled,
15.25: we unanimously judg'd it proper to send particular deputies to you, with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
15.26: men that have exposed their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.27: we therefore send Judas and Silas to inform you in person of this affair.
15.28: for by the holy spirit it seemed good to us, to lay no greater burthen upon you, than these necessary injunctions;
15.29: that you abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the flesh of strangled animals, and from fornication: you will do well to preserve your selves from these practices, farewel.
15.30: Being thus dispatch'd, they went to Antioch; where having assembled all the faithful, they deliver'd the letter: from the reading of which,
15.31: they were affected with joy at the comfortable contents, as for Judas and Silas,
15.32: they being also prophets, they consolated and confirm'd the brethren by several discourses.
15.33: and after they had stay'd there some time, with the good wishes of the brethren, they had leave to go to the apostles.
15.34: however Silas thought fit to stay at Antioch,
15.35: where Paul and Barnabas continued, teaching and preaching the doctrine of the Lord, with many others.
15.36: Some time after, Paul said to Barnabas, let us return to visit all those cities, where we have preach'd the word of the Lord, to see what condition the brethren are in.
15.37: upon which Barnabas propos'd to take John surnam'd Mark, with them.
15.38: but Paul did not think it proper to take one that had quitted them at Pamphylia, refusing to accompany them in their ministry.
15.39: and the contention was so sharp between them, that they separated: so Barnabas took Mark, and sailed to Cyprus.
15.40: but Paul chose Silas, and having been recommended by the brethren to the favour of God,
15.41: he departed, and passing through Syria and Cilicia, he settled the churches there.

16.1: Paul arrived then at Derbe and Lystra, where there was a disciple named Timothy, whose mother was a Jewish convert, but his father a Greek.
16.2: as the brethren of Lystra and Iconium gave him a good character, Paul had a mind he should accompany him.
16.3: so he took him and had him circumcised, out of regard to the Jews of that country, who all knew his father was a Greek.
16.4: as they pass'd through the cities, they recommended it to the faithful to observe the decisions, made by the apostles and presbyters at Jerusalem.
16.5: thus were the churches established in the faith, and daily grew more numerous.
16.6: but after they had travers'd Phrygia and Galatia, they were order'd by the holy spirit not to preach the gospel in Asia:
16.7: being therefore arrived in Mysia, they essayed to go into Bithynia, but the spirit of Jesus would not allow it: so they pass'd by Mysia,
16.10: immediately after he had had this vision, we endeavoured to go into Macedonia, concluding from thence, that the Lord had called us to publish the gospel there, we embark'd therefore at Troas,
16.11: and sail'd directly to Samothracia, and the next day landed at Neapolis.
16.12: from thence we marched to Philippi, the chief city of that part of Macedonia, and a colony, having stopp'd there some days,
16.13: we went out of town on the sabbath towards the river, where the Jews were allowed to have an oratory.
16.14: so we took our places, and convers'd with the women, that came there, one of them was nam'd Lydia of Thyatira, a trader in purple, and a Jewish proselyte, she heard us: and the Lord inclin'd her heart to attend to what Paul said.
16.15: so that having been baptized with her family, she made us this request, if you think me sincere in my profession, pray come and lodge at my house; and she prevail'd upon us.
16.16: One day as we went to the oratory, we happen'd to meet a slave, who had the spirit Python, and was very gainful to her masters by telling of fortunes.
16.17: as she followed Paul and the rest of us, she cried out, these men are the servants of the most high God, who show you the way to salvation.
16.18: this she did for several days, till Paul tir'd with it turn'd about, and said to the spirit, in the name of Jesus Christ I command you to quit her; and instantly he came out.
16.19: her masters finding they had lost such a prospect of gain, seized upon Paul and Silas, and hawl'd them to the publick place before the magistrates.
16.20: having presented them to the Officers, they said, these men, who are Jews, raise great disorders in our city, and preach such maxims,
16.21: as it is not lawful for Romans, as we are, to admit or practise.
16.22: upon this the populace rose upon them, and the Officers order'd them to be stript and scourg'd.
16.23: after they had been severely lash'd, they were thrown into prison, the jayler being charg'd to keep them safe.
16.24: in consequence of this order he thrust them into the inner prison, and made their feet fast in the stocks.
16.25: At midnight Paul and Silas went to prayers, and sang praises to God, which the other prisoners heard:
16.26: when all of a sudden there was such a great earthquake, that the foundations of the prison were shaken: immediately all the doors opened, and the setters dropp'd from the prisoners.
16.27: the jayler waking, and seeing the prison-doors open, drew his sword, designing to dispatch himself from the apprehension that the prisoners had escaped.
16.29: then having called for a light, he ran in, and with trembling fell down before Paul and Silas;
16.30: and bringing them out, he said, sirs, what must I do to be saved?
16.32: then they declared the word of the Lord to him, and to all his family.
16.33: at the same time of night he washed their stripes, and immediately he was baptized, he, and all that belong'd to him.
16.34: then he conducted them to his house, and gave them an entertainment; and he and his family were affected with joy, for having believed in God.
16.35: When it was day the officers sent their serjeants to bid the jayler let the men go.
16.36: so the jayler told Paul, the magistrates had order'd them to be discharg'd, depart then, said he, and go in peace.
16.37: but Paul replied, they have publickly scourg'd us, who are Romans, without any trial, they have thrown us into jayl, and now do they give us a private discharge? no, let them come themselves and release us.
16.38: the serjeants having reported what he said, to their officers, they began to be apprehensive upon hearing they were Romans.
16.39: so they came, and by persuasions brought them out, and desired them to leave the city.
16.40: then they quitted the prison, and went to Lydia's house, where finding the brethren, they gave them an exhortation, and departed.

17.1: Having pass'd thro' Amphipolis and Apollonia, they arriv'd at Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue.
17.2: Paul, as was his custom, us'd to go there, and for three sabbath-days discours'd to the Jews from the scriptures,
17.3: explaining them, and setting it to view, that the Messiah was to suffer and rise again from the dead: and that Jesus, whom he denounc'd to them, was that very Messiah.
