17.4: Some of them believed, and join'd themselves to Paul and Silas, besides a great number of Greek proselytes, and several women of distinction.
17.5: but the unbelieving Jews thro' envy, by the assistance of some loose strolers, rais'd a mob, set the whole city in an uproar, and attack'd Jason's house, thinking to find them there, and deliver them up to the populace.
17.6: but not finding them, they dragg'd Jason and some of the brethren to the magistrates, crying out, these that have been every where the disturbers of the publick peace, are come hither also, and have been entertain'd by Jason.
17.7: they all act in defiance of the edicts of Cesar, pretending there is another king, one Jesus.
17.8: the people, and the magistrates upon hearing this were alarm'd:
17.9: however having oblig'd Jason and the rest to give security, they let them go.
17.10: Immediately the brethren sent away Paul and Silas by night to Berea, where being arriv'd, they went into the synagogue.
17.11: the Jews there were of a more generous temper than those of Thessalonica: for they very readily embrac'd their doctrine, and daily examin'd, whether it was conformable to the scriptures.
17.12: so that many of them believed, besides a considerable number of women of distinction, and of men, that were Greeks.
17.13: but when the Jews of Thessalonica were inform'd that Paul had preached the word of God at Berea, they went thither to stir up the populace.
17.14: Upon this the brethren immediately sent Paul away to the sea-coast, but Silas and Timothy staid there.
17.15: however Paul's guides attended him to Athens: where they left him, after having received his orders for Silas and Timothy to come to him with all speed.
17.16: While Paul was expecting them at Athens, he was grieved to the soul to see the whole city o'er-spread with idols.
17.17: he disputed therefore in the synagogue with the Jews, and the proselyted Greeks: and in the publick place daily with those he met.
17.18: there certain Epicurean and Stoick philosophers encountred him: "what does this mountebank mean?" said some: "he seems to proclaim some strange deitys," said others: because he talk'd to them of Jesus and the resurrection.
17.19: One day they conducted him to the Areopagus, and said to him, may we know what this new doctrine is, which you publish?
17.20: for what you say sounds so very strange, we should be glad to know what it means.
17.21: now the Athenians, and the foreigners residing at Athens generally amus'd themselves about nothing, but hearing and spreading of news.
17.22: Then Paul being plac'd in the middle of the Areopagus, said thus, "I observe, O Athenians, that you are in a manner too devout.
17.23: for considering, as I pass'd along, the deitys, which you adore, I met with an altar that had this inscription, TO THE UNKNOWN GOD, now that GOD whom you worship without knowing him, is the same that I denounce to you.
17.24: the GOD who made the world and every thing therein, and is the Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples erected by men:
17.25: he receives no service from their officiousness: he is self-sufficient: it is he that gives to all their life and breath and every thing they have.
17.26: he he has deduced all mankind from one parent, to inhabit the surface of the whole earth, having pre-establish'd the appointed periods, and the boundarys of their dominions:
17.27: by which they might enquire, and by due reflection investigate the supreme being, although he be not far from every one of us: for in him we live,
17.29: since then we are the offspring of God, we should not imagine that the Deity bears any resemblance to the form which Gold, or Silver, or Stone has receiv'd from human art and industry.
17.30: God has been pleas'd to over-look this state of ignorance: but now he enjoins all men every where to repent:
17.31: because he has fix'd the day, when he will judge in equity, by that man, whom he has appointed thereto: of which he has given full proof to all the world, by having raised him from the dead."
17.32: When they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some made it a matter of ridicule: others said, we will hear you again upon this subject;
17.33: upon which Paul left the assembly.
17.34: however, there were some who adher'd to him, as Denis the Areopagite, a woman named Damaris, and others with them.

18.1: After this Paul left Athens and arriv'd at Corinth:
18.2: where having found a Jew nam'd Aquila, a native of Pontus, who lately came from Italy, with his wife Priscilla, because Claudius had order'd all the Jews to quit Rome; he went to them:
18.3: and being of the same trade, he liv'd with them, and follow'd the business of tent-making, every sabbath he disputed in the synagogue,
18.4: and try'd to gain upon the Jews and the Greek proselytes:
18.5: and when Silas and Timothy were arriv'd from Macedonia, Paul with great concern remonstrated to the Jews, that Jesus was the Messiah:
18.6: but as they oppos'd him with invectives, he shook his garment, and said, "you your selves be answerable for your own destruction, I am clear: and for the future I shall address my self to the Gentiles."
18.7: When he had left them, he went to the house of one Justus a proselyte to Judaism, who lived near the synagogue: however Crispus,
18.8: the chief ruler of the synagogue, believed on the Lord with all his family, as well as many of the Corinthians, who heard Paul, and were baptized.
18.10: (since I am with thee, and no man shall lift up his hand so as to hurt thee:) for my people in this city are numerous."
18.11: so he continued there a year and a half preaching the word of God among them.
18.12: When Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews made a general insurrection against Paul, and carry'd him to his tribunal.
18.13: this fellow, said they, would persuade us to set up a way of worship inconsistent with our law.
18.14: and when Paul was going to speak, Gallio said to the Jews, "if it were a matter of some injustice or something immoral, O Jews, it would be reasonable to hear you out.
18.15: but since it is about disputable matters, about names, and your own law, you may decide that among yourselves: for I won't take cognizance of such affairs."
18.16: upon which he order'd them to withdraw.
18.17: but the Greeks in a body fell upon Sosthenes the chief ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the tribunal: whilst Gallio was unconcern'd about the matter.
18.18: Paul still continued a considerable time at Corinth, and then taking his leave of the brethren, he set sail for Syria, with Priscilla and Aquila, who had his head shav'd in Cenchrea upon account of a vow.
18.19: being arriv'd at Ephesus, he left them there, and went himself to the synagogue, where he disputed with the Jews,
18.20: who desired him to stay longer with them, but he would not consent to it: for,
18.21: said he, in taking his leave, I must necessarily keep the approaching feast at Jerusalem: after which I will return to you if God permit.
18.22: having sail'd from Ephesus, he went ashore at Cesarea, where he saluted the church, and then proceeded to Antioch.
18.23: after he had stay'd there some time, he departed and pass'd through all Galatia and Phrygia, where he encourag'd the disciples.
18.24: In the mean time a Jew, nam'd Apollos, born at Alexandria, a man of letters, and vers'd in the scriptures, arriv'd at Ephesus.
18.25: he had been instructed in the doctrine of the gospel, and being full of zeal, he harangued with great assiduity about what related to Jesus, though he had been only instituted in the baptism of John.
18.26: having talk'd with great freedom in the synagogue, Aquila and Priscilla, who had heard him, invited him home, and gave him a more distinct view of the gospel.
18.27: and being determin'd to pass into Achaia, the brethren who advis'd him to it, writ to the disciples to receive him, when he was arrived, he was, by the divine favour, very useful to those, who had receiv'd the faith.
18.28: for he strenuously disputed with the Jews in publick, proving from the scriptures that Jesus was the Messiah.

19.1: Whilst Apollos was at Corinth, Paul, having pass'd through the upper provinces of Asia, arrived at Ephesus, where finding some disciples, he said to them,
19.3: what baptism then, said he, did you receive? they replied, the baptism of John.
19.4: upon which Paul said, John indeed administer'd the baptism of repentance, but with this admonition, that they should believe in him, who was to come after, that is, in Jesus the Messias.
19.5: when they heard this, they were initiated by baptism into the christian profession.
19.6: and Paul having given them imposition of hands, the holy spirit came upon them, and they spoke foreign languages, and prophesied:
19.7: the number of them being about twelve.
19.8: At length Paul went to the synagogue, where he spoke with great freedom, and for three months he conferr'd with them to persuade them of the truth of the evangelical kingdom.
19.9: but some of them being such obdurate infidels as to inveigh against the institution before the populace, he retired, and taking the disciples with him, he instructed them daily in the school of one Tyrannus.
19.10: this he continued for two years; so that the Jews and proselytes of that part of Asia heard the doctrine of the Lord Jesus.
19.11: the miracles which God wrought by the ministry of Paul being of such an extraordinary nature, that by applying the handkerchiefs,
19.12: or aprons that had touch'd his skin, to the distemper'd, they were cured, and the evil spirits came out of the possessed.
19.13: Upon this, certain vagabond Jews, who were exorcists, pretended to cure demoniacs by pronouncing the name of the Lord Jesus: their form being this, "I adjure you by Jesus whom Paul preaches."
19.14: these practitioners were seven in number, the sons of Sceva a Jew, one of the chief priests.
19.15: but the evil spirit said to them, "Jesus I know, and Paul I know; but who are ye?"
19.16: the man who was possess'd immediately leapt upon them, got the better, and used them so roughly, they were forc'd to fly out of the house, cover'd with nothing but their wounds.
19.17: this was known to all the Jews and Greeks, that liv'd at Ephesus, who were all seiz'd with fear, and the name of the Lord Jesus was exalted.
19.18: many that believed came to confess, and give an account of their past actions.
19.19: many that had practis'd magical arts, brought the books and publickly threw them into the fire: the value by computation amounting to fifty thousand pieces of silver.
19.20: thus the christian doctrine flourish'd and prevail'd.
19.22: he sent therefore Timothy and Erastus, two of his assistants in the ministry, before to Macedonia; but stay'd himself in Asia for some time.
19.23: It was then a tumult happen'd at Ephesus upon account of the christian sect.
19.24: for one Demetrius, a silver-smith, who made little models of Diana's temple, and so furnish'd a deal of employment to the workmen in that trade,
19.25: summon'd the company, and thus address'd them, "tho' you know, sirs, it is by this craft that we are in such plight,
19.26: yet your own eyes and ears have inform'd you, that not only at Ephesus, but almost throughout all Asia, this Paul by his persuasions has turn'd the heads of a world of people, asserting, that these are Gods of our own making, and not really such.
19.27: so that not only our profession runs the risk of being vilified; but the temple of the great goddess Diana will be depreciated, and her majesty, so rever'd thro' all Asia, and the whole world, will be discarded."
19.28: at these words, they were fir'd with indignation, and cry'd out, "great is Diana of the Ephesians."
19.29: and the whole city was fill'd with confusion: all crouded in a body to the theatre, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, both of Macedonia, who had travell'd with Paul.
19.30: upon this Paul was bent upon going, to the populace,
19.31: but was prevented by his disciples, and by the primates of Asia, who were his friends, and sent to desire he would not venture to the theatre:
19.32: there the mob were in the utmost riot, some bawling out in one cry, some in another, and the greatest part at a loss to know why they were met.
19.33: at last Alexander was disengag'd from the croud, and accus'd by the Jews, then he waved his hand, desiring to make his defence before them all.
19.34: but when they knew he was a Jew, they cry'd out one and all for the space of two hours, "great is Diana of the Ephesians."
19.35: at length the town-clerk appeased the people, and thus began, "who is there, O Ephesians, that does not know, that the city of Ephesus is the guardian of the temple of the great Diana, and of her statue, which fell from heaven:
19.36: since this is incontestible, it behoves you to be easy, and free from any rash conduct:
19.37: for the men you have brought here, have neither plunder'd your temples, nor inveigh'd against your goddess.
19.38: if Demetrius and the other artists, that are with him, can lay their action against any man, the law is open, and the proconsul is near; let them begin their process.
19.39: but if the contest be about other matters, it may be decided in a regular assembly.
19.40: for we run the risk of being answerable for this day's sedition: there being no justifiable occasion for such a commotion."
19.41: having thus harangued them, he broke up the assembly.

20.1: This disturbance being over, Paul sent for the disciples, took his leave and departed for Macedonia.
20.2: after having visited the faithful in those parts, and given them many exhortations, he went to Greece.
20.3: there he stay'd three months; and then the Jews conspiring to surprize him at his embarkation for Syria, it was thought adviseable he should return thro' Macedonia. Sopater of Berea,
20.4: Aristarchus and Secundus of Thessalonica, Gaius of Derby and Timothy, Tychicus and Trophimus both Asiatics, all accompanied him to Asia,
20.5: and then advanc'd before and waited for us at Troas.
20.6: after the feast of unleaven'd bread we sail'd from Philippi, and in five days we join'd them at Troas, where we stay'd seven.
20.7: on the first day of the week we assembled to break bread, when Paul, who was to depart on the morrow, gave them a sermon, which lasted till midnight.
20.8: in the upper chamber where we were assembled, several lamps were burning:
20.9: and as Paul continued his discourse a great while, a young man, named Eutychus, who was sitting in the window, was seiz'd with a deep sleep, which quite o'er-came him; so that he fell down from the third story, and was taken up dead.
20.11: then Paul went up again, and having broken bread and eaten, he reassumed his discourse till break of day, and then departed.
20.12: but the young man was brought in alive and well, to the joy of the whole assembly. As for us, we embark'd, and sail'd to Assos,
20.13: where by appointment Paul was to be taken aboard, designing himself to go thither by land.
20.14: meeting with him at Assos, we took him in and arriv'd at Mitylene:
20.15: from thence we bore away: the next day we came off Chios, and the day after we pass'd by Samos, landing at Trogyllium, and arrived at Miletus the next day.
20.16: for Paul had determined not to go ashore at Ephesus, to avoid losing time in Asia: because he was eager to get to Jerusalem, if possible, by the day of pentecost.
20.17: At Miletus he sent a message to the pastors of the church at Ephesus, to come to him:
20.18: and when they were arriv'd he told them, you know how I have always behav'd towards you from the first day of my arrival in Asia:
20.19: how I have serv'd the Lord with all resignation, with tears, and trials occasion'd by the insidious practices of the Jews:
20.20: that I have conceal'd nothing that might be useful to you, but have inform'd you of it, and instructed you therein, both in publick and in private:
20.21: remonstrating both to Jews and Gentiles the advantages of a sincere repentance, and of believing
20.23: save what the holy spirit in every city declares, "that bonds and afflictions wait for me."
20.24: things that little affect me, nor is life so much my concern, as to finish my course, and the charge I receiv'd from the Lord Jesus, to attest the declaration of the divine favour.
20.25: and now I am persuaded you will none of you see my face any more: whilst I have been among you, I have proclaim'd the kingdom of the Messias:
20.26: I therefore declare to you at this present time, that I am not responsible for the ruin of any:
20.27: for I have acquainted you with the whole dispensation of God without reserve.
20.28: be therefore upon your guard to secure your selves, and the whole flock over which the holy spirit has made you overseers, to feed the church of God, which he has purchased with his own blood.
20.29: for I know when I am gone, you will be oppress'd by wolves, that will not spare the flock.
20.30: nay, among your own body some will start up to vent their intricate conceits, and draw a number of followers.
20.31: be then upon the watch, and remember, that for three years I have not ceased by night, or by day to warn every soul of you, even with tears.
20.32: and now, my brethren, I recommend you to God, and to his gracious dispensation, which is able to improve you, and secure to you the inheritance with those who are sanctify'd.
20.33: I have not desir'd to get from any one either silver, or gold, or apparel.
20.34: you yourselves can witness, that what was necessary for myself and those who were with me, these very hands have supply'd.
20.35: my constant example has shown you that the disabled should be assisted by your labours, remembring the words of the Lord Jesus, who said, "it is a greater happiness to give than to receive."
20.36: After this discourse, he kneeled down, and prayed with them all.
20.37: then melted into tears, they fell upon his neck and kissed him,
20.38: being more particularly afflicted at his having said, "they should see his face no more." and then they conducted him to the ship.

21.1: After we were parted from them, and clear of land, we made directly for Cos, the next day to Rhodes, and from thence to Patara:
21.2: where finding a vessel bound to Phoenicia, we went aboard, and put off.
21.3: having made Cyprus, leaving it to the North, we took our course to Syria, and landed at Tyre, where the ship was to unlade her cargo.
21.4: we staid seven days with the disciples we met there: who told Paul from the holy spirit, that he should not go to Jerusalem.
21.5: that time being ended, we departed, being conducted by them in a body with the women and children quite out of the city, where we kneeled down on the shore, and prayed.
21.6: then having taken our leave of one another, we embark'd and they went home.
21.7: From Tyre we sail'd to Ptolemais, which ended our voyage, we saluted the brethren there, and staid a day with them.
21.8: on the morrow we set out, and arriv'd at Cesarea, and went to the house of Philip the evangelist, with whom we lodg'd:
21.9: he was one of the seven deacons, and had four daughters all virgins, prophetesses.
21.10: after we had been there several days, a prophet arriv'd from Judea, one Agabus, who made us a visit.
21.11: when taking Paul's girdle, he bound his own feet and hands, and said, "thus saith the holy spirit, so shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man, that owns this girdle, and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles."
21.12: upon hearing this, we and some of the city intreated him not to go to Jerusalem.
21.13: but Paul replied, what do you mean by afflicting me thus with your tears? I am not only ready to meet my chains, but even to die at Jerusalem, for the name of the Lord Jesus.
21.14: he being then inflexible, we desisted, saying, the will of the Lord be done.
21.15: after this we prepar'd for our journey to Jerusalem.
21.16: some of the disciples of Cesarea accompany'd us, bringing with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple, at whose house we were to lodge.
21.17: When we were arriv'd at Jerusalem, the brethren receiv'd us with joy.
21.18: the next day Paul went with us to James, where all the pastors assembled.
21.19: after having saluted them, he gave a particular account of what God had wrought by his ministry among the Gentiles.
21.20: upon hearing this, they gave glory to God: and thus address'd Paul, you see, brother, how many thousand believing Jews there are, all however zealous for the law.
21.21: now they have heard that you instruct the Jews that are among the Gentiles to abandon Moses, by telling them they must not circumcise their children, nor observe the establish'd rites.
21.22: what then is to be done? they will necessarily be all assembled, for they can't but hear, you are come.
21.23: yield then to our advice: there are four men here, who have made a vow:
21.24: these take, and perform the rites of purification with them, contributing to the expence of having their heads shav'd: this will convince them, what has been reported of you, is all groundless, and that you stick to the observances of the law.
21.25: as for the believing Gentiles, we have given them by letter this decision, "they need only take care to abstain from meats offered to idols, from blood, from the flesh of animals strangled, and from fornication."
21.26: accordingly Paul went to the men, and the next day was purified with them; then entring into the temple, he declar'd how long the time of the purification was to last, and when the offering was to be made for each of them.
21.27: The seven days being almost expir'd, the Asiatic Jews seeing him in the temple, rais'd a tumult, and fell upon him,
21.28: bawling out, "men of Israel, help: this is the man that every where inveighs upon all occasions against the people, against the law, and against this place, where they have brought Greeks too to profane this holy place."
21.29: (for having seen Trophimus an Ephesian with him in the city, they imagin'd Paul had conducted him into the temple.)
21.30: the whole city was in an uproar, the people crouded together: they seized Paul, dragg'd him out of the temple, and then shut the gates.
21.31: as they were busy upon his execution, news came to the commander of the cohort, that the whole city was in an uproar.
21.32: immediately he headed a detachment, with his centurions, and march'd briskly to them; who, upon seeing the officer and his men, left off beating Paul.
21.33: the commander advanc'd, seiz'd him, and order'd to load him with two chains: then demanded who he was, and what he had done.
21.34: in the hubbub some cry'd one thing, some another: so that not being able to get any information for the tumult, he order'd him to be carried to the castle.
21.35: as he was mounting the stairs, the soldiers bore him up thro' the violence of the people, who were all pressing after,
21.38: are not you the Egyptian, who lately made an insurrection at the head of four thousand banditti in the desart?
21.39: Paul replied, I am a Jew of Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of that famous city: and I beg you would give me leave to speak to the people: which being granted,
21.40: Paul then standing upon the stairs made a sign with his hand to the people, who being very silent, he rais'd his voice, and thus address'd them in the Hebrew tongue:

22.2: when they perceiv'd he talk'd Hebrew, they were the more silent.
22.3: then he said, I am a Jew, a native of Tarsus in Cilicia, but had my education in this city: at the feet of Gamaliel I was instructed in the law, and in the exact decisions of our fathers, and was as religiously zealous as you are at this time.
22.4: for I persecuted this sect even to death, throwing them into chains and prisons both men and women:
22.5: this the high-priest and the senate know too well: from them I receiv'd my warrant directed to the Jews of Damascus, where I went, to bring the converts there in chains to Jerusalem, in order to be punished.
22.7: I fell to the ground, and heard a voice pronounce these words, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?"
22.8: I answered, who art thou, Lord? it answered, "I am Jesus the Nazarene whom thou dost persecute."
22.9: the company actually saw the light, but did not hear the voice of him that spoke to me.
22.11: but as I had lost the use of my eyes by the splendor of that light, I was led by the hand to Damascus, by those who were with me.
22.14: then he said, the God of our fathers has singled you out to be acquainted with his will, to see the just one, and to hear the words of his mouth:
22.15: that you might testify to all men, what you have seen and heard.
22.16: why should you now delay? arise, be baptized, and cleansed from your sins, by invoking the name of the Lord.
22.17: at length being return'd to Jerusalem, one day as I was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance.
22.18: then I saw JESUS, who said to me, "make haste, and go out of Jerusalem immediately: for they will not receive the attestations you would give of me." Lord,
22.19: said I, they know it is I that imprison'd those who believed on thee, and caus'd them to be scourg'd in the assemblies:
22.20: that I was present, when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, that I abetted the slaughter, and watch'd the clothes of those who slew him.
22.21: but the Lord said to me, "be gone, for I will send you far hence, even to the Gentiles."
22.22: Till that word, the Jews had given their attention, but then they broke out into a full cry, "out of the world with such a fellow: for it is not fit he should live."
22.23: thus they roar'd, and threw off their cloaks, and scatter'd dust in the air:
22.24: when the commanding officer order'd him to be brought into the castle, and put to the question by the lash, in order to find out the reason of their exclamations against him.
22.25: as they were tying him with thongs, Paul said to the centurion, does the law allow to scourge a Roman citizen, and without any trial?
22.26: upon hearing that, the centurion went to acquaint the head officer, take care, said he, what you do; for this man is a Roman.
22.27: then the head officer came to him, and said, tell me, are you a Roman?
22.29: immediately those who were going to put him to the question, withdrew: the commander himself being under some apprehension for having order'd him to be bound.
22.30: as he was resolv'd to know for certain, the next day, what the Jews laid to his charge, he took off his chains, and summon'd the chief priests, and the council to appear, when Paul was brought, and presented before them.

23.2: at which the high priest Ananias order'd those that were near him to strike him on the face:
23.3: which made Paul say, "may God strike thee, thou plaister'd wall: you sit to judge me according to law, and in defiance of the law you order me to be struck!"
23.7: at these words the Pharisees and the Sadducees were all in confusion, the whole assembly being divided:
23.8: for the Sadducees maintain, there is neither resurrection, nor angel, or spirit, whereas the Pharisees acknowledge both: the clamour was great,
23.9: and the Scribes taking part with the Pharisees, grew warm in the debate, and said, "we find no harm in this man; perhaps a spirit or an angel has spoke to him."
23.10: but the tumult growing worse, the tribune apprehensive that Paul might be torn to pieces among them, order'd detachment to secure him by force of arms, and bring him to the castle.
23.11: The night following, the Lord appear'd to him, and said, Paul, take courage; for the same remonstrances that you have made concerning me at Jerusalem, you must likewise make at Rome.
23.12: when it was day, some Jews, that had form'd a conspiracy, engag'd themselves by an oath, not to eat, or drink, till they had kill'd Paul.
23.13: the conspirators, who were above forty in number,
23.14: went to the chief priests and senators, and said, "we have bound our selves by oath not to eat till we have slain Paul.
23.15: if you will move it then to the tribune in the name of the Sanhedrim, to send him here to-morrow, under colour of examining his affair with more solemnity, we shall take care to dispatch him, and make a short end of his journey."
23.16: Paul's sister's son hearing of the ambuscade, went to the castle, and being admitted, told Paul;
23.17: who having sent for one of the centurions, said, introduce this young man to the tribune, for he has something to communicate to him.
23.18: accordingly he went along with him, and having introduc'd him to the tribune, he said, Paul, who is in custody sent for me, and desired me to introduce this young man, who has something to tell you.
23.19: then the tribune taking him by the hand, retir'd with him in private, and ask'd, what he had to say.
23.20: the Jews, said he, have agreed to desire you would send Paul down to-morrow to the council, under the pretext of examining him more strictly.
23.21: but don't believe them: for above forty of them lie in ambush, having bound themselves by oath not to eat or drink till they have kill'd him: they are already prepar'd, and only wait your answer.
23.23: then calling two of his centurions, draw out, said he, two hundred foot, seventy horse, and two hundred archers, ready to march to Cesarea by the third hour of the night:
23.24: let them take care to see Paul mounted, and convoy him safe to governour Felix.
23.25: at the same time he writ a letter to Felix to this purport.
23.26: CLAUDIUS LYSIAS to the most excellent governour FELIX wishes health.
23.27: The Jews having seiz'd this man, were just upon the point to dispatch him, when I march'd with a body to his rescue;
23.28: having been informed he was a Roman, I had him brought before their Sanhedrim, to hear what crime they laid to his charge.
23.29: but I found their accusation turned upon certain topics of their law, and contain'd nothing that was capital, or that deserv'd imprisonment:
23.30: and having intelligence that the Jews had form'd a conspiracy against him, I immediately sent him to you, directing his accusers to lay their charge before you, farewel.
23.31: The soldiers pursuant to order took Paul, and conducted him by night to Antipatris.
23.32: on the morrow they march'd back to the castle, having left him to the custody of the horse:
23.33: who upon their arrival at Cesarea, delivered the letter to the governour, and presented Paul to him.
23.34: The governour having read the letter, ask'd Paul of what province he was, and being inform'd he was of Cilicia, you shall be heard,
23.35: said he, when your accusers are come: and then order'd him to the guard-room at Herod's palace.

24.1: Five days after the sovereign pontiff Ananias arriv'd and some of the senators, who with one Tertullus a pleader, appear'd before the governour as plaintiffs against Paul.
24.2: so Paul was call'd, and Tertullus thus open'd the charge.
24.3: "The happiness our nation enjoys, most noble Felix, by the wisdom of your administration, affects us too sensibly not to be acknowledg'd every where, and upon all occasions, with the utmost gratitude.
24.4: but not to trespass upon you too far, be pleas'd to hear what I have to say in brief, with your usual indulgence.
24.5: this man is known to be a pernicious fellow that goes about the world to raise seditions among the Jews: he is the ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes,
24.6: and has attempted to prophane the temple: we secur'd him, and would have try'd him by our law:
24.7: but general Lysias interpos'd, and with open force took him out of our hands,
24.8: ordering his accusers to appear before you, if you please to interrogate him yourself, you will find the whole charge to be truly laid."
24.9: this the Jews confirm'd by declaring it was all fact.
24.10: Then the governour sign'd to Paul to reply; who said, I enter upon my defence with the greater confidence, by considering you have govern'd this nation several years:
24.11: possibly you are appriz'd, that it is not above twelve days since, that I went to Jerusalem to worship.
24.12: they neither found me in conference with any one in the temple, nor working up the people either in the assemblies or in the streets:
24.13: so far are they from proving what they lay to my charge.
24.14: I do indeed own, that I serve the God of our nation according to the discipline they call sect: and believe whatever is written in the law and in the prophets.
24.15: I have the same expectations from the DEITY, which they themselves entertain, that of the resurrection both of the just and of the unjust.
24.16: and 'tis my endeavour to preserve a conscience free from reproach both with respect to God, and with respect to men.
24.17: after several years absence I came to Jerusalem, with contributions for my brethren, and oblations for the temple:
24.18: there religiously employ'd some Asiatic Jews found me, without crowd or tumult:
24.19: and here they ought to have appear'd, if they had any thing to object against me.
24.20: or let these now declare, if they could convict me of any misdemeanor, when I was brought before the Sanhedrim:
24.21: unless it be, that I did indeed break out into this expression, it "is for the resurrection of the dead, that I am now call'd into question."
24.22: Then Felix adjourn'd them, saying, I shall inform myself more particularly of this sect, and when general Lysias comes, I will give you a full hearing.
24.23: Felix then order'd a centurion to take Paul into his custody, without confining him so as to hinder his friends from waiting upon him.
24.24: some time after he came to Cesarea with his wife Drusilla, a Jewess, when sending for Paul, he heard him discourse about the Christian faith.
24.25: but as he was treating of justice, temperance, and a future judgment, Felix greatly alarm'd, said, "withdraw for the present; and when I am at leisure, I will send for you."
24.26: this he frequently did, and convers'd with him upon the presumption that Paul would have
24.27: offer'd him mony in order to obtain his discharge, but two years after he was succeeded by Porcius Festus, who to oblige the Jews left Paul under confinement.

25.1: Three days after his arrival in the province, Festus went from Cesarea to Jerusalem:
25.2: when the high priest and the chief of the Jews waited upon him with an information against Paul,
25.3: "desiring the favour he might be sent for to Jerusalem." they having prepar'd measures to assassinate him upon the road.
25.4: Festus answer'd, that Paul was in custody at Cesarea, where he design'd to be himself e'er long:
25.5: the most considerable, said he, among you may go with me, and if he has committed any crime, let 'em begin the process.
25.6: Having staid above eight, nay ten days, he went to Cesarea, and on the morrow mounting the tribunal, he order'd Paul to be brought before him.
25.7: when he appear'd, the Jews, who were come from Jerusalem presented themselves before Festus, and loaded Paul with abundance of accusations, which they were not able to prove.
25.8: to this he answer'd, "I have not been guilty of any misdemeanour, either against the law, or against the temple, or against Cesar."
25.10: "I stand, said Paul, to the tribunal of Cesar, where I ought to be judged, to the Jews I have done no wrong, as you yourself very well know.
25.11: if I am guilty of any capital crime, I am contented to die, but since their accusations are all groundless, that I may not be sacrificed to their humour, I appeal to Cesar."
25.12: upon this, Festus having deliberated with his council, answer'd, "since you have appeal'd to Cesar, to Cesar you shall go."
25.13: Some days after, king Agrippa and Bernice came to Cesarea to make Festus a visit.
25.14: as they continued there for some time, Festus represented Paul's case to the king: Felix, said he, had left here a certain prisoner:
25.15: and when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and senators of the Jews made their appearance, and demanded to have justice against him.
25.16: I told them, it was not the custom of the Romans to deliver up any man, till he was accus'd and confronted by his accusers, and had an opportunity of pleading to the charge.
25.17: the next day after they were come, to avoid delay, I mounted the tribunal, and order'd the man to be brought.
25.18: when his accusers appear'd, they did not charge him with any such crimes as I imagined they would.
25.19: they objected certain articles that related only to their superstition, and to one Jesus that was dead, but Paul asserted he was alive.
25.20: being at a loss how to determine such an affair, I ask'd him if he would go to Jerusalem, and take his tryal there.
25.21: but Paul having made his appeal, insisting to have his cause refer'd to the cognizance of the emperor, I order'd him into custody, till I could send him to Cesar.
25.22: thereupon Agrippa told Festus, he himself should be glad to hear the man, to-morrow, said Festus, you shall hear him.
25.23: On the morrow Agrippa and Bernice came in great state, and being introduc'd into the court attended by the officers and the principal men of the city, Festus gave the word, and Paul was brought to the Bar.
25.24: then Festus said, "King Agrippa, and you that are here present, you see the man, against whom a numerous body of the Jews have been practising with me both at Jerusalem, and in this city, urging with vehemence, that he should not be suffer'd to live.
25.25: but finding he had done nothing that deserv'd death, I have resolved to send him to the emperor, to whom he had appealed.
25.26: as I have no certain account to communicate to the emperor my master, I caus'd him to appear before this assembly, and before you, king Agrippa, in particular, that after he is examin'd, I may know how to represent the affair;
25.27: for it seems to me absurd to send a prisoner without expressing the crimes laid to his charge."

26.1: Then Agrippa said to Paul, you are at liberty to make your defence, upon which Paul disengaging his hand from his cloak, thus made his plea.
26.2: I think myself happy, king Agrippa, in having this opportunity of vindicating myself in your presence, from every thing the Jews have laid to my charge:
26.3: for I know you are fully acquainted with the Jewish customs and controversies: and therefore I beg the indulgence of your attention.
26.4: what course of life I led at Jerusalem, where I was brought up from my youth among those of my own nation, is known to all the Jews.
26.5: they can testify, if they will, that I early profess'd myself a Pharisee, a member of the most rigorous sect of our religion:
26.6: and now I stand arraign'd for expecting the accomplishment of the divine promise made to our fathers,
26.7: which our twelve tribes by their continual services, night and day, hope themselves to obtain: yet for that hope, king Agrippa, do the Jews now accuse me.
26.8: you may think it something incredible that God should raise the dead:
26.9: I myself too once thought myself oblig'd strenuously to oppose the professors of Jesus the Nazarene, as I actually did at Jerusalem,
26.10: where numbers of converts I threw into jail, by warrant from the high priests: and when they were put to death, I myself was an accomplice.
26.11: it was I that persecuted them from synagogue to synagogue, and tortured them even to blaspheme: and in the transport of my rage I pursued them to foreign cities.
26.12: with such views, authorized by commission from the high priests, I was on the road to Damascus:
26.13: when at mid-day, O king, a light from heaven exceeding the splendor of the sun, broke all around me, and those that accompanied me.
26.14: we were all struck down: when I heard a voice directed to me pronounce these words in the Hebrew tongue, "Saul, Saul, why dost thou persecute me? it is dangerous for thee to kick against the goad."
26.15: I answer'd, who art thou, Lord? he said, "I am Jesus, whom thou persecutest.
26.16: but rise upright upon thy feet: for I have appear'd to thee in order to establish you my minister in testifying both what you have seen, and what I shall hereafter show to you,
26.17: by delivering you from this people, and from the Gentiles to whom I now send thee, to open their eyes,
26.18: and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and partake of the inheritance of the saints, by believing on me."
26.19: this heavenly vision, king Agrippa, I presently obey'd:
26.20: first I warn'd the people of Damascus, of Jerusalem, of all Judea, and then the Gentiles, to repent, and turn to God, by acting suitably to their repentance.
26.21: for such a conduct the Jews seiz'd upon me in the temple, designing to assassinate me;
26.22: but by the divine favour I am still preserv'd alive, testifying to the small and to the great nothing but what Moses and the prophets have predicted should happen: "that Christ should suffer:
26.23: that he should be the first that was to rise from the dead: and that he should enlighten both the Jews and the Gentiles."
26.24: As he was thus making his defence, Festus broke out into this exclamation, "Paul, you are mad: much study has turn'd your brain."
26.25: I am not mad, said he, most noble Festus, but what I say, is very sound truth.
26.26: the king is inform'd of these things, to whom I address myself with the greater confidence, being persuaded he is fully apprized of these matters, that were far from being transacted in private.
26.27: king Agrippa, don't you give credit to the prophetic writings? I know you do.
26.29: I pray God, said Paul, that not only you, but all that now hear me, were both almost and altogether such as I am, the circumstance of my bonds excepted.
26.30: When he had said this, the king, the governour, Bernice, and all that were seated near them, rose up: and being retired,
26.31: they declar'd to one another, "this man has done nothing that deserves either death or imprisonment:"
26.32: nay, Agrippa said to Festus, "this man might have been discharg'd if he had not appeal'd to Cesar."

27.1: When it was resolv'd, that we should sail for Italy, Paul and other prisoners were delivered to the custody of one Julius, a centurion of
27.2: a cohort in Augustus's legion, we embark'd in a vessel of Adramyttium, designing to coast it along Asia, and set sail with Aristarchus a Macedonian of Thessalonica.
27.3: the next day we touch'd at Sidon, where the centurion, who was very civil to Paul, gave him leave to go, and refresh himself at his friends.
27.4: from thence we put off, and made our coast north of Cyprus, the wind being contrary.
27.5: after having travers'd the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we arriv'd at Myra, a city of Lycia.
27.6: there the centurion met with a ship of Alexandria, bound for Italy, and put us on board.
27.7: For several days we made very little sail, and having scarce got sight of Cnidus, the wind being against us, we bore away between Salmone and Crete:
27.8: with much ado we weathered the cape and got to Belhaven near Lasea.
27.9: having lost a good deal of time, and sailing being now dangerous, for the fast was now over, Paul gave them this warning,
27.10: "my friends, said he, I foresee our voyage will be attended with great difficulties, and no small risk of losing not only the ship and cargo, but our lives too."
27.11: however, the centurion minded the pilot and the ship's owner more than he did Paul's prediction.
27.12: for as that haven could not cover us from the storm, most were of opinion to bear away, and try to put in at Phenice, where we could ride safe, the port lying by south-west, and north-west.
27.13: a gentle breeze at south, secure of gaining their point, they weigh'd anchor, and coasted close under Crete:
27.14: but soon after it blew a storm from north-east, which bore so upon the ship,
27.15: we could not go upon the wind, but were forc'd to let her drive.
27.16: when we were nigh the isle Clauda, we had much ado to hoist in the skiff.
27.17: this done, all hands aloft they frapp'd the ship tought with her cables, and for fear of striking upon the sands, they struck the main sail, and so drove.
27.18: the next day the storm work'd the ship with great fury; they threw some of her lading over board:
27.19: and the third day we lent our hands to send the tackling after.
27.20: For several days, we had not seen either sun or stars: the tempest still bore hard: all our hopes of escape quite sunk,
27.21: and our spirits droop with fasting: when Paul presented himself, and said, "well, my friends, it had been, if I could have prevail'd upon you, to have sav'd your selves all this perplexity and loss by staying at Crete.
27.22: yet now I advise you to discard your fears: your lives are all safe, though the vessel will be lost.
27.23: for an angel of that God, whose minister I am, and whom I serve, this night appear'd to me, and said, Paul, be not afraid:
27.25: take courage then, my friends, for I have this confidence in God, that what has been told me, shall be effected,
27.26: notwithstanding we must be shipwrack'd upon some island."
27.27: It was the fourteenth night that we had been driving up and down in the Adriatick sea, when the ship's crew about midnight suspected they were making to land:
27.28: they threw the line and sounded twenty fathom water: a little further they sounded again, and came to fifteen fathom:
27.29: then for fear of striking upon the rocks, they dropt four anchors astern, and lay impatient for the day.
27.30: but the crew under pretext of dropping their anchors to moor, had hoisted out the boat; designing to make off:
27.31: upon this Paul said to the centurion and his men, "except the crew stay aboard, you can't be safe:"
27.32: and immediately the soldiers chopt the cable, and set the boat adrift.
27.33: while they were waiting for day, Paul advis'd the whole company to take some refreshment: "these fourteen days, said he, you have been very abstemious, and not made a meal:
27.34: therefore, pray, take something to recruit your strength: and be assur'd every one of you shall be preserv'd."
27.35: having said this, he took bread, and gave thanks to God, the whole company present: then he broke it and began to eat,
27.36: at which they all took heart and fell a eating likewise,
27.37: the whole number then on board being two hundred and seventy six.
27.38: when they had eat enough, they threw the wheat over board to ease the ship:
27.39: at day-break they made an unknown land, with a creek, where they resolv'd, if it were possible, to run the ship ashore.
27.40: accordingly, having heaved in their anchors, they drove with the sea, then loos'd the helm, bois'd the mizen-sail to wind, and made to shore:
27.41: when falling into the confluence of two currents, they ran the ship a-ground: where the fore-castle stuck fast and would not give, but her stern was shatter'd by the violence of the waves.
27.42: the soldiers propos'd to dispatch the prisoners, for fear any of them should swim for their lives; but the centurion,
27.43: who had a mind to save Paul, prevented their design: and order'd all that could swim immediately to get off to shore,
27.44: and the rest to get upon the planks, or other pieces of the wreck: and by this means it happen'd that they all came safe to land.

28.1: Having thus escap'd, we found we were upon the isle of Malta:
28.2: where the inhabitants, as much barbarians, as they were, receiv'd us with great humanity, they kindled a fire, and secur'd us from the falling rains, as well as the cold:
28.3: when Paul having taken up some brush-wood and laid it upon the fire, a viper started out from the heat, and seiz'd upon his hand.
28.4: the barbarians seeing the venomous creature hang fast to his hand, said to one another, this man is a murderer, no doubt; for, escaped from the wreck, the divine justice still pursues him to death.
28.5: but Paul shook off the animal into the fire without having receiv'd any hurt.
28.6: however, they expected to have seen him swell, or suddenly die away, but when they had waited a good while, and saw no harm come to him, they were of another opinion, and said he was a God.
28.7: The chief of the island, one Publius, had his estate in that quarter: he entertain'd us with diet and lodging for three days with great civility.
28.8: Publius's father happening then to lie sick of a fever, and a dysentery, Paul made him a visit, pray'd by him, gave him imposition of hands, and cur'd him.
28.9: upon this several that were indispos'd in the island came to Paul, and were cur'd,
28.10: showing their respect by many presents, and furnishing us with provisions upon our departure.
28.11: After having been there three months, we embark'd on board the Castor and Pollux from Alexandria, that had put in there by hard weather:
28.12: we landed at Syracuse, and stay'd there three days.
28.13: from thence we turn'd to the wind, and arriv'd at Rhegium: the next day the wind being at south, we came in two days to Puteoli:
28.14: where finding some brethren, they desir'd us to stay with them seven days, after which we set out for Rome:
28.15: the brethren there having had news of us, came as far as Appiiforum, and the Three inns to meet us: whom when Paul saw, he gave thanks to God, and was greatly encourag'd.
28.16: Upon our arrival at Rome, the centurion deliver'd the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was allow'd to be at private lodgings, under the custody of a soldier.
28.18: who, after my examination, would have discharg'd me, as having done nothing that was capital.
28.19: but the Jews opposing it, I was oblig'd to appeal to the emperor: not having however any design to accuse them.
28.20: for this reason I desir'd to see and talk with you; it being for the expectation of Israel that I am subject to this chain."
28.21: they reply'd, we have receiv'd no letter from Judea concerning you; nor have any of our brethren that are arrived, said any harm of you.
28.22: but we should be glad to know your sentiments: for as to this sect, we are sensible it is every where inveigh'd against.
28.23: Having therefore set him a day, they came in great numbers to his lodgings; where he explain'd and confirm'd the reality of the gospel-dispensation, from morning to night, enforcing what the writings of Moses and the prophets had affirm'd concerning Jesus.
28.24: some believed what he had said, but others did not believe:
28.25: so not being able to agree, they retir'd, upon Paul's having told them, that the holy spirit had very justly said to our fathers by the prophet Esaias,
28.26: "go to this people and say, hearing you shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive.
28.27: for the heart of this people is become gross, their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and be converted and I should heal them."
28.28: take notice therefore, that the offers of divine salvation are sent to the Gentiles, and they will receive them.
28.29: [ having said this, the Jews went out, warmly debating it among themselves.]
28.30: After this, Paul staid two whole years in a house he had hired, and gave access to all that visited him,
28.31: preaching the kingdom of God, and instructing them in all things relating to the Lord Jesus Christ, with the utmost freedom, without being molested.

1.1: Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, chosen to declare the gospel dispensation,
1.2: which God had promised by his prophets in the holy scriptures,
1.3: with relation to his son Jesus Christ our Lord, who was of the lineage of David as to his body,
1.4: but as to his holy spirit miraculously declared to be the son of God, by his resurrection from the dead:
1.5: by whose favour I have received the office of an apostle to bring the Gentiles every where to the obedience of faith preached in his name:
1.6: among whom Jesus Christ has also called you:
1.7: to all the beloved of God, the saints by this vocation, who are in Rome, grace to you, and peace from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.8: First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is celebrated through the whole world.
1.9: for God is my witness, to whom I am entirely devoted, in preaching the gospel of his son, that I constantly make mention of you, in my prayers, requesting,
1.10: if it be God's will, that I might now at length have the happiness of coming to you.
1.11: for I long to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift, in order to establish you:
1.12: or indeed that we may have mutual consolation from the faith which is in common to you and to me.
1.13: now I would not have you ignorant, my brethren, that I often purposed to come to you, tho' I have been hindered hitherto, that I might be useful among you as well as among other Gentiles.
1.14: I owe what service I can do to the Greeks, and to the Barbarians, to the learned, and to the illiterate.
1.15: so, that as far as it depends upon me, I am ready to preach the gospel to you also, who are at Rome.
1.16: for I am not ashamed of the gospel, since it is divinely effectual to salvation, to everyone that believes, to the Jew first, and then to the Gentile.
1.17: There it is that divine justification is revealed to be wholly by faith: as it is written, " the just shall live by faith."
1.18: there the divine wrath is revealed from heaven against all impiety, and injustice of men, who wickedly suppress the truth.
1.19: because what should be known of God they are acquainted with; for God hath manifested it unto them.
1.20: for ever since the creation of the world, his eternal power and divinity, things in themselves invisible, are clearly seen, being perceived by the things that are made; so that they are without excuse:
1.21: because when they knew God, they did not with gratitude glorify him as God, but their reasoning became extravagance, and their minds, void of judgment, were involv'd in darkness.
1.22: pretending to be wise, they became fools:
1.23: the honour due to God, who is immortal, they transferr'd to idols representing men, who are mortal, to birds, and beasts, and insects.
1.24: wherefore God abandon'd them to the impure passions of their own hearts, so that they themselves dishonour'd their own bodies;
1.25: they changed the true God for an idol, and adored and served the creature more than the creator, who is blessed for ever.
1.26: amen, for this cause God gave them up to infamous passions: for even the sex perverted the instinct of nature:
1.27: and the men unnaturally leaving the sex, were inflamed with mutual passions, which they shamefully indulged, and received in their own persons, the retribution that was justly due to such enormities.
1.28: As they did not seek the favour of God, by worshipping him, God gave them over to a depraved sense, to act unworthy of human nature;
1.29: they were full of all injustice, fornication, mischief, covetousness, malice; full of envy, murder, contention, fraud, malignity;
1.30: whisperers, backbiters, enemies of God, injurious, proud, vain, inventers of vices, disobedient to parents, void of judgment,
1.31: fidelity, and natural affection; implacable, and unmerciful:
1.32: who knowing the divine rule of right, did not perceive that they who commit such things are worthy of death, and not only they who do the same, but they who give countenance to those that do them.

2.1: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art, that condemnest another, for by condemning them, you condemn yourself; since you that condemn them, do the same things.
2.2: but we know that the judgment of God against those who commit such crimes, is just.
2.3: do you think then, O man, who do what you condemn in others, that you shall escape the judgment of God?
2.4: or do you despise the riches of his kindness, and forbearance, and long-suffering; not considering that the kindness of God invites you to repentance?
2.5: however by your impenitence, and the insensibility of your heart, you treasure up for yourself wrath against the day of wrath, and of the revelation of the righteous judgment of God,
2.6: who will render to every man according to his actions: eternal life to those,
2.7: who by patient continuance in well doing, seek for glory, honour, and immortality;
2.8: but unto those who are contentious, and do not yield to the truth, but give way to injustice, indignation and wrath,
2.9: tribulation and anguish to every one that doth evil, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile.
2.10: but glory, honour, and peace, to every man that acts right, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile:
2.11: since with God there is no respect of persons.
2.12: For as many as have sinned without the law, shall also perish without the law: and as many as have sinned under the law, shall be condemned by the law,
2.13: for not the bare hearers of the law, but they who observe the law, are such as shall be justified, before God.
2.14: when the Gentiles who have not the law, do by nature what the law prescribes, tho' these have not the law, they are a law to themselves:
2.15: for they shew that the duties prescrib'd by the law, are written in their hearts, their consciences bearing witness to it, by their own reasonings alternately accusing and excusing them.
2.16: in the day, when according to my gospel, God shall judge the secret actions of men by Jesus Christ.
2.17: 'Tis true, you bear the name of a Jew, you depend upon the law, and boast of your worship:
2.18: you know the divine will, and what is contrary thereto, having been educated in the law:
2.19: you think you are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
2.20: an instructer of the ignorant, a teacher to the weak, because you have a clear view of the true meaning of the law.
2.21: you therefore who instruct others don't you instruct yourself?
2.22: you who preach against stealing, do you steal? you who declaim against adultery, do you commit adultery? you who abhor idols, do you commit sacrilege?
2.23: and you, who glory in the law, do you dishonour God by the violation of the law?
2.24: for (as it is written) the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles by your miscarriages.
2.25: Circumcision indeed is an advantage, if you keep the law: but if you violate the law, your being a Jew makes you no better than a heathen.
2.26: if therefore an uncircumcised Gentile keep the moral precepts contained in the law, shall not he be reckon'd, as if he were circumcised?
2.27: and shall not a Gentile, tho' he is not actually circumcised, if he fulfil the law, condemn thee, who, tho' literally circumcised, dost yet transgress the law?
2.28: for it is not the Jew in outward appearance, neither is it the external mark of circumcision:
2.29: but it is the Jew, who is so inwardly, and it is the circumcision of the heart, according to the spiritual, not the literal sense, which have the approbation, I do not say of men, but of God.

3.1: What advantage then hath the Jew? or what benefit is there from circumcision?
3.2: much every way: chiefly, because they were intrusted with the oracles of God.
3.3: for what if some betrayed their trust? shall their unfaithfulness render
3.4: the faithfulness of God of no effect? by no means; yea, let God be acknowledged to be true, tho' men should be all deceivers; as it is written, " that you might be justified in your sayings, and might overcome when you are judged."
3.5: but say you, "if our unfaithfulness displays the veracity of God, what shall we say? is it not injustice in God to inflict punishment?"
3.6: not at all: for then how could God judge the world?
3.7: "but, say you, if the veracity of God hath appeared more illustrious thro' my unfaithfulness, why then am I condemned as a sinner?
3.8: and why may we not do evil, that good may come?" which is slanderously reported to be our maxim, by some, whose condemnation is just.
3.9: "how then are we better than they?" why, not at all: for we have already convicted both Jews and Gentiles, of being all under the guilt of sin.
3.10: as it is written, " there is none righteous, no not one:
3.11: there is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God.
3.12: they are all gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable, there is none that doth good, no not one.
3.13: their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips:
3.14: whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness.
3.15: their feet are swift to shed blood.
3.16: destruction and misery are in their ways:
3.17: and the way of peace have they not known.
3.18: there is no fear of God before their eyes."
3.19: Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law: that every one may be silenc'd, and all the world plead guilty before God.
3.20: for by the observation of the law no one shall be justified in his sight, since it is the law that takes cognizance of sin.
3.21: but the divine justification certified by the law and the prophets, is now clearly proposed independently of the law:
3.22: that divine justification, which by faith in Jesus Christ is extended to all, that believe; for there is no distinction:
3.23: for all having sinned, all have forfeited eternal glory:
3.24: being justified by his unmerited favour through the redemption that is by Jesus Christ:
3.25: whom God had ordained, thro' faith, to be the propitiatory victim by his blood, for the manifestation of his goodness, by patiently passing over their past transgressions: to manifest,
3.26: I say, his goodness at this time: that he might appear to be just, and the justifier of him who believes in Jesus.
3.27: what reason then is there for boasting? it is excluded, what, by the ceremonial law? no: but by the law of faith.
3.28: for we conclude, that a man is justified by faith, without observing the legal rites.
3.29: is God the God of the Jews only, and not of the Gentiles? surely he is of the Gentiles too;
3.30: since it is one God, who will justify both the Jews and the Gentiles, through faith.
3.31: do we then make the law useless by our doctrine of faith? by no means; on the contrary, it is we that observe the law.

4.1: How then can we assert, "that Abraham our father obtained this from circumcision?"
4.2: for if Abraham was justified by works, he had matter of pretension, whereas he had no such claim from God.
4.4: the reward is not counted as a favour to him that has done good actions, but as a debt:
4.5: whereas he that trusts in God to be made righteous, tho' he has not done such actions, shall find his faith accounted as righteousness.
4.6: even as David also speaks of the happiness of the man whom God accounted righteous independently of his works,
4.8: happy is the man to whom the Lord will not account sin."
4.9: Is this happiness then for the circumcised only, or for the uncircumcised also? for we say that faith was accounted to Abraham for righteousness.
4.10: how was it then accounted? whilst he was circumcised, or uncircumcised? he was not then circumcised, but uncircumcised:
4.11: and he received the sign of circumcision, as a seal of the justification by that faith, which the uncircumcised have: that he might be the father of all those who believe, tho' they are uncircumcised, that it might be accounted to them also for righteousness:
4.12: and the father of the circumcised, that is of those who are not barely circumcised, but who imitate that faith which our father Abraham had, being yet uncircumcised.
4.13: Besides, the promise that he should possess the world, was not made to Abraham, or to his posterity in consideration of the law, but with regard to the righteousness by faith.
4.14: for if they only who are of the law have right of possession, faith is made useless, and the promise becomes of no effect.
4.15: because the effect of the law is punishment: for if there had been no law, there could have been no transgression.
4.16: therefore the inheritance is of faith, that it might be meerly of favour, to the end the promise might be assured to all his posterity, not to that part only who have the law, but to that also who have the faith of Abraham, the father of us all, as it is written,
4.17: " I have made thee a father of many nations," then existing in the sight of God, whom he believed, who gives life to the dead, and calls forth things that are not, as if they were:
4.18: he it was who against hope believed in hope, that he should become the father of many nations, according to what was told him, "so shall thy posterity be:"
4.19: far from being weak in faith, unconcern'd at his own bodily decay, being then about an hundred years old, and at Sarah's incapacity of child-bearing,
4.20: he was not incredulously diffident of the divine promise; but was strong in faith, and did honour to God,
4.21: by the full persuasion he had, that what he had promised, he was able also to perform.
4.22: and therefore it was accounted to him for righteousness.
4.23: now this saying, "that it was accounted to him," was not written for his sake alone,
4.24: but for us also, to whom it shall be accounted, if we believe on him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead,
4.25: who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification.

5.1: Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God, through our Lord Jesus Christ,
5.2: who has given us access by faith to that degree of favour, we are in, by which we triumph in the hopes of divine glory.
5.3: and not only so, but we triumph in tribulation also, knowing that tribulation worketh patience; and patience, probation;
5.5: now hope will not deceive us, because the love of God is diffused thro' our hearts, by the holy spirit which is given to us;
5.6: for at the appointed time Christ died for us, when we were in a helpless, sinful state.
5.7: now for a wicked man no one would willingly die; but for a benefactor some have readily offer'd to die.
5.8: but herein hath God displayed his love towards us, in that Christ died for us, even while we were yet sinners.
5.9: much more then being now justified by his blood, shall we thro' him be delivered from the wrath to come.
5.10: for if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his son: much more being reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.
5.11: and not only so, but we have present joy in God, through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now obtained the reconciliation.
5.12: Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, so death by this sin; and thereby death passed upon all men, who all by his means became mortal.
5.13: sin indeed was in the world all the time before the law: but then sin is not punished when there is no law.
5.14: nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned by violating a positive law, as did Adam, who is
5.15: the type of him that was to come: but yet the damage of the fall does not exactly correspond to the advantages of the divine favour: for tho' through the fall of one, mankind became mortal, yet this is greatly over-ballanced by the favour and bounty of God, in the benevolence of one man, Jesus Christ, to all mankind.
5.16: neither is the gift, as was the fall by one sin: for the sentence of condemnation, was for one offence; but the divine favour extends to justification from a multitude of sins.
5.17: for tho' death reigned thro' the single offence of one, they who receive the most valuable favour, even the gift of righteousness, shall much more easily reign by the life of one, even Jesus Christ.
5.18: Therefore as by one offence all men fell under condemnation: even so by one act of righteousness, all men are restored to life.
5.19: for as by one man's disobedience many receiv'd the punishment of sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many receive the reward of the righteous.
5.20: the law was introduc'd, that the greatness of the fall might fully appear; but the more sin display'd its enormity, the divine favour was so much the more transcendent.
5.21: that as sin prevailed unto death, even so might the divine favour prevail by righteousness unto eternal life, thro' Jesus Christ our Lord.

6.1: Do we then conclude thus, let us continue in sin, that the divine favour may be more fully display'd?
6.2: God forbid, that we who have died to sin should live any longer therein.
6.3: don't you know that when we were all baptized in the name of Jesus Christ, we were plunged into a state figurative of his death.
6.4: therefore we are buried with him by being plunged into a sort of death: that as Christ was raised up from the dead into a state of glory with the father, even so we also should proceed to a new state of life.
6.5: for if we resembled him with regard to death, certainly we shall likewise do so with regard to his resurrection:
6.6: considering this, that our vicious passions were crucified with him, that the body of sin being destroyed, we might not any longer be vassals to sin.
6.7: for by its being dead, we are set free from sin.
6.8: since then we died with Christ, we are persuaded that we shall also live with him:
6.9: knowing that Christ being raised from the dead, is to die no more; death hath no more dominion over him.
6.10: for as to his death, he died upon the account of sin once for all; but as to his being alive, he lives to the glory of God for ever.
6.11: in like manner consider your selves as dead to sin; but alive to God, through Jesus Christ our Lord.
6.12: Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, by making you slaves to the lusts thereof.
6.13: neither yield your members as instruments to iniquity: but yield yourselves unto God, as being alive after having been dead; and your members as instruments of righteousness.
6.14: for then sin shall have no dominion over you: because you are not under the legal, but under the gospel dispensation.
6.15: What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the law, but under the gospel?
6.16: by no means, know ye not, that to whom ye subject your selves vassals at command, his vassals you are whom you thus obey; the vassals either of sin to destruction, or of obedience to justification?
6.17: but God be thanked, that you, who were the vassals of sin, have sincerely obeyed in the manner the gospel prescribed.
6.18: being then set free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness.
6.19: (I allude to civil affairs, because of your unacquaintedness with spiritual matters:) as then you made your natural faculties subservient to impurity, and all manner of vice; make them now subservient to virtue and holiness.
6.20: for when ye were the vassals of sin, ye were not in the service of virtue.
6.21: what benefit had you then in those things whereof you are now ashamed? since they terminated all in death.
6.22: but now being set free from sin, and actually in the service of God, the present advantage you reap is holiness, and the future everlasting life.
6.23: for the wages of sin is death: but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

7.1: Know ye not, brethren, (for I speak to Jews acquainted with the law) that the law hath authority over a man, till it be abrogated?
7.2: now a married woman is bound by the law to her living husband: but if her husband dieth, she is released from the marriage-contract.
7.3: wherefore she will be reputed an adulteress if she become another man's during her husband's life: but if her husband dies, she is clear from that law, from the imputation of being an adulteress, though she become another man's.
7.4: thus, my brethren, the law is become dead with respect to you by the body of Christ; that you might be subject to another, even to him who is raised from the dead, that we should bring forth fruit unto God.
7.5: for when we were in the carnal state of the law, the sinful passions of that state set our animal faculties to work in the service of death.
7.6: but now we are delivered by the death of the law, which held us in bondage: that we might serve according to the living spirit, and not in the dead letter of the law.
7.7: Do we then conclude, that the law is the cause of sin? by no means; but I should not have had such a notion of sin, had it not been for the law: for I should not have known concupiscence was a sin, unless the law had said, "thou shalt not covet."
7.8: but sin receiving strength by the commandment, wrought in me all manner of concupiscence, for before the law sin appear'd dead.
7.9: then it was I once liv'd secure; but when the prohibition came, sin exerted it self, and I was in a dying condition:
7.10: and the commandment which leads to life was instrumental to my ruin.
7.11: for sin getting power by the commandment, deceived me, and by it slew me.
7.12: wherefore the law is holy; and the commandment holy, and just, and good.
7.13: was it then good that brought death upon me? no, but it was sin, that sin might show it self by being able to bring death upon me by means of that which is good; that sin, I say, by the commandment might appear to be exceedingly destructive.
7.14: for we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold a slave to sin.
7.15: what I do I allow not: for what my mind leads me to, that do I not; but what I have an aversion to, that I do.
7.16: if then I do what I in my mind am against, the consent of my mind is, that the law is right.
7.17: now then, it is not wholly I that do it, but the sinful passions that dwell in me.
7.18: for I experience, that in the carnal part of me dwells no good: for it is familiar to me, to will, but not to execute that which is good.
7.19: for the good that I purpose to do, I do not: but the evil which I resolve against, that I do.
7.20: now if I do that which my mind is against, it is not meerly I that do it, but sin that dwells in me.
7.21: I find then a settled custom, that evil is objected in my way whenever I have a mind to act well:
7.22: for my mind takes delight in the law of God,
7.23: but I perceive in the animal part of me another law warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin, which is in my animal part.
7.24: O wretched man that I am, what shall deliver me from this body of death?
7.25: the divine grace thro' Jesus Christ our Lord, so then, with the mind I my self am devoted to the law of God; tho' my carnal inclinations are enslaved to the law of sin.

8.1: Sentence of death therefore shall not pass upon those christians who do not lead a vicious life.
8.2: for the christian dispensation of a spiritual life has set me free from the legal state of sin and death.
8.3: God having sent his own son invested with a body like that of sinful men, as a sacrifice for sin, thereby destroyed its power; which the law could not effect, human nature being in such a corrupted state.
8.4: so that the moral obligations of the law might be fulfilled by us, in living according to the spiritual, and not the carnal tenor thereof:
8.5: for they that are sensually affected, abandon themselves to sensuality, but the spiritual pursue their spiritual entertainments.
8.6: now sensual inclinations lead to death; but spiritual affections to a life of tranquillity.
8.7: because a sensual disposition of mind is averse to God: for it is not subject to the divine law, nor indeed can it be.
8.8: so that they who are in a carnal state, cannot be acceptable to the divine being, as for you,
8.9: you are not in such a state, but in a spiritual one, provided the divine spirit dwell in you, now if any man have not the spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
8.10: and if Christ be in you, tho' the body is mortal in consequence of sin; the spirit gives life by justification.
8.11: for if the spirit of him that raised up Jesus from the dead, dwell in you; he that raised up Christ from the dead, shall likewise restore your mortal bodies to life, by his spirit that dwelleth in you.
8.12: You are, therefore, brethren oblig'd to oppose your sensual passions;
8.13: for if you lead a sensual life, you will be miserable: but if through the spirit you mortify the affections of corrupted nature, you will be happy.
8.14: as many as are actuated by the spirit of God, they are the sons of God.
8.16: the same spirit testifies to our spirit, that we are the children of God.
8.17: and if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ; although we now suffer with him, that we may also be glorified with him.
8.18: for I consider, that the sufferings of this present life are infinitely over-ballanc'd by that glory which shall hereafter be discovered to us.
8.19: mankind impatiently desire that the divine being would display himself to his creatures,
8.20: who were not, by their own choice, expos'd to this uncertain state, but by virtue of him, who subjected them thereto:
8.21: and therefore hope to be removed from this slavish condition of mortality to the free inheritance of divine glory.
8.22: for we know that the whole creation groans, and labours with general pain even to this day.
8.23: and not only they, but even those who have the first fruits of the spirit, even we our selves do inwardly groan for the fruit of our adoption, by the deliverance of our body from corruption.
8.24: for we are saved but by hope: but hope supposes things not yet present; for how can a man hope for what he has now in possession?
8.25: but if we hope for what is yet to come, our patience does necessarily intervene.
8.26: The spirit likewise softens our afflictions: for being at a loss to apply for the most proper relief; the spirit it self affects us with those pious ejaculations, which we can't well express.
8.27: and he that penetrates into the heart approves what the spirit desires, because what he demands for the saints is agreeable to the divine will.
8.28: We know too, that all things co-operate for the good of those who love God, who, pursuant to his purpose, has now called them:
8.29: for whom he before approv'd, he predispos'd to follow the example of his son, who was to conduct them all as their elder brother;
8.30: but whom he predispos'd, he calls: and whom he has call'd, he justifies: and whom he has justified, he glorifies.
8.31: What shall we conclude then from this? if God be for us, who can be against us?
8.32: he that spared not his own son, but delivered him up for us all, will he not with him likewise freely give us all things?
8.33: who shall plead against God's elect? shall God who justifieth them?
8.34: who shall condemn them? shall Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, and makes intercession for us?
8.35: what shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or penury, or peril, or sword?
8.37: yet after all we are more than conquerors, through him that loved us.
8.38: for I am fully persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come,
8.39: neither the high, nor the low, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God by Christ Jesus our Lord.

9.1: I call Christ, and the holy spirit to witness with my conscience, that I speak the truth without guile, when I say,
9.2: that I have great heaviness, and continual sorrow in my heart.
9.3: for I could wish to be as one anathematiz'd from the christian church for my brethren, who are of the same race as my self,
9.4: who are Israelites; who had the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the law, the form of divine worship, and the promises;
