9.5: who are the offspring of the patriarchs, and of whom as to the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.
9.6: However, the divine promise cannot but have its effect, for they are not the whole of Israel, who are descended from Israel:
9.7: neither are they who are the race of Abraham, all children: but 'tis said, "in Isaac shall thy posterity be called."
9.8: that is, the children by natural descent are not thereby the children of God: but the children of the promise are alone considered as his posterity.
9.10: this appears too from the case of Rebecca, who conceived twins by our father Isaac.
9.11: for before they were born, and had done neither good or evil, that the distinction which God had purposed to make might appear to be, not in consideration of their actions, but of his own free call,
9.12: it was said to her, "the elder shall serve the younger."
9.13: as it is written, "Jacob have I loved, but Esau I have discarded."
9.14: What do we say then? is there injustice in God?
9.15: God forbid, for he saith to Moses, "I will show favour to whom I will show favour, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion."
9.16: so that this is a matter not dependent on him that wills or runs, but on God, who shews mercy.
9.17: for 'tis said in scripture to Pharaoh, "even for this same purpose have I raised thee up, that I might shew my power in thee, and that my name might be declared throughout all the earth."
9.18: thus some he pursues with his favours, and abandons others to their obduracy, according as he thinks fit.
9.19: But you will object, why does he then find fault? for "who can resist his will?"
9.20: nay, but, O man, who art thou, to raise a dust against heaven? shall the pitcher say to him that formed it, "why hast thou made me thus?"
9.21: is not the potter the master of his own clay, of the same mass to make one vessel for use and ornament, and another for a meaner purpose?
9.22: if the divine Being has patiently bore with those objects of his displeasure, that had been working out their own destruction, why may he not reveal himself to make them feel his vindictive power,
9.23: and display his infinite goodness to such objects of mercy, as he had prepared for glory?
9.24: to such as we, whom he has called, both from among the Jews, and from among the Gentiles.
9.25: as he saith himself in Osee, "I will call them my people, which were not my people; and her, beloved, which was not beloved.
9.27: Esaias also breaks out concerning Israel, " tho' the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant only shall be saved.
9.28: for in ballancing the account, the Lord will leave a small remainder upon the land."
9.29: and as Esaias said before, "except the God of heaven had left us a remnant, we had been as Sodoma, and brought to the state of Gomorrha."
9.30: What shall we hence conclude? that the Gentiles who sought not after justice, have obtained justice, even to that which is by faith:
9.31: but Israel, who followed the law of justice, hath not attained to the law of justice.
9.32: why? because they sought it not by faith, but indeed by the works of the law: for they stumbled at that stumbling-stone;
9.33: as it is written, "behold, I lay in Sion a stumbling-stone, and a rock of offence: and whosoever believeth in him, shall not be ashamed."

10.1: Brethren, my hearty desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they may be saved.
10.2: for I bear them witness, that they have a zeal for God, but not guided by true knowledge.
10.3: because being ignorant of the justice which is of God, and going about to establish a justification of their own, they have not submitted themselves to that which is of God.
10.4: for the end of the law was to bring men to Christ, that every one who believeth, might be justified.
10.5: For Moses describes the justice that was to be had by the law, thus: "the man who performeth the things here required, shall have life thereby."
10.7: or, who shall descend into the deep, in order to bring up Christ again from the dead?"
10.8: what does it say "more? the word is nigh thee, let it be in thy mouth and in thy heart:" that is the word of faith which we preach.
10.9: for if you openly confess, that Jesus is the Lord, and sincerely believe, that God has raised him from the dead, you shall be saved.
10.10: for with the heart man believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.
10.11: for the scripture saith, "whosoever believeth on him, shall not be ashamed."
10.12: In reality there is no difference between the Jew and the Gentile: they have all the same Lord, who is bountiful to all that call upon him.
10.13: "whoever shall call upon the name of the Lord, shall be saved."
10.14: But how, say you, shall they call on him on whom they have not believed? and how shall they believe in him of whom they have not heard?
10.15: and how shall they hear without a preacher? and how shall they preach except they be sent? as it is written, "how beautiful are the feet of those who preach the gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things!"
10.16: 'tis true, faith comes by preaching, and preaching is by the divine appointment.
10.17: but all do not obey the gospel, for Esaias saith, "Lord, who hath believed our report?"
10.18: I reply, have they not heard? on the contrary, "their voice spread thro' all the earth, and their words to the remotest inhabitants thereof."
10.19: but still I ask, did not Israel know this? first, Moses saith, "I will provoke you to jealousy, by those that are no people, and by a foolish nation I will anger you."
10.20: but Esaias is more express, and says, "I was found of them that sought me not; I was made manifest to them that asked not after me.

11.1: You will say then, hath God discarded his people? by no means, for I my self am an Israelite, of the posterity of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
11.2: God hath not discarded his people whom he formerly approv'd, don't you know what the scripture says of Elias? how he complain'd to God against Israel,
11.3: in these words, "Lord, they have killed thy prophets, and digged down thine altars; and I alone am left, and they seek my life also."
11.4: but what said the oracle to him? "I have reserved to my self seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to Baal."
11.5: in like manner at this time there is also a remnant chosen by the divine favour;
11.6: and if it be by favour, it is not upon the account of merit, for then mercy would not be mercy.
11.7: "What then, hath not Israel obtained what he sought for?" no, but the chosen remnant have obtained it, and the rest are obdurate to this day,
11.8: as it is written, "God hath given them up to a state of insensibility, so that their eyes could not see, and their ears could not hear."
11.9: and David says, "let their table be made a snare, and a trap, and a gin, and a recompence for their iniquity.
11.10: let their eyes be darkned, so as not to see, and let their back be continually bowed down."
11.11: You will say then, "were they suffer'd to stumble meerly for their ruin?" no: but that thro' their fall, salvation might be offer'd to the Gentiles, in order to provoke their emulation.
11.12: now if their fall be to the advancement of the world, and the few converts among them bring in whole numbers of the Gentiles: how much more so will it be, when the Jewish body recover?
11.13: this concerns you Gentiles, for as I am the apostle of the Gentiles, I should do honour to my character,
11.14: if I could by any means excite the emulation of my dear countrymen, in order to save some.
11.15: for, if by rejecting them, the world may be reconciled; what shall their restoration be, but a general resurrection?
11.16: Now if the first-fruits be holy, so is the whole product: and if the root be holy, so are the branches.
11.17: if then, some of the branches are broken off, and thou like a wild olive, were grafted in their place to partake of the root and sap of the olivestock;
11.18: don't triumph over the branches: or if you do, remember the root is not dependent upon you, but you upon the root.
11.20: well, be it so, for their incredulity they were broken off, and you by faith stand firm: be not then elated, but let this be your fear,
11.21: lest God should not spare you, since he did not spare even the natural branches.
11.22: consider then the divine benignity, and his severity: his severity to those who fell, and his benignity to you, provided you adhere thereto; otherwise you likewise will be lopt off.
11.23: nay, even the Jews, if they don't continue still incredulous, shall be grafted in: since divine power can graft them in again.
11.24: for if you were taken from the wild olive, which was natural to you, to be grafted into a good olive-stock of a different nature, with how much greater reason shall these who are the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive-tree?
11.25: I would not, brethren, have you ignorant of this secret, (for fear you should presume too much on your selves) that blindness has fallen upon a part of Israel, until the time when the Gentiles shall be fully come in.
11.26: and then all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, "there shall come out of Sion the deliverer, and shall turn away Jacob from his impiety.
11.27: for this is my covenant with them, that I shall take away their sins."
11.28: Though they are violently prejudiced against the gospel upon your account: yet they are objects of favour upon the account of their having been chosen out of respect to your fore-fathers.
11.29: for the divine gifts and vocation are irrevocable.
11.30: as you in times past did not obey God, yet have now obtained mercy upon the occasion of their disobedience:
11.31: so the Jews are at present incredulous, by reason of the mercy shown to you; so that they themselves are now to be pitied.
11.32: for God hath manifested to all the disobedient, that he would have mercy upon all.
11.33: O the depth of the divine goodness, wisdom, and contrivance! how impenetrable are his decrees, and his ways past finding out!
11.34: for who hath known the mind of the Lord, or who hath been his counsellor?
11.35: who hath given any thing to him, and he will repay it?
11.36: for of him, and through him, and in him are all things: to whom be glory for ever. Amen.

12.1: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God to you, that you present your bodies a living victim, holy, acceptable unto God, as the service of a rational being.
12.2: and be not conformed to the present age: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that you may perceive what God requires of you is good, and acceptable, and perfect.
12.3: Now it is by virtue of my apostolical commission, that I charge every man among you, not to entertain too high an opinion of himself; but modestly consider, that 'tis God who has dealt to every man his proportion of spiritual gifts.
12.4: for as there are many members in one and the same body, but all the members have not the same office:
12.5: so we who are many, make all but one body in Christ, and every member subservient to one another.
12.6: having then different gifts, according to the respective favour bestowed upon us; if it be prophecy, let him prophesy according to the proportion of his gift.
12.7: if it be the ministry, let him attend on that ministry; and he that teacheth, on teaching; he that exhorteth,
12.8: on exhortation: he that giveth, let him be disinterested; he that presideth, let him be diligent; he that sheweth mercy, let him do it with cheerfulness.
12.9: Let love be without dissimulation, abhor that which is evil, adhere to that which is good.
12.10: in brotherly kindness be passionately affected to one another; in honour prefer one another:
12.11: in business be not slothful, but of an active mind, making the best use of every incident.
12.12: be joyful in hope; be patient under affliction; persevere in prayer;
12.13: distribute to the necessity of the saints; cultivate hospitality.
12.15: bless them, but curse not, rejoice with those that do rejoice, and weep with those that weep.
12.16: have the same respect for one another, let not your behaviour be haughty, but soften'd to the condition of those below you, be not wise in your own conceits.
12.17: Render no man evil for evil, mind such things as are approved not only by God, but by men.
12.18: do all you can to live peaceably, if it be possible, with all mankind.
12.19: dear brethren, avenge not yourselves, but leave that to the resentment of another: for it is written, "vengeance is mine; I will repay, saith the Lord."
12.20: therefore if thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink: for in so doing, you will heap coals of fire on his head.
12.21: be not overcome by evil, but overcome evil by good.

13.1: Be every one of you subject to the ruling powers, for every ruler holds of God: the rulers in being are constituted by God.
13.2: so that he who opposes the ruler, disobeys the orders of God: and will be punished too for resisting, by those very powers.
13.3: rulers are not a terror to virtue, but to vice, would you then live without any dread of the civil power? do what is right, and you shall have his commendation.
13.4: for his administration is appointed by God for your good, but if you do wrong, you have reason to be afraid; for he bears not the sword in vain: he being the minister of God, to execute punishment upon malefactors.
13.5: wherefore you ought to submit not only from an apprehension of punishment, but
13.6: from a principle of conscience, for this is the reason why you also pay tribute, because under God, they are continually
13.7: attending upon the publick administration, render therefore to all their dues: tribute to whom tribute is due, custom to whom custom, reverence to whom reverence, honour to whom honour.
13.8: Owe no man any thing, but mutual love: for he that
13.9: loves others hath fulfilled the law, for this, "thou shalt not commit adultery, thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not steal, thou shalt not bear false witness, thou shalt not covet;" and whatever social precept there be, it is reduced to this single head,
13.10: thou shalt love thy neighbour as thy self." the benevolent never does wrong to his neighbour: therefore benevolence is the fulfilling of the law.
13.11: Consider likewise the present season, that now it is high time to rouse out of sleep: for now is our salvation nearer than when we first believed.
13.12: the night is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore throw off the habits of darkness, and be invested with the ornaments of light.
13.13: let us behave with decency as in open view; not with rioting and drunkenness, not with lewdness and brutality, not with strife and envy.
13.14: but imitate the Lord Jesus Christ, and by no means indulge any sensual desires.

14.1: A weak convert receive as a friend without regard to any difference of opinion.
14.2: for one makes no difficulty of eating all sorts of food: another is so scrupulous, he lives upon herbs.
14.3: let not him that eateth, despise him that does not; and let not him that refrains, pass censure on him that eateth: for God hath received him.
14.4: who art thou that judgest the domestick of another? his staying or removal depends solely upon his master: yea, he shall be fixed: for God is able to establish him.
14.5: one man thinks one day fitter for religious worship than another: another thinks every day alike, let every man follow the persuasion of his own mind.
14.6: he that observes a day, and he that obobserves it not, act both from a sense of duty, he that eats, consisiders it as the bounty of his Lord, for he giveth God thanks; and he that forbeareth to eat, considers his forbearance as enjoined by his Lord, and giveth God thanks for the rest.
14.7: for we neither live, nor die, as if we were our own masters.
14.8: if we live, our life is appropriated to the Lord; and if we die, we die as his servants: whether we live therefore or die, we are the Lord's.
14.9: for to this end Christ both died, and rose, and revived, that he might be Lord both of the dead and living.
14.10: why then dost thou judge thy brother? or why dost thou think contemptibly of thy brother? since we shall all of us be brought before the judgment-seat of Christ.
14.12: Since then every one of us shall give an account of himself to God;
14.13: let us not judge one another any more: but rather come to this determination, not to put a stumbling-block, or any thing in a brother's way, that may make him fall.
14.14: I know, being fully assured by the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing unclean of itself: it is only so to him that thinks it is unclean.
14.15: now if your brother be endanger'd by your eating, you violate the obligations of love: for such a matter as eating, will you risk his life, for whom Christ died?
14.16: Don't let our religion then be expos'd to reproach.
14.17: for the gospel dispensation does not consist in meats and drinks, but in piety and peace, and spiritual joy.
14.18: for he that thus pays his allegiance to Christ, is acceptable to God, and approved of men.
14.19: Let us therefore pursue those things which tend to peace, and mutual edification.
14.20: do not for such a thing as meat, pull down what God has been raising, all things indeed are pure; but they become evil to him who by eating giveth offence.
14.21: it is better to abstain from flesh, and wine, and every thing whereby your brother is in danger of falling off.
14.22: keep the persuasion you have, to your own conscience, blessed is he that approves himself to God, without making any difference about meats:
14.23: for he that makes a difference, is self-condemn'd, if he eats against his own persuasion: for every action of that kind is sin.

15.1: I add, we that are better inform'd ought to bear the infirmities of the weak, and not study our own pleasure.
15.2: let every one of us consult the good of his neighbour to his edification.
15.3: for even Christ did not consult his own satisfaction; but as it is written, "the reproaches of them that reproached thee are fallen upon me."
15.4: now whatever was heretofore writ, was writ for our instruction; that we through patience and the comfortable promises of the scriptures might have hope.
15.5: May the God of patience and consolation, make you equally concern'd for one another, according to the example of Christ Jesus,
15.6: that ye may unanimously with one voice glorify God, even the father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.7: wherefore be kindly affected to one another, as Christ was to you, that you might glorify God.
15.8: for I tell you, that Jesus Christ was a minister to the Jews, to manifest the veracity of God in fulfilling the promises made to the fathers:
15.9: and you Gentiles ought to glorify God for his mercy; as it is written, "for this cause I will confess to thee among the Gentiles, and sing unto thy name."
15.10: and again the scripture saith, "rejoice, ye Gentiles, with his people."
15.11: and elsewhere, praise the Lord, all ye Gentiles, and laud him, all ye people."
15.12: besides Esaias saith, "there shall be a root of Jesse, and he that shall rise to reign over the Gentiles; in him shall the Gentiles hope."
15.13: Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope through the power of the holy spirit.
15.14: As to myself, I am persuaded, my brethren, that you abound in goodness, and in variety of knowledge, and are able to instruct one another.
15.15: nevertheless, brethren, I have writ to the Gentile part of you, and admonish'd you with the greater freedom by virtue of the commission that God has given me,
15.16: to be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, officiating the gospel of God, that the Gentiles might be made an acceptable offering, being sanctified by the holy spirit.
15.17: I have therefore matter of glorying thro' Jesus Christ, with respect to divine service.
15.18: for I will not offer to mention any thing, but what Christ has wrought by me, to make the Gentiles christians, both in profession and practice:
15.19: by virtue of the miracles and prodigies wrought by the power of the divine spirit; so that from Jerusalem, and the neighbouring country, quite to Illyricum,
15.20: I have effectually preached the gospel of Christ: yet so as studiously to avoid preaching it where Christ was owned, lest I should build upon another man's foundation; for,
15.21: as it is written, "they to whom he was not mentioned, shall see: and they that have not heard, shall understand."
15.22: This has chiefly hindred me from coming to you.
15.23: but now there being no further occasion for me in these parts, and having had a great desire these many years to visit you;
15.24: when I take my journey into Spain, I hope to see you in my way, and be forwarded by you to that place, after having for some time enjoy'd the pleasure of your company.
15.25: but now I am going to Jerusalem, to distribute charity to the converts.
15.26: for those of Macedonia and Achaia, have thought fit to make a contribution for the poor converts at Jerusalem.
15.27: they have thought fit, I say, and they owed them as much, for if the Gentiles have participated of their spirituals, they are bound on their side to minister to them in their temporals.
15.28: when I have dispatch'd this affair, and have secur'd to them this collection, I will come to you in my way to Spain.
15.29: and I know that when I do come, I shall come charged with the blessings of Christ.
15.30: in the mean time, I conjure you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ, and by the love of the spirit, that you join with me in earnest prayers to God for me;
15.31: that I may be delivered from the unbelievers in Judea; and that the charitable service which I am employed about, for the converts at Jerusalem, may be acceptable to them:
15.32: that by the will of God we may meet with joy, and rest together in peace.
15.33: now the God of peace be with you all. Amen.

16.1: I recommend to you Phebe our sister, who is a deaconess of the church at Kenchrea; receive her for Christ's sake,
16.2: as becometh christians, and assist her in every thing her business requires: for she hath assisted many besides my self.
16.3: salute Priscilla and Aquila, my fellow-labourers in the gospel of Christ Jesus:
16.4: who have for my life readily exposed their own: to whom not only I, but all the churches of the Gentiles too give thanks.
16.5: salute the church that is in their house, salute my dear Epenetus, who is the first christian convert of Asia.
16.6: salute Mary, who spared no trouble upon our account.
16.7: salute Andronicus and Junias my relations, and fellow-prisoners, who are distinguish'd among the apostles,
16.8: and were christians before me, salute Amplias, whom
16.9: I value as a good christian, salute Urbane my assistant in the cause of Christ,
16.10: and my dear Stachys, salute Apelles, an approved christian, salute the family of Aristobulus.
16.11: salute Herodion my kinsman, salute the family of Narcissus, who have embraced the gospel.
16.12: salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, who labour for the Lord, salute my dear Persis, who laboured much in the gospel.
16.13: salute Rufus chosen by the Lord, and his mother and mine.
16.14: salute Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermas, Patrobas, Hermes, and the brethren who are with them.
16.15: salute Philologus, Julia, Nereas, his sister, Olympas, and all the converts who are with them.
16.16: salute one anther with an holy kiss, all the churches of Christ here, salute you.
16.17: Now I beseech you, brethren, mark those who cause divisions and revolts against the doctrine which you have learned; and avoid them.
16.18: for such as these serve not our Lord Jesus Christ, but their own selfishness; and by flourish and flattery, deceive the open-hearted simple.
16.19: your christianity is very well known in the world. I am glad therefore on your behalf: but yet I would have you as expert in that which is good, as unpractis'd in what is evil.
16.20: the God of peace will soon bruise Satan under your feet, the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen.
16.21: Timotheus my collegue, Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my kinsmen, salute you.
16.22: I Tertius, who wrote this epistle, salute you in the Lord.
16.23: Gaius, with whom I lodge, who purveys for the church in general, salutes you. Erastus the chamberlain of the city salutes you; and Quartus a brother.
16.24: [the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.]
16.25: Now to him that is able to establish you according to my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ, conformable to the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret from antient times, but now is laid open,
16.26: and by the writings of the prophets (according to the commandment of the eternal God) made known to all the Gentiles, to induce them to obey the faith:
16.27: to God, I say, who is only wise, be glory thro' Jesus Christ for ever. Amen.

1.1: Paul an apostle (not from men, nor by man, but by Jesus Christ, and God the father who raised him from the dead) and all the brethren,
1.2: who are with me, unto the churches of Galatia: grace be to you, and peace from God the father,
1.3: and from our Lord Jesus Christ: who gave himself for our sins,
1.4: that he might deliver us from the vices of this present age, according to the will of God, even our father: to
1.5: whom be glory for ever and ever, amen. I wonder you have so soon deserted unto another gospel,
1.6: from me, who called you by the grace of Christ; this can be
1.7: owing to nothing but your being practised upon by some, who would overturn the gospel of Christ.
1.8: but tho' I, or an angel from heaven should preach any thing to you for gospel, different from the gospel I have preached unto you, let him be accursed.
1.9: as I said before, so say I now again, if any one preach any other thing to you for gospel, than what you have received, let him be accursed.
1.10: for do I now act in obedience to men, or to God? or do I seek to please men? if I had hitherto pleased men, I should not have been the servant of Christ.
1.11: I certify to you, brethren, that the gospel, which has been preached by me, is not the result of human artifice:
1.12: for I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it but by the revelation of Jesus Christ.
1.13: you have heard of my former behaviour, whilst I was of the Jewish religion, with what excessive violence I persecuted the church of God, and laid it waste:
1.14: and that I made a greater proficiency in Judaism than many my contemporaries of my own nation, being an extraordinary zealot for the traditions of my forefathers.
1.15: but when it pleased God, who ordained me from my birth, and called me by his especial favour, to reveal his son to me,
1.16: that I might preach him among the Gentiles, I did not thereupon apply my self to any man;
1.17: neither went I up to Jerusalem, to those who were apostles before me: but I went immediately to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.
1.18: After three years, I went up to Jerusalem, to see Peter, and abode with him fifteen days:
1.19: but other of the apostles saw I none, except James the Lord's brother.
1.20: what I write to you, I call God to witness is all true:
1.21: afterwards I came into the regions of Syria and Cilicia;
1.22: but was personally unknown to the churches of Christ in Judea,
1.23: who had only heard, that I, who formerly persecuted them, did now preach the gospel of faith, which I once endeavoured to suppress:
1.24: and they glorified God upon my account.

2.1: Fourteen years after I went up again to Jerusalem, with Barnabas, and took Titus also with me:
2.2: and I went up according to revelation, and communicated to them that gospel, which I preach among the Gentiles; but privately to those who were of note, lest the pains, that I have already taken, or may hereafter take in the gospel, should be in vain.
2.3: however, Titus who was then with me, being a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised:
2.4: and as to the false brethren, who insidiously crept in to spy out our liberty which we have by Christ Jesus, that they might bring us into servitude;
2.5: I did not show them the lest compliance by way of submission, that the doctrine of the gospel might remain among you.
2.6: But as for those who were men of real eminency, how considerable soever they were heretofore, it does not any ways affect me; God accepts not the person of any man: for they who were of note, in conference with me, had nothing new to add.
2.7: on the contrary, when they perceived that I had the province of preaching the gospel to the Gentiles, as Peter had that of preaching it to the Jews,
2.8: (for he that had wrought powerfully in Peter with respect to his apostleship among the Jews, had also wrought powerfully in me upon account of the Gentiles:) and when James,
2.9: Peter, and John, who were esteemed to be pillars, perceived the favour that was bestowed on me, they admitted me and Barnabas into fellowship, and agreed, that we should go to the Gentiles, and they to the Jews.
2.10: only they recommended to us to get collections for the poor in Judea: which I was very careful to do.
2.11: But when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, for he was to be blamed.
2.12: for till certain Jews came thither from James, he used to eat with the Gentiles; but when they were come, he withdrew and separated himself, for fear of those, who were for circumcision:
2.13: and the rest of the Jews dissembled likewise with him, insomuch that Barnabas himself was carried away with their hypocrisy.
2.14: but when I saw, they conformed not their conduct to the truth of the gospel, I said to Peter before them all: if you being a Jew, live after the manner of the Gentiles, and not according to that of the Jews, why do you constrain the Gentiles to judaize?
2.15: We are Jews by birth, and not of the sinful race of the Gentiles,
2.16: yet knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by faith in Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, that we might be justified by faith in him, and not by the works of the law, by which there is no justification.
2.18: on the contrary, if I re-establish what I have demolish'd, I show myself a prevaricator.
2.20: I am crucified with Christ, it is not I that now live, but Christ that liveth in me; the life I have in this body I live by faith in the son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
2.21: I do not frustrate the grace of God: for if justification be by the law, Christ died to no purpose.

3.1: O foolish Galatians, who hath deluded you, you that have had the crucifixion of Jesus Christ represented to your view?
3.2: this one thing I desire to know of you, did you receive the spirit by the works of the law, or by the gospel preach'd to you?
3.3: have you so little understanding, as having begun in the spiritual doctrine of the gospel, to turn again to the law?
3.4: have you suffered so many things in vain?
3.5: if it be in vain, he therefore that ministreth the spirit to you, and worketh miracles among you, doth he it by the works of the law, or by the preaching of faith?
3.6: As Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness:
3.7: so hence ye know, that it is they who believe who are the children of Abraham.
3.9: so that it is they who believe, who are blessed with Abraham, who did believe.
3.11: but that no man is justified by the law in the sight of God, is evident: for, " the just shall live by faith."
3.12: now the law does not justify by FAITH, but says, "he that DOES these things shall live by them."
3.14: that the blessing promised to Abraham might come on the Gentiles thro' Jesus Christ; that we by believing might receive the spirit that was promised.
3.15: Brethren, I speak according to the practice of men; contracts between men, when once ratified, cannot be disannulled or altered afterwards by any man.
3.17: this therefore I say, that the law, which was not till four hundred and thirty years after, cannot disannul the promise, that was ratified before by God, so as to set the promise afoot.
3.18: now if the right to the inheritance be from the law, it is no longer founded upon the promise; altho' God made a donation of it to Abraham by promise.
3.19: "To what purpose then was the law?" it was added as a check to transgressors, till the offspring should come to whom the promise was made; and it was ordained by angels with the intervention of a mediator.
3.20: now a mediator supposes two parties, of which God is but one.
3.21: Is the law then opposite to the promises? by no means, for if there had been a law given, which could have given life, certainly justification should have been by the law.
3.22: but the scripture has declar'd all guilty of sin, that the blessing promised on condition of faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.
3.23: but before faith came, we were shut up together as prisoners under the custody of the law, 'till faith was to be revealed.
3.24: so that the law was our school-master to bring us to Christ, that we might be justified by faith.
3.25: but now faith being come, we are no longer under a pedagogue.
3.26: for you are all the sons of God by faith in Christ Jesus.
3.27: for as many of you as have been baptized into christianity, have been invested as christians.
3.28: there is now no distinction of Jew or Greek, of bond or free, of male or female: for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
3.29: and if you belong to Christ, you are Abraham's offspring, and his heirs by virtue of the promise.

4.1: Now I say, that the heir, as long as he is a child, is in a state of servitude, tho' he is to be lord of all;
4.2: being under tutors and guardians, 'till the time prefix'd by his father.
4.3: even so we, whilst we were children, were in a state of servitude to the elements of the world, but when the time appointed was accomplished,
4.4: God sent forth his own son born of a woman, and subject to the law, to redeem those,
4.5: who were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons.
4.7: so that thou art no longer a bond servant, but a son: and if a son, then an heir of God thro' Christ.
4.8: When you did not know God, you did service to those, who in reality are no Gods; but now that you know God,
4.9: or rather that you are favoured by him, how can ye turn again to the weak and beggarly elements of the law, to which you desire again to be in bondage?
4.10: observing as you do, the days, the moons, the feasts and years.
4.11: you make me apprehensive, that the labour I have bestowed upon you will be all in vain.
4.12: I beseech you, brethren, be as I am, for I was as you are.
4.13: It is not you that have done me any injury: tho' you knew through what infirmity of the flesh I heretofore preached the gospel to you,
4.14: yet you did not despise me for the trial which attended my person, nor treated me with scorn; but received me as an angel of God, even as Christ Jesus.
4.15: what benedictions did you then pour out upon me! for I bear you witness, that, had it been practicable, you would have pulled out your very eyes, and given them to me.
4.16: am I now become your enemy in continuing to tell you the truth?
4.17: they court your affection, but not in a fair way; for they design to exclude me, that you might have the greater esteem for them.
4.18: but it is just you should cultivate my affection for you upon all proper occasions, and not only when I am present with you.
4.19: my dear children, how am I in pain, till Christ be formed in you?
4.20: I wish I could be present this very moment with you, and suit my discourse accordingly, for I stand in doubt what to think of you.
4.21: But tell me, you that are so willing to be under the law, why don't you consider the law?
4.22: for it is there written, Abraham had two sons, the one by a bond-maid, the other by a free-woman.
4.23: he, who was of the bond-woman, was born according to the ordinary course of nature; but he, who was of the free-woman, was born by virtue of the promise.
4.24: these things have an allegorical meaning: the two women signify the two covenants, the one from mount Sinai, which is represented by Agar, whose children were born in a state of servitude.
4.25: this Agar answers to the Jerusalem now in being, for she is in servitude with her children:
4.26: but the heavenly Jerusalem is represented by the free-woman, who is the mother of us all.
4.27: for it is written, "rejoice thou barren, that bearest not; break out into loud acclamations, thou that hast not the travels of childbirth, for more are the children of the desolate, than of her that hath an husband."
4.28: Now we, my brethren, as Isaac was, are the children of the promise.
4.29: but as then, he that was born in the ordinary course of nature, persecuted him, who was born by an extraordinary power; even so it is now.
4.30: but what saith the scripture? "cast out the bond-woman and her son; for the son of the bond-woman shall not share the inheritance with the son of the free-woman."
4.31: so then, my brethren, we are not children of the bond-woman, but of the free-woman, by virtue of that freedom which Christ has procur'd for us.

5.1: Stand fast therefore, and be not hampered again with the yoke of bondage.
5.2: take notice, 'tis I Paul declare it to you, that if you are circumcised, Christ shall be of no advantage to you.
5.3: for I testify to every man that is circumcised, that he is under an obligation to perform the whole law.
5.4: Christ is of no use to you, whoever of you seek to be justified by the law; you have lost all interest in the gospel-dispensation.
5.5: but as for us, our minds are possessed with the hopes of justification by faith.
5.6: for in the christian-dispensation, neither circumcision avails any thing, nor uncircumcision, but an active benevolent faith.
5.7: You set out well in your course: who hath obstructed your progress in the truth?
5.8: this opinionativeness does not come from him that called you.
5.9: a little leaven affects the whole mass.
5.10: I have confidence in you, that, through the Lord, you will be of the same mind with me, so that he who troubles you shall fall under the censure he deserves, whoever he be.
5.11: as for me, brethren, if I yet preach circumcision, why am I yet persecuted? for then there would not be so much objection to the doctrine of the cross.
5.12: I wish they who unsettle you were entirely circumcised.
5.13: for, brethren, you have been called to liberty, only abuse not this freedom as a pretext to vice, but in offices of love be as servants one to another.
5.14: for all the law is comprehended in this one precept, "thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself."
5.15: but if you bite and tear one another, take heed that you be not consumed by one another.
5.16: I say then, conduct yourselves by the spirit, and you will not then gratify the animal passions.
5.17: for the vicious desires are contrary to those of the spirit, and the inclinations of the spirit are contrary to those of the animal part; these are opposite to each other, so that you do not the things that you would.
5.18: but if you are governed by the spirit, you are not subject to the law.
5.19: now the effects of vicious passions are manifestly these, fornication, uncleanness,
5.20: brutality, idolatry, poisoning, enmities, quarrels, emulations, animosities, strife, seditions, factions, envyings,
5.21: drunkenness, revellings, and such like, concerning which I forewarn you now, as heretofore I have done, that they who practise such vices, shall not inherit the kingdom of God.
5.22: but the fruit of the spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, sweetness of disposition, beneficence, faithfulness, meekness, temperance:
5.23: against such there is no law.
5.24: now they who belong to Christ, have crucified the animal nature with the affections and passions thereof.
5.25: if we live by the spirit, let us regulate our actions by the spirit:
5.26: let us not be vain-glorious, provoking one another, envying one another.

6.1: Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, do you, who are spiritual, restore him with all gentleness, taking heed lest you yourselves be overcome by temptation.
6.2: bear with one another's infirmities, and so fulfil the law of Christ.
6.3: for if a man thinks himself to be considerable, when he is not, he deceives himself.
6.4: but let every one bring his own work to the test, and then he will have matter of glorying in himself alone, and not in another.
6.5: for every man must be answerable for his own actions.
6.6: Let him that is instructed in the word freely communicate his good things to him that teaches him.
6.7: be not deceived, God will not be mocked: for what a man soweth, that shall he also reap:
6.8: he that soweth to his vices, shall reap the deadly fruit of his vices; but he that sows to the spirit, shall of the spirit reap everlasting life.
6.9: let us then not be weary in doing good, for in due season we shall reap, if we be not tired.
6.10: therefore as we have opportunity, let us do good offices to all men, especially to the family of believers.
6.11: You see how long a letter I have writ to you with my own hand.
6.12: they who desire to make a figure in the world, constrain you to be circumcised, only to avoid being persecuted for the cross of Christ.
6.13: for even they who are circumcised, do not themselves observe the law in other respects; but they dedesire to have you circumcised, that they may have matter of glorying upon that account.
6.14: but far be it from me that I should glory, save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by which the world is as contemptible to me, as I am to the world.
6.15: for in the dispensation of Jesus Christ, neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but the new creation.
6.16: as many as walk by this rule, peace and mercy be on them, even upon the Israel of God.
6.17: from henceforth let no man give me trouble; for I bear in my body the marks of the Lord Jesus.
6.18: Brethren, the favour of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, amen.

1.1: Paul an apostle of Jesus Christ, by the divine appointment to the converts which are at Ephesus, who stand firm in the faith of Christ Jesus:
1.2: grace be to you, and peace from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: Blessed be the God and father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who hath blessed us with all the spiritual blessings in Christ's kingdom.
1.4: according as he had chosen us in himself before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy, free from vice, and devoted to virtue.
1.5: having predetermin'd to adopt us by Jesus Christ to be his children, according to the good pleasure of his own will,
1.6: to display the glory of his grace, which has render'd us acceptable by his beloved son:
1.7: who has by his blood obtained for us the redemption, even the forgiveness of our sins, according to the riches of his grace,
1.8: out of the over-flowing treasures of his comprehensive wisdom and contrivance.
1.9: for he has discover'd to us the secret of his will, that out of his meer good pleasure, he had purposed in himself,
1.10: when the full time of the dispensation was come, to reduce all things both in heaven and on earth, under one head in Christ.
1.11: It is by him, that we have a share in the inheritance, which was before allotted to us, in consequence of his design, who executes the whole plan, as he himself had contriv'd it:
1.12: that we should celebrate his glory, who were the first that plac'd our hopes in Christ.
1.13: by whom you also have heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation: and having believed in him, ye were mark'd with the seal of the holy spirit, which was promised:
1.14: and this is the pledge of our inheritance, being given for the deliverance of his peculiar people, to the display of his glory.
1.15: Wherefore having heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus, and of your love to all christians,
1.16: I continually give thanks upon your account, making mention of you in my prayers;
1.17: that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the father of glory, may give you the spirit of wisdom and revelation, whereby ye may know him:
1.18: an enlightned understanding, that ye may see what great expectations he has called you to, and what abundant glory it is to the saints to be the lot of his inheritance.
1.19: and how exceedingly great that power is, which he has employ'd upon us who believe, a power corresponding to that energy of his mighty strength;
1.20: which he exerted in Christ, when he raised him from the dead, and set him at the head of his heavenly kingdom,
1.21: far above all the principalities, all the powers, all the potentates, all the dominations, and whatever order can be named, not only in this age, but also in the age to come:
1.22: for he has subjected all things to him, and constituted him supreme head of the church,
1.23: which is his body, a work compleatly finished in all its parts.

2.1: When you were in that destructive state of transgression and sin,
2.2: in which you formerly liv'd, influenc'd by the customs of this world, and by the prince of the aerial powers, the spirits that now actuate the incredulous:
2.3: of which number we all have formerly been, leading our dissolute lives in gratifying the desires of our sensual imaginations: and were indeed obnoxious to the divine displeasure, as other. Gentiles were:
2.4: then it was that God, who is rich in mercy, thro' his great love, wherewith he loved us,
2.5: did raise us all, who were in that deadly state of sin, to life by Christ, for by grace ye are saved:
2.6: he hath raised us up together, and made us partakers of his heavenly kingdom.
2.7: that in the ages to come, he might shew the immense riches of his gracious kindness towards us, through Christ Jesus.
2.8: for by grace are ye saved, thro' faith (and that not from us:
2.9: it is the gift of God) but not by works, so that no man can boast:
2.10: for he hath made us a-new, and form'd us by Christ Jesus to do good works, for which God had before prepared us, that we might live in them.
2.11: Wherefore remember that you were heretofore Gentiles, being denominated the uncircumcised, by those who are the circumcised by a manual operation;
2.12: that at that time ye were without all knowledge of the Messiah, being aliens from the common-wealth of Israel, and strangers to the covenants of promise, having no hope, and living in the world without any true knowledge of God.
2.13: but now you who were formerly at a distance, are brought near by the death of Christ Jesus.
2.14: for he is our peace-maker, who hath united both Jew and Gentile, and hath by his flesh broken down the middle wall of partition
2.15: (which kept us at variance) by abolishing the dogmatical injunctions of the law, that having made the peace, he might incorporate the two into one new body under himself;
2.16: that he might reconcile both in one body unto God by the cross, wherefore he destroyed the enmity that was between them:
2.17: and being come, he preached the glad tidings of peace to YOU who were afar off, and to US that were nigh.
2.18: for thro' him both of us have access by the same spirit to the father.
2.19: Therefore now, you are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellow-citizens with the saints, and domesticks of God's family,
2.20: being built upon the foundation laid by the apostles and prophets, whereof Jesus Christ himself is the main stone of the angle:
2.21: on which the whole structure rises with symmetry into a temple, consecrated by the Lord:
2.22: who by his spirit has likewise made you a part of this divine mansion.

3.1: This it is that makes me Paul a prisoner for Jesus Christ upon your account, O Gentiles;
3.2: if so be you have heard of the charge, which God has graciously dispens'd to me for you Gentiles;
3.3: having revealed to me the secret, I now mention'd in short,
3.4: by the reading whereof you may perceive how far I am let into the secret of Christ.
3.5: which preceeding was not discover'd to men, as now it is to his holy apostles and prophets by the spirit; to wit,
3.6: "that the Gentiles should be heirs as well as the Jews, make one body together, and partake of the divine promise in Christ by the gospel."
3.7: of this I was made a minister, according to the gracious gift God bestowed on me, by the effectual operation of his influence:
3.8: upon me, who am the meanest of all christians, is this favour bestowed, that I should proclaim to the Gentiles the undiscoverable advantages by Christ;
3.9: and display to all the world that mysterious dispensation, which from all past ages has been conceal'd in the secret purpose of God, who created all things:
3.10: that the manifold wisdom of God, in ordering his heavenly kingdom, might by his church be now made known, to princes and magistrates,
3.11: in pursuance of that dispensation which he made to former ages by Christ Jesus our Lord:
3.12: by whom we have freedom of access to God, with confidence, by faith in him.
3.13: Wherefore I desire that you be not dejected at the tribulations I am under for your sake, which are matter of glory to you.
3.14: for this cause I bow my knees unto the father of our Lord Jesus Christ,
3.15: from whom the whole family in heaven and earth are denominated his children:
3.16: that by his immense power he would strengthen the faculties of your minds by his spirit:
3.17: so that your souls may be possess'd with faith in Christ.
3.18: Be ye rooted and grounded in social virtue, that you may be able to comprehend with all saints, what is the breadth, and length, and depth, and height of this mystery:
3.19: and be sensible of his exceeding love, in giving you the knowledge of Christ, that you may be filled with all the supplies of divine bounty.
3.20: Now unto him that is able to do infinitely above what we ask or comprehend, by his power operating in us,
3.21: unto him be glory in the church, even by Christ Jesus, thro' all the successions of future ages, amen.

4.1: I therefore the prisoner for the Lord, beseech you to live suitably to the offers that have been made to you:
4.2: with all humility, meekness, and patience, bearing with one another in love;
4.3: endeavouring to preserve the spiritual union by your affectionate attachment to one another.
4.4: Being one body, acted by one spirit, since you all have but one expectation in view;
4.5: there is but one Lord, one faith, one baptism,
4.6: one God and father of all, who is above all, and through all, and in all.
4.7: but to every one of us a different charge is given, according to the distribution which Christ has made;
4.8: wherefore 'tis said, " when he ascended up on high, he made a number of captives, and gave gifts to men."
4.9: now his having ascended, what does it mean, but that he had descended into the lower parts of the earth?
4.10: he that descended, is the same too that ascended far above all heavens, to perfect all things.
4.11: It is he then that made some, apostles: some, prophets: some, evangelists: and others, pastors, and teachers:
4.12: thus fitly qualifying his servants for their respective offices, in order to build up the body of Christ:
4.13: till being united in a perfect belief, and acknowledgment of the son of God, we grow up to that full state of maturity required by Christ:
4.14: that we should be no longer children, fluctuating, and carried about with every empty doctrine, by men vers'd in sleight and the crafty arts of deceit:
4.15: but being sincere in mutual love, may be entirely united to Christ, who is the head:
4.16: from which the whole body fitly framed, and compacted by the entire adherence and contribution of every part performing its respective function, increases and improves itself by the mutual concern of the parts.
4.17: This I say therefore, and conjure you by the Lord not to live for the future as other Gentiles do, in the vanity of their minds,
4.18: which are overspread with darkness, and averse to a religious life, thro' their innate ignorance and obduracy:
4.19: who without remorse, have abandon'd themselves to brutality, in gratifying every lewd unnatural passion.
4.20: but you have learned other things from Christ,
4.21: if you have heard of him, and have been taught the truth as he preach'd it:
4.22: to quit the vicious habits of your former conversation, corrupted by deceitful passions:
4.23: and to be renewed in your mind, by living like men formed anew,
4.24: after the image of God, in justice, sanctity, and truth.
4.25: Wherefore leave off the practice of lying, and let every man speak truth to his neighbour: for we are all members of one society.
4.26: are you angry? have a care you don't sin. "let not the sun go down upon your wrath,"
4.27: lest the devil take hold of the opportunity.
4.28: let him that stole, steal no more: but rather let him labour, to encrease his fortune with his own hands, that he may have wherewithal to relieve the needy:
4.29: let no obscene language defile your mouth, use only such as tends to edification, that it may be beneficial to the hearers.
4.30: grieve not the holy spirit of God, by whom you are sealed against the day of deliverance:
4.31: banish all resentment and indignation, anger, vehemence, detraction, and every thing like malice.
4.32: be mutually kind, tender-hearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.

5.1: Be ye therefore imitators of God, as his dear children; live together in love,
5.2: for Christ loved us, and for us gave himself an offering and a sacrifice acceptable to God.
5.3: But fornication, and all impurity, or inordinate desire, let it not be approved by you, as being unworthy of christians: neither ribaldry,
5.4: nor buffoonry, which they call pleasantry, but is indecent: be you rather exercised in social virtue.
5.5: for this you know, that no licentious or dissolute person, no lewd libertine, that is, an idolater, hath any part in the kingdom of Christ, and of God.
5.6: let no man mislead you by vain reasonings: for it is for these vices, that the wrath of God lights upon the incredulous.
5.7: don't you therefore be concern'd with them.
5.8: you were heretofore altogether in the dark, but now being enlightned by the Lord, behave as children of light:
5.9: for the natural effect of light, is universal benevolence, justice, and truth:
5.10: consider what is acceptable to the Lord;
5.11: and be not accomplices in the fruitless practices of vice; on the contrary, condemn them.
5.12: for it is a shame even to mention what they practise in secret.
5.13: but whatever is unjustifiable will be brought to light: and that will show them to be unjustifiable.
5.14: wherefore 'tis said, " awake thou that sleepest, arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light."
5.15: See then that you behave circumspectly, and not as fools, but as wise,
5.16: weighing the circumstances of the season, because the times are dangerous.
5.17: wherefore be not imprudent, but consider what is agreeable to the divine will.
5.18: do not drink to excess, for that tends to dissoluteness, but be regal'd with spiritual entertainments:
5.19: expressing yourselves in psalms, in hymns, and spiritual songs; and let your hearts beat the time, in concerts of praises to the Lord,
5.20: and this the burthen of the song, "thanks be to God, even the father, for his son Jesus Christ our Lord."
5.21: Be mutually obsequious with christian respect.
5.22: let married women be submissive to their husbands, out of regard to the Lord.
5.23: for the husband presides over his wife, as Christ presides over the church: and he it is that preserves the whole body.
5.24: as the church then is subordinate to Christ, so let women be to their husbands upon all occasions.
5.25: You husband, love your spouse, even as Christ loved the church, and laid down his life for her:
5.26: to sanctify and purify her by the ablution of his word,
5.27: that he himself might make her appear illustrious to his own eye, a church without spot, or any thing like a defect; so as to be holy and irreprehensible.
5.28: in like manner ought men to love their wives, as their own bodies: "he that loves his wife, loveth himself."
5.29: no man was ever yet averse to his own flesh; but nourisheth and cherisheth it, as the Lord doth the church:
5.30: of which we are the several parts constituting his body.
5.31: the scripture says, "for this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall be united to his wife, and they two shall be as one."
5.32: these words contain a very mystical sense, I mean in reference to Christ and the church.
5.33: wherefore let every one of you without exception, love his wife even as himself; and let the wife respect her husband.

6.1: Children, obey your christian parents: for this is the law.
6.2: the first commandment with a promise annexed, is, "honour thy father and mother,
6.3: that it may be well with thee, and thou mayst be long-lived on the earth."
6.4: and you fathers don't exasperate your children: but instruct them in the discipline and institution of the Lord.
6.5: Servants, be obedient to your legal masters, with awful reverence and sincerity of heart, as unto Christ:
6.6: not doing your work meerly out of regard to their presence or their pleasure, but as the servants of Christ, in hearty obedience to the will of God:
6.7: serve them with affection, as if it was to the Lord,
6.8: and not to men: considering that whatever good any man doth, he shall be rewarded for it by the Lord, whether he be a slave or free.
6.9: and you masters have a just regard to them, by softning your authority: knowing that both their and your master is in heaven, where there is no respect of persons with him.
6.10: Finally, my brethren, place your strength in the transcendent power of the Lord.
6.11: put on the set of divine armour, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.
6.12: for our conflict is not barely with men, but with principalities, with potentates, with the princes of darkness, with wicked aereal spirits.
6.13: wherefore invest yourselves with the set of divine armour, that ye may be able to withstand in the difficult day, and having overcome all to maintain your ground.
6.14: stand firm, the belt of truth round your waist, let justice invest you like mail:
6.15: wing your feet with the gospel of peace:
6.16: cover all with the shield of faith, to repel all the fiery darts of the adversary:
6.17: let salvation be your helmet, and the divine doctrine your spiritual sword.
6.18: Pour out your souls unto God upon all occasions, watching in prayer with all perseverance and supplication for all christians:
6.19: in particular for me, that I may have leave to speak without any restraint, and make known the mystery of the gospel,
6.20: for which I am an embassador, tho' in chains: that I may duely represent it to the full.
6.21: As to the state of my affairs, and health, Tychicus our dear brother, and faithful minister in the Lord, will very particularly acquaint you with them.
6.22: I have sent him to you on purpose to acquaint you with our concerns, and to comfort your hearts.
6.23: may our brethren have peace, social affection, and faith from God the father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
6.24: grace be with all those that have love uncorrupted for our Lord Jesus Christ, amen.

1.1: the servants of Jesus Christ, to all the christians that are at Philippi, to the bishops, and to the deacons.
1.2: Grace and peace be with you from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: I thank God, for your remembrance of me,
1.4: and I never pray without praying for you all with joy, for your liberality to the gospel,
1.5: from the first day to the present time, being persuaded that
1.6: he who has begun this good work in you will bring it to perfection against the appearance of Christ, it is but just
1.7: I should have this opinion of you, being sensible you make the dispensation I am under a common concern, with respect to my confinement, and the defence and confirmation of the gospel.
1.8: for God is my witness, that I love you with a christian tenderness.
1.9: and the favour I ask of him is this, that your kindness to me may be crown'd with farther improvements in knowledge and all prudence;
1.10: that being capable to distinguish what is best, you may remain stedfastly sincere until the day of Christ,
1.11: abounding in good works by Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.
1.12: Now I would have you know, my brethren, that what has happen'd to me, has only conduc'd to the progress of the gospel;
1.13: so that the whole court and publick are well appriz'd that I am a prisoner upon the account of Jesus Christ.
1.14: even many of our brethren, encourag'd by my bonds, preach the word with greater freedom and intrepidity.
1.15: it is true, there are some who preach Christ out of a spirit of envy and contention; but others do it out of pure affection.
1.16: those preach the gospel of Christ, not in sincerity, but from a principle of contention, with a view to inflame the persecution against me:
1.17: the others act from affection, as knowing that I suffer for having defended the gospel.
1.18: is it not however some advantage? since in either way, whether it be occasionally, or professedly, Christ is preach'd; which is now, and always will be matter of joy to me.
1.19: for I know that this shall turn to my deliverance, thro' your prayers, by the spirit, which Jesus Christ will supply me with,
1.20: agreeably to that expectation and persuasion I have, that I shall not labour in vain; but as I always have, so I shall still glorify Christ in my body, whether it be by life or by death: for if I live, I live to Christ;
1.21: and if I die, I gain.
1.22: whether it be an advantage to me or not still to lead this mortal life, what to chuse I cannot tell.
1.23: I am doubly press'd between my desire to depart, in order to be with Christ, which is by far the best for ME;
1.24: and my inclination to abide in this life, as being more advantageous for YOU:
1.25: which consideration persuades me that I shall abide, and even continue some time with you all, to improve your advancement in the faith, and to promote your joy:
1.26: that by my being present with you again, I may be the occasion of heightning your christian joy.
1.27: only conduct yourselves in a manner becoming the gospel of Christ, that whether I come to see you, or else am absent, I may have this account of you, that you are stedfastly of the same resolution, and unanimously contend for the faith of the gospel,
1.28: without being under any the least apprehension from your adversaries: this will be to them a sign of their ruin, and to you of salvation, by the divine appointment.
1.29: for it is a favour bestowed upon you, that you not only believe on Christ, but suffer also for his sake,
1.30: being engag'd in the same conflict, in which you saw I was formerly, and hear that I am at present engag'd.

2.1: If then there be any christian consolation, any charitable relief, any communion of the spirit, if any tenderness of compassion,
2.2: compleat my joy, by pursuing the same view, living in mutual love, by being unanimous, and cultivating that harmony.
2.3: Do nothing out of a spirit of contention, or for vain-glory, but modestly look upon others as if they were better than yourselves.
2.4: let no man consult only his private interest, but let every man consult likewise the interest of others.
2.5: for the same temper of mind ought to be in you as was in Christ Jesus:
2.6: who tho' he was the image of God, did not affect to appear with divine majesty, but divested himself thereof,
2.7: by assuming the form of a servant: being made in the likeness of men,
2.8: and his whole exterior showing nothing more than a meer man, he abased himself, and carried his submission so far as to die, even the death of the cross.
2.9: wherefore God has highly exalted and given him a name, which is above every name;
2.10: that at the name of Jesus both angels and men, the living and the dead, should pay their adorations,
2.11: and that every nation should confess that Jesus Christ is the Lord, to the glory of God the father.
2.12: Wherefore, my beloved, as you have always obey'd the gospel, not only when I was with you, but much more now while I am absent, continue the work of your own salvation, whatever persecutions you apprehend:
2.13: for it is God that influences your desires and endeavours, out of his benevolence to you.
2.14: do every thing without murmuring and disputes:
2.15: that you may be without reproach, the inoffensive spotless children of God in the midst of a depraved and perverse generation (among whom you should shine as stars in the world,
2.16: you, who display the doctrine of eternal life) that in the day of Christ I may have the satisfaction of not having pursued my laborious course in vain.
2.17: and if my blood should serve as a libation to ratify your faith, I should rejoice and congratulate with you all thereupon;
2.18: and you too should be glad and congratulate me upon that account.
2.19: However, I hope by the favour of the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you very soon, that I may have some encouragement by knowing the state of your affairs:
2.20: for there is no one that is so dear to me as he, and no one will more sincerely interest himself in your concerns.
2.21: the most consult their private advantage, and neglect the dispensation of Jesus Christ.
2.22: you know he has stood the test, and has serv'd with me in the gospel, as a son serves with his father.
2.23: I hope therefore to send him to you as soon as I find what turn my affairs shall take:
2.24: nay, I trust in the Lord, that I myself too shall visit you very soon.
2.25: however I thought it necessary to send you Epaphroditus my brother, my collegue in the ministry, and my fellow-soldier, whom you had sent to supply my wants:
2.26: for he long'd to see you all, and was greatly concern'd, that you should hear he was sick, and indeed he was sick almost unto death:
2.27: but God had pity on him, and not on him only, but on me likewise, lest I should have sorrow upon sorrow.
2.28: I sent him therefore with the greater dispatch, that I might have the less disquietude, by the satisfaction you will find in seeing him again.
2.29: receive him then in the Lord with all alacrity, and let such be the objects of your esteem:
2.30: for he was upon the brink of death for the service of Christ, having expos'd his life to the greatest dangers, to perform those kind offices, which you could not do yourselves.

3.1: Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord, it is not uneasy to me to write what I have already said, and it is an advantage to you.
3.2: be upon your guard against snarlers, against the contrivances of the crafty, against the spurious breed;
3.3: for we are the genuine sons of Abraham, who worship God in the spiritual manner, and value no other dependance than that on Jesus Christ, without confiding in any external advantages:
3.4: which I might do more justly than any other man can pretend to:
3.5: being circumcised the eighth day, of the family of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, an Hebrew by descent, by sect a Pharisee.
3.6: if zeal is to be regarded, I persecuted the church; if the integrity prescrib'd by the law, I am without reproach;
3.7: these advantages I renounce for Christ,
3.8: nay I think them disadvantages when put in competition with the excellency of the knowledge of Jesus Christ my Lord: for whose sake I abandon all these things, and count them as straw, that I may gain Christ,
3.9: and be his true disciple, not professing that justification, which is derived from the law, but that which is from the gospel,
3.10: the justification which God grants to those who acknowledge Christ and the power of his resurrection, who suffer after his example, and die to sin, as he died to the world,
3.11: in order to obtain the resurrection of the just.
3.12: for I am not yet secure of the prize, I have not yet finish'd my course: but I press to obtain the reward, which Jesus Christ invited me to.
3.13: I don't imagine, my brethren, that I am arriv'd at the goal; but this I do, unmindful of what is pass'd, I stretch towards that which is in view,
3.14: I press towards the mark for the prize to which God has called me from above by Jesus Christ.
3.15: Let us therefore, who have been instructed, have this in view: and if you are sollicitous about any thing else, God will reveal even that unto you.
3.16: in the mean while, as we are already advanc'd so far, pursue your course, and keep it still in view:
3.17: tread in my steps, my brethren, and fix your eyes upon those who follow the example I give you.
3.18: for there are many that wander about, of whom I have frequently told you, and now repeat it with tears, that they are enemies to the cross of Christ:
3.19: who in the, end will be ruin'd, who place their religion in sensuality, their glory in that which is their shame, and fix their thoughts upon this earth.
3.20: but we are the denisons of heaven, from whence we expect the saviour Jesus Christ our Lord.
3.21: it is he, that will change our vile body into a like form with his glorious body, by displaying that power which is able to subdue all things unto himself.

4.1: Wherefore, my dearly beloved brethren, my joy and my crown, whom I long to see, continue firm in your christian profession, my beloved.
4.2: I conjure Euodias, and I conjure Syntyche to be perfectly united in the Lord.
4.3: yea, I intreat thee too, my faithful collegue, to assist them both, for they assisted me in the gospel, as well as Clement, and my other collegues, whose names are in the book of life.
4.4: Rejoice in the Lord alway: I say it again, rejoice.
4.5: let your meekness be known unto all men.
4.6: the Lord is coming: be not in any manner of sollicitude, but in all your occasions lay your requests before God by prayer and supplication accompany'd by thanksgiving.
4.7: and the favour of God, which surpasses all comprehension, shall keep your hearts and mind attach'd to Jesus Christ.
4.8: Finally, my brethren, whatever has the character of truth, of dignity, of justice, of chastity, whatever can procure you esteem and reputation, in a word, if there be any thing virtuous or praise-worthy, let that be the object of your enquiry.
4.9: practise what I have taught, what you have learnt of me, what you have heard me preach, and seen me practise, this do, and the God of peace will then be with you.
4.10: Now I joyfully thank the Lord, that your concern for me has at length reviv'd, not that you wanted the disposition, but only the opportunity.
4.11: it is not my indigence that makes me say this: for I have learn'd, in whatevever state I am, therewith to be content: I know how to be in want,
4.12: I know how to abound: every where, and in every circumstance, I have been prepar'd for fulness or famine, for plenty or penury:
4.13: to these things I am equal, thro' Christ who strengthens me.
4.14: however, you acted generously in assisting me in my necessity:
4.15: and you yourselves know, O Philippians, that when I first preach'd the gospel, at my departure from Macedonia, I receiv'd no manner of assistance from any other church but yours;
4.16: for you sent more than once to Thessalonica to supply my occasions.
4.17: not that I desire a present; but what I desire is, that the fruits of your liberality may greatly redound to your own account.
4.18: I have now receiv'd the whole, and have more than sufficient: I am loaded with the presents you sent by Epaphroditus, which I have receiv'd as grateful incense, as a sacrifice which God accepts and approves.
4.19: for which may my God crown all your desires with glory by Christ Jesus.
4.20: to God our father be glory for ever, amen.
4.21: Salute all the christian converts, the brethren who are with me salute you.
4.22: all the converts here salute you, particularly those of Cesar's houshold.
4.23: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. AMEN.

1.1: Paul an apostle of Jesus Christ by the divine appointment, and Timothy our brother,
1.2: to our faithful brethren the christian converts at Coloss, favour and peace be to you from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: In our prayers we continually give thanks to the God and father of our Lord Jesus Christ upon your account,
1.4: having heard of your faith in Christ Jesus, and of the affection you have to all christians;
1.5: for the sake of that happiness, which you hope for, and is reserv'd for you in heaven, of which you have already been inform'd by the preaching of the truth, that is, the gospel:
1.6: which is not only come to you, but to all the world; where it produces its effects, and increases, as it does also among you, ever since you sincerely embrac'd the divine favour,
1.7: which you heard was offer'd to you, by the instructions of Epaphras, our dear fellow-servant, who is to you a faithful minister of Christ:
1.8: who also declared to us the love you bear to us upon a spiritual account.
1.9: For this cause, ever since we heard of it, we incessantly pray for you, requesting that you may be endued with respect to the knowledge of his will, with all wisdom and spiritual discernment:
1.10: that your conduct may be worthy of the Lord, in every respect agreeable to him, being friutful in every kind of virtue, and increasing in divine knowledge:
1.11: being fortified in so effectual a manner, as to sustain your trials with constancy and joy:
1.12: giving thanks to the father, who has qualified you to share in that light he affords to his people:
1.13: who has deliver'd you from the state of darkness, and has translated you into the kingdom of his beloved son.
1.14: It is by him, that we have obtain'd the redemption, even the remission of our sins:
1.15: he is the image of the invisible God, the first-born of the whole creation.
1.16: for by him were all things created, that are in heaven, and that are on earth, both visible and invisible, the thrones, and the sovereigntys, the principalitys, and the powers: all were created by him, and for him: he is before all things,
1.17: and by him all things consist.
1.18: he himself is the head of the church, which is his body, he is the prince, the first-born from the dead, that in all things he might be chief.
1.19: for it seemed good to the father to inhabit the whole body of the church by Christ:
1.20: and having made peace by the blood of his cross, to reconcile all things to himself, both those in heaven, and those upon earth.
1.21: You then that formerly were alienated from God, and were enemies by your imaginations and wicked practices, even you has Jesus Christ now reconciled to the body of his church,
1.22: through his own death, to present you holy, and unblameable, and unreproveable in his own sight:
1.23: provided you continue well-grounded and settled in the faith, and do not abandon that hope which has been offer'd to you by the gospel, and is proclaim'd to all mankind; of which I Paul am made a minister.
1.24: Now I rejoice in my sufferings for you, and am filling up the measure of those remaining afflictions, which in my turn I am to suffer in this life, in the cause of Christ, for the sake of his body, which is the church:
1.25: of which I have been established a minister, according to the charge which God has given me to preach his gospel faithfully among you. ---
1.26: that mystery, which has been hid from ages and generations, but is now made manifest to his saints:
1.27: to whom God does disclose the glorious advantages of this mystery to you Gentiles, to wit, "that by Christ you may have the expectation of glory."
1.28: he it is that we preach, exhorting, and instructing men in every part of divine knowledge, that they may all be perfectly acquainted with the doctrine of Christ Jesus.
1.29: this is what I earnestly strive to effect, by virtue of that power, which effectually operates in me.

2.1: For I wish you knew how great my concern is for you, and for those of Laodicea, and for such as have never seen me in person:
2.2: that their hearts might be comforted, and that being firmly united in love, they might possess the highest and fullest persuasion of the truth of this doctrine, by entring into this mystery, even of God the father, and of Christ,
2.3: in whom are reserv'd all the treasures of wd om and knowledge.
2.4: I mention this, lest any one should deceive you by specious pretences.
2.5: for tho' I am absent in person, yet I am present with you in my mind, and am glad to perceive the regularily of your affairs, and the stedfastness of your faith in Christ.
2.6: continue therefore to follow the doctrine of our Lord Jesus Christ, as you have receiv'd it:
2.7: being firmly attach'd to, and founded upon him: establishing yourselves in the faith you have been taught, and being thankful for the improvement you make therein.
2.8: beware lest any one seduce you by the vain illusions of philosophy, founded upon human traditions, and meer shadows, and not upon Christ:
2.9: for in him all divine plenitude does substantially reside.
2.10: and ye are filled by him, who is the chief of all principality and power:
2.11: by whom also ye have obtain'd the true spiritual circumcision, not effected by men, when you were by a christian circumcision divested of all your carnal affections,
2.12: which were buried (as Christ was) in your baptism, by virtue of which you rise (as he did) to a new life, through a belief of that divine power, which raised him from the dead.
2.13: Even you, who were in a dying sinful state, and were uncircumcised Gentiles, has God raised to life, as he did Christ, having pardoned all your sins:
2.14: and cancell'd the obligation of the ceremonial law, which was disadvantageous to us, removing that which divided us, and nailing it to the cross.
2.15: and having divested principalitys and powers, he made them an example of obedience, and caus'd them to triumph in Christ.
2.16: Let no man therefore condemn you for meats or drinks, or in respect of feasts, or new moons, or sabbaths:
2.17: for these were only the shadows of future things, prefiguring Christ, who is the substance.
2.18: Let no man condemn you, from an affectation of humility, in worshipping of Angels, boldly prying into matters which he knows nothing of, being vainly puft up with his Jewish conceits:
2.19: not adhering to the head, from which all the parts of the body derive its nutrition, and being firmly united together by its joints and ligaments, receives a divine increase.
2.20: If then you are dead with Christ, in respect of those shadows of the Jewish state; why do ye, as if you were still in that state, submit to those ordinances?
2.22: which yet were all made to be consumed for our use, notwithstanding the injunctions and doctrines of men:
2.23: by which indeed they make a pretence to wisdom, by a worship of their own devising, by an air of humility, and self-denial, and a disregard to the gratifications of sense.

3.1: If then you are risen with Christ, seek the things, that are above, where Christ sits at the right hand of God.
3.2: let the things above, and not such worldly matters be the object of your thoughts.
3.3: for you are dead to them, and Christ has secured your life with God.
3.4: Christ is your life, and when he shall appear, then shall you also appear with him in glory.
3.5: Mortify therefore your sensual appetites, fornication, impurity, irregular passions, wicked desires, and that licentiousness practised by idolaters.
