3.6: these are vices which draw down the divine vengeance upon unbelieving nations;
3.7: among whom you had your conversation, when you followed their practices.
3.8: but now renounce them all, as well as anger, animosity, malice: let calumny and obscene discourse be banish'd from your lips.
3.9: let there be no fraud among you, since you have discarded your former habits and practices, and are become new men,
3.10: improv'd by knowledge into a resemblance of him, who made this change:
3.11: by which there is now neither Greek, or Jew; circumcised, or uncircumcised; Barbarian, or Scythian; slave, or freeman; but Christ is all, and in all.
3.12: be you therefore adorn'd with a compassionate temper, with benevolence, humility, meekness, patience as becometh saints and chosen favourites of God:
3.13: bearing with one another, and forgiving one another, when one has any cause of complaint against another: as the Lord forgave you, do you likewise forgive.
3.14: to all this add love, which is the band of perfect union:
3.15: may the peace of Christ, to which you are called to be but one body, influence your hearts, to be benevolent.
3.16: Let the christian doctrine be the familiar subject of your entertainment: in all wisdom instructing and exhorting one another, in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, melodiously tuning your grateful praises to God.
3.17: let your discourse and your actions be all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the father by him.
3.18: Dames, be submissive to your husbands, as becomes christians.
3.19: husbands, love your wives, and do not exasperate them.
3.20: children, obey your parents upon all occasions, for that is graceful in a christian.
3.21: fathers, don't treat your children with severity, lest they be discourag'd.
3.22: servants, be entirely obedient to those, whom the laws have made your masters, and not meerly out of regard to their observation, as designing only to please men, but from a principle of integrity, as fearing God:
3.23: and whatever you do, do it heartily, as serving the Lord, and not men:
3.24: knowing that as you are the servants of Christ our Lord, you shall receive from him the inheritance for your reward.
3.25: but he that does wrong shall be punish'd for his injustice: for no regard will be shown to the external characters of men.

4.1: as for you, masters, give to your servants what is just and suitable: considering that you also have a master in heaven.
4.2: Persevere and be vigilant in prayer and in thanksgiving:
4.3: put up your requests likewise for me, that God would give me an opportunity to declare the mystery of Christ (for which I am even in bonds:)
4.4: that I may publish it in the manner, it should necessarily be done.
4.5: Be prudent in your conduct to those, who are not christians: and make the best of of every opportunity.
4.6: let an air of modesty appear in all your discourse; and let it be seasoned with discretion, in making a proper reply, when you are call'd into question.
4.7: As to what relates to me, you will be inform'd of it by Tychicus my dear brother, who is a faithful minister of the Lord, and serves him with me.
4.8: I sent him on purpose to acquaint you with my circumstances, and give you matter of comfort.
4.9: I have sent him with Onesimus a faithful and beloved brother, who is of your city: they will inform you of what passes here.
4.10: Aristarchus my companion in bonds salutes you, and so does Mark, nephew to Barnabas, for whom you have receiv'd recommendations, if he come to you, give him a kind reception.
4.11: Jesus, who is called Justus, salutes you: these are the only Jews who by assisting me in preaching the gospel,
4.12: have cordially reliev'd me. Epaphras a servant of Christ, and your countryman, salutes you, who is always very earnest in his prayers, that you may be perfectly acquainted with, and constantly observe,
4.13: the whole will of God, for I can witness for him, that he is ardently concern'd for you, and the christians of Laodicea,
4.14: and Hierapolis, our dear brother Luke the Physician, and Demas salute you.
4.15: Salute our brethren of Laodicea, and Nymphas, and the
4.16: church which uses to meet in his house, when this epistle has been read among you, take care that it be read likewise in the church of the Laodiceans, and
4.17: that you read the epistle from Laodicea, give Archippus this instruction from me, take care to discharge the function, you
4.18: have received from the Lord. I Paul salute you, and this salutation I write with my own hand, remember my bonds, grace be with you. AMEN.

1.1: Paul a servant of God, and an apostle of Jesus Christ, to declare the faith which recommends men to the divine favour, and to convince them of that truth, which leads to piety,
1.2: and gives the expectation of eternal life, which the God of veracity promised so many ages ago;
1.3: and has in due time manifested by the preaching of his word, which is committed to me according to the commandment of God our saviour:
1.4: TO Titus my own convert to the common faith: grace and peace from God the father, and the Lord Jesus Christ our saviour.
1.5: I left you in Crete, to regulate what was amiss, and to ordain pastors in every city, as I had appointed you,
1.6: to chuse such as are without reproach, married to but one wife, whose children are obedient, not accused of debauchery, nor unruly.
1.7: for a bishop must be blameless, as the steward of God; not morose, not soon angry, not given to wine, not violent, not desirous of unlawful gain.
1.8: but a lover of hospitality, humane, prudent, just, holy, temperate;
1.9: attach'd to the truth, that has been taught him, that he may be able to teach others sound doctrine, and to convince those who oppose it.
1.10: For there are many, especially among the Jews, who are obstinate, vain talkers and deceivers;
1.11: who ought to be curb'd, who pervert whole families, teaching things which they ought not, for sordid lucre.
1.13: the charge is true: wherefore rebuke them sharply, that they maybe sound in the faith;
1.14: not doating on Jewish Fables, and the tenets of men, that deviate from the truth.
1.15: to the pure all things are pure: but to corrupt infidels nothing is pure; whose very mind and conscience is polluted.
1.16: they make a profession of knowing God; but in fact they deny him, being execrably incredulous, and utter strangers to all virtue.

2.1: As for you, teach nothing
2.2: but what is agreeable to sound doctrine: advise the aged to be prudent, grave, temperate, sound in faith,
2.3: in charity, in patience: the aged women likewise, to behave with sanctity of manners, not false accusers, not given to tipling,
2.4: but to lectures on virtue, that they may teach the young women prudence, to love their husbands,
2.5: to love their children, to be discreet, chaste, good oeconimists, beneficent, submissive to their husbands,
2.6: that the word of God may not be blasphemed, the young men likewise exhort to be modest.
2.7: In all things show yourself a pattern of virtue: in teaching shewing uncorruptness,
2.8: gravity; let your doctrine be sound and inoffensive, that your opponents may be ashamed, and have nothing that is ill to say of us.
2.9: Exhort servants to be obedient to their masters, to be
2.10: entirely obsequious without grumbling, not to pilfer, but to show the strictest fidelity; that they may do honour to the doctrine of God our saviour in all things.
2.11: For the divine savour has display'd its salutary effects to all mankind:
2.12: teaching us to renounce impiety and worldly passions, and to practise temperance, justice and piety in this present world;
2.13: in expectation of that desirable happiness, the glorious appearance of the supreme God, and of our saviour Jesus Christ,
2.14: who gave himself for us, to redeem us from all iniquity, and qualify us to be his peculiar people, passionately affected to virtue.
2.15: these things remonstrate: recommend and enforce with all your authority: guard yourself against all contempt.

3.1: Admonish them to be subject to princes and to magistrates, to obey their orders, and to exert their virtue and loyalty upon all occasions.
3.2: to speak evil of no man, to avoid contention, to be moderate and entirely inoffensive to all men.
3.3: for even we ourselves were once inconsiderate, disobedient, deluded, addicted to variety of passions and pleasures, living in malice and envy, the deserving objects of mutual hatred.
3.4: but when the kindness and love of God our saviour display'd itself to mankind,
3.5: he saved us not in consideration of any virtuous actions which we had done, but out of his meer mercy, by the baptism of regeneration, he form'd us anew, by the plentiful effusion of the holy spirit,
3.6: thro' Jesus Christ our saviour:
3.7: that being justified by his favour, we should have the inheritance of eternal life, according to our hopes.
3.8: This is a secure rule, and what I would have you constantly maintain, that they who have believed in God, should take care to be examples of virtue, for that is commendable and useful to mankind.
3.9: but avoid frivolous enquiries about genealogies, and vexatious disputes about the law; for they are unprofitable and vain.
3.10: A man that is an heretick, after the first and second admonition, avoid:
3.11: it being plain that such a person is perverted, and knows in his own conscience that his tenets are false.
3.12: When I shall send you Artemas, or Tychicus, endeavour to meet me at Nicopolis: for I have determined to winter there.
3.13: dispatch Zenas the lawyer, and Apollos, and take care that nothing be wanting to their journey.
3.14: Let our brethren too learn some honest profession to supply their occasions, that they may not be destitute of an income.
3.15: All that are with me salute you, salute our christian friends, grace be with you all. AMEN.

1.1: Paul a prisoner for Jesus Christ, and Timothy our brother, to Philemon our dearly beloved, and fellow-labourer,
1.2: to our beloved Appia, to Archippus our fellow-soldier, and to the church in your house, favour and peace be with you,
1.3: from God our father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.4: I mention you always in my prayers,
1.5: and thank my God for the account I have of your faith in the Lord Jesus and the love you bear to all the saints;
1.6: so that the christian faith, which you have in common with us, displays itself to the observation of all good men about you.
1.7: for your liberality, my brother, affected us with great joy and comfort, by your having refresh'd the bowels of the saints.
1.8: Wherefore, tho' I have a right by virtue of my character, to prescribe what is fit:
1.9: I had rather apply to your benevolent temper, and desire you would regard the years of Paul, who am now also a prisoner for Jesus Christ,
1.10: and intercede with you for my son Onesimus, whom I made a convert whilst I was in chains.
1.11: 'tis true he was formerly useless to you, but now he will be useful to us both:
1.12: I have sent him back, therefore receive him as one that I tenderly love.
1.13: I would have kept him with me, to assist me in your stead during my confinement for the gospel.
1.14: but I would not do any thing without your consent; that your benefaction might not appear any ways forc'd, but perfectly voluntary.
1.15: perhaps he quitted you for a while, to be yours for ever after:
1.16: not as a slave, but in another quality, as a dear brother whom I particularly value, but much more should you, both as he is your servant, and as he is a christian.
1.17: I beg you therefore by the common ties of friendship to receive him as you would myself.
1.18: if he has wrong'd you, or is indebted to you, place that to my account.
1.19: I Paul give it under my own hand, I will repay it; not to say, that you owe your very self to me.
1.20: for the Lord's sake, brother, let me have this satisfaction: refresh my heart for his sake.
1.21: I writ this upon the presumption of your compliance, being persuaded that you will even do more than I mention.
1.22: pray at the same time prepare me a lodging: for I trust that through your prayers I shall be restored to you.
1.23: Epaphras my fellow-prisoner in the cause of Christ Jesus; Marcus,
1.24: Aristarchus, Demas, Luke, my fellow-labourers, salute you.
1.25: the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. AMEN.

1.1: God who at sundry times, and in divers manners, spake in time past to the fathers by the prophets, hath in these last days spoken unto us by his SON,
1.2: whom he hath constituted heir of all things, by whom also be made the world.
1.3: who being the radiation of his glory, and the imprest image of his substance, and governing all things by his powerful command, after having himself made expiation for our sins, sat down on the right hand of the divine majesty in the highest heavens.
1.4: He is so much superiour to the angels, as the authority he possesses is more excellent than theirs.
1.5: for to which of the angels did he ever say, " thou art my son, this day have I begotten thee? and again, I will be his father, and he shall be my son?
1.6: and when he re-introduces the first-begotten into the world, he saith, " and let all the angels of God worship him."
1.7: and of the angels, he saith, who employs his angels like the winds, and flames of fire as his ministers."
1.8: but to the son he saith, "God is thy throne for ever and ever; the sceptre of thy kingdom is a sceptre of equity.
1.9: thou hast loved justice and hated iniquity; therefore God, even thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy peers."
1.10: again, "thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth; and the heavens are the works of thy hands.
1.11: they shall perish, but thou shalt remain: and they all shall come to an end like an old garment;
1.12: as a vesture shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed: but thou art the same, and thy years shall never end."
1.13: But to which of the angels did he ever say, "sit on my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool?"
1.14: are not all those spirits dispatch'd as ministers to take care of those who shall belong to the christian church.

2.1: Therefore we ought to give the greater attention to the things we have heard, for fear we should abandon the gospel.
2.2: for if the law deliver'd by angels was put in execution, and every transgression and disobedience was justly punish'd as it deserv'd;
2.3: how shall we escape, if we neglect that salutary doctrine? which was first published by the Lord, and was confirmed to us by those that heard him;
2.4: God also giving an additional testimony both by signs, by prodigies, by divers miracles, and gifts of the holy spirit, which he distributes as he pleases.
2.5: 'Tis not therefore to the angels that he has subjected the gospel state of which we are treating.
2.6: and this is attested by a certain writer, who says, "what is man that thou art mindful of him, or the son of man that thou visitest him?
2.7: thou hast made him for a while lower than the angels; thou hast crown'd him with glory and honour, and hast set him over the works of thy hands:
2.8: thou hast put all things in subjection under his feet." now since he has put all in subjection to him, he left nothing that is not subjected to him, however we do not see as yet that all things are put under him.
2.9: but Jesus, who was for a while inferior to the angels by his sufferings and death, we see was crown'd with glory and honour; when by the divine goodness, he had pass'd thro' death for every man.
2.10: For it was agreeable to his wisdom, for whom are all things, and by whom are all things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to consecrate the author of their salvation by his sufferings.
2.11: for both he that sanctifieth, and they who are sanctified, are all deriv'd from one: for which cause he is not asham'd to call them brethren, saying,
2.12: "I will declare thy name unto my brethren, in the midst of the church will I sing praise unto thee."
2.13: and again, "I will put my trust in him." and again, "behold, I, and the children which God hath given me.
2.14: Since then the children were made subject to a state of mortality, so he himself likewise was subject to the same condition: that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil;
2.15: and deliver them who thro' fear of death were all their life-time in a state of slavery.
2.16: for he is not the deliverer of angels; but the deliverer of Abraham's posterity.
2.17: whence it was necessary he should be in all things like his brethren; that he might be a merciful high priest, and faithfully discharge the divine office of expiating the sins of the people.
2.18: for having himself stood the test of sufferings, he is capable of being moved to relieve those who undergo such tryals.

3.1: Wherefore, christian brethren, you who are called to an heavenly inheritance, consider the apostle and high priest of the faith we profess, even Christ Jesus;
3.2: who was faithful to him that constituted him such, as Moses likewise was faithful in all his administration of God's house.
3.3: but as the architect is of much greater dignity than the house he has made; so the glory which Christ received was greater than that of Moses.
3.4: no house is without a builder; now he that built the whole house of Israel is God.
3.5: besides Moses throughout his whole administration acted in quality of a servant, representing to the people what he was order'd to say.
3.6: but Christ govern'd his own house in quality of son and heir, and 'tis we that are his house, provided we stedfastly persevere unto the end in the publick profession of that hope, in virtue of which we glory.
3.7: Wherefore as the holy spirit saith, "since to-day you hear his voice,
3.8: harden not your hearts, as at Meriba and Massa in the desart:
3.9: where your fathers provoked me to give proofs of my power forty years, tho' they saw my works.
3.10: wherefore I was displeased with that generation, and said, they do alway err in their hearts; and they have not known my ways.
3.11: so I swear in my wrath, that they should not enter into my rest."
3.12: Take heed, brethren, lest there be in any of you such incredulity as to make you desert the living God.
3.13: but exhort one another daily while the day lasts, lest any of you be hardned through the deceitfulness of sin.
3.14: for we were receiv'd into the communion of Christ, upon condition of inviolably maintaining the hope we had at the beginning even unto the end,
3.15: which is imply'd by, "to-day since ye hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as at Meriba."
3.16: for some when they had heard his voice, did provoke him: however, not all that were brought out of Egypt by Moses did so.
3.17: but with whom was he displeased forty years? was it not with those that had sinned, whose carcases fell in the desert?
3.18: and who were they, who, he sware, should not enter into his rest, but those that did not believe? so we see that they could not enter in,

4.1: Let us therefore fear, lest any of us by rejecting the promise of entring into his rest, should be excluded from it.
4.2: for to us was the good promise made, as well as to them: but the word address'd to them was not effectually receiv'd with faith by those that heard it.
4.3: Whereas 'tis we who have believed that shall enter into rest, as he said, "wherefore I have sworn in my wrath, that they shall not enter into my rest." which is different from that rest, at the beginning of the world, when the work of creation was finished.
4.4: of which in a certain place relating to the seventh day, 'tis said, "and God did rest the seventh day from all his works."
4.5: but in this place 'tis said, "they shall not enter into my rest."
4.6: Since there remains then a rest which some are still to enter into, for they to whom the promise was first made, did not enter in, because of their incredulity;
4.7: he pointed out another time in the words, which were spoken by David, a long time after their going into Canaan, in the passage just now quoted, "today since ye hear his voice, harden not your hearts."
4.8: for if Joshuah had given them rest, David would not afterwards have mentioned another day.
4.9: which shows that the people of God have a sabbath still to come.
4.10: then he that enters into divine rest, will indeed rest from his works, as God did from his.
4.11: Let us labour therefore to enter into that rest, lest any of us by imitating their incredulity, should fall short thereof like them.
4.12: for the word of God is active and efficacious, sharper than any two-edged sword, penetrating even to the division of soul and spirit, to the smallest and most inward parts, distinguishing the thoughts, and intentions of the heart.
4.13: so that there is not a creature that is concealed from his view: but all is naked and open to the eyes of him of whom we speak. Having then so great a high priest,
4.14: who is passed into the heavens, Jesus the son of God, let us hold fast our profession, for we have
4.15: not an high priest who is incapable of compassionating our miseries; since he was exposed to the same trials as we are, sin only excepted, let
4.16: us therefore approach with confidence to the throne of grace, that we may obtain the seasonable assistance of divine mercy and favour.

5.1: For every high priest is appointed to officiate for men in religious matters, offering gifts and sacrifices for their sins: being chosen from among the people, that as he himself is surrounded with infirmities,
5.2: he might have the greater compassion for those who sin through ignorance or mistake, and for the same reason
5.3: he is obliged to offer sacrifices for his own sins as well as for those of the people, besides, no man can assume
5.4: to himself the honour of the priesthood: he must be called thereto by God, as Aaron was.
5.5: Wherefore Christ himself did not assume the character of an high priest; but it was confirm'd by him that said, "thou art my son, to-day have I begotten thee."
5.6: as he saith too in another place, "thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec."
5.7: this was Jesus, who while he was in a mortal body, having offered up prayers and supplications, with strong cries, and with tears, to him that was able to save him from that death, was heard so as to be delivered from his fear;
5.8: for tho' he was the son of God, yet he found by his own sufferings what it was to obey,
5.9: and by a perfect obedience he procured eternal salvation for all that obey him;
5.10: God having declared him an high priest after the order of Melchisedec.
5.11: On this head we have many things to say, not easily to be comprehended, because of your prejudices.
5.12: for though by this time you ought to be capable of teaching others, you want to be instructed anew in the first principles of the divine oracles; and are in such a state as to stand in need of milk, rather than of solid nourishment.
5.13: now he that is disciplined like a child, is not prepared for the doctrine of justification:
5.14: such solid nourishment is only fit for such as are arriv'd at their full growth and strength, whose senses have been exercis'd in distinguishing what is good, and what is prejudicial.

6.1: Therefore omitting for the present the principles of the christian doctrine, we shall proceed to something more sublime, without mentioning those fundamental articles of repentance from destructive vices, and of divine faith:
6.2: the doctrine of baptisms, and laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment:
6.3: of which we shall treat another time, if God permit.
6.4: For it is impossible for those who were once enlightned, and have received the heavenly gifts, communicated by the holy spirit,
6.5: and have known by experience the truth of the divine promises, and the miracles of the age that was to come; it is impossible,
6.6: if they shall fall away, to re-instate themselves by repentance: seeing, as far in them lies, they crucify the son of God afresh, and expose him to open shame.
6.7: for the earth which drinks up the frequent show'rs that fall upon it, and produces plants fit for the use of him that cultivates it, is stiled heavenly land:
6.8: but that which bears thorns and briars, is look'd upon as lying under a curse; whose end will be to be burnt.
6.9: But though we speak in this manner, my dear brethren, we expect better things of you, and such as are more suitable to your salvation.
6.10: for God is too just to his promise not to regard your piety, and the love which you have shewn to the christian religion by the assistance ye have given to the saints, and still continue to give.
6.11: but we desire that every one of you may shew the same concern, continuing to discharge the condition upon which your hopes are founded: that ye be not unactive,
6.12: but imitate the example of those who by faith and patience have obtain'd the inheritance that was promis'd to them.
6.13: For when God gave his promise to Abraham, because he could swear by no greater, he sware by himself, saying,
6.14: "surely I will heap blessings upon thee, and will give thee a numerous posterity."
6.15: and after he had patiently waited, he obtained what was promised.
6.16: for when men swear by a superior, the ratifying what they say with an oath, puts an end to all further debate.
6.17: wherefore God was willing to give the heirs of promise a stronger proof of the immutability of his counsel, by the intervention of an oath:
6.18: that by two immutable things in which it was impossible for God to deceive us, we, who have no other refuge to fly to, but to maintain our present hopes,
6.19: might have strong consolation to serve as a sure and stedfast anchor to the soul: till it arrives within the veil,
6.20: where Jesus is gone to usher us in, having been made an high priest for ever, after the order of Melchisedec.

7.1: For this Melchisedec was both king of Salem, and a priest of the most high God; 'twas he who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him:
7.2: to whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of the whole booty: first, being by the signification of his name king of justice, and in fact king of Salem, which is, king of peace;
7.3: without father, without mother, without genealogy; his days have no beginning, and his life no end; but like the son of God, he was a perpetual priest.
7.4: Now consider the dignity of this person, to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave the tenth of the spoils.
7.5: 'tis true they of the race of Levi, who assume the office of the priesthood, have a right by law to take tithes of the people, that is, of their brethren, though they all issued from Abraham:
7.6: but he who was not of their pedigree, received tithes from Abraham, and blessed him to whom the promises were made.
7.7: now 'tis past dispute, he that is blessed is inferior to him that blesses:
7.8: besides here they that receive tithes are men who die: but there 'twas he of whom it is testified that he liveth.
7.9: and even Levi who received tithes, pay'd tithes, if I may so say, in the person of Abraham.
7.10: for he was even then in the loins of his father, when Melchisedec met him.
7.11: If therefore the Levitical priesthood, concerning which the people received a law, could have given perfection, what further need was there that another priest should rise, to be named after the order of Melchisedec, and not after the order of Aaron?
7.12: now the priesthood being changed, the law must necessarily be changed too.
7.13: for he who was there mention'd was of another tribe, none of whom ever gave attendance at the altar.
7.14: since it is evident that our Lord sprang out of the tribe of Juda, to which Moses never ascribed the priesthood.
7.15: This appears still more clear from another priest's arising like Melchisedec,
7.16: who was not establish'd by virtue of a temporary law, but with the power of being a perpetual priest.
7.17: for it is said, "thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec."
7.18: wherefore the preceeding law is abolished for its being weak and useless.
7.19: for the law made no man perfect, but this was effected by introducing a better hope, which brings us nearer to the divine presence.
7.20: Besides those priests were establish'd without any oath: but this with an oath,
7.21: by him that said to him, "the Lord has swore, and will not repent, thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec."
7.22: so that Jesus was made guarantee of an alliance so much the more excellent, as it was not without the solemnity of an oath.
7.23: besides, the priesthood then devolv'd to many, death depriving them of a lasting possession.
7.24: but he, by virtue of his immortal state, hath a priesthood that does not pass by succession.
7.25: so that he has an uninterrupted power to save those, that come to God by him, because he ever lives to make intercession for them.
7.26: and indeed we wanted an high priest of such a character, one that is holy, innocent, undefiled, one that is separated from sinful men, and exalted above the heavens; one who was under no necessity,
7.27: as those high priests of the law were, to offer up daily sacrifices, first for his own sins, and then for those of the people: having done this once for all, by offering up himself.
7.28: for the law appointed frail mortals to be high priests, but the oracle pronounc'd with an oath, which was since the law, established the son, who is crown'd with immortal perfections.

8.1: What we have said amounts to this; we have an high priest, who sits in heaven on the right hand of the throne of the divine majesty.
8.2: a priest of the sanctuary, and of the true tabernacle which the Lord made, and not man.
8.3: every high priest being establish'd to offer gifts and sacrifices: it was necessary that he likewise should make a peculiar offering,
8.4: which office he could not discharge here upon earth, where priests are already establish'd, who offer gifts according to the law:
8.5: and officiate in the sanctuary, which was a gross representation of that in heaven, agreeable to the order given by God to Moses, when he projected the tabernacle, "be very exact, said he, in following the model which was laid before thee in the mount."
8.6: Our high priest then has obtained a priesthood so much the more excellent, as he is the mediator of a better alliance, established upon better promises.
8.7: for if the first alliance had been without defect, there could have been no occasion for the second.
8.8: nor for that reproach, which was made to our fathers, where 'tis said, "behold, the days come, saith the Lord, when I will make a new alliance with the house of Israel, and with the house of Juda:
8.9: not according to the alliance that I made with their fathers, when I took them by the hand, to lead them out of the land of Egypt; for they have not kept my alliance, wherefore I have rejected them, saith the Lord.
8.10: but this is the alliance that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, saith the Lord: I will put my laws into their mind, and write them in their hearts: I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
8.11: they shall no longer instruct every man his neighbour, and every man his brother, saying, know the Lord: for all shall know me, from the least to the greatest.
8.12: for I will pardon their iniquity, and their sins and their trangressions will I remember no more."
8.13: now by stiling the second a new alliance, he has antiquated the first, but to be antiquated and obsolete is next to being abolished.

9.1: The first alliance then had rites of divine service, and a worldly sanctuary.
9.2: for the disposition of the tabernacle was such, that in the first part named the sanctuary, were placed the candlestick, the table, and the shew-bread;
9.3: and beyond the veil, was the second part of the tabernacle which is called the holy of holys;
9.4: there was the golden censer, and the ark of the covenant gilded all over with gold, wherein was the golden urn containing the manna, and Aaron's rod that budded, and the tables of the alliance.
9.5: over the ark were the cherubims of glory covering the propitiatory with their wings, of which we cannot now enter into a particular detail.
9.6: These things being thus disposed, the priests went at all times into the first part of the tabernacle, to officiate the divine service, but into the other part,
9.7: the high priest only enter'd, and that but once every year, when he carried the blood, which he offered for himself, and for the errors of the people.
9.8: the holy spirit showing thereby, that the way to the holy of holys, was not yet open, while the first tabernacle was standing.
9.9: This type subsists to the present time, both gifts and sacrifices being still offered, which cannot purify the mind of him that officiates
9.10: only in matters relating to meats and drinks, and divers baptisms, meer external rites which were to subsist only till the time of reformation.
9.11: but Christ, the high priest of a better dispensation that was to come, having appeared, is enter'd into the holy of holys by a nobler and more perfect tabernacle, not the effect of human art, but of a higher nature;
9.12: nor with the blood of goats and calves, but with his own blood he enter'd once for all into the holy of holys, after having obtained for us an eternal redemption.
9.13: For if the blood of goats and of bulls, and the ashes of an heifer sprinkled on the unclean, can cleanse them from external impurities;
9.14: how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the holy spirit offered himself a spotless victim to God, purify our souls from deadly sins, to serve the living God?
9.15: and for this cause he is the mediator of the new testament, that, the transgressions that were unexpiated by the first testament, being expiated by his death, they who are called might receive the eternal inheritance, which was promised.
9.16: For where a testament is, there the death of the testator is necessarily pre-suppos'd.
9.17: because a testament has no effect till after the demise: it not being in force while the testator is alive.
9.18: whence even the first testament was not established without the effusion of blood.
9.19: for when every precept of the law had been represented by Moses to all the people, he took the blood of calves and of goats, with water, wool of a scarlet dye, and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book of the law and all the people,
9.20: saying, "this is the blood of the testament which God has made in your behalf."
9.21: he sprinkled likewise the tabernacle with blood, and all the vessels used in divine service.
9.22: and indeed according to the law almost every thing is purified with blood, without the effusion of which, there is no remission of sins.
9.23: It was therefore necessary that what was only a type of the heavenly sanctuary, should be purified by such sacrifices; but the heavenly sanctuary itself, by a more excellent sacrifice.
9.24: for Christ is not entred into a sanctuary made by human art, such as is only representative of the true one, but into heaven itself, to appear from henceforth in the presence of God on our behalf:
9.25: nor to make a frequent offering of himself, as the high priest every year enters into the holy of holies with other blood than his own.
9.26: for then must he have suffered several times since the beginning of the world, when in the consummation of the ages, he has appeared once for all to expiate sin by offering himself as a sacrifice.
9.27: as then it is appointed that men should die but once, after which the judgment ensues;
9.28: so Christ being once offered up to take away the sins of many; he shall appear the second time, without making any further expiation to save those who expect him.

10.1: For the law being only an allusion to a future dispensation that was more excellent, and not an exact imitation of such a state, cannot by the anniversary sacrifices, which are offered, entirely purify those that present themselves.
10.2: for then they would not have been repeated, because they who sacrificed being once purified, would not have been conscious of wanting any further atonement for their sins:
10.3: whereas their annual sacrifices were accompanied with an anniversary commemoration of their sins.
10.4: And indeed it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats, should take away the guilt of sin.
10.5: wherefore at his appearing in publick, he saith, "sacrifice and offering thou wouldst not, but a body hast thou prepared me:
10.6: in burnt-offerings and sacrifices for sin thou hast had no pleasure:
10.7: then said I, lo I come, as in the volume of the book it is written of me, to do thy will, O God."
10.8: after having said, "victims, oblations, holocausts, and sacrifice for sin, thou wouldst not, neither hadst pleasure therein," tho' they are all prescrib'd by the law;
10.9: he immediately adds, "lo, I come to do thy WILL, O God." he abolishes the first to establish the second:
10.10: in consequence of which WILL we are sanctified by the oblation which Jesus Christ has made once for all of his own body.
10.11: While the high priest in his daily administrations frequently repeated the same sacrifices which could by no means expiate sin;
10.12: Christ, after he had offered one sacrifice for sin, sat down on the right hand of God for ever:
10.13: expecting the only event still remaining, the entire subjection of his enemies.
10.14: for by one single oblation he has purified for ever those that are sanctified.
10.15: and this is what the holy spirit declares, when after having said,
10.16: "this is the alliance that I will make with them after those days, saith the Lord; I will put my laws into their hearts, and in their mind will I write them:
10.17: he adds, and their sins and iniquities will I remember no more."
10.18: now where they are remitted, there is no need of any further oblation for sin.
10.19: Wherefore, my brethren, since by virtue of the blood of Jesus we have the liberty of entring into the holy of holies,
10.20: by a new and living way which he has first open'd for us, thro' the veil, that is, thro' his flesh;
10.21: and having an high priest, who is established over the house of God,
10.22: let us draw near with sincerity, in full assurance of faith, having our consciences purified from guilt, and our bodies washed with pure water.
10.23: Let us stedfastly maintain the hope which we have avow'd, since he is faithful that has promised:
10.24: and let us animate one another to the mutual returns of love, and kind offices: not abandoning our assemblies,
10.25: as some do; but encourage one another: even so much the more, as you see the day approaching.
10.26: for if we wilfully apostatize, after having received the knowledge of the truth, it is as a sin for which there is no sacrifice appointed.
10.27: and nothing is to be expected but that dreadful judgment, and fiery indignation, which shall devour all such adversaries.
10.28: He that by two or three witnesses was convicted of violating Moses's law, was put to death without mercy.
10.29: don't you think then that he deserves a much greater punishment, who hath despised the son of God, and counted the blood of the covenant wherewith be was sanctified, to have been justly shed, thereby offering an indignity to the spirit of grace?
10.30: for we know who it is that has said, "vengeance belongeth unto me, I will repay." and again, "the Lord shall revenge his people."
10.31: it is a terrible thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
10.32: Call to remembrance the former times, in which after ye were illuminated, you were forc'd to struggle with sufferings,
10.33: some of you being expos'd to publick obloquy and persecution: whilst others had their share of affliction in seeing such treatment.
10.34: for you were passionately affected for those who were in bonds, and were pleas'd at the seizing of your goods, knowing that you have what is more excellent and lasting.
10.35: don't therefore quit that resolution you have, which will be attended with so great a reward.
10.36: for it is necessary you should persevere, that after having perform'd what God has commanded, you may receive what he has promised.
10.37: only wait but a little while, and he that is to come, will come without delay.
10.38: the just shall have life by trusting in me, but if he revolt, he will be the object of my displeasure.
10.39: as for us, we are not such as desert to their own destruction; but such as persevere in the faith, to the saving of our souls.

11.1: Now faith is the foundation of our hopes of happiness, and the persuasion we have about things not evident to our senses.
11.2: and it was for their faith that our fore-fathers acquired so great a reputation.
11.3: 'Tis by faith we learn that the worlds were framed by the word of God, so that the visible world was not made out of any thing that did appear.
11.4: 'Twas by faith that Abel offered unto God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, by which he was declared righteous, God himself having testified that he accepted his offering, and after he died for his faith, he was not silent.
11.5: By faith Enoch was translated that he might avoid dying; and he could not be found, because God had translated him: for 'tis recorded, that before his translation he was approved by God.
11.6: now without faith it is impossible to be acceptable to him: for he that presents himself to God, cannot but believe he exists, and that he is a rewarder of those who make their addresses to him.
11.7: 'Twas by faith that Noah being divinely warned of unforeseen events, with a religious concern built an ark to the preservation of his family; whereby the world became inexcusable, and he obtained the reward of that righteousness which is by faith.
11.8: 'Twas by faith that he who was named Abraham, showed his obedience in travelling to a foreign country, which he was afterwards to inherit; and began his journey without knowing where he was going.
11.9: 'twas by faith that he sojourned in a land that was promised, as in a strange country, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, who were equally entitled to the same promise.
11.10: for he had in view the city, whose foundations are sure, the architect and founder being God.
11.11: 'Twas likewise through faith that Sara, though barren, received the power of becoming pregnant, and was delivered of a child when she was past age, because she judged him faithful who had promised.
11.12: so that even a single person whose vigour was gone, gave rise to a posterity as numerous as the stars of the sky, or the sands on the sea-shore, which cannot be numbred.
11.13: These all died in faith, without receiving what was promised, having only a distant view of what they eagerly expected, professing to live as strangers and pilgrims in the land.
11.14: for they, that make such a declaration, show plainly that they seek some other country.
11.15: and truly, if that had been in their view, they might have had an opportunity of returning to the place from whence they came.
11.16: they desired therefore a better, that is, an heavenly country: so that God is very justly stiled their God: for he had appointed a city for them.
11.17: 'Twas by faith that Abraham, when put to the trial, offered up Isaac: HE offered up his darling son, to whose posterity the promises were to be made good:
11.18: of whom it was said, "only the descendants of Isaac shall be counted your posterity:"
11.19: concluding that God was able to raise him up, even from the grave; from whence, in a figurative sense, be may be said to have been recover'd.
11.20: By faith Isaac predicted the future fortunes of Jacob and Esau.
11.21: by faith Jacob when he was a dying, blessed both the sons of Joseph; and worshipped leaning upon the top of his staff.
11.22: by faith Joseph when he died, made mention of the departure of the children of Israel; and gave directions concerning his burial.
11.23: 'Twas by faith that the parents of Moses conceal'd him for three months after his birth, because they saw he was a beautiful child; and they were not afraid of the king's edict.
11.24: by faith Moses when he was grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter;
11.25: chusing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season;
11.26: esteeming the sufferings of Israel greater riches than the treasures of Egypt: for he had an eye to the reward.
11.27: by faith he left Egypt without being apprehensive of the king's resentment: for he remain'd firm, as if he saw him who is invisible.
11.28: through faith he celebrated the passover, and sprinkled blood, that the destroying angel might pass by the first-born.
11.29: By faith they passed thro' the red sea, as by dry land: which the Egyptians attempting to do, were drowned.
11.30: by faith they made the tour of Jericho for seven days, in consequence of which the walls fell down.
11.31: by faith Rahab having given the spies a safe reception, escap'd being destroyed with unbelievers, tho' she had led a dissolute life.
11.32: And what shall I say more? for the time would fail me to tell of Gedeon, of Barak, of Samson, of Jephthae, of David, of Samuel, and of the prophets:
11.33: who through faith subdued kingdoms, practis'd justice, obtained what was promised, stopped the mouths of lions,
11.34: were proof against the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, show'd their resolution in distress, and their valour in fight, putting to flight the armies of the aliens.
11.35: women recovered their children, tho' dead, by their being raised to life again: some expired under torments, refusing to be delivered; that they might obtain a better deliverance at the resurrection.
11.36: others suffer'd cruel indignities and scourgings, besides chains and imprisonment.
11.37: they were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain with the sword: they wandred about in sheepskins, and goat-skins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented:
11.38: (of whom the world was not worthy) they wandred in desarts, and in mountains, having no retreat but the dens and caves of the earth.
11.39: Tho' these were all celebrated for their faith, they did not receive the reward that was promised:
11.40: because God out of his distinguishing kindness to us, would not let them arrive before us to the enjoyment of perfect felicity.

12.1: Wherefore, since we are surrounded with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every incumbrance, and the sin which does so easily embarrass us, and let us pursue with constancy the course that is proposed to us:
12.2: having Jesus in our view, the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him, endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down on the right hand of the throne of God.
12.3: for you should consider how he endured such opposition from sinners against himself, lest ye be tired out, and quite despond.
12.4: You have not yet resisted unto death, striving against sin.
12.5: have you forgot the exhortation which is address'd to you, as to children? "my son, despise not thou the chastning of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of him.
12.6: for whom the Lord loveth, he chastises, and scourgeth every son whom he receives."
12.7: if you are to endure chastisement, God treats you as his children: for where's the son whom his father does not chastise?
12.8: but if you were exempted from that discipline which others are subject to, then are you bastards, and not sons.
12.9: when our natural parents corrected us, we gave them reverence: is it not much more reasonable to be in subjection to the father of spirits, in order to have life?
12.10: their discipline was temporary, and the effect of humour; whereas God chastises us for our advantage, to make us partakers of his holiness.
12.11: 'tis true, all correction at first is far from appearing agreeable, yet afterward it produces the agreeable fruits of virtue in those who are exercised thereby.
12.12: Wherefore "strengthen your weak hands and your feeble knees.
12.13: clear the way for your feet, lest that which is lame should be quite out of joint, instead of being redress'd."
12.14: seek peace with all men, and sanctity of life, without which no man shall see the Lord:
12.15: take care not to deprive yourselves of the divine favour: and that no poisonous root spring up, and spread a general infection among you.
12.16: let there be no licentious or profane person, such as Esau, "who sold his birth-right, for a single mess."
12.17: for you know that afterward, when he would have inherited the blessing, he was rejected: not being able to make Isaac to retract, though he importun'd him with tears.
12.18: You do not approach to any thing corporeal, to scorching fire, to smoak, darkness, and tempest,
12.19: nor to the sound of trumpets, and the voice which pronounc'd such words, that they who heard, intreated they might hear it no more.
12.20: nor could they endure that threat, "if so much as a beast touch the mountain, it shall be stoned."
12.21: and so terrible was the appearance, that Moses cry'd out, "I tremble with the fright."
12.22: but you are come to mount Sion, to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an innumerable congress of angels, to the general assembly,
12.23: the church of the first-born who are enroll'd in heaven, to God the judge of all, to the spirits of just men made perfect,
12.24: to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant, and to the aspersion of that blood which cries for pardon, and not for vengeance as that of Abel.
12.25: Take care that you be not deaf to him that speaketh: for if they did not escape, who disregarded the oracles pronounc'd on earth, much less shall we escape, if we turn away from him that delivered the oracles from heaven:
12.26: whose voice then shook the earth: but he has promised to do it now, saying, " yet once more I will shake, not the earth only, but heaven too."
12.27: and this expression, yet once more" signifies the abolition of those changeable things which were only contriv'd, that what is unalterable might lastingly succeed.
12.28: since then we are entring into a kingdom which cannot be changed, let us maintain the divine favour, whereby we may serve God acceptably, with reverence and fear.
12.29: for "our God is a consuming fire."

13.2: be not unmindful of hospitality: for thereby some have unknowingly entertained angels.
13.3: remember those that are in chains, as if you were confin'd with them; and those who suffer adversity, as being your selves of the same body.
13.4: Marriage is every where honourable, and that state is innocent: but the licentious and adulterers God will punish.
13.5: let your morals be free from avarice, being contented with what you have: for he hath said, "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee."
13.6: so that we may boldly say, " the Lord is my helper, and I will not fear what man shall do unto me."
13.7: Remember those who have the rule over you, who have preach'd to you the word of God: imitate their faith; consider their conduct, and the exit they made.
13.8: Jesus Christ is always the same, yesterday, to-day, and for ever, be not then misled by artful, novel doctrines:
13.9: for the mind is better improv'd by the gospel-dispensation, than by the distinctions about meats, in which some have been so uselesly vers'd.
13.10: We have a victim, whereof they, who still serve at the tabernacle, have no more right to eat,
13.11: than the sacrificers had to eat of the flesh of those beasts, which were burnt without the camp, and whose blood the highpriest carried into the sanctuary.
13.12: for Jesus likewise suffered without the gate, to show he was the expiatory victim for the people.
13.13: let us therefore decamp, and bear the reproach of following his example:
13.14: for we have, no settled corporation here, but are in expectation of that which is approaching.
13.15: Let our sacrifice then, which we are to offer to God by Jesus Christ, be that of incessant praises, the offering of our lips, which celebrate his name:
13.16: but don't forget to be beneficent to the community; for such sacrifice is acceptable to God.
13.17: Confide in your guides, and be respectful: that they who are vigilant, as being accountable for your souls, may discharge themselves with cheerfulness, and not with anxiety, which would be to your prejudice.
13.18: Pray for us, for we trust we have a clear conscience, and desire our virtuous conduct may appear to all the world.
13.19: I conjure you the more earnestly to do this, that I may be restored to you the sooner.
13.20: May the God of peace, who has raised from the dead our Lord Jesus (who by the blood of the eternal covenant is become the grand pastor of
13.21: the sheep) make you perfect in every virtue, to the accomplishment of his will: effecting that in you by Jesus Christ, which is agreeable to him: to whom be glory thro' all ages.
13.22: Pray, my brethren, favourably receive this exhortation, which I have writ to you in brief.
13.23: know, that our brother Timothy is set at liberty, if he comes quickly, I shall make YOU a visit with him.
13.24: salute those who conduct you, and all the christians, they of Italy salute you.
13.25: grace be with you all. AMEN.

1.1: James a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the TWELVE TRIBES dispers'd thro' the world, sends greeting.
1.2: Consider the various tryals that surround you, my brethren, as matter of great joy; knowing this,
1.3: that the bringing your faith to the test, produces constancy.
1.4: but constancy should be brought to its perfection, that you may be entirely accomplished, without any defect.
1.5: If any of you is deficient in prudence, let him ask it of God, who liberally gives to all without upbraiding: and he will give it.
1.6: but let him be fully persuaded of the lawfulness of what he asks: for he that is diffident about that, is like the waves that fluctuate with the wind.
1.7: such a man must not expect any answer from the Lord.
1.8: a diffident man is inconstant in all his actions.
1.9: Let him that is poor triumph in the advantages of being a christian.
1.10: let the rich be humbled by his instability: for he is as transitory as a flower in the field.
1.11: the sun is up and darts its rays, the grass is wither'd, its flowers droop, and all their beautiful appearance vanishes away, just so the rich man fades with all his projects.
1.12: happy is he that can stand the tryal: for when he has undergone the test, he shall receive that crown of life which the Lord has promised to those that love him.
1.13: Let no man under temptation, say, it is God that tempts him; for as he is incapable of moral evil, he can't influence any one thereto.
1.14: a man is instigated, and drawn into the snare by his own vicious passions, which once indulg'd, are productive of sin,
1.15: and the genuine offspring of sin is death.
1.16: Don't be deluded, my brethren;
1.17: every thing that is valuable, every gift that leads to perfection is deriv'd from heaven, it descends from that original light, which knows no change, no shadow, or decline:
1.18: 'tis he that has voluntarily renew'd us by the oracles of truth, that we might be the first converts of the new creation.
1.19: Wherefore, my dear brethren, let every one be eager to hear, averse to contradiction, and deaf to passion.
1.20: for he that is not dispassionate is a stranger to the practice of true virtue.
1.21: throw off then your vices as dregs and scum: and receive with docility that genuine doctrine, which is effectual to your salvation.
1.22: Don't delusively content your selves with being of the audience, but put what you hear in practice:
1.23: for a bare auditor without practice is like one who sees his image form'd by a mirror:
1.24: he takes a view, turns away, and instantly loses his appearance.
1.25: whereas, he that attentively considers the perfect law of liberty, and is attach'd thereto, he is not a forgetful hearer, but reduces it to practice, and his conduct is crown'd with hapiness.
1.26: If a person of an ungovernable tongue pretends to religion, he abuses himself: for his religion is meer illusion.
1.27: pure and unadulterated religion, in the eye of God our father, consists in taking care of orphans and widows in their distress: and in keeping clear of the vices of the age.

2.1: My brethren, let not your christian profession be accompanied with partiality.
2.2: when any one, adorn'd with a gold ring, and a splendid dress, enters into your assembly; and a poor man comes in meanly habited:
2.3: if you should respectfully say to the suit of fine cloths, sit you there, that's for quality; and to the poor man, stand thou there, or place your self at my feet:
2.4: have not you made an arbitrary distinction, don't your judgments flow from a vicious principle?
2.5: consider, my dear brethren, has not God chose the poor of this world to be rich by faith, and to inherit the kingdom he has promised to those who love him?
2.6: but you, who despise the poor, are not you oppress'd by the rich? is it not they who drag you to their tribunals?
2.7: they who blaspheme that sacred name by which you are distinguish'd?
2.8: If, agreeably to the scriptures, you observe that royal law, "thou shalt love thy neighbour as thy self," you do well.
2.9: but partiality is iniquity; and the law will convict the offender of transgression.
2.10: for he that violates but one precept of the whole law, is as obnoxious to punishment, as if he had broke thro' all the rest.
2.12: speak and act as those, who are to be judged by the law of liberty.
2.13: for he that has not shewed mercy, shall be condemn'd without mercy: while the merciful shall triumph at his trial.
2.14: What advantage is it, my brethren, for a man to say he has faith, if he has no beneficence? can such a faith save him?
2.15: suppose one of your brethren should be destitute of cloths, and of his daily nourishment,
2.16: and one of you should thus address him; "go and prosper, I wish you a warm fire, and a full meal:" without relieving his wants, would he be the better for your wish?
2.17: just so faith, if it be not operative, is intirely lifeless.
2.18: it will be said, "you have a speculative faith, but mine is practical, where is your faith, if no effects appear? as for me, my actions will vouch for my faith.
2.19: you believe there is but one God, very well: the demons believe as much, and tremble."
2.20: Vain man, must I show you how lifeless a thing faith is, without its effects?
2.21: was not our father Abraham treated as just, in consequence of his actions, when he had attempted to sacrifice his son upon the altar?
2.22: don't you see his actions and his faith conspir'd, and that his faith had its perfect effect in his conduct?
2.24: you see then, that a man is accounted just for his actions, and not for his bare faith.
2.25: was it not likewise for her actions, that Rahab, formerly a loose liver, was accounted as just, for having entertain'd the messengers of Joshuah, and dismiss'd them the securest way?
2.26: as the body then without the soul is a meer carcase, so faith without its effects is lifeless.

3.1: My brethren, don't affect many of you to be doctors, considering, that those of us who are such, shall be tried with the greater severity.
3.2: for we are all liable to frequent mistakes, he that does not give too great a loose to his tongue, is an accomplish'd person and fit to moderate the whole church.
3.3: you see how manageable horses are made by the application of a bit, which makes them take what motion we please.
3.4: a ship too of the greatest burthen, tho' the wind bears hard, by means of an inconsiderable helm, veers about as the hand of the pilot directs her.
3.5: so the tongue is but a small part of the body, yet how grand are its pretensions, a spark of fire! what quantities of timber will it blow into a flame?
3.6: the tongue is a brand that sets the world in a combustion: it is but one of the numerous organs of the body, yet it can blast whole assemblies: tipp'd with infernal sulphur it sets the whole train of life in a blaze.
3.7: creatures of every kind, beasts, birds, reptiles, and sea-monsters, are frequently tamed by human industry.
3.8: but who could ever tame the tongue? arm'd with deadly poison, the mischief scorns restraint.
3.9: By that we give praises to God the father: and that pronounces curses even against men, who are form'd after the divine resemblance.
3.10: from the same mouth shall blessing and cursing proceed? this ought not to be practis'd, my brethren;
3.11: does a fountain throw up salt water and fresh, by the same conveyance?
3.12: can a fig-tree, my brethren, produce olives, or a vine figs? no more can the sea yield water that is fresh.
3.13: Whoever is a skilful moralist, let him show by his virtuous conduct, that he practises the humble precepts of wisdom.
3.14: but if envy and contention imbitter your minds, don't think your false pretences can stand against the truth:
3.15: such wisdom is not derived from heaven; but is terrestrial, sensual, demoniacal.
3.16: where false zeal, and a spirit of contention reign, there confusion and every vice prevail.
3.17: but wisdom deriv'd from heaven is first dispassionate, then pacific, equitable, and obsequious: full of beneficence, and all social virtue, free from partiality, and hypocrisy.
3.18: they who cultivate peace, enjoy the reward of their virtue.

4.1: you breathe slaughter and revenge for what you cannot obtain.
4.2: you quarrel and go to war, but without success, because you don't petition for it: and if you did,
4.3: you would not obtain it, because you wickedly request to have your passions gratified.
4.4: Degenerate race, don't you know that friendship with vice is hostility against heaven, he that is a friend to the vicious world, is an enemy to God.
4.5: or do you imagine that passage of scripture to be insignificant, "does the spirit that dwells in you, incite you to vice?"
4.6: on the contrary, he heaps his favours upon you, wherefore 'tis said, "God defeats the proud, but is gracious to the humble."
4.7: Surrender therefore to God, resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
4.8: address your selves to God, and you will find him present with you: cleanse your hands, ye sinners; and purify your hearts, you that are diffident.
4.9: be afflicted, be mournful, and weep: let your mirth be converted to sadness, and your joy to vexation.
4.10: humble your selves before the Lord, and he will raise you up.
4.11: Don't, my brethren, treat one another with detraction, he that reflects upon his brother, and censures his brother, reflects upon the law, and censures the law: if you censure the law, instead of obeying it, you set up for a judge.
4.12: there is but one legislator, and judge, he that has the power of life and death: who art thou, to pass sentence upon another?
4.13: As for you, who affirm, "to-day, or, to-morrow we will go to such a city, we will stay there a whole year, there we will traffic, and find our account."
4.14: how do you know, what will happen to-morrow? for, "what is your life?" a vapour that just appears, and then vanishes.
4.15: your language ought to be this, "if the Lord pleases to give us life, we shall do this, or that."
4.16: you triumph in your vain projects, but your presumption is vicious.
4.17: he then that knows what is virtuous, and does not practise it, is a criminal.

5.1: As for you that are rich: weep, and lament the miserys that are falling upon you.
5.2: your wealth is wasted, your wardrobe is devour'd by the worm,
5.3: and your gold and silver by rust: that rust shall convict you: that rust shall corrode your flesh like a caustic, which you have treasur'd up against the last days.
5.4: hark! what a noise there is of hire, of which you cheated the labourers, who gather'd in your harvest! the cries of the reapers have reach'd even the Lord of the celestial militia.
5.5: you have liv'd on the earth in voluptuousness and luxury: you have indulg'd your selves as in a day of sacrifice:
5.6: you have condemn'd the just, you have put him to death, though he did not oppose you.
5.7: As for you, my brethren, bear your sufferings with constancy, till the advent of the Lord, the farmer, from the prospect of a golden crop, patiently expects the showers of the spring and the autumn.
5.8: be you equally patient, and exercise your fortitude, for the advent of the Lord is nigh.
5.9: don't repine, my brethren, against one another, for fear you should be condemn'd, behold, the judge is at the gate.
5.10: let the prophets, my brethren, who were commission'd by the Lord, be your examples; suffer persecution with constancy like them.
5.11: we pronounce those happy, who have so endur'd, you have heard of the constancy of Job, you know with what success he was crown'd by the Lord, who is all mercy and compassion.
5.12: Above all things, my brethren, don't swear, neither by the heaven, nor by the earth, nor use any other oath; but let your affirmation, or negation, be sincere, lest you fall under condemnation.
5.13: Is any among you afflicted? let him pray, is his mind serene? let him sing psalms.
5.14: Is any of you sick? let him send for the pastors of the church, to pray for him, and after giving him the unction, in the name of the Lord,
5.15: the prayer that proceeds from faith, shall save the sick; the Lord will raise him up, and his sins that may have been the occasion, shall be forgiven.
5.16: confess then to one another the offences you have committed, and pray for one another, that you may be healed; the fervent prayer of a virtuous man has great influence.
5.17: Elias was only a man, as we are; however, having ardently prayed, that it might not rain, it did not rain in that country for three years and a half:
5.18: then be pray'd again: the heavens sent its showers, and the earth push'd out its fruit.
5.19: My brethren, when any of you deviates from the truth, whoever sets him right, may be assured,
5.20: that the retrieving of a sinner from his erroneous habits, is saving a soul from ruin, and cancels a multitude of sins.

1.1: Jude the servant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to those that are sanctified by God the father, and by their vocation are reserved for Jesus Christ.
1.2: mercy, peace and love be multiplied to you.
1.3: My beloved, as I was strongly bent upon writing to you of our common salvation, I thought it necessary to write to you at present, and exhort you to contend earnestly for the faith, which was once delivered to the saints.
1.4: For certain men have insinuated themselves among you, who were formerly proscrib'd to be punish'd; impious men, who pervert the divine favour to licentiousness, and renounce their only master, and Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.5: Now, I would call to your remembrance what you once were inform'd of, that when the Lord had delivered the people from the land of Egypt, he afterward destroyed those that were disobedient.
1.6: and the angels which kept not their original dignity, but deserted their proper abode, he hath reserved in everlasting chains under darkness, to the judgment of the great day.
1.7: so it was with Sodom, Gomorrha, and the neighbouring cities, who abandoning themselves to the same licentiousness and abominable passions, were made examples by suffering the punishment of eternal fire.
1.8: yet these visionary debauchees despise princes, and traduce dignitys.
1.9: whereas Michael the archangel, when contending with the devil, he disputed about the body of Moses, did not take the liberty to inveigh against him, but said, "the Lord rebuke thee."
1.10: As for these, they inveigh against what they do not understand: and abuse those natural instincts which regulate brute animals.
1.11: unhappy creatures! they have followed the practices of Cain, they have addicted themselves to the mercenary illusions of Balaam, and perish in their rebellion like Core.
1.12: they are a disgrace to your love-feasts, they indulge themselves at your festivals without reserve: clouds without water, transported with every wind: trees whose fruit soon withers and is useless, twice dead and rooted up:
1.13: raging waves of the sea, foaming out their own shame: wandering lights, to whom is reserv'd the thickest darkness for ever.
1.14: Of these did Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesy in these words, "see! the Lord is coming with ten thousand of his saints,
1.15: to execute judgment upon all, and to convict all the impious among them, of all the impious actions they have committed, and of all the injurious expressions, which impious sinners have utter'd against him."
1.16: These are murmurers, complainers, who pursue their own passions: their language swells with flattery, which they offer to the personages of men from a prospect of gain.
1.17: As for you, my beloved, remember what the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ have formerly told you.
1.18: for they assur'd you, there would be impostors in the last days, who would follow their own impious passions.
1.19: these are they who distinguish themselves, though they are sensual, and have nothing that is spiritual.
1.20: but you, my brethren, improve yourselves in your most holy faith, present your addresses by the holy spirit,
1.21: and thereby cultivate the divine favour, in the expectation of eternal life by the mercy of Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.22: Make use of your discernment; some reprove:
1.23: of others be compassionately tender, snatching them, as it were, out of the fire: and avoid even the garment of the infected.
1.24: Now to him that is able to keep you from falling, and make you appear in his glorious presence, without defect, and full of joy:
1.25: to God only wise, our saviour, be glory, magnificence, power, and empire, both now and for ever.

1.1: The REVELATION of Jesus Christ, which God gave him, to shew to his servants things which must shortly come to pass; this he signified by his angel whom he dispatch'd to his servant John:
1.2: who publish'd the divine message, and gave his attestation to every thing that he saw concerning Jesus Christ.
1.3: Happy is he that reads, and attends to the words of this prophecy, and observes the matter therein contain'd: for the time draws nigh.
1.4: JOHN to the seven churches which are in Asia: favour and peace be with you from him WHO IS, WHO WAS, WHO WILL BE; and from the seven spirits who are before his throne;
1.5: and from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witness, the first-born of the dead, and the prince of the kings of the earth: unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins by his own blood,
1.6: who hath made us kings and priests to his God and father; to him be glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen.
1.7: See! he is coming on the clouds; and every eye shall see him, even they who pierced him: then all the tribes of the earth will smite their breasts at the sight: even so it will be.
1.8: I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, saith the Lord, who is, and who was, and who will be, the almighty.
1.9: I JOHN, who am your brother, and partake in the tribulation, in the reign, and in the patience of Jesus Christ, was in the isle called Patmos, for the word of God, and for the testimony I gave of Jesus Christ.
1.10: there I was in an exstacy on the Lord's day, and heard behind me a loud voice, like the sound of a trumpet,
1.11: saying, "I am Alpha and Omega, the first and the last: and, what you shall see, write in a book, and send it to the seven churches which are in Asia; to Ephesus, to Smyrna, to Pergamos, to Thyatira, to Sardis, to Philadelphia, and to Laodicea."
1.12: and I turned to see from whence the voice came that spake to me, and turning about, I saw seven golden candlesticks;
1.13: and in the midst of the seven candlesticks, one who resembled the son of man, cloathed with a garment down to the foot, and girt below the breast with a girdle of gold.
1.14: his head and his hairs were white like wool, as white as snow; and his eyes were as a flame of fire; his feet were like fine brass,
1.15: when glowing in a furnace; and his voice as the sound of many waters.
1.16: in his right hand he held seven stars: out of his mouth went a sharp two-edged sword, and his countenance was as the sun shining in his full glory.
1.18: I am he that liveth; I was dead; but now you see I am alive for all eternity, amen; and I have the keys of the grave, and of death."
1.19: write what you have seen, the things which are, and the things which shall be hereafter.
1.20: the conceal'd meaning of the seven stars which you saw in my right hand, and of the seven golden candlesticks, is this: the seven stars signify the angels of the seven churches: and the seven candlesticks which you saw, signify the seven churches.

2.1: To the angel of the church of Ephesus, write, "HE that holds the seven stars in his right hand, who walks in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks, says thus,
2.2: I know thy works, thy labour, and thy patience, and that thou canst not bear those who are evil: thou hast tried those who say they are apostles, but are not; and hast found them lyars:
2.3: thou hast suffer'd, hast patience, for my name's sake thou hast laboured, and hast not fainted.
2.4: nevertheless, I have somewhat against thee, because thou hast left thy first love.
2.5: remember therefore from whence thou art fallen, and repent, and do the first works; or else I will come unto thee quickly, and will remove thy candlestick out of his place except thou repent.
2.6: but in this thou art right, that thou hatest the deeds of the Nicolaitans, which I also hate.
2.7: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith to the churches, to him that overcometh will I give to eat of the tree of life, which is in the paradise of my God."
2.8: And to the angel of the church in Smyrna, write, "THESE things saith the first and last, who was dead, and is alive."
2.9: "I know thy works, thy tribulation and poverty (tho' thou art rich) and I know the blasphemy of those who say they are Jews, and are not, but are the synagogue of satan.
2.10: fear none of those things which thou shalt suffer: behold, the devil shall cast some of you into prison, that ye may be tried; and ye shall have tribulation ten days: be thou faithful unto death, and I will give thee a crown of life.
2.11: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith to the churches, he that overcometh, shall not be hurt by the second death."
2.12: And to the angel of the church in Pergamos, write, "THESE things, saith he, who hath the sharp sword with two edges,
2.13: I know thy works, and where thou dwellest, even where the throne of satan is: thou maintainest my name, and hast not renounced your faith in me, even at a time when Antipas my faithful martyr was slain among you, where Satan dwells.
2.14: but I have a few things against thee, because thou hast there those that hold the doctrine of Balaam, who counselled Balac to ensnare the children of Israel, to eat things sacrificed to idols, and to commit fornication.
2.15: you have likewise those that hold the doctrine of the Nicolaitans, which I hate.
2.16: repent; or else I will come unto thee quickly, and will fight against them with the sword of my mouth.
2.17: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith unto the churches: to him that overcometh, will I give to eat of the hidden manna, and will give him a white stone, and in the stone a new name written, which no man understands, except he that receives it."
2.18: And unto the angel of the church in Thyatira, write, "THESE things saith the son of God, whose eyes are like a flame of fire, and his feet like fine brass; I know thy works,
2.19: your charitable offices, your faith, and your patience, and that your last works exceed the first.
2.20: notwithstanding, I have a few things against thee, because thou sufferest that woman Jezabel, who stiles herself a prophetess, and teaches and seduces my servants to commit fornication, and to eat things sacrificed to idols.
2.21: I gave her space to repent of her fornication, but she repented not.
2.22: behold, I will confine her to her bed, and those that commit adultery with her I will severely afflict, except they repent of their actions.
2.23: I will strike her children dead; and all the churches shall know that I am he who searcheth the reins and the heart: and I will give to every one of you according to your works.
2.24: but I say to the rest that are in Thyatira, who do not follow this doctrine, and have not been initiated in the depths, as they are called, of satan, I will put upon you no other burden, but what you have:
2.25: hold that fast till I come.
2.26: he that overcometh, and keepeth my works unto the end, to him will I give power over the nations:
2.27: he shall rule them with a rod of iron: as the vessels of a potter shall they be broken to shivers, according to the power I have received of my father.
2.28: I will even give him the lustre of the morning-star.
2.29: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith to the churches."

3.1: And unto the angel of the church in Sardis, write, "THESE things saith he that hath the seven spirits of God and the seven stars; I know thy works, that thou hast the reputation of being alive, but art dead.
3.2: be watchful, and fortify the rest that are ready to die: for I have not found thy works perfect before God.
3.3: remember therefore what thou hast received and heard: observe it and repent, if therefore thou art not vigilant, I will come upon thee as a thief, thou shalt not know what hour I will come upon thee.
3.4: thou hast a few persons in Sardis who have not defiled their garments; they shall walk with me in white: for they are worthy.
3.5: he that overcometh, the same shall be cloathed in white raiment; I will not efface his name out of the book of life, but I will own him before my father, and before his angels.
3.6: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith unto the churches."
3.7: And to the angel of the church in Philadelphia, write, "THESE things saith He that is holy, He that is true, He that hath the key of David, He that openeth what no man can shut; and shutteth what no man can open:
3.8: I know thy works: behold, I have set before thee an open door, and no man can shut it: for tho' few in number, you have kept my word, and have not renounced my name.
3.9: you shall see I will make those of the synagogue of satan, who say they are Jews, and are not, but do lye: you shall see I will make them come, and throw themselves at your feet, and they shall know that you are the objects of my love.
3.10: because you have kept my precept about patience, I also will keep you in the time of persecution, which shall happen to all the world, to try the inhabitants of the earth.
3.11: behold, I come quickly: hold that fast which you have, let no man take your crown.
3.12: him that overcomes, will I make a pillar in the temple of my God, and he shall go out no more: I will write upon him the name of my God, and the name of the city of my God, which is new Jerusalem, which descends from heaven from my God: even my new name will I write.
3.13: he that hath an ear, let him hear what the spirit saith unto the churches."
3.14: And unto the angel of the church of the Laodiceans, write, "these things saith the AMEN, the faithful and true witness, the beginning of the creation of God;
3.15: I know thy works, that thou art neither cold nor hot: I would thou wert cold or hot.
