11.6: a woman may as well have the tonsure, as not wear her veil: the one is as indecent as the other.
11.7: A man ought not to be veil'd: he has the honour of being invested with authority from God, and may glory in his priority to the woman.
11.8: for the man was not taken from the woman: but the woman from the man.
11.9: nor was the man copied from the woman: but the woman from the man.
11.10: therefore the woman ought to be veil'd, out of regard to the angels.
11.11: however, the man and the woman are equal with respect to the Lord.
11.12: for as the woman was taken from the man, so man is born of the woman: and all are from God.
11.13: Be you yourselves judges: is it decent for a woman to pray to God without a veil?
11.14: does not settled custom show it is a shame for a man to have long hair?
11.15: on the contrary, such is an ornament to a woman: because it was given her as a sort of veil.
11.16: but if any man has a mind to be contentious, I answer, we have no such custom, nor any of the churches of God.
11.17: Now in what I am going to say, I do not commend you, because your assemblies are not to your advantage, but to your prejudice.
11.18: for first, I hear, that when you come together in the church, you fall into parties; and I believe it is true of some of you.
11.19: for there must be factions among you, whereby it will appear who among you are the approved.
11.20: when you thus assemble therefore, this is not eating the Lord's supper.
11.21: for in eating every one strives to take his own supper first, and while one is hungry, another is surfeited.
11.22: what, have you no houses to eat and drink in? or have ye a contempt for the church of God, or is it to insult those who are in want? what shall I say to you? shall I commend such behaviour? I do not approve of it.
11.23: For I received it from the Lord, and I inform'd you of it: that the Lord Jesus, the night in which he was betrayed, took bread:
11.24: and when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, "take, eat; this is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me."
11.25: in the same manner he took the cup, after supper, and said, "this cup is the new covenant in my blood: this do ye, as oft as ye drink it, in remembrance of me."
11.26: As often then as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye make a declaration of the Lord's death till he come.
11.27: so that whosoever eats this bread, and drinks this cup without respect to the Lord, does make a criminal use of the body and blood of the Lord.
11.28: Let a man then sift and approve himself, and accordingly let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup.
11.29: for he that eats and drinks in a disrespectful manner, not discriminating the Lord's body, eateth and drinketh to his own punishment.
11.30: hence it is, that many are weak and sickly among you, and no small number now sleep in their graves.
11.31: for if we made such a discrimination, we should not be punished.
11.32: but when we are punished, we are chastised by the Lord, that we may not be condemned with the world.
11.33: wherefore, my brethren, when you come together to eat, stay for one another.
11.34: and if any one is press'd with hunger, let him eat at home; that ye may not otherwise meet with punishment, as for other matters, I will set them in order when I come.

12.1: Now concerning those who are spiritual, my brethren, I would not have you be mistaken.
12.2: when you were Gentiles, you know how you were seduced by your leaders, to the worship of dumb idols.
12.3: wherefore I give you to understand, that no man who has the spirit of God, can pronounce Jesus anathema: and that no man can acknowledge Jesus to be the Lord, but by the holy spirit.
12.4: Now there are different gifts, but the same spirit.
12.5: and there are different offices, but the same Lord.
12.6: and there are different operations, but it is the same God who performs them all in every one.
12.7: now to particular men the spirit gives particular gifts, that they may be displayed to greater advantage.
12.8: for to one the spirit gives the knowledge of the prophetical writings; to another the same spirit gives the knowledge of the doctrines of religion;
12.9: to another faith; to another the gifts of healing;
12.10: to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy, to another discerning of spirits; to another diversity of languages; to another the interpretation of languages.
12.11: but all are wrought by one and the same spirit, distributing to every one in particular, as he thinks fit.
12.12: For as the body is one, tho' it has many members, and all the members of that one body, tho' many, are one body: so also is the body of Christ.
12.13: for by one spirit we have all been baptized, to be form'd into one body, whether Jews or Gentiles, slaves or free; and have been all made to drink of one spirit.
12.14: the body is not one member, but many.
12.17: if the whole body were an eye, where would be the hearing? if the whole were hearing, where would be the smelling?
12.18: now God disposed every one of the members in the body as he thought fit.
12.19: but if they were all one member, where would be the body?
12.20: thus, tho' there are many members, yet there is but one body.
12.21: and the eye cannot say to the hand, "I have no need of thee:" nor again, the head to the feet, "I have no need of you."
12.22: nay, those parts of the body, which seem to be of the least account, are much more necessary.
12.23: what we think to be less honourable, is loaded with additional ornaments, and the less graceful have adventitious finery,
12.24: of which the graceful have no need: but God has contrived the symmetry of the body, by bestowing an additional advantage where it seem'd to want it.
12.25: that there might be no schism in the body; but that the members should have the same mutual concern for one another.
12.26: so that if one member suffer, they all suffer with it: or if one be honoured, they partake of it.
12.27: Thus you are the body of Christ, being the particular members of it.
12.28: which God has placed in the church, first apostles, next prophets, then teachers, after that miracles, then gifts of healings, assistants, governours, interpreters of languages.
12.29: are all apostles? are all prophets? are all teachers? are all workers of miracles?
12.30: have all the gifts of healing? do all speak divers languages? do all interpret?
12.31: you are contesting about the superiority of your gifts: but I point out to you a more excellent way.

13.1: For tho' I should speak with the eloquence of men, and of angels, and not have social affection, I should be like sounding brass, or a noisy cymbal.
13.2: and tho' I should have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and tho' I had all the faith necessary to remove mountains, and had no benevolence, it would signify nothing.
13.3: and tho' I distribute my whole substance to the poor, and give my body to be burned, and have not social affection, it profits me nothing.
13.4: Social affection is patient, is kind; is a stranger to envy; is not insolently vain, nor arrogant: does not behave indecently,
13.5: is not self-interested, is not easily provoked, nor suspects any ill;
13.6: it does not countenance injustice, but smiles upon virtue;
13.7: it excuses all things, believes what is favourable, hopes for the best, and suffers the worst.
13.8: Social affection will never fail: but as for prophecies, they shall be out of use; as for languages, they shall cease; as for knowledge, it shall vanish away.
13.9: for our knowledge is defective, and our prophesying is defective.
13.10: but when that which is perfect is come, then that which is defective shall be laid aside.
13.11: when I was a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I reasoned as a child: but when I became a man, I laid aside my childish ways.
13.12: now we do but indirectly see the faint images of things; but then the objects themselves will be before our eyes; now I have a partial knowledge, but then shall I know, even as I myself am known.
13.13: and now faith, hope, social virtue, these three will all remain; but the most permanent of the three is social virtue.

14.1: Cultivate social virtue; then desire spiritual gifts, but chiefly that of explaining the prophetical writings.
14.2: for he that speaks in an unknown tongue, speaks not to men, but to God: for no man can understand the mysteries he delivers by the spirit.
14.3: but he that expounds, speaks to the edification, exhortation, and comfort of men.
14.4: he that speaks in an unknown tongue, edifies himself alone: but he that expounds, edifies the church.
14.5: I wish you all had the gift of languages, but rather that you expounded: for greater is he that expounds, than he that speaks unknown languages, except he interpret what he says, that the church may be edified by it.
14.6: for instance, brethren, if I deliver myself to you in an unknown tongue, what good shall I do you, except I deliver to you the meaning of what is said, whether it relate to revelation, to mystical knowledge, to prophecy, or to doctrine.
14.7: And even inanimate instruments of sound, whether pipe or harp, except they have a distinct variety of notes, how can they express any significant tune?
14.8: for if the trumpet give an undistinguish'd sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?
14.9: in like manner, if you express yourselves in words of obscure signification, you may as well talk to the wind, for how shall any comprehend you?
14.10: there are, it may be, as many different languages in the world as there are people, and none of them without signification.
14.11: therefore if I don't know the meaning of the language, with respect to him that speaks, I shall be a barbarian; and he that speaks shall be a barbarian to me.
14.12: But since there is emulation among you concerning spiritual gifts, seek to abound in the exercise of such gifts as tend most to the edification of the church.
14.13: wherefore let him that speaketh in an unknown tongue, pray for the gift of interpretation.
14.14: for if I pray in an unknown tongue, my spirit indeed prays, but my meaning is of no benefit to others.
14.15: what then is to be done? why, I will pray by the spirit, but my prayer shall be intelligible: I will sing by the spirit, but my hymn shall be intelligible.
14.17: thy thanksgiving indeed is right, but the other is not all edified by it.
14.18: I thank God, I speak more languages than you all:
14.19: yet in the church I had rather speak five words that convey my meaning to the instruction of others, than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue.
14.20: Brethren, be not childish in understanding: be as innocent as babes, but use your understanding like men.
14.21: in the law it is written, " with men of other tongues and other lips, will I speak unto this people: and yet for all that will they not hear me, saith the Lord."
14.22: wherefore tongues are for a sign, not to believers, but to unbelievers: but expounding the prophets, not for unbelievers so much as for those who believe.
14.23: when therefore the whole church is assembled, and all speak different languages, if such as are either unlearned, or are unbelievers should come in, will they not say you are all mad?
14.24: but if you all expound, and an unbeliever, or one unlearned come in, he is examin'd by all, he is tryed by all:
14.25: the secrets of his heart become manifest; and so falling down on his face, he will worship God, and declare that God is certainly amongst you.
14.26: what is then to be done, my brethren? when you come together, one of you with a psalm, another with a doctrine, another with a strange tongue, another with a revelation, another with an interpretation: let the whole be done to edification.
14.27: and if any man do speak in an unknown tongue, let but two speak, or three at the most, and that by turns: and let there be but one to interpret.
14.28: but if there be no interpreter, let him keep silence in the church; and tacitly address himself to God.
14.29: of the prophets let but two or three speak by turns, and let the others deliberate.
14.30: if the meaning be revealed to another that sits by, let the first be silent.
14.31: for ye may all prophesy one by one, that all may receive instruction and exhortation.
14.32: the prophetic gifts are to be subservient to the prophets.
14.33: for God is not the God of confusion, but of peace, in all christian assemblies.
14.34: Let your women be silent in your assemblies: for they are not allowed to discourse there; but are to observe orders, as indeed the law implies:
14.35: and if they desire to have information about any point, let them consult their husbands at home: for it does not become women to ask questions in the church.
14.36: What, did the gospel take its rise from you? or was it communicated to you alone?
14.37: if any one pretends to be a prophet, or to spiritual gifts, let him be assured that the rules which I have here prescrib'd, are the commandments of the Lord.
14.38: but if he will be blind, I leave him to his blindness.
14.39: wherefore, brethren, zealously exercise the gift of prophecy, and don't prohibit those that speak in an unknown language.
14.40: let all things be done with decency, and without disorder.

15.1: What I have explain'd to you, my brethren, is the gospel which I preached to you, which you have received, and wherein you have persisted:
15.2: by which also you will be saved, if you so retain it as I preached it to you, unless you have believed without sufficient grounds.
15.3: I acquainted you chiefly with what I received myself, that Christ died for our sins, as the scriptures foretold:
15.4: that he was buried, and rose again the third day, as the scriptures foretold:
15.5: that he was seen by Cephas, then by the twelve:
15.6: after that, he was seen by above five hundred brethren at once: of whom the greater part remain alive to this day, but some are now dead.
15.7: after that he was seen by James; then by all the apostles.
15.8: and last of all, he was seen by me too, who am as it were an abortive;
15.9: for I am the meanest of the apostles, not worthy the name of an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
15.10: it is by the divine favour that I am what I am: and his favour to me was not in vain; no, I laboured more than they all: yet it was not I, it was the divine favour which assisted me.
15.11: but whether I or they labour'd most, this is what we preach, and this is what you believed.
15.12: Now if it has been declared, that Christ rose from the dead, how comes it, that some among you assert, "there is no resurrection of the dead?"
15.13: for if there be no resurrection of the dead, then Christ is not risen.
15.14: and if Christ be not risen, then our preaching is empty talk, and your faith even meer amusement.
15.15: yea, and we are no better than enthusiastic impostors by affirming that God raised up Christ, when he never did raise him up.
15.16: for if the dead are not raised, then was not Christ raised:
15.17: and if Christ was not raised, your faith is meer illusion, your sins are not yet forgiven.
15.18: then they too who died christians, are entirely lost.
15.19: if our expectations as christians all terminate in this life, we of all men are most to be pitied.
15.20: But Christ is actually risen, as previous to those who were dead.
15.21: for since by man came death, by man the resurrection of the dead will likewise come.
15.22: for as by Adam all die, even so by Christ shall all be restored to life.
15.23: but every one in proper order: Christ has the precedence, next they who were Christians shall rise at his advent.
15.24: and then will be the end, when he shall deliver up the kingdom to God even the father; after having abolished all rule, and all authority, and power.
15.25: for he must reign, "till God has cast all his enemies under his feet."
15.26: the last enemy that shall be destroyed, is death.
15.28: and when all things shall be reduced under subjection to him, then shall the son also himself be subject to him that put all things under his subjection, that God may be all in all.
15.29: If it be not so, what can they effect who are baptized for the dead? if the dead rise not at all, why are they then baptized for the dead?
15.30: and why do we continually expose our lives to danger?
15.31: I am daily receiving new mortifications, witness your cruel boastings against me, which I bear for the sake of Christ Jesus our Lord;
15.32: besides, my engaging with those monsters, as I may say, at Ephesus, what advantage was it to me? if the dead don't rise, "let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die."
15.34: rouze from your sins, as is but just; for some of you have not the knowledge of God: I speak it to your shame.
15.35: But some will say, how will the dead be raised? with what kind of body will they appear?
15.36: foolish as you are, the grain you sow, is not revived except it die.
15.37: and whatever you sow, you don't sow that body which shall afterwards appear, but only the bare grain of wheat, for instance, or of some other grain.
15.38: but God gives it such a body, as he thinks fit, to every seed its peculiar body.
15.39: All flesh is not of the same kind: but there is one kind that belongs to men, another to beasts, another to fishes, and another to birds.
15.40: there are celestial bodies, and bodies terrestrial: but the glory of the celestial is of one kind, and the glory of the terrestrial of another.
15.41: the glory of the sun is of one kind, the glory of the moon of another, and the glory of the stars still different; nay, one star differs from another star in glory.
15.42: such will be the resurrection of the dead: the body is sown corruptible, it will be raised incorruptible.
15.43: it is sown in dishonour, it will be raised in glory: it is sown in decay, it will be raised in power:
15.44: it is sown an animal body, it will rise a spiritual body, there is an animal body, and there is a spiritual body.
15.45: and so it is written, the first man Adam was made an animating soul, the last Adam was made a vivifying spirit.
15.46: but the spiritual body was not first, but the animal; and afterwards the spiritual.
15.47: the first man was formed from the dust of the earth: the second man was from heaven.
15.48: as was the terrestrial, such are they also that are terrestrial: and as is the celestial, such also shall they be who are to be celestial.
15.49: for as we have born the image of the terrestrial, so we shall bear the image of the celestial.
15.50: this I say, my brethren, because the body, as it is at present, cannot possess the kingdom of God; and what is corruptible, can't enjoy incorruptibility.
15.51: I shall now tell you a very great secret: we shall not all of us sleep, but we shall all be changed,
15.52: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the sound of the last trumpet (for the trumpet shall sound) and the dead shall rise incorruptible; but as for us, we shall be changed.
15.53: for this corruptible body must be invested with incorruptibility, this mortal be invested with immortality.
15.55: "O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?"
15.56: the sting of death was sin; and the strength of sin was the law.
15.57: but thanks be to God, who has given us the victory, thro' our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.58: therefore, my beloved brethren, be ye inflexibly steady, and continually surpass others in the work of the Lord, knowing that he will not leave your christian labour unrewarded.

16.1: Now as to the collection for the converts at Jerusalem, do as I have directed for the churches of Galatia.
16.2: every sabbath-day let every one of you set apart something of what he has happily gain'd, for the common treasury, that there may be no collection when I come.
16.3: and when I come, I shall send such as you shall approve of, who will convey letters, and your kind present to Jerusalem.
16.4: and if it be so considerable as to induce me to go, they shall accompany me.
16.5: I shall come to you, by the way of Macedonia: (for I
16.6: pass thro' Macedonia) and perhaps I shall make some stay, if not pass the winter with you, that you may forward me on my journey, wherever I go.
16.7: for I do not design to see you in my passage thither, yet I hope to spend some time with you, if the Lord permit.
16.8: I shall stay at Ephesus, till whitsontide.
16.9: for I have a very fair and promising opportunity given me of propagating the gospel, tho' there are many opposers.
16.10: If Timothy visit you, take care he may be perfectly safe: for he labours in the cause of christianity, as well as I.
16.11: let no man therefore despise him: but conduct him safe, that he may come to me: for I and the brethren expect him.
16.12: as to brother Apollos, I earnestly entreat him to make you a visit, with the brethren: but he has not the least mind to it at present; however, he will be with you when a fit occasion offers.
16.13: Be upon the watch, stand firm in the faith, behave your selves like men of fortitude:
16.14: let all your transactions flow from social affections.
16.15: You know brethren, that the family of Stephanas were the first converts of Achaia, and have made it their business to be serviceable to christian converts: to such,
16.16: I beseech you be subservient, and to every one that helpeth us with his labours.
16.17: I am glad that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus are come: for what was wanting on your side, they have supplied.
16.18: for they have quieted my mind as well as yours: therefore to such have a regard.
16.19: The churches of Asia, salute you. Aquila and Priscilla salute you with much christian affection, and so do the church that is in their house.
16.20: all the brethren salute you, salute one another with an holy kiss.
16.21: I Paul salute you, and with my own handwriting.
16.22: If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be accurst.
16.23: the favour of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
16.24: present my love to every christian among you, amen.

1.1: Paul an apostle of Jesus Christ, by the divine appointment, and Timothy our brother, to the church of God, which is at Corinth, with all the christians throughout Achaia: favour,
1.2: and peace be to you from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: Blessed be the God, and father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the father of mercies, and the God of all consolation:
1.4: who comforteth me in all my tribulations, that I may be able to comfort them who are in any trouble, by the comfort wherewith I myself am comforted of God.
1.5: for as I have greatly suffered for Christ, so I have been greatly comforted thro' Christ.
1.6: but whether I am afflicted, it is for your consolation and relief, which is effected by your perseverance, patiently enduring the same sufferings which I also undergo: or whether I am comforted, it is for your consolation and relief.
1.7: and the hopes I had of you continue still the same, knowing that as you have had your share of suffering, so you will likewise have of consolation.
1.8: For I would not, brethren, have you ignorant of that insupportable weight of affliction that over-whelm'd me so in Asia that I despaired even of life:
1.9: nay, I abandon'd my self to death, that I might not rely upon my self for deliverance, but on God who raiseth the dead.
1.10: and he did deliver me from so terrible a death, and on him I have relied for further deliverance: especially,
1.11: being assisted by your prayers for me, so that thanks may be returned by many, for the gracious deliverance procur'd me by their prayers.
1.12: for this is to me matter of glorying, the testimony of my conscience, that without artifice, and with religious sincerity, not by worldly wisdom, but by God's favourable assistance I have behaved my self towards all men, but more particularly to you.
1.13: In reality, we writ nothing to you, but what you may perceive by the reading, and I trust you ever will perceive.
1.14: as some of you have already own'd, that I am matter of joy to you, as you will be to me in the day of the Lord Jesus Christ:
1.15: in this confidence I purposed to visit you before now, (that you might have again the like satisfaction)
1.16: not to call upon you as I pass into Macedonia, but in my return from thence, to be conducted by you toward Judea.
1.17: was this design therefore the effect of levity? or do I design first one thing, and then another, as it best suits my worldly interest?
1.18: God is my witness, I never prevaricated with you.
1.19: for what I, and Timothy, and Silvanus preached concerning Jesus Christ, the son of God, is not inconsistent, but invariably the same.
1.21: now it is God who keeps you fix'd in the doctrine of Christ; who has appointed me,
1.22: and mark'd me with his seal, and given me the earnest of the spirit in my heart.
1.23: I call God to witness, and may I die if it is not true, that the reason of my not coming yet to Corinth, was to avoid using any severity towards you.
1.24: not that I would arbitrarily prescribe what you should believe, but rather encourage you to go on: for 'tis by faith you have stood.

2.1: But I purposed in my self, I would not be the occasion of any uneasiness to you when I come again.
2.2: why should I make you uneasy, for who then could give me comfort, but those to whom I give uneasiness?
2.3: and I wrote to you upon that disagreeable subject, that when I came, I might not receive uneasiness from those from whom I ought to receive comfort, being persuaded that you will all think yourselves interested to promote my satisfaction.
2.4: for out of much affliction and anguish of heart, I wrote to you with many tears; not to make you uneasy, but to make you sensible of the overflowing tenderness which I have for you.
2.5: The affliction I have had, comes only from a particular quarter, so that my resentment does not affect the whole church.
2.6: the punishment, which was inflicted by the community, is sufficient on this occasion.
2.7: so that now you ought rather to forgive, and comfort him, for fear he should be overwhelm'd by an excess of sorrow.
2.8: wherefore, pray, convince him of your affection to him:
2.9: for this was one view I had in writing, to have this trial of you, whether you are intirely obedient.
2.10: to whom you forgive any thing, I also forgive: for if I have forgiven any thing, I forgave it, for your sakes (as Christ is
2.11: witness) lest satan should have got some advantage of us: for we are apprized of his artifices.
2.12: When an opportunity was given me by the Lord to preach the gospel of Christ, upon my arrival at Troas,
2.13: I was so uneasy in my mind for not finding Titus my brother, that taking my leave of them, I went from thence into Macedonia.
2.14: but thanks be to God, who maketh me triumph, thro' Christ, and spreads his healing doctrine by me, in eevery place:
2.15: for God is pleased to accept my christian labours, in favour both of those who are in a saving, and of those who are in a ruinous state:
2.16: by the one my preaching is taken as a deadly poison, to the other it is a reviving potion, and who is so sufficient for such a commission?
2.17: for we are not like others, who adulterate the word of God; but we preach the pure gospel of Christ, as I receiv'd it from God, and as in the presence of God.

3.1: Do I begin again to commend my self? or need I, as some others, commendatory letters to you, or from you?
3.2: you are my epistle, your conversion being writ in, my heart, known and read by all men:
3.3: which shows you to be the epistle of Christ, written by my ministration, not with ink, but with the spirit of the living God; not on tables of stone, but on living tables of the heart.
3.4: It is by Christ that I have this confidence in God.
3.5: not that I am sufficient of myself to effect any thing by the strength of my own reason: but my sufficiency is from God.
3.6: who also hath enabled me to be a minister of the new covenant, not of the literal sense, but of the spiritual meaning: it is the letter that denounces death, but the spirit gives life.
3.7: now if the law engraven on stone, the letter of whose sanction is death, was delivered with such glory, that the children of Israel could not steadily behold the face of Moses, for the glory of his countenance, tho' it was transient;
3.8: shall not the ministration of the spirit be more glorious?
3.9: for if the ministration of condemnation was illustrious, the ministration of righteousness will be much more glorious.
3.10: since that which distinguished the first had no glory, when compared to that of the other, which far excell'd it.
3.11: if that which was only temporary was glorious, much more shall that which is permanent be glorious.
3.12: Having then such an opinion of my ministry, I use great plainness of speech.
3.13: and do not act as Moses did, who threw a veil over his face so as to hinder the children of Israel from perceiving the end of that which was to cease:
3.14: besides, their minds were greatly prejudiced: for that very veil would still have obstructed the understanding of the old testament, unless it had been taken away by Christ.
3.15: nevertheless, when Moses is read, the veil upon their mind continues unto this day:
3.16: but when their mind shall turn to the Lord, that veil too shall be taken away.
3.17: for the spiritual meaning of the law centers in him, and the spirit of the law is gospel-liberty:
3.18: but as we lay aside the veil, the divine light gradually informs the mind, according as we attend to that spiritual sense, which points out the Lord.

4.1: Therefore, having by the divine favour such a ministry, I exert myself:
4.2: renouncing all secret dishonesty, and void of all artifice, I deliver the word of God unadulterated, and recommend my self by urging the truth home to every man's conscience, as in the presence of God.
4.3: but if our gospel be obscure, it is so only to those who are lost:
4.4: to those unbelievers, whose minds the God of this world has so blinded, that the glorious lustre of the gospel of Christ, who is the image of God, does not enlighten them.
4.5: for we preach not our selves, but Christ Jesus the Lord, professing our selves your servants for his sake.
4.6: for God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, to enlighten others in the knowledge of the glory of God, which shines in the person of Jesus Christ.
4.7: but this treasure is lodg'd in such earthen vessels as we are, that the exceeding efficacy of it may appear to be from God, and not from us.
4.8: I am press'd on every side, yet not crush'd; perplexed, but not in despair;
4.9: persecuted, but not forsaken; dejected, but not destroyed;
4.10: always bearing about in my body the marks of sufferings like those of Jesus, so that Jesus might be plainly prov'd to be alive by the sufferings of my body.
4.11: for as long as I live I shall be exposed to death for the sake of Jesus, that the life also of Jesus might be made manifest by the preservation of our mortal life.
4.12: so that I suffer the influences of his death, while you only feel the effects of his life.
4.13: Having by the same spirit the same faith as David had when he said, "I believed, and therefore have I spoken:" I also believe, and therefore I speak;
4.14: knowing that he who raised up the Lord Jesus, shall raise up me also by Jesus, and shall present me with you:
4.15: for all things are for your sakes, that the grace which was conferr'd upon many, might by the gratitude of so many, redound to the glory of God.
4.16: for which cause I am not discouraged, but tho' my body decays, yet my mind is daily renewed.
4.17: for the light affliction, which I at present suffer, will be infinitely over-ballanced by an eternal weight of glory;
4.18: for I have no regard to the things which are visible, but to such as are invisible: since visible things are temporary, but the invisible are eternal.

5.1: For I know, that if my body, which is but a tent for my sojourning upon earth, were dissolved, I have what is not fram'd by human art, but by the divine architect, a mansion eternal in the heavens.
5.2: while I am thus incas'd, I groan with desire to have that celestial vehicle superinduc'd:
5.3: tho' should I be divested of this body, I shall not even then be destitute of one.
5.4: we that are in this tabernacle do groan under the burden of it: not that we desire to be divested of it, but we desire to have our celestial body, that this mortal state may vanish into immortality.
5.5: now he that hath prepared us for this very state, is God, who hath given us the spirit as a pledge of it.
5.6: therefore being always certainly assur'd that whilst I sojourn in this body, I am absent from the Lord,
5.7: (for I regulate my conduct by my future expectations, not by visible enjoyments:
5.8: ) in this assurance, I say, I think it best to be quit of this body, and be present with the Lord.
5.9: wherefore I studiously endeavour, whether staying in it, or departing out of it, to be acceptable to him.
5.10: for we must all appear before the tribunal of Christ; that every one may receive the retribution, according as his actions in the body were either good or evil.
5.11: Shall I then, who know this terrible judgment of the Lord, endeavour to appease men? as for God, I am approved by him, and I trust also you are convinced of my being so approved.
5.12: and this I say, not to commend myself again unto you, but to give you an occasion of glorying on my account, that you may confront those who make a false show of glorying.
5.13: for if I glory even to transport, my glorying is in God: if I am moderate, my glorying is for your service.
5.14: to this I am urg'd by the love I bear to Christ, persuaded as I am, that if one died for all, then were all in a dying state: and that he died for all,
5.15: that they who are in a state of life should not live at their own discretion, but to the service of him who died for them, and rose again.
5.16: Wherefore, henceforth I have no regard to any man for his external appearance: for tho' I formerly look'd for worldly grandeur in the Messiah, yet now I see things in another light.
5.17: therefore, if any man be a christian, he is in a new creation: the old state of things is chang'd to one entirely new.
5.18: Now this is all owing to God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ, and hath made us the ministers of this reconciliation;
5.19: for it is God that has reconciled the world to himself, by Jesus Christ, by not imputing their sins to them; and hath committed to us the gospel of reconciliation.
5.20: we then are ambassadors for Christ, and 'tis God who makes you the offers by us: we pray you in the name of Christ, to make your peace with God.
5.21: for he hath made him who knew no sin to be a sin-offering for us, that we might be justified by God thro' him.

6.1: Invested then with such a commission, I beseech you let not the offers of divine favour be made to you in vain.
6.2: for he saith, " I have heard thee in a favourable time, and in the day of salvation have I succoured thee." now this is the favourable time; this is that day of salvation.
6.3: as for us, we give no occasion of offence, that our ministry may not be blamed:
6.4: but in all things I approve myself as the minister of God, by great constancy in afflictions, in torments, in distresses, from stripes,
6.5: from imprisonments, from tumults, from labours, from watchings, from penury.
6.6: I approve myself, by chastity, by knowledge, by meekness, by kindness, by sanctity of mind, by undisguised benevolence,
6.7: by the preaching of truth, by the power of God, by the arms of justice, both offensive and defensive.
6.8: in honour and disgrace, under infamy, and in repute: look'd upon as an impostor, while I say what is true;
6.9: as unknown, and yet celebrated; as dying, and yet I am alive; as chastised, but not slain;
6.10: as sorrowful, though always cheerful; as poor, tho' inriching many; as having nothing, though contented with every thing.
6.11: O Corinthians, my heart is so full, my tongue cannot be silent:
6.12: our affections are as enlarged towards you, as yours are contracted towards us.
6.13: I address myself to you as a parent, be not you wanting in the returns of filial respect to me.
6.14: Are you not become associates with infidels? but what affinity is there between virtue and vice? and what communication has light with darkness?
6.15: what concord can Christ maintain with Belial? what concern has a believer with an infidel?
6.16: and what agreement hath the temple of God with idols? for ye are the temple of the living God; as God has said, "I will dwell with, and walk among them; I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
6.18: I will be a father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty."

7.1: since then, we have these promises, my dear brethren, let us cleanse our selves from all impurity, whether of body or mind, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
7.2: Receive me as one who has wronged no man, who has corrupted no man, who has defrauded no man.
7.3: I speak not this to your reproach: for I have already assured you, that I am so heartily well affected to you, I could live and die with you.
7.4: I use indeed great freedom of speech toward you, yet I greatly glory upon your account: I am filled with comfort, and my joy is still superiour to all my affliction.
7.5: for when I came to Macedonia, I had no respit from the trouble that beset me on every side: oppositions from without, and apprehensions within.
7.6: nevertheless, God who comforteth those that are cast down, gave me comfort by the arrival of Titus: not barely by his presence,
7.7: but by the consolation I received from you by him, when he acquainted me with your earnest desire to see me, with your concern, and your zeal for me; which greatly increas'd my joy.
7.8: For tho' I was sorry my letter gave you some uneasiness, I do not repent of it, perceiving, that the uneasiness you had from that letter, did not dwell upon your minds.
7.9: now I rejoice, not at your uneasiness, but at your repentance which succeeded: for your sorrow was a religious sorrow, such as convinc'd you I had done you no wrong.
7.10: for religious sorrow produces that salutary repentance, which we never regret: but worldly sorrow preys upon life.
7.11: 'tis observable, even this religious sorrow which you had, what solicitude has it not wrought in you, what apologies, what indignation, what fear, what desire, what zeal, yea, what revenge! so that by your whole conduct, ye have shown your selves to be clear from guilt in this matter.
7.12: wherefore, my writing to you so severely did not proceed from any prejudice to him, that had done the wrong, or from favour to him that suffered wrong, but to show my conscientious regard to your welfare.
7.13: so that your comfort was no small satisfaction to me: yea, and I was the more exceedingly pleased for that cheerful tranquillity of mind which Titus received from the behaviour of you all.
7.14: so that I am not ashamed of the commendations I have formerly given you to him; but as I have always preached the truth to you, so in my commendation to Titus, I have said nothing but truth of you.
7.15: and his affection to you is abundantly increased, whilst he remembers your obedience, and that fear and reverence with which you all received him.
7.16: my having therefore such an entire confidence in you, does agreeably affect me.

8.1: I must acquaint you, brethren, with the contribution which the churches of Macedonia have religiously made,
8.2: who tho' labouring under great trial of affliction, and extreme poverty, have notwithstanding with exceeding cheerfulness contributed very liberally: being forward of themselves to the utmost of their power,
8.3: (I bear them witness) yea, and beyond their power:
8.4: earnestly intreating me to take the gift, and the charge of conveying it to the converts at Jerusalem:
8.5: and in this they out-did my expectation; such was the divine pleasure, they first gave themselves to the Lord, and then made me an offer to go themselves to Corinth.
8.6: I therefore desired Titus, as he had begun, to finish this contribution among you.
8.7: that as you excel in every thing, in faith, in language, mystical knowledge, in all virtue, and in your affection to us; I hope you will excel too in this charitable disposition.
8.8: I don't mean to prescribe to you, but that the zeal of others may show you are as sincerely well-affected.
8.9: for you are sensible of the beneficence of our Lord Jesus Christ; powerful as he was, for your sake he became poor, that you through his poverty might be made rich.
8.10: in this I only advise you: it being for your credit, since you have not only begun to execute it, but you were the first that form'd the design a year ago.
8.11: Pray then, dispatch this affair; as you readily undertook it, as readily perform it, to the best of your abilities.
8.12: for what a man gives with a ready mind, according to his abilities, is well received; but not when he goes beyond his circumstances.
8.13: my meaning is not, that you should be distress'd to relieve others, I only recommend an equality;
8.14: that as your present sufficiency supplies their wants, their sufficiency may supply your occasions another way: and thus there will be an equality.
8.15: as it is written, " he that had much, had nothing over, and he that had little, had no lack."
8.16: But thanks be to God, who disposed Titus to be so industrious for you.
8.17: for he not only complyed with my exhortation, but being more than ordinarily concern'd, he voluntarily went to you;
8.18: with whom I have sent one of the brethren, who is not only distinguish'd among all the churches, by his preaching the gospel,
8.19: but was chosen by the churches to accompany me with this collection; which service I undertook for the sake of Christ, and to encourage your generous design.
8.20: this I did, to prevent any suspicion that might be rais'd from my having the management of so great a sum:
8.21: always considering what is virtuous, with respect to God, and with respect to men.
8.22: I have sent likewise another of our brethren, whose diligence I have experienc'd in several affairs.
8.23: now as to Titus, he is my collegue, and assists me in your affairs: as to our brethren, they are the deputies of the churches, and the glory of the christian profession.
8.24: wherefore show how much you love them, and how well you deserve the character I gave you, before all the churches.

9.1: As to the relief of the converts, it is superfluous for me to write to you.
9.2: for I know your generous propensity, and I mention'd it with applause to the Macedonians, that Achaia was ready a year ago; so that your zeal has influenc'd many others.
9.3: yet have I sent the brethren, that my character of you may not appear to be groundless, with respect to that part wherein I said, ye would be ready:
9.4: for if the Macedonians should come with me, and find you unprepared, how shall I, not to say you, be ashamed for having had so little ground to boast of you?
9.5: I thought it therefore necessary to counsel the brethren to go before, and settle the management of the contribution by this previous notice, that it might have such dispatch, as shows a bountiful, and not a niggardly temper.
9.6: remember, " he who sows sparingly, shall reap also sparingly: and he who sows bountifully, shall reap also bountifully."
9.7: let every man give as he is disposed in his own mind, without any regret or reluctance: for God loves a cheerful benefactor.
9.8: and God is able to make every charitable gift redound to your advantage; that being always sufficiently supply'd in every thing, you may excel in every good work:
9.9: as it is written, " he hath distributed, he hath given to the poor: his liberality remaineth for ever."
9.10: now he that furnishes seed to the sower, and bread for food, shall furnish and multiply what you sow, and increase the fruits of your liberality.
9.11: so that being enriched in every thing, you may be continually beneficent to the glory of God by our thanksgiving.
9.12: for the execution of this charitable office, does not only supply the necessities of the converts, but by the thanksgivings of many redounds also to the glory of God.
9.13: having this proof of you by such a supply, they will glorify God for your profess'd subjection to the gospel of Christ, and for your liberal distribution to them as well as others;
9.14: and you will have the advantage of their earnest prayers, for the exceeding favour God has bestowed upon them by you:
9.15: thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift.

10.1: I who am a person of a mean presence, when among you, but exert myself upon your account, when absent; I Paul intreat you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ, not to let me exert that authority,
10.2: when I am present, which I think to exercise against some, who censure me, as if I was actuated by worldly views.
10.3: for tho' I am involv'd with the world, I don't sustain the war with their poor arts:
10.4: our military arms are not so defective, but divinely effectual to demolish all their ramparts;
10.5: to level all the barriers they contrive for obstructing the divine doctrine, and to make their pride captive to the authority of Christ.
10.6: and I am prepar'd, when you have discharg'd your duty, to make examples of the rest for their disobedience.
10.7: Do ye judge of things by the outward appearance? if any man is confident in himself, that he is Christ's, let him from himself conclude too, that as he is Christ's, even so are we.
10.8: for though I should more than ever magnify my authority, which the Lord hath given us for your improvement, and not for your ruin, I should have no reason to be ashamed;
10.9: but that I may not seem as if I would strike a terror in you by letters:
10.10: (for 'tis objected that my letters are weighty and powerful, but my bodily presence weak, and my preaching
10.11: contemptible) let such a one depend upon this, that the same authority which appear'd in my letters, when I was absent, will appear in fact, when I am present.
10.12: for I dare not rank or compare my self with some who vaunt themselves: but they making their self-conceit the only standard whereby to judge of themselves, show their want of judgment.
10.13: I will not boast of any thing done without my province, but confine myself within that line by which God has mark'd out my bounds, and in which you are included.
10.14: for I do not stretch beyond my limits to take you in; since in preaching the gospel of Christ, we are advanced even to you.
10.15: I don't assume to myself the credit of other men's labours in another province, but hope, that when your faith is increased, the bounds now prescribed will be enlarged by you yet farther;
10.16: so that I may preach the gospel in the regions beyond you, and not assume the credit of things ready prepared to my hand, in another man's province.
10.17: but he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord.
10.18: for not he that commendeth himself, but he whom the Lord commendeth, is the approved.

11.1: Would you could bear with me a little in my vanity, but indeed you do bear with me.
11.2: for I am jealous over you with religious jealousy: since I have espoused you to one husband, that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ.
11.3: but I fear lest by some means or other, as Eve was beguiled by the subtilly of the serpent, your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is due to Christ.
11.4: if he that is come to you, preaches another Jesus whom I have not preached, or if ye receive other gifts of the spirit, than what ye have received from me, or another gospel, than what you have accepted, you might well bear with his pretensions:
11.5: for I think I am not at all inferior to the chiefest of the apostles.
11.6: if my language is inelegant, my knowledge is not contemptible; but has been fully display'd among you on all occasions.
11.7: If I have degraded myself for your advantage by preaching the holy gospel to you gratis, is that such a trespass?
11.8: by taking wages of other churches, I may have injured them, to do you service.
11.9: when I was present among you, and in want, I was chargeable to no man: for the brethren which came from Macedonia, supplied my necessities: and as I have, so I always shall keep myself from being burdensome to you.
11.10: I solemnly protest, no man shall hinder me of this applause, in the regions of Achaia.
11.11: why so? is it because I love you not? far otherwise, God knows.
11.12: but this I do, and shall do, to make them drop their hire, who are so bent upon hire: and then indeed they will be as they pretend to be, like me.
11.13: for these are false apostles, deceitful workmen, disguised so as to pass for true apostles.
11.14: and no wonder; for satan himself may put on the appearance of an angel of light.
11.15: therefore it is not strange if his agents are so disguised as to appear like ministers of the gospel; but their end shall be answerable to their actions.
11.16: I say it again, let no man think me vain; but if they do, yet as such, bear with me, that I too may applaud my self a little.
11.17: what I say, I say it not as an apostle, but as it were to indulge my vanity in this matter of boasting.
11.18: since many glory in outward advantages, I will glory too.
11.19: for as wise as you are your selves, you easily bear with the folly of others.
11.20: if a man impose upon you, if he preys upon you, if he makes a gain of you, if a man insults you, if he disgracefully assaults you, I mean it as to their reproaches, you take it all;
11.21: as if I was inferior to them, but whatever they pretend to, (I must be so vain) I pretend to the like.
11.22: Are they Hebrews? so am I: are they Israelites? so am I: are they of the race of Abraham?
11.23: so am I: are they ministers of Christ? is it my vanity? I am more so: in toilsome labours I surpass them, in stripes I am exceedingly beyond them, in prisons I have been oftner, and frequently in the very jaws of death.
11.24: from the Jews I have five times received forty stripes save one.
11.25: thrice was I whip'd with rods, once was I stoned, thrice I was shipwreck'd; a night and a day I was floating on the deep:
11.26: in my voyages I have been frequently in perils from rivers, in perils from robbers, in perils from my own countrymen, in perils from the Gentiles, in perils in the city, in perils in the country, in perils at sea, in perils among false brethren;
11.27: expos'd to toil, to fatigue, to frequent watchings, to hunger and thirst, to frequent fastings, to cold and penury.
11.28: besides these troubles from without, that which crouds upon me daily, the care of all the churches.
11.29: who is afflicted, and I not suffer? who is offended, and I not inflam'd?
11.30: If I must be compell'd to glory, I will glory on the account of my sufferings.
11.31: the ever-blessed God, and father of our Lord Jesus Christ, knows that I speak truth.
11.32: in Damascus the governor for king Aretas, posted guards at the city-gates, with a design to apprehend me:
11.33: but thro' a window I was let down in a basket by the wall, and so escap'd.

12.1: Have not I reason to glory? for now I shall mention my visions and revelations from the Lord.
12.2: I knew a christian who above fourteen years ago, was snatch'd up even to the third heaven, whether in the body, I cannot tell; or whether out of the body, I cannot tell: God knows.
12.3: but tho' I don't know whether it was in the body, or out of the body, which God only knows,
12.4: this I know, that he was snatch'd up into paradise, and heard such secrets as it is not lawful for a man to reveal.
12.5: I might glory in being the man; but I will not glory in any thing relating to myself, unless it be my sufferings.
12.6: tho' if I had a mind to glory, I might do it without vanity, for I should say nothing but what is true: but now I forbear, lest any man should ascribe more to me than my actions, or my preaching can justify.
12.7: and lest I should be exalted above measure by the extraordinary revelations I have had, I was afflicted in my person, so that the messenger of satan insulted me; concerning which,
12.8: I besought the Lord thrice, to make him leave me.
12.9: but he said to me, "my favour is sufficient for thee: for my strength is shown to be perfect by thy weakness." with pleasure therefore will I glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may be seen to dwell in me.
12.10: I take pleasure then in infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses for Christ's sake: for when I am afflicted, then it is I have fortitude.
12.11: Am I become vain? 'tis you have forc'd me to it: for I ought to have been commended by you: since I am not inferior to the chiefest of the apostles, tho' in myself I am nothing.
12.12: the marks indeed of an apostle I have shown among you by my extreme patience, by signs, and prodigies, and miracles.
12.13: for in what were ye inferior to other churches, except it be that I myself was not burdensome to you? an injury I hope you will easily forgive.
12.14: This is the third time I purposed to come to you; but I will not be burdensome to you; for I seek not yours, but you: since it is not expected children should lay up for their parents, but parents for their children: on the contrary,
12.15: I shall be glad to sacrifice myself and all I have for your service, even tho' it should happen that the more I love you, the less I should be beloved.
12.16: 'tis own'd I did not put you to any charges myself: but was so crafty, as to over-reach you, by others.
12.17: what, did I make a gain of you by any body I sent to you?
12.18: I desired Titus, and with him I sent a brother: did Titus make a gain of you? didn't we follow the same principles, and take the same measures?
12.19: do you think I have been making excuses for not coming? as I am a christian, in the presence of God, I have, my beloved, in every thing consulted your advantage.
12.20: yet I fear when I do come I shall not find you such as I would, and that you will find me such as you least desire: I am afraid there are among you debates, envyings, animosities, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, arrogance, tumults:
12.21: and I am afraid, God will humble me when I come again among you, and I shall bewail many who have formerly sinned, and have not yet repented of their impurity, their fornication, and dissoluteness.

13.1: This is the third time I am coming to you: "in the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established."
13.2: I told you once before, and now being absent I write to forewarn you and all that have sinned, that when I shall arrive, I will not spare them;
13.3: since you demand a proof of my mission from Christ, who with regard to you has shown no want of power among you.
13.4: for tho' he was crucified with the appearance of weakness, yet he lives by the power of God; tho' we are afflicted upon his account, we shall live with him by the power of God toward you.
13.5: Examine yourselves, whether you be in the faith; bring yourselves to the proof; are you so little acquainted with yourselves, as not to know whether Jesus Christ be in you? but if you are destitute of proofs,
13.6: I trust you shall know that we are not so destitute,
13.7: now I pray God that I may not punish you; not that I may show you my proofs to your cost, but that by your acting honestly, I may be as if I had no proofs:
13.8: for I can employ no power against the truth, but for the truth.
13.9: I am therefore glad when I am disarm'd by the strength of your integrity: and this is what I pray for, even your perfection.
13.10: these things therefore I write to you being absent, that when I come I may not use severity, according to the power which the Lord hath given me for edification, and not for destruction.
13.11: Finally, brethren, be cheerful: redress yourselves, encourage one another, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace shall be with you.
13.12: salute one another with religious affection.
13.14: the favour of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communication of the Holy Spirit, be with you all, amen.

1.1: Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy to the church of the Thessalonians, who believe in God the father, and in our Lord Jesus Christ, grace and peace be with you from God our father, and from Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.2: We always mention you in our prayers, and give thanks to God for you all:
1.3: never forgetting the effects of your faith, your charitable offices, and the constancy of your hope in our Lord Jesus Christ; of which God is our witness.
1.4: for we are persuaded, my brethren, that you are the peculiar objects of divine favour;
1.5: since the gospel we preach'd, did not consist only of words, but was fully confirm'd by miracles and gifts of the holy spirit, you yourselves being witnesses, what we did among you and for you.
1.6: and you imitated us, and were imitators of the Lord, having receiv'd the word, notwithstanding all your afflictions, with that alacrity, which the holy spirit inspires.
1.7: so that you became examples to all the believers in Macedonia and in Achaia.
1.8: for the gospel has made so favourable a progress not only in Macedonia and Achaia, but in every other place, where the reputation of your divine faith has spread, that 'tis needless to mention any thing of it; since they all relate of us,
1.9: how successful our arrival was among you, and how you renounc'd your idols to serve the living and true God,
1.10: and to expect his son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, even Jesus, who delivers us from impending ruin.

2.1: And you are satisfied, my brethren, that our address to you was not fallacious:
2.2: on the contrary, notwithstanding the outrages, you know we suffer'd at Philippi, we had still the resolution, by the divine assistance, to preach the gospel of God to you without reserve against all opposition.
2.3: for our doctrine was free from all imposture, avarice, and fraud.
2.4: we preach the gospel just as God thought fit to intrust it with us, not being studious to please men, but God, who approves our sincerity.
2.5: our address to you was without any flattery, as you yourselves can witness, and God is witness that we had no avarice to disguise.
2.6: we never courted you nor any others, from an affectation of human applause, instead of making our apostolical character any ways expensive to you, as we might;
2.7: we behav'd to you with a tender regard, even as a mother, who nurses her own children.
2.8: Our affection therefore to you being so great, we were as ready to give our lives for you, as we were to communicate the divine gospel to you, so much did you engage our love.
2.9: for you remember, my brethren, our labour and toil: how we worked day and night, that in preaching the gospel of God, we might not be chargeable to any of you.
2.10: you are witnesses, and God is so too, how holy, how just and irreproachable our behaviour was to you, who believe.
2.11: you likewise know, that we exhorted and encouraged every one of you, as a father doth his children,
2.12: conjuring you to live suitably to the favour of God, who has called you to his kingdom and glory.
2.13: nor do we fail of giving thanks to God continually, that, when you received the word of God, which we preach, you did not receive it as the doctrine of men, but as a doctrine that appears to be truly divine, by the influences it displays in you, who believe.
2.14: for, my brethren, you have followed the example of the christian churches in Judea; by having suffer'd the same persecutions from your own nation, as the churches have suffer'd from the Jews,
2.15: the very men who have persecuted the Lord Jesus, and the prophets even to death; who have persecuted us; they who are regardless of pleasing the deity, and are enemies to all mankind;
2.16: who by obstructing our endeavours to save the Gentiles, continue to fill up the measure of their enormities; for which consummate vengeance is falling upon them.
2.17: As for me, my brethren, having been so abruptly separated from you, in person, tho' not in affection, I have the more ardently endeavour'd to see you again.
2.18: this I Paul have frequently attempted, but Satan has been my obstacle.
2.19: for what can be our hope, or joy, what can crown our pretensions, unless it be you, when we shall appear before the Lord Jesus Christ at his coming?
2.20: for ye are our glory and our joy.

3.1: Being therefore impatient to hear of you, we judg'd it proper to stay at Athens alone, and send you our brother Timothy,
3.2: a minister of God, and our collegue in preaching the gospel of Christ, that by establishing you in the faith, and by his exhortations,
3.3: none of you might be stagger'd by these persecutions: for you know that we are destin'd to suffer.
3.4: and even when we were with you, we foretold you, that we should be persecuted, as you know it happen'd.
3.5: not being able therefore to wait any longer, I sent Timothy to know the state of your faith, for fear the tempter should have seduc'd you, and all our labour have prov'd abortive.
3.6: but Timothy, upon his arrival here from you, brings us the agreeable news of the perseverance of your faith and charity, that you always make honourable mention of us, and that you desire to see us as ardently as we do to see you.
3.7: Thus, my brethren, your conduct has given us great consolation, under all our persecutions and distress.
3.8: for now I am reviv'd, since you continue stedfast in the christian profession.
3.9: how can I be sufficiently thankful to God upon your account, for all the joy, which by your means we have been affected with,
3.10: whilst night and day we make our ardent requests to him, that we may once more be present with you, that nothing may be wanting to the perfection of your faith?
3.11: now may God our father, and our Lord Jesus Christ remove all the obstructions of our journey to you.
3.12: may the Lord make you increase and abound in mutual love, in love towards all men, as we do towards you:
3.13: that by the sanctity of your affections, you may stand unreprov'd in the presence of God our father, when our Lord Jesus Christ shall come with all his holy angels.

4.1: Finally, my brethren, we intreat and conjure you by the Lord Jesus Christ, to observe the instructions we gave you about your religious conduct, and to make continual progress therein.
4.2: for you know the precepts we gave you in the name of the Lord Jesus.
4.3: and such is the will of God, that you should be holy, and avoid licentiousness;
4.4: that every one of you should take care to preserve the dignity of his
4.5: person unsullied by the vices of the Gentiles, who know not God:
4.6: that no man should be exorbitant, and behave contumeliously to his brother: because the Lord is the avenger of all such crimes, as we have formerly remonstrated to you.
4.7: for God has not called us to impurity, but to holiness:
4.8: he therefore that violates these precepts, does not despise man, but God, who has endued me with his holy spirit.
4.9: As to brotherly love, I have no occasion to write about it, God himself having instructed you to love one another.
4.10: this indeed you practise towards all our brethren in Macedonia; and we only exhort you to advance more and more therein:
4.11: to study your own quiet, to mind your own affairs, and follow some handicraft trade, as we recommended it to you:
4.12: so that your way of life may stand fair to the world, and prevent your being dependent upon any man.
4.13: Now I would not have you, my brethren, be mistaken about the state of the dead, lest you should be as greatly afflicted as those, who have no hope.
4.14: for if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, we must believe that God by Jesus will raise the dead, and assemble them with him.
4.15: for one thing I have in charge to tell you from the Lord, that we, who shall be found still alive at the coming of the Lord, shall not get the advance of those that are dead:
4.16: for the Lord himself will descend from heaven, and by the voice of the archangel, with the trumpet of God, resound the summons: they who died christians shall rise first:
4.17: then we, who shall be still alive, shall be convey'd together with them in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air, and so we shall ever be with the Lord.
4.18: therefore comfort one another with this information.

5.1: It is not necessary, my brethren, to specify the exact time:
5.2: for you very well know, that the day of the Lord steals on like a thief in the night.
5.3: whilst they flatter themselves with peace and safety, destruction shall fall upon them, like the pangs of a woman in travail, and they shall not escape.
5.4: but you, my brethren, are too well inform'd to be surpriz'd by that day, as by a thief.
5.5: you inherit the advantages of meridian light: we are not involv'd in the obscurity of night.
5.6: therefore let us not sleep away our time like others, but be vigilant and temperate.
5.7: they that are sober take their rest in the night, whilst they that are sots, are drunk in the night:
5.8: but let us, who enjoy the light, be temperate; let us be arm'd with the breast-plate of faith and charity, and for an helmet, with the hope of salvation.
5.9: for God did not design to make us the objects of his displeasure, but to effect our felicity by the Lord Jesus Christ, who died for us,
5.10: that whether we happen to be alive or dead, we may be secure of living with him.
5.11: wherefore comfort and edify one another, as you have hitherto done.
5.12: We entreat you, brethren, to respect those, who labour in the ministry, who by divine appointment preside over you, and instruct you.
5.13: maintain an intire affection for them, upon account of their office, and don't form any brigues against them.
5.14: and we exhort you, brethren, reprove the disorderly, comfort the pusillanimous, support the weak, and be patient toward all men.
5.15: Don't allow any one to return evil for evil, but strive to do all the good you can to one another, and to all the world.
5.18: be thankful to God for every thing, for so christians are oblig'd to be.
5.19: don't abuse the gifts of the spirit.
5.21: bring every thing to the test: if it be proof, abide by that:
5.22: if it has the least appearance of evil, reject it.
5.23: Now may the God of peace make you intirely holy: may every part of you, your spirit, soul, and body be preserved irreprovable at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
5.24: he that has called you, is faithful, and this he will effect.
5.26: salute all the brethren with an holy kiss.
5.27: I conjure you by the Lord, that this epistle may be read to all our christian brethren.
5.28: the favour of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. AMEN.

1.1: Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy, to the church of the Thessalonians, that believe in God our father, and in the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.2: favour and peace be with you from God our father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: We are oblig'd, my brethren, to render thanks to God continually upon your account, as it is but just; since your faith still improves, and your mutual love is always increasing.
1.4: so that you are the subject of our glorying in the churches of God, for the constancy of your faith, under all the persecutions and afflictions you endure from men,
1.5: by which you may be assur'd, that they will be punish'd by the divine justice, and that you shall be rewarded with the kingdom of God, for which you suffer;
1.6: since it is agreeable to his justice to afflict those in their turn, who afflict you:
1.7: and that you, who are distress'd, should obtain your repose, together with us, when the Lord Jesus, with his angels, the ministers of his power, shall descend from heaven,
1.8: in flaming fire, to take vengeance on those, who know not God, and do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ:
1.9: the Lord shall punish them with everlasting destruction, when he shall appear in the glory of his power,
1.10: and come to be glorified by his saints, and to be the object of admiration to all who believed, that the testimony we gave you, would be justified in that day.
1.11: Wherefore we continually pray, that our God would by his power effect all the gracious designs of his goodness, and accomplish the work of faith in you;
1.12: that the name of our Lord Jesus Christ may be glorified by you, and you by him, by the favour of our God, and of our Lord Jesus Christ.

2.1: Now we conjure you, brethren, that with respect to the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and our being assembled with him,
2.2: you would not by any pretended revelation, by any discourse or epistle ascrib'd to us, be immediately perplex'd in your minds, or under any concern for the approach of the day of the Lord.
2.3: don't be led into any mistake, because the previous rebellion does not yet appear, nor the man of sin throw off the disguise, that offspring of perdition:
2.4: that adversary that exalts it self above the divine authority of majesty: that is seated in the temple of God, pretending to be it self divine.
2.5: don't you remember, I told you this, when I was with you?
2.6: and you know what hinders his throwing off the disguise at a time which he enjoys for the present.
2.7: for the secret spirit of misrule is ready to break out as soon as the obstacle is taken away:
2.8: and then the lawless will be discover'd, whom the Lord will extirpate by the spirit of his mouth, and at his glorious advent, will intirely abolish him,
2.9: who by the instigation of satan will make his parade with various arts, with fallacious signs and prodigies,
2.10: and with all the vile methods of imposture, to the ruin of those, who are averse to the truth, by which they might be saved.
2.11: wherefore God will suffer a spirit of delusion to work them into the belief of a lye:
2.12: to the condemnation of all those, who instead of embracing the gospel, had pleasure in iniquity.
2.13: As for you, my brethren, the favourites of the Lord, we are oblig'd to render perpetual thanks to God, for having chosen you from the beginning, in purifying you by his spirit, upon your believing the gospel.
2.14: to this he has called you, to a life of glory with our Lord Jesus Christ.
2.15: be stedfast therefore, and firmly maintain the doctrine I have delivered to you, either by word of mouth, or by my letter.
2.16: Now may our Lord Jesus Christ, and God our father, who has loved us, and by his favour given us the advantageous hopes of eternal joys, consolate your souls,
2.17: and establish you in all sound doctrine and virtue.

3.1: To conclude, pray for us, my brethren, that the doctrine of the Lord may make its progress, and be respected every where as it is among you:
3.2: and that we may be delivered from vexatious wicked men; for all have not the faith.
3.3: but as for you, the Lord, who is faithful, will establish you, and protect you from the malicious one.
3.4: and we have this hope in the Lord, that you will still continue to observe the directions we give you.
3.5: may the Lord qualify your hearts with divine affection, and a patient expectation of Jesus Christ.
3.6: We direct you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, to withdraw from all those of your brethren, whose conduct is irregular, and not agreeable to the instructions they received from us.
3.7: for you know what an example we have given for your imitation: that our conduct among you was regular:
3.8: that we did not eat any man's bread for nothing: but with toil and fatigue work'd night and day to avoid being chargeable to any of you:
3.9: not, that we had no just claim, but to present ourselves as a pattern, which you should imitate,
3.10: pursuant to the maxim, which we laid down, when among you, "he that refuses to work should be deny'd food."
3.11: now being inform'd, that there are among you people of an irregular conduct, who neglect their own business, and busy themselves with the affairs of others:
3.12: we command these persons, and exhort them by the Lord Jesus Christ, to stay at home, and earn their bread by labour.
3.13: As for you, my brethren, be not weary of your commendable industry:
3.14: and if any one should disregard what we have prescrib'd, signify it to us by letter, and don't converse with him, that he may be put to shame.
3.15: however, don't treat him as an enemy, but reprove him as a brother.
3.16: Now the Lord of peace grant you continual peace in all respects, the Lord be with you all.
3.17: I Paul salute you, this salutation being my own hand writing, which is the distinguishing mark of all my letters, so I write.
3.18: the favour of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. AMEN.

1.1: Paul an apostle of Jesus Christ by the appointment of God our saviour, and of Jesus Christ our hope,
1.2: to Timothy my sincere convert, favour, mercy and peace from God our father, and Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.3: At my departure from Macedonia, I advised you to stay at Ephesus in order to charge certain persons not to teach any different doctrine,
1.4: or trouble their heads with fables and endless genealogies, which rather promote disputes than the gospel-dispensation:
1.5: such a charge will produce that charity, which arises from purity, from a good conscience, and a sincere belief:
1.6: for want of which, some have lost themselves in frivolous disputes,
1.7: pretending to be doctors of the law, tho' they neither understand what they advance, nor upon what it is founded.
1.8: I own that the law is good, if a man make a right use of it:
1.9: it being plain, that the law was not design'd against the just, but against the lawless and refractory, against irreligion and vice, impiety and prophaneness, parricide and man-slaughter,
1.10: against licentiousness and unnatural passion, against men-stealers, lyars, perjured persons, and every thing that is inconsistent
1.11: with the salutary doctrine of the gospel of immortality, which the blessed God committed to my trust.
1.12: I offer thanks to Jesus Christ our Lord, who qualified me for the ministry he has plac'd me in, for having appointed me to such a trust,
1.13: who was before a blasphemer, and a violent persecutor; but I obtained mercy, because I acted thro' ignorance in incrudelity.
1.14: but the favour of our Lord display'd itself by that faith and charity, which was wrought in me by Jesus Christ.
1.15: it is a proposition worthy to be believ'd, and be embrac'd by all, that Jesus Christ is come into the world to save sinners, of whom I am the greatest.
1.16: however I obtained mercy, that Jesus Christ might demonstrate the greatness of his clemency, by making me an eminent instance of it to those who should hereafter believe in him, in order to eternal life.
1.17: to the king of the world, the immortal, invisible, and the only God be honour and glory to endless ages, amen.
1.18: This charge, my son Timothy, I recommend to you, agreeably to the prophetic gifts heretofore conferr'd on you, by virtue of which you might carry on a successful warfare,
1.19: assisted by faith and a good conscience: for some having discarded the one, have entirely lost the other.
1.20: Hymeneus and Alexander are of that number, whom I have deliver'd to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme.

2.1: I exhort you therefore, above all things, to present supplications, prayers, intercessions and thanksgiving for all men:
2.2: for kings, and for all that are in authority, that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in the practice of all piety and virtue;
2.3: for such offices are commendable, and agreeable to God our saviour,
2.4: who wills that all men be saved, by embracing the truth.
2.5: for there is but one God, and but one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus,
2.6: who gave himself for the redemption of all mankind: this is what was to be promulg'd in due time:
2.7: for this I was establish'd a herald and an apostle, I speak the truth without disguise, a doctor to instruct the Gentiles in the true faith.
2.8: I direct therefore that the men pray in publick and private, lifting up their hands to heaven with innocence, charity, and composure.
2.9: and that the women be decent in their apparel, adorned with modesty and reserve, not with broider'd hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly array;
2.10: but, as becomes women, who make a profession of religion, to be adorn'd with virtue.
2.11: Let the women with submissive silence attend to instruction.
2.12: for I don't allow a woman to be a teacher, nor to dictate to her husband; but let her be silent.
2.13: for Adam was the first that was form'd, then Eve.
2.14: Adam was not seduc'd, but the woman, who was the cause of his transgression.
2.15: however the women may be saved by educating their children, and persevering themselves in faith, in charity, in holiness and chastity, this may be depended upon as true.

3.1: He that aspires to be a bishop, desires an office that is honourable.
3.2: a bishop therefore ought to be of an unspotted character, to have but one wife, to be sober, prudent, grave, hospitable, and qualified for teaching:
3.3: not given to wine or violence, but of a gentle temper, averse to contention and avarice: a master of economy,
3.4: obliging his children to behave with decorum.
3.5: for if a man is incapable of governing his own family, how can he take care of the church of God?
3.6: nor must he be a new convert; for fear he should be elated with pride, and so involve himself in the same ruin as the devil.
3.7: besides, he ought to stand fair in the opinion of unbelievers, lest he fall into disgrace, and the ambushes of the accuser.
3.8: The deacons too must be grave, not double tongued, not addicted to drinking, or sordid gain,
3.9: but by their integrity maintain the reverence due to the gospel.
3.10: let them be first examin'd, and if they are without reproach, let them enter upon their office.
3.11: their wives must be likewise grave, free from scandal, sober, and always faithful.
3.12: a deacon must have but one wife, and govern his children, and the rest of the family in a proper manner.
3.13: for they who duly discharge that office, prepare their way to a higher degree, and may promote the christian faith with the greater freedom.
3.14: This I write, tho' I hope to make you a visit in a little time, that in case I am retarded,
3.15: you may know how to conduct yourself in the house of God, that is, in the church of the true God.
3.16: the mystery of piety is the pillar and basts of truth; and certainly most extraordinary. God has appear'd in the flesh, been justified by the spirit, seen by angels, proclaim'd to the Gentiles, believ'd by the world, and assum'd into glory.

4.1: Now the spirit says expresly, that in the latter times some shall abandon the faith, by giving credit to seducing spirits, and the doctrine concerning demons;
4.2: broach'd by hypocrititical impostors, whose consciences are cauteriz'd,
4.3: interdicting marriage; and the use of animal food; which God created for the repast of the faithful, who embrace the truth with thankfulness.
4.4: for all that God has created is good, and nothing is to be rejected, provided it be receiv'd with thanksgiving:
4.5: since it is sanctified by the divine permission, and by prayer.
