4.6: If you represent these things to the brethren, you will appear to be a true minister of Jesus Christ, brought up in the institutions of faith, and the true doctrine to which you were attach'd.
4.7: as for prophane and groundless fables, reject them.
4.8: exercise yourself in piety: for those exercises which relate only to the body are of little consequence, but piety is of absolute use, having the promises both of the present life, and of the life that is to come.
4.9: what I tell you is certain, and deserves entire credit.
4.10: for to that end we expose ourselves to trouble and reproach, because we hope in the living God, who is the saviour of all men, especially of believers.
4.11: These things recommend and teach.
4.12: don't give occasion to any to despise your youth: but be a pattern to believers in your discourse, in your behaviour, by your charity, faith and chastity.
4.13: while I am absent apply yourself to reading, to exhortation, and instruction.
4.14: don't neglect the gift you have, which was given you with the ministerial charge, when you receiv'd imposition of hands from the presbytery.
4.15: meditate upon these things, be wholly employ'd about them, that your proficiency may appear to all.
4.16: take care how you behave, and what you teach, persevere in these duties: for by the practice of them, you will save both yourself, and those who hear you.

5.1: Don't treat a senior with harsh reproof, but exhort him as a father, and the young men, as brethren:
5.2: the elder women as mothers; the younger, as sisters, with all purity.
5.3: show regard to widows that are really such.
5.4: if a widow has children or grand-children, let them above all things instruct their own family to be religious, and let them be grateful to their parents, for this is acceptable to God.
5.5: as for the widow, who is really such, and without any assistance, let her place all her hopes in God, and be assiduous in supplication and prayer.
5.6: the widow of pleasure is dead tho' she lives.
5.7: these things recommend to them, that they may be without reproach.
5.8: he that takes no care of his relations, especially those of his own family, has renounc'd the faith and is worse than an infidel.
5.9: Let none be put upon the list of widows, but such as are at least threescore years of age, and have been married but once:
5.10: such as have been recommended by their good actions, by the education of their children, by their hospitality, by their officiousness to the faithful, by relieving the afflicted, and by the practice of every virtue.
5.11: as for young widows, don't admit them: for being impatient of religious restraint, they will be marry'd:
5.12: for which they are much to be condemn'd, because they violate the engagements they had before enter'd into:
5.13: besides, having nothing to do, they get the habit of rambling from one house to another, and are not only idling, but prattle and intermeddle, and utter what is not decent.
5.14: I enjoin therefore the young women to marry, to detest abortion, to govern their families, and give our enemies no handle for reproach.
5.15: for some have already revolted to paganism.
5.16: If any convert has widow-relations, let such relieve them, that the church may not be charged, but with the relief of such as are entirely destitute.
5.17: Let the presbyters that govern well receive a double salary, especially those who are employ'd in preaching and instructing.
5.18: for the scripture says, "thou shalt not muzzle the ox, when he treads the corn." and, "the labourer is worthy of his reward."
5.19: don't receive any accusation against a pastor, but upon the deposition of two or three witnesses.
5.20: Those that transgress reprove in publick, to strike a terror in the rest.
5.21: I conjure you before God, before our Lord Jesus Christ, and his chosen angels, to observe these rules without prepossession and partiality.
5.22: Don't be hasty to ordain any man: and be not accessory to the faults of others: preserve your own integrity.
5.23: Discontinue the drinking of bare water, take a litle wine out of regard to your weak stomach, and your frequent indispositions.
5.24: The vices of some men are so notorious, they prevent any inquisition: others don't discover themselves till they have been ordain'd.
5.25: virtue wears no disguise, and vice cannot be long conceal'd.

6.1: Let those who are in a state of servitude, consider the entire respect due to their masters, that the name of God, and the doctrine of the gospel may not be blasphemed.
6.2: let them not treat their christian masters, on pretence of being their brethren, with less respect: but be the more obsequious, because they are believers, and deserve to be belov'd, for the kind provision they make for them, let this be the subject of your instructions, and exhortation.
6.3: If any one deviate from this doctrine, not adhering to the wholesome instructions of our Lord Jesus Christ, the true doctrine of piety,
6.4: he is full of pride and ignorance, touch'd with a spirit of chicanery and wrangling, productive of envy, contention, calumny,
6.5: mischievous opinions, and a familiarity with pernicious ignorant impostors, who consider religion only as it makes for their gain.
6.6: Religion indeed with contentment leads to great gain.
6.7: as we brought nothing into the world, certain it is, we can carry nothing away, having therefore food and raiment,
6.8: we ought to think that sufficient, but they who will be rich, expose
6.9: themselves to temptations and snares, and to many foolish noxious passions, which plunge men into ruin and perdition, for the love of money is the root of all evil:
6.10: which some having obtain'd, have revolted from the faith, and brought upon themselves variety of piercing pains.
6.11: As for you the minister of God, avoid those things: adhere to justice, piety, faith, charity, patience, and benignity of temper.
6.12: exert yourself in the glorious cause of faith, and secure the prize of eternal life, to which you were called, when you made that excellent profession of faith before so many witnesses.
6.13: I enjoin you, before God, who gives life to all, and before Christ Jesus, who made a glorious confession before Pontius Pilate;
6.14: to observe these precepts, to lead an unspotted life without reproof until the appearance of our Lord Jesus Christ,
6.15: whose advent HE will in his own time display, WHO is perfectly happy, who alone is omnipotent, the king of kings, and the lord of all that bear rule;
6.16: who alone is essentially immortal, dwelling in that inaccessible light, which no mortal ever saw, or can see: to whom belongs everlasting honour and empire, amen.
6.17: Charge those that are rich in this world, not to be elated, not to depend upon their perishable wealth, but upon the God of life, who furnishes us with every thing in plenty for our enjoyment;
6.18: to be beneficent, to be rich in good works, to be liberal to the common fund,
6.19: securing to themselves a well-grounded expectation of obtaining hereafter an immortal life.
6.20: O Timothy, keep what is deposited in your care, avoiding the prophane empty declamations and objections of a spurious science, which some have profess'd,
6.21: and thereby deviated from the true principles of faith, grace be with you. AMEN.

1.1: Paul an apostle of Jesus Christ, appointed by God to declare the promise, which Jesus Christ has made of eternal life;
1.2: to Timothy, my dear son, grace, mercy and peace from God the father, and from Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.3: When I remember you, as I continually do in my prayers night and day, I give thanks to God, whom I serve with a pure conscience, after the example of my fore-fathers.
1.4: when I call to mind your affliction, it makes me ardently desire the exceeding pleasure I shall have in seeing you:
1.5: especially when I reflect upon the sincerity of your faith, and the attachment your grand-mother Lois first show'd, and then your mother Eunice, examples which I am persuaded you will follow.
1.6: For which reason I remind you to exert the divine gifts you received, when I gave you the imposition of hands.
1.7: for the spirit, which God has given us, is not a spirit of timidity, but of fortitude, of benevolence, and of moderation.
1.8: be not therefore asham'd of the testimony of the Lord, nor of me who am a prisoner upon his account, but share with me in the afflictions, which attend the gospel, supported as you are by the power of God,
1.9: who has saved us, and by the gospel hath called us to holiness, not in consideration of our works, but in pursuance of his own resolution, and the favour, which having been promised us by Jesus Christ several ages ago,
1.10: has now been display'd by the coming of Jesus Christ our saviour, who has defeated the power of death, by bringing a life of immortality to light thro' the gospel.
1.11: For this I was establish'd the herald, the apostle, and doctor of the Gentiles, this has drawn upon me the evils I suffer.
1.12: yet I am not ashamed, for I know in whom I have confided, and I am persuaded he is able to keep what I have committed to him against that day.
1.13: Keep that form of sound doctrine you receiv'd from me, which consists in christian faith and charity:
1.14: that valuable depositum do you preserve by the holy spirit, which resides in us.
1.15: You know that I have been abandon'd by all the Asiatics, by Phygellus and Hermogenes among the rest.
1.16: the Lord be favourable to the family of Onesiphorus; for he often reliev'd me, and was not asham'd of my chains:
1.17: but when he was at Rome, he enquired for me very diligently, and found me.
1.18: the Lord grant he may obtain mercy from him in that day, for you know very well what services de did me at Ephesus.

2.1: As for you, my son, strenuously acquit yourself of the charge you have receiv'd from Christ Jesus.
2.2: and what you heard me deliver in the presence of many, intrust to such persons of integrity as are qualified to instruct others
2.3: bravely endure hardships, like a soldier of Jesus Christ.
2.4: he that enters into the service, disengages himself from civil affairs, that he may be acceptable to his officer.
2.5: a combatant does not receive the crown, unless he has observ'd the laws of the games.
2.6: the labourer must work before he can obtain his reward.
2.7: consider what I say, and the Lord will give you understanding in all things.
2.8: Remember that Jesus Christ, who is of the posterity of David, is raised from the dead, according to my gospel,
2.9: for which I suffer even the chains of a malefactor: but the word of God is not so confin'd.
2.10: I therefore bear with every thing for the sake of the converts, that they may obtain that salvation, which Jesus Christ has procur'd us, even eternal glory.
2.11: it is an undoubted truth, that if we die for him, we shall live with him:
2.12: if we suffer, we shall also reign: if we renounce him,
2.13: he will renounce us likewise: tho' we are diffident, he is still faithful, and will not retract his word.
2.14: These things represent, conjuring them by the presence of the Lord, to avoid disputes about words, which only serve to pervert the audience.
2.15: endeavour to approve yourself to God, as an artist that is not afraid of reproach, by rightly explaining the word of truth.
2.16: discountenance such as hold vain irreligious discourse; for they will grow bold in impiety,
2.17: and their doctrine will spread like the gangrene. Hymeneus and Philetus are such:
2.18: they have deserted the faith themselves, and debauch'd the faith of others, by maintaining, "the resurrection is already past."
2.20: in a palace there are vessels not only of gold, and of silver, but of wood and of earth likewise: some are for honourable uses, and others for meaner purposes.
2.21: he that is clear of vice, is a vessel of the first kind, sanctified and fit for the master's use, and qualified for every virtuous action.
2.22: Avoid the passions of youth, pursue justice, fidelity, benevolence and concord with all sincere christians.
2.23: decline all impertinent barren disputes, since they only serve for contention.
2.24: a christian must not be litigious, but easy to all men, qualify'd to instruct,
2.25: with great temper and meekness informing those, who differ in opinion; because he does not know, but God may change their minds, by convincing them of the truth.
2.26: and so they may rouze out of the snare of the devil, who leads them captive at his discretion.

3.1: Take notice that in the latter days difficult incidents will arise;
3.2: for men will be selfish, avaricious, vain, proud, slanderers, disobedient to parents, ungrateful,
3.3: villainous, unnatural, perfidious, defamers, debauchees,
3.4: cruel, enemies to virtue, traitors, insolent, conceited, and more devoted to pleasure than to piety:
3.5: of which they wear the appearance, but disclaim its influence, have no intercourse with such.
3.6: Of this number are they, who insinuate themselves into families, to make a prey of the weaker sex, who are inveigled by their vitious suggestions, abetted by their own subtle passions,
3.7: and by lending an assiduous ear to such lessons, render it impossible they should ever be acquainted with the truth.
3.8: Moses did not meet with greater opposition from Jannes and Jambres, than truth does from men so corrupted in their mind, and so adulterated in their faith.
3.9: but they will be stop'd in their career; for they shall be expos'd to the world for impostors, as those magicians were.
3.10: As for me, you are perfectly acquainted with my doctrine, my conduct, my designs, my temper, my benevolence, my constancy,
3.11: my persecutions, and the sufferings that befel me at Antioch, at Iconium, at Lystra; what persecutions did I endure? but the Lord deliver'd me out of them all: yes,
3.12: and those who will live like Christians, shall generally suffer persecution.
3.13: as for these impious impostors, they will go on from bad to worse, seducing others, and deluding themselves.
3.14: But be you attach'd to the doctrine you have learnt, with which you are intrusted, considering by whom you have been instructed:
3.15: and that from your infancy you were acquainted with the sacred writings, which point you the way to salvation, by believing in Christ Jesus:
3.16: for all divinely inspired writings are conducive to instruction, to conviction, to reformation, and the practice of virtue;
3.17: that the minister of God may be perfectly accomplished for every office of religion.

4.1: I conjure you in the name of God, and of the Lord Jesus Christ, who is to judge the living and the dead, at his appearance in his kingdom,
4.2: to preach the word with assiduity upon all occasions: reprove, censure, exhort, with the most tender persuasions.
4.3: for the time will come, when they will not endure sound doctrine, but get teachers of their own corrupt taste, to sooth their ears that itch for flattery:
4.4: which, while they are deaf to the truth, attentively listen to fables.
4.5: be you then entirely upon the watch: be insensible to toil: perform the work of an evangelist, and discharge your ministerial function.
4.6: as for me, my blood will soon be pour'd out, and the time of my departure draws nigh:
4.7: I have struggled in a glorious cause: I have finish'd my career: I have stood to the faith:
4.8: I have nothing more to do, but to receive the crown of virtue reserv'd for me, which the Lord, the just judge, will give me in that day: and not only to me, but to those also, who have long'd for his appearance.
4.9: Endeavour to come to me very soon:
4.10: for Damas, out of love to this world has abandon'd me, and is gone to Thessalonica: Crescens, to Galatia: and Titus, to Dalmatia.
4.11: only Luke is with me, take Mark and bring him with you; because he will be useful to me in the ministry.
4.12: Tychicus I have sent to Ephesus.
4.13: when you come, bring the cloke and books, but especially the roll, which I left with Carpus at Troas.
4.14: Alexander the copper-smith did me many injuries: the Lord may reward him according to his actions.
4.15: beware of him, for he violently opposed our doctrine.
4.16: At my first defence, I had no assistance, for every body deserted me. I wish it may never be laid to their charge.
4.17: however the Lord assisted and strengthen'd me, that the gospel might be confirm'd by my remonstrance, and all the nations might hear it; so that I was deliver'd out of the mouth of the lion:
4.18: and the Lord will deliver me from every malicious design, and preserve me for his heavenly kingdom, to him be glory to endless ages, amen.
4.19: Salute Prisca, and Aquila, and the family of Onesiphorus.
4.20: Erastus staid at Corinth: but Trophimus I left sick at Miletum.
4.21: endeavour to come before winter. Eubulus, Prudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brethren salute you.
4.22: the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, grace be with you. AMEN.

1.1: PETER an apostle of Jesus Christ, to the foreigners dispers'd thro' Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia, whom God the father has chosen in pursuance of his decree,
1.2: to sanctify them by his spirit, that by their obedience they might be sprinkled with the blood of Jesus Christ, may the divine savour make you continually prosper.
1.3: Blessed be the God and father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to his great mercy has regenerated us, and given us by the resurrection of Jesus Christ, the expectation of immortal life,
1.4: in the enjoyment of a state, that can never change or decay, a state reserv'd in heaven for us,
1.5: whom the divine power preserves through faith for that salvation, which is going to be made manifest in the latter time.
1.6: This it is that fills you with joy, notwithstanding the various tryals, which still necessarily afflict you,
1.7: that your faith being put to a more advantageous proof, than that of gold, which loses by the essay, may redound to your praise and highest honour at the appearance of Jesus Christ:
1.8: whom though you have not seen, you love: and though he is not now the object of your view, yet you believe in him, and triumph with such a laudable transport, as cannot be express'd:
1.9: since the salvation of your souls is the reward you receive for your faith.
1.10: 'Twas this salvation, that employ'd the most profound enquiries of those, who predicted the dispensation that was to be in your behalf:
1.11: when the spirit of Christ inform'd the minds of the prophets of his future sufferings, and of the glorious consequences, they were solicitous to know the circumstances of the times pointed at:
1.12: and were answer'd, that it was not they, but we, who were concern'd in the events which they predicted, events which have been now represented to you by those, whom the holy spirit from heaven inspired to preach the gospel to you: a secret which the angels desire to penetrate into.
1.13: Let your minds then be duely prepar'd, be vigilant, and constantly expect the favour you will meet with at the appearance of Jesus Christ.
1.14: as obedient children be no longer influenc'd by those passions, which were the effects of your former ignorance.
1.15: but as he, who has called you, is holy: let your whole conduct be an imitation of his holiness.
1.16: for it is written, "be ye holy, because I am holy."
1.17: and since you invoke him as your father, who without respect of persons judges every one according to his actions; while you are passing thro' this world, be fearful of offending him:
1.18: considering, that it was not by such perishable things as silver or gold, that you were releas'd from those vain rites and customs impos'd upon you by your fathers,
1.19: but by the precious blood of Christ, who is the lamb without spot, and without blemish:
1.20: who was destin'd before the creation of the world, tho' 'tis of late only that he has appear'd, upon your account:
1.21: it is by him that you believe in God, who has raised him from the dead, and invested him with glory, that your faith and your hope might be in God.
1.22: You that have purified your souls by the holy spirit, in obeying the gospel, which obliges you to an undisguised benevolence, let your hearts be mutually affected with the most disinterested ardour;
1.23: since your regeneration is not owing to any corruptible principles, but to the unchangeable word of the immortal God.
1.25: but the word of the Lord remains for ever: and that is the gospel, which has been preached to you.

2.1: Renouncing therefore every kind of malice, and knavery, hypocrisy, envy, and detraction, as new-born infants desire that mystical milk,
2.2: which is without any mixture, and will make you thrive. Since you have tasted how good the Lord is,
2.3: adhere to him as to a living stone,
2.4: which however rejected it is by men, is the precious stone, which God has chosen: and
2.5: you your selves are as so many living stones, you are the edifice, the spiritual house, a holy priesthood, to offer up spiritual sacrifices, agreeable to God by Jesus Christ.
2.6: wherefore it is said in the scripture, I lay in Sion the principal stone of the angle, a choice one of great value: he that
2.7: trusts thereon shall not be confounded, it will prove an honour to you, who believe; but to the incredulous, the same stone, which is the chief of the angle,
2.9: and this they were destin'd to, but you are the chosen race, you are kings and priests, the holy nation, the peculiar people, that you might display his glory, who called you out
2.10: of darkness into his marvellous light: you, who formerly were not a people, but are now the people of God, who had not obtained mercy,
2.11: but at present have obtain'd it. I exhort you, my dear brethren, as strangers and travellers to avoid all sensual passions, as destructive to your
2.12: souls. Let your behaviour among the Gentiles be virtuous, that instead of inveighing against you as vicious, they may observe your honest behaviour,
2.13: and glorify God in the times of distress, be subject therefore, for the Lord's sake to every human establishment: whether it be to the king,
2.14: as supreme; or to governors, as being deputed by him to punish those who do ill,
2.15: and to encourage those who do well, for such is the divine pleasure, that by your good conduct you obviate the cavils of inconsiderate
2.16: men. You are free, don't let your liberty serve as a pretext for vice: but act as the servants
2.17: of God. Be respectful to all, love your brethren, fear God, and honour the king.
2.18: You that are servants, be subject to your masters with all reverence: not only to such as are kind and gentle,
2.19: but even to the morose, for it is a recommendation to the divine favour, to suffer unjust persecution
2.20: from a principle of conscience, what glory is there in suffering corporal punishment for real offences? but if you meet with ill usage for doing your duty, and bear it with constancy,
2.21: this will conciliate the divine favour, and this is the condition of your vocation, since Christ himself has suffer'd for us,
2.22: leaving an example for your exact imitation, he who never offended, and from whose lips no fallacy was ever utter'd,
2.23: who, when he was reviled, did not revile again: when he was in his sufferings, he did not threat, but referr'd his cause to the righteous judge.
2.24: he himself cancel'd our sins by the crucifixion of his body, that we being set free from sin, might live in the service of virtue, it is by his bruises that you were healed:
2.25: for you were as sheep going astray, but now you are brought back to the pastor and overseer of your souls.

3.1: Let the married women be subservient to their husbands, that if they happen to disbelieve the gospel, they may be gain'd by the instructive conduct of their wives,
3.2: by observing the religious chastity of their manners.
3.3: let their ornament consist, not in what is external, in curling the hair, in appendages of gold, or finery of dress;
3.4: but in the internal qualities of the mind, in that purity, in that mild and dispassionate temper, which is so acceptable to the divine being.
3.5: the holy religious women of former times were thus adorned, and were submissive to their husbands.
3.6: such was Sarah, who show'd her obeysance to Abraham, by stiling him her Lord: and you will be stiled her children, if you imitate her conduct, and are not to be terrified out of your virtue.
3.7: You husbands, do you on your part behave with prudence towards your wives: who being of a more delicate make, ought to be treated with the greater tenderness: and consider they are equally intitled to the evangelical gifts, that your prayers may not be frustrated.
3.8: In a word, live all of you in perfect agreement and sympathy, be full of fraternal love, compassion, and affability.
3.9: don't return evil for evil, nor calumny for calumny; on the contrary, bestow your benedictions, considering that your vocation obliges you thereto, as a means to obtain the divine blessing.
3.10: " He that desires to live in prosperity, must restrain his tongue from detraction, and his lips from uttering falsehood:
3.11: he must avoid vice, practise virtue, seek peace, and persevere in the enquiry.
3.12: for the eyes of the Lord are upon the virtuous, and his ears attend to their prayers, but the wicked he discountenances."
3.13: for who can hurt you, if you strive to excel in virtue.
3.14: However, if you suffer in the cause of virtue, it is your happiness: and instead of being over-awed by their threats, and struck with concern,
3.15: adore the Lord God in your hearts, and be ready to show with modesty and respect to every one that asks it, what ground there is for the expectations you have:
3.16: always maintaining a good conscience, that instead of inveighing against you as evildoers, they may be cover'd with confusion, who traduce your virtuous behaviour as Christians.
3.17: for since it is the will of heaven you should suffer, it is better you should suffer for your virtue, than for any crimes.
3.18: for Jesus Christ himself has already suffer'd for our sins, the innocent for the guilty, to bring us to God: who, tho' he died with respect to his body, was rais'd to life by that spirit,
3.19: by which he went with guardian spirits to preach to
3.20: those antient rebels in the time of Noah, when the divine forbearance waited, till the ark was quite finish'd, in which only eight persons were saved by means of the water.
3.21: thus baptism, which corresponds to the deluge, does now save us, not as it is a cleansing from external filth, but as it is an engagement to lead a divine life, from the belief of the resurrection of Jesus Christ,
3.22: who being ascended into heaven, is seated at the right hand of God, where angels, dominations, and potentates have been subjected to him.

4.1: Since then Christ has with respect to his mortal nature died for us, arm yourselves with this reflection, that he, who is dead with respect to sensuality, has renounced sin;
4.2: so that for the future he does not pass the rest of this life in gratifying his sensual passions, but in conformity to the divine precepts.
4.3: for the time past of your lives may suffice, to have liv'd in conformity to the Gentile customs, in impurity, licentiousness, sottishness, in dissolute festivals, and the criminal rites of idolaters.
4.4: As they think it strange, that you don't concur in the same profusion of luxury, they traduce you.
4.5: but they will be call'd to account by him, who is ready to judge both the living and the dead.
4.6: for to this end was the gospel preach'd to those, who are now dead, that after having suffer'd the loss of this frail life from men, they might enjoy an immortal life with God.
4.7: The consummation of all things draws nigh, be temperate, be vigilant in prayer.
4.8: but above all, let your mutual benevolence be intense, for benevolence cancels a multitude of offences.
4.10: as good economists of the different dispensations of God, communicate to one another the gifts you have receiv'd.
4.11: let a speaker deliver nothing but what is agreeable to the divine oracles: and let him that attends the poor, be active in proportion to the strength God has given him, amen.
4.12: My dear brethren, don't be surpriz'd at your being brought as it were to the test of fire; as if some strange thing had happen'd to you.
4.13: on the contrary, rejoice at the share you have of sufferings, as well as Christ: that you may likewise triumph, when he shall appear in his glory.
4.14: if you suffer indignities in the cause of Christ, you are happy: for the glorious spirit of God rests upon you.
4.15: take care therefore not to suffer upon the account of homicide, or thievery, or for any criminal, or pragmatical practices.
4.16: but whoever suffers as a christian, let him not be asham'd, but rather give thanks to God upon that account.
4.17: for now is the time when God will begin his judgments with his own church, now if he begins with us, what will the conclusion be to those who do not obey the divine gospel?
4.18: if the virtuous escape with difficulty, what will become of impious transgressors?
4.19: let those then, whom God calls to sufferings, by virtue recommend their souls to him, as to a creator, who will make good his promise.

5.1: I address myself to you pastors, as being a pastor myself, and a witness of the sufferings of Christ, and as one who is to partake of the glory, that shall hereafter be made manifest;
5.2: to exhort you to feed the flock of God, which is among you: to take care of it, voluntarily, without reluctance, not from any view to sordid gain, but out of real affection;
5.3: not to domineer over the laity, but to be examples for their imitation;
5.4: that when the sovereign pastor shall appear, you may carry off a glorious crown, that will never fade.
5.5: As for you that are young, be you submissive to those of a more advanc'd age: and do you all of you pay a becoming deference to one another: be cloak'd with humility, for " God opposes the proud, and shows favour to the humble."
5.6: submit yourselves therefore to the divine jurisdiction, that he may exalt you in due time.
5.7: refer all your disquietudes to him, for you are the objects of his care.
5.8: Be temperate, be vigilant: for your adversary the Devil goes about like a roaring lion, seeking whom he may devour.
5.9: resist him by the steadiness of your faith, considering that your brethren among the Gentiles, suffer the same persecutions as you do.
5.10: but may the all-gracious God, who has called us to eternal glory, perfect, confirm, fortify, and settle you, during the short interval of your sufferings.
5.11: to him belongs eternal glory and empire, amen.
5.12: I formerly writ to you a short epistle, by Silvanus, I think, a faithful brother, to declare and testify to you, that the true dispensation of God is that to which you are attach'd.
5.13: the church at Babylon, who are likewise Christians, and Mark my son salute you.
5.14: salute one another with social affection, peace be with every christian among you. Amen.

1.1: Simon Peter the servant and apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who equally share with us in the advantages of faith, thro' the veracity of our God, and of Jesus Christ.
1.2: may the divine favour and felicity be poured upon you, by the knowledge of God, and of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: It is thus his divine power has given us every thing conducive to life and piety, by making us acquainted with him, who has called us by his illustrious power;
1.4: by which we have receiv'd the most inestimable promises, that thereby you might become partakers of the divine perfections, after having escap'd from the corruption of a sensual world.
1.5: Do you on your part employ all your care in adding to your faith, fortitude: to fortitude, knowledge:
1.6: to knowledge, temperance: to temperance, patience: to patience, piety:
1.7: to piety, fraternal affection: and to fraternal affection, universal benevolence.
1.8: for if you are possess'd of these virtues and improve therein, they will prevent the knowledge you have of our Lord Jesus Christ from being useless to others, and unprofitable to yourselves.
1.9: but he that is destitute of them is blind or short-sighted, having forgot he was purified from his past sins.
1.10: Wherefore be the more diligent, my brethren, to secure your vocation and election by your virtuous actions, for by so doing, you will never relapse:
1.11: and thus you will have a free admittance into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
1.12: for this reason I shall never omit to put you in mind of these things, however knowing you are already, and settled in the truth.
1.13: whilst I am alive, I think it my duty to awaken you by my admonitions:
1.14: knowing that I must soon leave this tabernacle, as our Lord Jesus Christ has signify'd to me.
1.15: However, I shall inculcate these things so as to make you continually remember them, even after my departure.
1.16: for, the information we gave you of the powerful advent of our Lord Jesus Christ, did not proceed from any artfully contriv'd fables, we our selves having been spectators of his majesty.
1.17: for he received this honourable and glorious testimony from his father, when the voice broke out from the magnificent splendor, in these words, "this is my beloved son in whom I am well pleased."
1.18: we our selves heard this voice, that came from heaven, when we were with him upon the holy mountain.
1.19: Besides, we have the more authentic accounts of the prophets, to which you do well in giving your attention, as to a lamp shining in an obscure place, till the day dawn, and the morning-star arises in your hearts.
1.20: But you must above all consider, that no prophecy of the scripture did proceed
1.21: from the prophet's OWN MOTION; but the holy men of God spoke by the IMPULSE of the holy spirit.

2.1: As there were false prophets among the people of Israel, there will likewise be false doctors among you, who by introducing pernicious sects, and by renouncing the Lord, who bought them, will bring upon themselves swift destruction.
2.2: many will follow their destructive maxims, and by their means christianity will be traduc'd.
2.3: By their artful discourses they will make you the tools of their avarice; but their condemnation has been a long time advancing, and their ruin is far from lingring.
2.4: for since God did not spare the angels, who had sinned, but having precipitated them to hell, confin'd them to chains of darkness, where they are reserv'd for judgment:
2.5: since he did not spare the old world, having preserved only eight persons, including Noah, that preacher of virtue, when he brought the deluge upon the impious world:
2.6: since he condemn'd the cities of Sodom and Gomorrha to an entire subversion, and reduc'd them to ashes, to make them serve for examples to future impiety:
2.7: since he deliver'd that just man Lot, who was grieved at the enormous practices of the licentious;
2.8: for whilst this good man was among them, it daily pierc'd his virtuous soul, to see and hear of their detestable behaviour: this consider'd,
2.9: I say, the Lord will deliver those, who fear him, from their affliction, and reserve the wicked to be punish'd at the day of judgment.
2.10: especially those, who prostitute themselves to sensual infamous passions: who despise magistrates, who being audacious, and insolent, intrepidly calumniate the higher powers;
2.11: whereas the angels, who are of superiour power and dignity, don't inveigh against one another.
2.12: But as for these, they have no more reason than brute beasts that are naturally made for hunting, and slaughter: so these who calumniate what they do not understand, shall receive the reward of their iniquity by perishing in their own corruption.
2.13: they place their felicity in daily pleasure: they are a vile scandal to religion: when they are present at your love-feasts they indulge their luxury:
2.14: their eyes are inflam'd with adultery, and unextinguishable vice: they insnare the souls of the inconstant, their minds are practis'd in the arts of avarice: an execrable race, who have deserted the right way,
2.15: and are gone astray to follow the practices of Balaam of Bosor, who loved the wages of iniquity;
2.16: but he was rebuked for his transgression: for an ass, as dumb as it was, spoke with an articulate voice, and reprimanded the extravagance of the prophet.
2.17: These are wells without water; clouds agitated with a tempest, who are consigned to the obscurity of eternal darkness.
2.18: when their language swells with vanity, by applying to the sensual passions of the licentious, they allure those who were escap'd for a while, from such deceivers:
2.19: whilst they promise others liberty, they themselves are slaves to their corrupt passions, for he that is vanquished, is a slave to the conqueror.
2.20: As for those who have renounc'd the pollutions of the world, by their owning Jesus Christ for their Lord and saviour, if they are prevail'd upon to be entangled therein again, their last state is worse than the first.
2.21: for it had been better for them, not to have made any profession of the gospel, than after they have embraced it, to abandon the holy injunction, that was delivered to them.

3.1: This is the second letter I now write to you, my brethren, by which I would awaken your sincere attention,
3.2: by admonishing you to be mindful of the predictions of the holy prophets, and of the directions of the apostles of our Lord and Saviour.
3.3: Above all things you are to know, that in these last times, impostors will appear, who will abandon themselves to their own sensual passions, whose cry will be,
3.4: "where is the promise of his coming? for since our fathers are dead, the state of things is the same it has ever been since the beginning of the world."
3.5: but they are wilfully ignorant, that the heavens were originally form'd by the divine Logos, and likewise the earth, which was separated from the water, and still subsists upon it.
3.6: whence the former world was destroyed by an inundation.
3.7: but the heavens and the earth now existing are kept in store by his Logos, reserv'd for the conflagration of doomsday, when the impious shall be involv'd in perdition.
3.8: But there is one thing, my brethren, you ought to be appriz'd of, which is this, that "with the Lord one day is as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day."
3.9: the Lord does not delay the accomplishment of his promise, as some do imagine, but he waits with patience upon our account, as being unwilling that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance.
3.10: As for that day of the Lord, it will advance like a thief: then the heavens will rush with violence, the boiling elements will be dissolved, and the earth with all its contents, shall be burnt away.
3.11: Since then this whole system is to be destroyed, how holy should your conduct be, and how ardent your piety?
3.12: expecting, and vehemently desiring the day of the Lord would come, when the heavens all on fire shall be dissolv'd, and the elements shall melt with intense heat.
3.13: As for us, in consequence of his promise, we expect a new heaven, and a new earth, where justice shall reside.
3.14: since then, my dear brethren, your expectations are such, take care to appear before him, without any defect or blemish, in order to be happy; and be persuaded,
3.15: that the patience of our Lord is for your advantage: as our dear brother Paul, according to the information he receiv'd, has writ to you,
3.16: as it were in all his epistles, where he takes notice of these things: in which there are some passages that are difficult to understand, which the illiterate, and unstable wrest, as they do the rest of the scriptures, to their own ruin.
3.17: Do you then, my dear brethren, being thus forewarn'd, take care not to be seduc'd by those prophane impostors, and so lose the reward of your constancy.
3.18: on the contrary, may you increase in the favour, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ! to him be glory both now and for ever. AMEN.

1.1: Concerning the Logos, the author of Life, we declare what was from the beginning, what we have heard, what we have seen with our eyes, what we have consider'd, and what has been the object of our touch.
1.2: for the life was manifested, we have seen it, we testify of it, and denounce unto you, that eternal life which was with the father, and was manifested unto us.
1.3: what we have seen and heard, we declare unto you, that ye also may be of the same society with us: and truly associated with the father, and with his son Jesus Christ.
1.4: and these things write we unto you, that our joy may be perfect.
1.5: This then is the commission we have from him, to declare unto you, that God is light, and in him there is no darkness.
1.6: if we say that we have communion with him, and walk in darkness, we lye, and do not act sincerely:
1.7: but if we walk in the light, as he is in the light, we have society one with another, and the blood of his son Jesus Christ cleanseth us from all sin.
1.8: If we say that we are without sin, we deceive ourselves, and have no regard to truth.
1.9: if we confess our sins, as he is faithful and just, he will forgive us our sins, and cleanse us from all iniquity.
1.10: if we say that we have not sinned, we impeach his veracity, and discredit his word.

2.1: My dear children, these things I write unto you, that ye may avoid sin, but if any man has failed, we have an advocate with the father, Jesus Christ the just.
2.2: he is the the victim that has expiated our sins: and not ours only, but likewise the sins of the whole world.
2.3: if we keep his commandments, that is a proof that we know him.
2.4: he that says, he knows him, and does not keep his commandments, is a lyar, and an enemy to the truth:
2.5: but he that observes his precepts, loves God with a true and perfect love: 'tis by this we know that we are truly christians.
2.6: he that says he is attach'd to Christ, ought to regulate his conduct by his example.
2.7: My brethren, I don't prescribe you any new commandment, but the antient precept which you had from the beginning: and that is no other than the word which was originally delivered.
2.8: however, it is really, in effect, a new commandment I write unto you, with respect to you: because the darkness is past, and things now appear in their true light.
2.9: he that says, he is in the light, and yet hates his brother, is still in darkness.
2.10: he that loves his brother, abides in the light, and will be secure from stumbling.
2.11: but he that hates his brother, is in darkness, he walks in darkness, and knows not whither he is going, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes.
2.12: I write to you, dear children, because your sins are forgiven you upon the account of Christ.
2.13: I write to you, fathers, because ye have known him that is from the beginning. I write to you, young men, because you have overcome the wicked spirit. I write to you, little children, because ye have known the father.
2.14: I write to you, fathers, because you have known him that is from the beginning. I write to you, young men, because ye are strong, and the word of God abideth in you, and ye have overcome the wicked spirit.
2.15: Love not the world, nor let worldly things engage your affections, he that is worldly affected is a stranger to divine love.
2.16: for what the world is so full of, sensuality, avarice, and pride, is not deriv'd from the creator, but is the offspring of a vicious world.
2.17: and the world is passing away, with all its vices: but he that obeys the divine will, shall enjoy a life of immortality.
2.18: Dear children, the last time is come: as ye have heard that antichrist was to come, accordingly many antichrists have already appeared; whereby we know that we are now in the last times.
2.19: they went out from us, but they were not of us: for if they had been of us, they would no doubt have continued with us: but they went out, that it might be manifest, that they were not all of us.
2.20: As for you who have receiv'd the unction of the holy spirit, you know the whole affair.
2.21: I have not written to you, as to people unacquainted with the truth of the gospel: but as to such who know it, and know that it cannot give rise to any imposture.
2.22: who is so great an impostor as he, who denies that Jesus is the Christ? he is antichrist, that denies the father and the son.
2.23: whosoever denieth the son, disowns the father:
2.24: adhere therefore to what ye have learnt from the beginning, if you adhere to what ye have heard from the beginning, you will still persist to own both the son and the father.
2.25: and this is the reward that he hath promised us, even eternal life.
2.26: These things have I written to you concerning those that would seduce you.
2.27: but as the unction which ye have received from him, abides in you, you don't need any instruction: being then fully instructed by his unction, which is true and not fallacious, adhere to what that has taught you.
2.28: adhere to that, my dear children, that when he shall appear, we may have confidence, and not be ashamed before him at his coming.
2.29: since you know that God is the source of virtue, you know that every one who has virtue, derives it from him.

3.1: Consider what proof the father has given us of his love, in allowing us to be called the sons of God: therefore the world does not know us, because it knew him not.
3.2: beloved, we are now the sons of God, tho' it does not yet appear what we shall be: but we know, that when this change shall be, his immediate presence will give us a divine resemblance.
3.3: he that hath such an expectation should purify himself, even as he is pure.
3.4: he that is vitious, is lawless: for sin is the transgression of the law.
3.5: and you know that he appear'd to abolish our sins; and that he was himself without sin.
3.6: whosoever adheres to him, sinneth not: whosoever sinneth, hath not seen him, he does not know him.
3.7: dear children, let no man deceive you: only he that acts justly is just, as he is just.
3.8: he that lives in sin, imitates the devil; for the devil was a sinner from the beginning, for this purpose the son of God appeared, that he might destroy the works of the devil.
3.9: whosoever is born of God, does not commit sin; for the divine principle remaineth in him: he will not sin, because he is born of God.
3.10: In this the children of God are distinguished from the children of the devil: he that does not practise virtue, and fraternal benevolence, is not of God.
3.11: for this is the doctrine that you have heard from the beginning, that we should love one another.
3.12: not acting like Cain, who was of that wicked one, and slew his brother: but why did he slay him? because his own actions were evil, and his brother's were virtuous.
3.13: Marvel not, my brethren, if the world hate you.
3.14: as for us, we know, that we have passed from a state of death to that of life, because we love our brethren: he that does not love his brother, is in a destructive state.
3.15: whosoever hateth his brother, has the disposition of a murderer: and you know that no murderer has any title to eternal life.
3.16: this is the proof of the divine love, Christ expos'd his life for us: and we ought to expose our lives for the brethren.
3.17: he that possesses the enjoyments of life, and seeing his brother in want, has no compassion for him, how can he be said to have any divine love?
3.18: my dear children, let not our love be only in the language of our lips, but in the real effects of the heart.
3.19: Hereby we shall know that we are true professors, and set our consciences securely at rest.
3.20: for if our conscience condemn us, God knows us better than we do our selves, he knoweth all things.
3.21: beloved, if our heart condemn us not, we may securely confide in God.
3.22: whatever we ask, we shall receive it of him, because we keep his commandments, and do what is agreeable to him.
3.23: now this is his commandment, that we believe in his son Jesus Christ, and that we love one another, as he commanded us.
3.24: he that observes his commandments, dwelleth in God, and God in him: and hereby we know that he abideth in us, by the spirit which he hath given us.

4.1: Beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world.
4.2: by this you may distinguish the spirit of God: "every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is from God.
4.3: and every spirit that does not own that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is not from God." this is that anti-christian spirit which you have heard was to come, and even now it appears in the world.
4.4: ye are of God, my dear children, and you have overcome them: because he that is in you, is superior to him that is in the world.
4.5: they are of the world: therefore their doctrine is worldly, and the world are their disciples.
4.6: we are of God: he that knoweth God, heareth us; he that is not of God, heareth not us, by this we distinguish the spirit of truth from the spirit of imposture.
4.7: Beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth, is born of God, and knoweth God.
4.8: he that has not social affection, does not know God; for God is love.
4.9: by this was the love of God displayed towards us, in that God sent his only begotten son into the world, that we might live thro' him.
4.10: and what heightens his love, was this, that it was not we who first loved God, but it was he that first loved us, and sent his son to expiate our sins.
4.11: beloved, if God so loved us, we ought to love one another.
4.12: no man hath ever seen God, if we love one another, God dwelleth in us, and our love for him is then sincere.
4.13: Hereby we know that we dwell in him, and he in us, because he hath given us of his spirit.
4.14: and we have seen, and do testify, that the father hath sent the son to be the saviour of the world.
4.15: whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the son of God, God dwelleth in him, and he in God.
4.16: and we have known, and are convinced that God hath loved us. God is love; and he that cultivates social affection, dwelleth in God, and God in him.
4.17: the divine love to us will be in the highest degree, if our condition in this world be the same as was that of Christ Jesus; so that we may appear with confidence in the day of judgment.
4.18: Fear is a stranger to love; for perfect loves excludes all fear: since pain is the object of fear, he that is affected with fear, cannot be sincere in his love.
4.19: let us love him; since he first loved us.
4.20: if a man says he loves God, and yet hates his brother, he is a lyar: for he that does not love his brother, who is before his eyes, how can he love God who is invisible?
4.21: besides, 'tis a commandment we have receiv'd from him, that he who would love God, must love his brother also.

5.1: Whosoever believeth that Jesus is the Messiah, is born of God: and every one that loves the father, will likewise be affected with love to his son.
5.2: by this we may know that we love the children of God, if we love God, and keep his commandments.
5.3: for our love of God consists in the observation of his precepts: precepts that are far from being grievous.
5.4: for he that is a true christian, overcomes the world: by obtaining faith, we have gain'd a victory over the world.
5.5: Who is it that overcomes the world, but he that believes that Jesus is the son of God?
5.6: it appear'd by the water, and by the blood, who he was, even Jesus the Messiah; not by the water only, but by the water and by the blood: besides, the spirit is a witness too, now the spirit is truth itself.
5.7: There are three witnesses in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three testify the same thing.
5.8: so that there are three witnesses, the spirit, the water, and the blood: and these three testify the same thing.
5.9: if we receive the testimony of men, the testimony of God is greater: now this is the testimony, which God has given us of his son.
5.10: he that believeth on the son of God, hath the testimony of God thereto: he that does not believe God, impeaches his veracity, because he does not believe the testimony that God gave of his son.
5.11: Now what is testified, is this, that God has given to us eternal life: and this life is by his son.
5.12: he that receives the son, is intitled to life; and he that does not receive the son of God, has no title to life.
5.13: these things have I written to you, that you may know that you have eternal life, by your believing on the name of the son of God.
5.14: Besides, we have this confidence in him, that if we ask any thing according to his will, he will hear us.
5.15: and since we are sure that he hears all our prayers, we are sure that the petitions we presented to him, will be answered.
5.16: If any man see his brother commit a sin, which is not a mortal sin, let him pray to God, who will grant him life, for such as do not commit a mortal sin, there is a sin unto death: in which case I do not enjoin any prayer to be made.
5.17: every thing that is contrary to virtue, is a sin: but every sin is not a mortal sin:
5.18: we know that a true christian will not commit such a sin, for he that is the child of God keeps upon his guard, so that the wicked spirit does not approach him.
5.19: we know that we are the children of God, and the rest of the world are subject to the evil spirit.
5.20: We know that the son of God is come, and hath given us an understanding to know him that is true: and we are with him that is true, by his son Jesus Christ. "he is the true God, who is the author of eternal life."
5.21: dear children, keep yourselves from idols. AMEN.

1.1: The PRESBYTER to the lady ECLECTA and her children, whom I sincerely love, and not only I, but all true christians,
1.2: in consideration of the true doctrine, we all profess, and in which we shall for ever persevere.
1.3: Grace, mercy, and peace be with you from God the father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ the son of the father, in consequence of your sincere piety, and social virtue.
1.4: It was a great satisfaction to me, to see the conduct of your children, was so agreeable to the directions, we received from the father.
1.5: and now, my lady, I beg our love may be mutual, since what I write, is no new prescription, but what was originally enjoin'd.
1.6: now love consists in the practice of the divine precepts, this is the precept you have originally receiv'd, as the rule of your conduct.
1.7: For there are many impostors started up in the world, who will not own that Jesus Christ was incarnate, such a one is an impostor and an anti-christ.
1.8: be upon your guard, that we may not lose the fruit of our labours, but that we may receive our full reward.
1.9: no renegado that deserts the doctrine of Christ, has any interest in the deity: he that adheres to the doctrine of Christ, has an interest both in the father, and in the son.
1.10: whoever comes to you unaccompanied with this doctrine, don't admit him to your house, nor treat him with the common term of civility.
1.11: for he who shows that respect to such a man, is accessary to his wicked actions.
1.12: I had many things to write to you, but I don't think it proper to commit them to paper and ink, because I hope to make you a visit, and deliver them by word of mouth; that so our joy may be compleat.
1.13: The children of your sister ECLECTA salute you. AMEN.

1.1: The PRESBYTER to my dear Gaius, whom I truly love.
1.2: I wish, my beloved, you may be as prosperous with regard to your health and other circumstances, as in what concerns your soul.
1.3: For I was greatly pleased when the brethren came and assured me of your fidelity and religious conduct.
1.4: greater joy I cannot have, than to hear that my children are attach'd to the truth.
1.5: My dear child, whatever you do in behalf of the brethren, and of those who are strangers, is commendable.
1.6: they have made a publick declaration of your charity, and you will do well to accompany them in the most effectual manner.
1.7: for they set out upon account of the gospel, and refus'd to take any thing of the Gentiles.
1.8: it behoves us to give a kind reception to such, that we may be assistant in promoting the truth.
1.9: I have writ to the church: but Diotrephes, who affects the superiority, has no regard to our representations.
1.10: for which reason, when I come, I shall animadvert upon his conduct, and the malicious aspersions he casts upon us: not contented with this, he will neither receive the brethren himself, nor suffer those who are better inclin'd, to do it; but drives them out of the church.
1.11: my beloved, don't imitate vice, but virtue, he that does good, is a child of God: he that does evil, is not acquainted with God.
1.12: Demetrius has the applauses of all men, and the testimony of his own virtue: we likewise certify in his behalf, and you know that our testimonial deserves credit.
1.13: I have many things to write, which I don't think fit to commit to paper and ink:
1.14: hoping I shall shortly see you, and then communicate them in person.
